
Homewood, IL Code of Ordinances


Village of
Homewood, Illinois
MUNICIPAL CODE



Includes Ordinances Through MC-977



PREFACE



This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the general and permanent
ordinances of the Village of Homewood, Illinois. 1



Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1965 Code, as
supplemented through August 26, 1997, and ordinances subsequently adopted by
the board of trustees. The source of each section is included in the history
note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note
indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the
adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back
of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1965 Code, as
supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein.



The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical
order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to
facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and
which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the
state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is
included at the back of this Code.



   Chapter and Section Numbering System



The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system
used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists
of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the
chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the
section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered
1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each
section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can
be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments.
For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically
come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section
would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in
the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the
chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed
at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number
shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be
included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken
that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including
new chapters.



   Page Numbering System



The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters
to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain
portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the
number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the
number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the
case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the
colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts
of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this
time, and their corresponding prefixes:



                  CODE . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
. . . . . . . . . . . CD1:1



                  CODE APPENDIX . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
. . . . CDA:1



                  CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES . . . . .  CCT:1



                  STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE . . .    SLT:1



                  CODE INDEX . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
. . . . . .    CDi:1



   Index



The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item
has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay
phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language
generally used by local government officials and employees. There are
numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts
to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested.



   Looseleaf Supplements



A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and
supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication
will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly
edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages
will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication.



   Acknowledgments



The publisher is most grateful to Mr. Ray Gosack, Director of Management
Services, and Mr. Walter Cummings, Village Attorney, for their cooperation
and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is
hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a
Municipal Code which will make the active law of the village readily
accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the
day-to-day administration of the village's affairs.

Sec. 1-1. Title.



   This code of ordinances may be known and cited as the "Homewood
Municipal Code."



(Code 1965, § 1.01)



   State law reference(s)--Statutory provisions authorizing municipalities
to adopt codes by reference, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-3; provisions concerning the
revision and publication of ordinances in book form, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-3 et seq.



Sec. 1-2. Rules of construction and definitions generally.



   (a)   Terms used in this Code, unless specifically defined in this
Code, have the meanings prescribed by the Illinois Compiled Statutes for the
same terms.



   (b)   In the interpretation and construction of this Code, the
following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless
they are inconsistent with the manifest intent of the village board or the
context clearly requires otherwise:



   Code. The words "Code" or "this Code" shall mean the Homewood Municipal
Code, as amended from time to time.



   Computation of time. The time within which any act provided by law is
to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the
last, unless the last day is Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday, and then it
shall also be excluded. If the day succeeding such Saturday, Sunday or
holiday is also a holiday or a Saturday or Sunday, such succeeding day shall
also be excluded.



   County. The word "county" means Cook County, Illinois.



   State law reference(s)—Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/1.11.



   Gender. Words importing the masculine gender may be applied to females.



   State law reference(s)—Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/1.04.



   ILCS. The abbreviation "ILCS" means the Illinois Compiled Statutes, as
amended from time to time.



   Illinois Municipal Code. The term "Illinois Municipal Code" means Act 5
of Chapter 65 of the Illinois Compiled Statutes, as amended from time to time.



   May, shall. The word "may" is permissive; the word "shall" is mandatory.



   Number. Importing the singular number may extend and be applied to
several persons or things, and words importing the plural may include the
singular.



   State law reference(s)—Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/1.03.



   Officers, departments, etc. Officers, departments, boards, commissions,
committees and employees referred to in this Code shall mean officers,
departments, boards, commissions, committees and employees of the village,
unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.



   Or, and. The term "or" may be read as "and," and the term "and" may be
read as "or," if the sense requires it.



   Person. The word "person" as well as all words referring to or
importing persons, may extend and be applied to bodies politic and corporate
as well as individuals.



   State law reference(s)—Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/1.05.



   State. The word "state" means the State of Illinois.



   Tense. Words in the present tense include the future.



   Village. The word "village" means the Village of Homewood, Illinois.



   State law reference(s)—Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/1.02.



   Village board or board of trustees. The terms "village board" or "board
of trustees" means the board of trustees of the Village of Homewood.



(Code 1965, § 1.04)



Sec. 1-3. Jurisdiction of Code.



   Unless otherwise provided in this Code, this Code applies to acts
performed within the corporate limits of the village. Provisions of this Code
also apply to acts performed outside the corporate limits and up to the
limits prescribed by law, where the law confers power on the village to
regulate such particular acts outside the corporate limits.



(Code 1965, § 1.07)



Sec. 1-4. Catchlines of sections and other headings.



   The catchlines of the several subsections and sections, and the
headings of chapters, articles and divisions of this Code are intended as
mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the subsection, section, chapter,
article or division, and shall not be deemed or taken to be a substantive
part of such subsections, sections, chapters, articles or divisions, nor,
unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such
subsections, sections, chapters, articles or divisions, including the
catchlines or other headings, are amended or reenacted.



Sec. 1-5. Amendments to Code.



   (a)   Reference to Code. Any additions or amendments to this Code
shall be deemed to be incorporated in this Code so that a reference to the
Homewood Municipal Code includes such additions and amendments.



   (b)   Recording amendments. It shall be the duty of the village
clerk to keep at least one copy of this Code which he shall mark in the
following manner: Whenever any ordinance which amends or makes an addition to
this Code is passed and approved, he shall note on the margin of the sections
amended that the amendment has been made and where the amendment may be found
in an amendment book, and in the case of an addition, he shall make in the
appropriate place a notation that such addition has been made with a similar
reference to the amendment book. All ordinances which amend or make an
addition to this Code shall be numbered consecutively, with the prefix "MC."
The village clerk shall keep copies of all such ordinances in a separate
amendment book, with a reference thereon as to the place where the original
record may be found in the record of ordinances which the clerk is required
to keep by statute.



(Code 1965, § 1.02)



Sec. 1-6. Supplementation of Code.



   (a)   By contract or by village personnel, supplements to this Code
shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the village
board. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive parts of
permanent and general ordinances passed by the village board during the
period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code.
The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly
into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages that have become
obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that,
when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of
the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement.



   (b)   In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the
Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission
thereof from reprinted pages.



   (c)   When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier
(meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the
supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts
of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so
to embody them into a unified Code.  For example, the codifier may:



      (1)   Organize the ordinance material into appropriate
subdivisions.



      (2)   Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for
sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and
make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles.



      (3)   Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other
subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate
new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers.



      (4)   Change the words “this ordinance” or words of the
same meaning to “this chapter,” “this article,” “this division,”
etc., as the case may be, or to “sections ________ to ________”
(inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody
the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code).



      (5)   Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve
the original meaning of ordinance sections or the alphabetical arrangement of
new chapters inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make
any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the
supplement or already embodied in the Code.



Sec. 1-7. Altering Code.



   It shall be unlawful for any person in the village to change or amend,
by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or
delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any
manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the village to be
misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this section shall be punished
as provided in section 1-11.



Sec. 1-8. Separability of provisions of Code.



   Each section, paragraph, sentence, clause and provision of this Code is
separable and, if any provision is held unconstitutional or invalid for any
reason, such decision shall not affect the remainder of this Code nor any
part of this Code, other than that part affected by such decision.



(Code 1965, § 1.10)



Sec. 1-9. References and notes.



   Cross references, state law references, editor's notes and history
notes are by way of explanation only and shall not be deemed a part of the
text of any section.



Sec. 1-10. Copies of Code on file.



   Copies of this Code shall be kept on file in the village clerk’s
office for inspection by the public at all reasonable hours.



(Code 1965, § 1.12)



Sec. 1-11. General penalty.



   (a)   Standard penalty. Unless another penalty is expressly provided
by this Code for any particular provision, section or chapter, any person
violating any provision of this Code, or any rule or regulation adopted or
issued in pursuance thereof, or any provision of this Code adopted herein by
reference shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of not less than
$25.00 nor more than $750.00 and the costs of prosecution. Upon default of
payment of any fine, sanction or costs imposed by this Code, any fees or
costs incurred by the village with respect to attorneys or private collection
agents retained by the municipal attorney shall be charged to the offender.



   (b)   Same offense. In all cases where the same offense is
punishable or created by different clauses or sections of this Code, the
prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but not more than one
recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense. The
revocation of a license or permit shall not be considered a recovery or
penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced.



   (c)   Continuing violations. Each act of violation and every day
during or upon which a violation occurs or continues constitutes a separate
offense.



   (d)   Applicability of penalty. The penalty provided by this section
or any section of this Code applies to the amendment of any section of this
Code or any Code adopted by reference to which the penalty relates, whether
or not such penalty is reenacted in the amending ordinance, unless otherwise
provided or unless the penalty is specifically repealed in the amendment.



   (e)   Reference to sections. Reference to any section of this Code
shall be understood also to



refer to and include the penalty section relating thereto, unless otherwise
expressly provided.



   (f)   Failure of officers to perform duties. The failure of any
officer or employee to perform any official duty imposed by this Code shall
not subject such officer or employee to any fine or penalty imposed for
violation of this Code, unless the intention to impose such fine or penalty
is specifically expressed in the provision creating such duty.



(Code 1965, § 1.08)



   Cross reference(s)--Board of fire and police commissioners, § 2-411;
alcoholic beverages, ch. 10; civil emergencies, ch. 30; emergency services,
ch. 34; law enforcement, ch. 62; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch.
70; traffic and vehicles, ch. 106.



   State law reference(s)--Penalties for ordinance violations, 65 ILCS
5/1-2-1.



   (g)   Whenever a check made payable to the Village of Homewood is
returned by a financial institution for any reason (i.e., insufficient funds,
missing signature, a closed account, etc.), the account to which the payment
was credited will be charged a $25.00 service fee by the Village of
Homewood.  The issuer of the non-cashable check is responsible for redeeming
the check immediately using only cash, cashier's check or money order.



   Whenever an electronic payment has been authorized and the payment is
not honored by the financial institution, the account to which the payment
was credited shall be charged a $25.00 service fee by the Village.  The
account's responsible party shall be notified of the returned electronic
payment and shall make arrangements to settle the account immediately using
only cash, cashier's check or money order.



   Whenever payment is made using a credit card or a debit card and the
financial institution that issued the card subsequently denies or refuses to
honor said transaction for any reason, the village shall impose a $25.00
service fee.  The account's responsible party shall be notified of the
denied payment and shall immediately settle the account using only cash or
certified funds.



(MC-806, § 1, 8-12-08; MC-878, § 1, 10-23-12)



Sec. 1-12. Responsibility for acts.



   Every person concerned in the commission of any act prohibited by this
Code, whether he directly commits the act, or prosecutes, counsels, aids, or
abets in its commission, may be prosecuted and, on conviction, is punishable
as if he had directly committed the act.



(Code 1965, § 1.09)



Sec. 1-13. Ordinances and other matters not affected by adoption of Code.



   (a)   The repeal provided for in section 2 of the ordinance adopting
this Code shall not affect any of the following:



      (1)   Ordinances authorizing contracts for the issue of
municipal warrants, notes or bonds;



      (2)   Ordinances levying taxes or making special assessments;



      (3)   Ordinances appropriating funds or establishing salaries;



      (4)   Ordinances granting franchises or special rights to
persons or corporations, and ordinances relating to railroads or public
activities except as provided for herein;



      (5)   Ordinances relating to the establishment, dedication,
opening, grading, naming, improvement, altering, widening or vacating of any
streets, alleys or sidewalks, parks or public grounds;



      (6)   Ordinances respecting the annexation of territory to the
village, or the conveyance or acceptance of real property or easements in
real property by or from the village, or the location of shorelines;



      (7)   Ordinances authorizing or relating    to particular
public improvements;



      (8)   Ordinances relating to elections or  voting precincts;



      (9)   The zoning ordinance; and



      (10)   Any other special ordinances not in conflict with the
provisions of this Code.



   (b)   The provisions of this Code, so far as they are the same in
substance as those of heretofore existing ordinances, are continuations of
such ordinances and not new enactments. Any act done, offense committed, or
right ordained, accrued or acquired, or liability, penalty, forfeiture or
punishment incurred prior hereto shall not be affected, but may be enjoyed,
asserted, enforced, prosecuted or inflicted as fully and to the same extent
as if the repeal had not been in effect, providing that any proceedings
thereafter shall conform to this Code in force at the time of the proceeding,
so far as practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment is mitigated
by any provision of this Code, each provision may be, by the consent of any
party affected, applied to any judgment or verdict rendered after this Code
takes effect. The preceding sentence shall apply to all repeals, and nothing
contained in this section shall be construed as abating any action now
pending under any ordinance repealed in this Code, or abating or modifying
any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any
person, or as waiving any rights of the village under any ordinance
provisions existing at the time of passage of this Code.



(Code 1965, § 1.05)



Sec. 1-14. Ordinances repealed not reenacted.



   No ordinance or part of any ordinance heretofore repealed shall be
considered revived, reordained or reenacted by virtue of this Code, unless
specifically reenacted in this Code. The repeal of any curative or validating
ordinance does not impair or affect any cure or validation already affected
thereby.



(Code 1965, § 1.06)

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL



Sec. 2-1. Form of government.



   The village shall be governed according to the managerial form of
municipal government prescribed by the Illinois Municipal Code, art. 5 (65
ILCS 5/5-1-1 et seq.), as amended from time to time, as voted by the electors
of the village in the village election of March 28, 1953.



(Code 1965, § 3.03)



Sec. 2-2. Village datum.



   The base or datum for village levels is hereby fixed and established as
made by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey on standard tablet at intersection
of Western Avenue and 183rd Street at an elevation of 663.808 feet above sea
level.



(Code 1965, § 4.21)



Sec. 2-3. Village seal.



   The seal heretofore provided and used by and for the village, the
impression of which is a scroll bearing the inscription "Village of Homewood,
Cook County, Illinois, Corporate Seal" shall be and is hereby declared and
established to have been, and now to be the seal of the village.



(Code 1965, § 4.22)



Secs. 2-4--2-30. Reserved.



ARTICLE II. BOARD OF TRUSTEES



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Sec. 2-31. Composition.



   The village shall be governed by a board of trustees which shall be
elected at large and shall consist of a president and six trustees.



(Code 1965, § 3.01)



Sec. 2-32. Elections, terms, vacancies, and commencement of terms.



   (a)   The term of office of the trustees shall be four years and
until their successors are elected and have qualified.



   (b)   The terms of office of the village president and village clerk
shall be four years. They shall be elected by the electors of the village at
the regular village election held in April in the first odd-numbered year
following a leap year, or as otherwise required by state law.



   (c)   Vacancies in the offices of trustees or village president
shall be filled as prescribed by the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/1-1-1
et seq.).



(Code 1965, § 3.02)



   (d)   The proclamation of the results of the regular municipal
election shall be made at the first regular or special meeting of the village
board following the canvass of the election.  The term of elected village
officials shall commence no later than the first regular or special meeting
of the village board thereafter (65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-15).



Sec. 2-33. Salary.



   Each trustee shall receive as salary for his service the sum of
$2,000.00 per year, payable quarterly. (Code 1965, § 3.04, MC-678)



Sec. 2-34. Meetings.



   The board of trustees shall hold regular meetings at the village hall
or at such other public place within the village as the board shall designate
on the second and fourth Tuesdays of each month, at 7:30 p.m., except when
such date falls on a legal holiday, in which event the meeting shall be held
on the next succeeding business day, or at such other times as it may by
ordinance or motion prescribe. No notice of regular meetings shall be
required to be given to the president and board of trustees. The president or
any three of the trustees may call special meetings of the board at any time.
The clerk shall notify all members of the board of such meeting at least two
days before the same is held, by delivering a written notice, stating the
time and place of such meeting, to each member personally or by leaving the
same at his residence; provided, however, that if the president and all of
the trustees are present at a special meeting, no notice shall be necessary,
and such notice shall be deemed waived. Notice of all board meetings shall
also be given in accordance with 5 ILCS 120/2.02 and 120/2.03.



(Code 1965, § 3.05)



Sec. 2-35. Reports of committees.



   The special committees to which referrals are made shall report in
writing upon the request of any member of the board of trustees. Upon the
request of any two trustees present, action upon any committee report shall
be deferred until the next meeting of the board of trustees.



(Code 1965, § 3.06)



Sec. 2-36. Attendance at meetings.



   Any member failing to attend any regular meeting of the board of
trustees, without first being excused by the president, shall be subject to a
fine of $15.00 for every meeting not attended. Such fine shall be
automatically imposed on such offending member, and shall stand unless
rescinded by the board of trustees. Upon the filing of a written appeal with
the board of trustees for remittance of the fine imposed, the fine shall be
suspended, unless the fine is approved by the president and three or more
trustees. Any fines imposed and collected under this section shall be placed
in the general fund.



(Code 1965, § 3.13)



Sec. 2-37. Compelling attendance.



   Where any member fails to attend a regular meeting of the board of
trustees, provided a quorum is present, on motion approved by a majority of
those present, the president shall issue an order to the chief of police to
bring such member to the meeting if he can be found within the village. Any
member of the police department may enforce such an order.



(Code 1965, § 3.14)



Secs. 2-38--2-60. Reserved.



DIVISION 2. RULES OF ORDER



Sec. 2-61. Order of business.



   The order of business to be observed at all meetings of the board of
trustees shall be according to an agenda prepared by the village manager and
approved by the village president. The agenda may be suspended upon a
majority vote of all trustees present.



(Code 1965, § 3.09)



Sec. 2-62. Quorum.



   A majority of the trustees, or three trustees and the president, shall
constitute a quorum.



(Code 1965, § 3.10)



Sec. 2-63. Power of majority.



   Unless otherwise provided by ordinance or statute, the action of the
president and board of trustees shall be controlled by a majority of those
present exclusive of the president, except the president shall vote where the
vote of the trustees has resulted in a tie; where one-half of the trustees
elected have voted in favor of an ordinance, resolution or motion even though
there is no tie vote; or where a vote greater than a majority of the
president and trustees is required by the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS
5/1-1-1 et seq.); a president pro tem shall vote in his capacity as trustee,
but shall not be entitled to another vote in his capacity as president pro
tem.



(Code 1965, § 3.11)



Sec. 2-64. Vote required.



   Every member who shall be present when a question is stated from the
chair shall vote, unless excused by the board of trustees, and the refusal by
the president, or any member, to vote, unless excused, shall be a vote in
favor of the question and shall be so recorded by the clerk. Any abstention
shall be in accordance with state statute and case law.



(Code 1965, § 3.12)



Sec. 2-65. Reconsideration of vote.



   No vote of the board of trustees shall be reconsidered, or the action
of the board of trustees rescinded at a special meeting, unless at such
special meeting there shall be present as many trustees as were present when
such vote was taken.



(Code 1965, § 3.15)



Sec. 2-66. Resolutions in writing.



   Any resolution of the board of trustees, or amendment, shall be reduced
to writing before presentation upon the request of any trustee, and after
being read, shall be handed to the clerk. If the resolution before the board
of trustees consists of several distinct propositions, each shall be voted
upon separately at the request of any trustee.



(Code 1965, § 3.16)



Sec. 2-67. Resolutions, motions or orders.



   All resolutions, motions or orders of the board of trustees shall be
definite and explicit and define any powers conferred thereby.



(Code 1965, § 3.17)



Sec. 2-68. Rules of order.



   Unless otherwise provided in this article, in the conduct of the
meetings of the board of trustees, the president shall decide all questions
of order and be governed in his decisions by parliamentary law as prescribed
by Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised. In case of disturbance or
disorder, he may require the meeting room to be cleared.



(Code 1965, § 3.18)



Secs. 2-69--2-90. Reserved.



DIVISION 3. ORDINANCES, RESOLUTIONS, MOTIONS AND ORDERS



Sec. 2-91. Referendum of ordinances.



   Any ordinance which by statute shall require a referendum shall be
submitted to the legal voters of the village either at a special or a general
election, or as provided by statute.



(Code 1965, § 3.07)



Sec. 2-92. Style of ordinances.



   The style of ordinances shall be "Be It Ordained by the President and
Board of Trustees of the Village of Homewood."



(Code 1965, § 3.08)



Secs. 2-93--2-115. Reserved.



ARTICLE III. OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Sec. 2-116. Oaths of office.



   (a)   Each of the following officers and employees shall be required
to take an oath of office before entering upon the discharge of his duties,
which oath shall be filed in the office of the village clerk:



      (1)   Village manager.



      (2)   Every member of the police department, including any
reserve or special police officers which the village might find necessary to
appoint.



      (3)   Every member of the fire department, including any
volunteer or auxiliary firefighters the village might find necessary to
appoint.



   (b)   The oath of office shall be in the following form:



   I, ________, having been appointed to the office of ________ for the
Village of



Homewood, do solemnly swear that I will support the Constitution of the
United States, the Constitution of the State of Illinois and the municipal
ordinances of the Village of Homewood, and that I will faithfully discharge
the duties of the office of ________ according to the best of my ability.



(Code 1965, § 4.11)



Sec. 2-117. Bonds of village officers.



   Officers of the village shall execute bonds, with premiums paid by the
village, to the village as required by the Illinois Municipal Code, Sec.
3-14-3 (65 ILCS 5/3-14-3) in the following amounts:



Village president. . . . . . . . . . . . . . .          $3,000.00



Village manager. . . . . . . . . . . . . .              20,000.00



Village treasurer. .. . . . . . .            as provided by the
Illinois Municipal Code, sec. 3-14-3



(65 ILCS 5/3-14-3)



Village collector . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .        50,000.00



Village clerk . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .        1,000.00



Reserve police officers, each . . . . . . . .        10,000.00



Finance Department    .. . . . . . .                100,000.00



Volunteer firefighters, each. . . . . . . . . . .    10,000.00



All other employees, each. . . . . . . . . . . .    10,000.00



(Code 1965, § 4.12)



Sec. 2-118. Discontinuance of office.



   The president and board of trustees, by a two-thirds vote, may
discontinue any office created by ordinance, except where required by
statute. Such discontinuance shall take effect upon passage of an ordinance.



(Code 1965, § 4.13)



Sec. 2-119. Merger of offices.



   Neither the president, any trustee of the village nor the village clerk
shall hold any other village office during his term of office. However, on
discontinuance of any appointive office, the duties of such office may be
imposed on any other appointive office, and one person may fill the office
and bear the title of any two or more appointive offices except that of the
treasurer.



(Code 1965, § 4.14)



Sec. 2-120. Delivery of records to successor.



   Every officer shall, within five days after notification and request,
deliver to his successor in office all property, books, and effects of every
description in his possession belonging to the village and appertaining to
his office, and his refusal or willful neglect so to do shall constitute a
misdemeanor.



(Code 1965, § 4.15)



Secs. 2-121—2-140. Reserved.



DIVISION 2. PRESIDENT



Sec. 2-141. General powers.



   The  village president shall preside at meetings of  the 
president  and board of  trustees. He shall enforce all ordinances, orders
and resolutions passed by the board of trustees. He shall examine the grounds
of all reasonable complaints  made against any officer or employee of the
village and cause all violations of duty or other misconduct to be punished
or reported to the proper tribunal for correction.



   He shall sign all contracts, leases, deeds, easements and other
documents, also all warrants on the treasurer. He shall perform such other
duties and enjoy such powers as may be prescribed by statute, resolution,
motion or this Code, except any such duties as may be assigned to the village
manager or other administrative officer by statute or this Code.



(Code 1965, § 3.19(a))



Sec. 2-142. Special powers and duties.



   The president may revoke licenses, exercise police power, suppress
riots, make arrests, release any person held or convicted for violation of
any village ordinance or remit any fine inflicted for violation thereof, but
in such cases he shall report such acts to the board of trustees at its next
regular meeting and give his reasons therefor.



(Code 1965, § 3.19(b))



Sec. 2-143. Compensation.



   The president shall receive as salary for his services the sum of
$2,500.00 per year, payable quarterly.



(Code 1965, § 3.19(c)) (MC-678)



Sec. 2-144. President pro tem.



   One of the trustees shall be chosen by the board of trustees as
president pro tem to act as president in the temporary absence or disability
of the president, with all the duties, rights and powers pertaining to the
office of the president.



(Code 1965, § 3.19(d))



Secs. 2-145—2-165. Reserved.



DIVISION 3. MANAGER



Sec. 2-166. Office created; appointment; acting manager; removal.



   There is hereby established the office of village manager. The village
manager shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees, voting
jointly, and shall be the administrative head of the village government. He
shall be responsible for the efficient administration of all departments of
the village. He shall be appointed without regard to his political beliefs,
and need not be a resident of the village when appointed. He shall be
appointed solely on the basis of his proven education, training, knowledge,
and ability in the field of municipal administration. The village manager
shall be appointed for an indefinite term. In the case of the absence or the
disability of the manager, the president and board of trustees may designate
a qualified administrative officer of the village to perform the duties of
the manager during such absence or disability. The manager may at any time be
removed from office by a majority vote of the president and board of trustees
at a regular meeting.



(Code 1965, § 4.01)



Sec. 2-167. Powers and duties.



   It shall be the duty of the village manager to:



      (1)   Enforce this Code and other ordinances within the
village, including applicable state statutes.



      (2)   Appoint and remove or suspend all heads of departments
and the heads of divisions of departments. No appointment shall be made upon
any basis other than that of merit and fitness.



      (3)   Exercise control of all departments and divisions
thereof created by the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/1-1-1 et seq.), by
any ordinance of the village, and by this Code and all amendments to this
Code.



      (4)   Have all the powers and exercise all the duties granted
in the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/1-1-1 et seq.) to municipal clerks
and comptrollers with respect to the preparation of a report of the estimated
funds necessary to defray the expenses of the village for the fiscal year for
the consideration of the president and board of trustees prior to the
preparation of the annual appropriation ordinance.



      (5)   Attend all meetings of the board of trustees with the
right to take part in the discussion but with no right to vote.



      (6)   Recommend to the board of trustees for adoption such
measures as he may deem necessary or expedient.



      (7)   See that all terms and conditions imposed in favor of
the village or its inhabitants in any contract or public utility franchise
are faithfully kept and performed.



      (8)   Make, in the ordinary course of business,  all
purchases  of  materials and  supplies necessary  for the village as
provided for in the annual budget, provided  that for  purchases of more
than $20,000.00 he shall first procure the approval of the board of trustees.
In all cases he shall comply with the statutory provisions as to solicitation
of bids.



      (9)   Have and exercise the power, authority and duties of any
head of a department or division of a department prescribed by this Code or
any amendment thereof, during the time when such office shall be vacant or no
person shall have been appointed thereto.



      (10)   Act as agent for the local liquor control commissioner
in all matters pertaining to the administration of the licensing and control
of the sale of alcoholic liquors within the village and the administration of
the state statutes and the provisions of this Code pertaining thereto.



      (11)   Issue all licenses and permits not otherwise provided
for by the state statutes.



      (12)   Appoint administrative assistants.



      (13)   Recommend to the board of trustees the compensation of
all appointive officers and employees not otherwise provided for.



      (14)   Prescribe rules and regulations for the conduct of the
various departments of the village and divisions under such departments.



      (15)   Require periodic reports from each department as he may
deem necessary.



      (16)   Direct any department or division to perform work for
any other department or division.



      (17)   Prepare and present to the president and board of
trustees an annual report of village affairs.



      (18)   Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the
Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/1-1-1 et seq.) or by this Code or any
ordinance or resolution of the board of trustees.



(Code 1965, § 4.02)  (MC-796, § 1, 12-11- 07; MC-935, § 1, 10-13-15)



Secs. 2-168.  Members.



   The village manager’s office shall consist of a village manager,
assistant village manager and such other personnel as may be provided for
from time to time by the president and board of trustees. The village
manager’s office shall include all matters pertaining to office
administration, personnel management, economic and community development,
information technology, public relations, marketing, and community events.



   The economic and community development division, under the direction of
the economic and community development director, shall be responsible for
enforcement of all planning, zoning, subdivision and other
development-related regulations of this Code. The division also shall provide
advice on and administration of economic development programs as directed by
the village manager and board of trustees.



(MC-919, § 1, 2-24-15)



Secs. 2-169—2-190. Reserved.



DIVISION 4. CLERK



Sec. 2-191. Election.



   The village clerk shall be elected as provided in the Illinois
Municipal Code, section 3.1-25-90 (65 ILCS 5/3.1-25-90).



(Code 1965, § 4.16(a))



Sec. 2-192. Duties generally.



   The village clerk shall be ex-officio clerk of the board of trustees,
and shall attend all meetings, keep a full correct journal of its
proceedings, and all ordinances ordained, resolutions, motions and orders
passed. He shall carefully preserve all books, records and papers which may
come into his possession belonging to the village, and do and perform all
duties which may be required of him by statute, this Code, ordinance,
resolution, motion or order.



(Code 1965, § 4.16(b))



Sec. 2-193. Docketing and filing documents.



   It shall be the duty of the clerk to number, docket and file in regular
order all official documents coming into his custody as such officer,
indexing the same so that they can be referred to.



(Code 1965, § 4.16(c))



Sec. 2-194. Clerk's register.



   The clerk shall keep a register in which shall be entered all warrants
drawn on the treasurer, stating the number and date of issue, to whom issued,
for what purpose, the amount of the warrant and when cancelled; also a
register of licenses issued by the village, giving the number of the license,
to whom issued, for what purpose, date of issue, and the amount paid for same
to the collector, clerk or treasurer; also a register of the officers elected
each year and officers appointed giving the names of the officers, title of
the office, date of election or appointment, date of bond and qualification
and when the term of office commences and expires.



(Code 1965, § 4.16(d))



Sec. 2-195. Certified copies.



   The clerk shall furnish such certified copies of ordinances,
resolutions, motions and orders as may be requested by the president and as
may be filed in the county clerk's office, or other office.



(Code 1965, § 4.16(e))



Sec. 2-196. Signature.



   The clerk shall countersign all warrants drawn on the treasurer and
shall attest and affix the corporate seal of the village where required by
statute, ordinance, resolution, motion or order.



(Code 1965, § 4.16(f))



Sec. 2-197. Notification of election or appointment to officers.



   The clerk shall, within five days after the result of an election is
declared or appointment made, notify in writing all persons so elected or
appointed of their election or appointment.



(Code 1965, § 4.16(g))



Sec. 2-198. Corporate seal.



   The clerk shall be the custodian of the village corporate seal.



(Code 1965, § 4.16(h))



Sec. 2-199. Record of funds collected; reports.



   The finance department shall keep accurate accounts of all funds
received by it for license fees and otherwise.



(Code 1965, § 4.16(i))



Sec. 2-200. Disposition of funds collected.



   The finance department shall deposit to village accounts all funds
received by it within one business day of receipt.



(Code 1965, § 4.16(j))



Sec. 2-201. Clerk pro tempore.



   In the temporary absence of the village clerk, the village clerk shall
appoint some qualified person clerk pro tempore to act as ex-officio clerk of
the board of trustees, and to do such other acts in place and stead of the
village clerk not prohibited by statute or law.



(Code 1965, § 4.16(k))



Sec. 2-202. Publication of annual reports.



   The clerk shall publish or post the annual reports of the village
treasurer and village collector and of such other officers as he is required
to do by law or this Code.



(Code 1965, § 4.16(l))



Sec. 2-203. Compensation.



   The village clerk shall receive as salary for her services the sum of
$2,100.00 per year, payable quarterly.



(Code 1965, § 4.16(m)) (MC-678)



Secs. 2-204--2-230. Reserved.



DIVISION 5. TREASURER



Sec. 2-231. Appointment.



   The village treasurer shall be appointed by the president by and with
the consent of the board of trustees.



(Code 1965, § 4.17(a))



Sec. 2-232. Duties generally.



   The village treasurer shall perform the duties prescribed by statute,
ordinance, resolution, motion or order. He shall keep a full and complete
record of all financial operations of the village, receive all moneys
belonging to the village, and be responsible for such funds. He shall keep a
regular and fair account of all moneys received and disbursed, of whom
received and to whom paid.



(Code 1965, § 4.17(b))



Sec. 2-233. Inspection of accounts.



   The books of the treasurer shall at all times be open to inspection by
the village manager, the president or any member of the board of trustees.



(Code 1965, § 4.17(c))



Sec. 2-234. Monthly statements; warrants; vouchers; register.



   The treasurer shall, at the end of every month, and oftener if
requested, render an account to the village manager showing the state of the
treasury at the date of such account, and the balance of money in the
treasury. He shall also accompany such accounts with a statement of all
moneys received into the treasury, and on what account, together with all
warrants redeemed and paid by him; which warrants, together with any and all
vouchers held by him, shall be delivered to the village clerk (and the clerk
shall give receipt therefor) and filed with his account in the clerk's office
upon every day of such settlement. He shall return all warrants paid by him
stamped or marked paid. The village manager shall, at the earliest possible
date, submit such report and account to the president and board of trustees
for approval. The treasurer shall also keep a register of all warrants
redeemed and paid, which shall describe such warrants and show the date,
amount, number, the fund from which paid, the name of the person to whom and
when paid.(Code 1965, § 4.17(d))



Sec. 2-235. Annual report; publication.



   The treasurer shall annually prior to August 31, make out and file with
the clerk a full and detailed sworn to account of all receipts and
expenditures, and all of his transactions as such treasurer, during the
preceding year, which account shall also show the state of the treasury. The
clerk shall present such account to the village manager and immediately cause
such account to be published as provided by the Illinois Municipal Code,
section 3.1-35-65 (65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-65).



(Code 1965, § 4.17(e))



Sec. 2-236. Separate accounts.



   The treasurer shall keep a separate account for each fund or
appropriation, and the debts or credits belonging thereto.



(Code 1965, § 4.17(f))



Sec. 2-237. Special assessment funds.



   All moneys received on any special assessment shall be held by the
treasurer as a special fund to be applied only to the payment of the
improvements, or bonds and vouchers issued therefor, together with interest
thereon, for which the assessment was made. Such money shall be used for no
other purpose, unless to reimburse the village for money expended for such
improvement. Payments on bonds or vouchers shall be made in accordance with
the statutes and the law, and the treasurer shall keep his books and accounts
in such a manner so that proper prorations in payments or principal and
interest can be made and ascertained.



(Code 1965, § 4.17(g))



Sec. 2-238. Receipts and vouchers.



   The treasurer shall give every person paying money into the treasury a
receipt therefor, specifying the date of payment and upon what account paid.
He shall also file copies of such receipts with the clerk at the date of his
monthly reports.



(Code 1965, § 4.17(h))



Sec. 2-239. Warrants; transfer of funds.



   All warrants drawn on the treasurer must be signed by the president and
countersigned by the clerk, stating the particular fund or appropriation to
which the same is chargeable, and the person to whom payable. No money shall
be otherwise paid except as may be provided by statute. Money shall not be
transferred by the treasurer from one fund to another, after it has been
received by him, nor appropriated to any other purpose than that for which it
has been collected or paid, except as may be ordered by the president and
board of trustees in the manner and form prescribed by statute.



(Code 1965, § 4.17(i))



Secs. 2-240--2-260. Reserved.



ARTICLE IV. DEPARTMENTS



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Sec. 2-261. Administrative departments.



   The executive and administrative powers and duties of the village shall
be delegated and exercised through the following departments and the
following heads of departments which are hereby established:



 

Finance department
 
Director of Finance


Police department
 
Chief of Police


Fire department
 
Fire Chief


Department of public works
 
Director of Public Works


Legal department
 
Village Attorney



 



(Code 1965, § 4.03)  (MC-919, § 1, 2-24-15)



Sec. 2-262. Conflicts.



   If other sections, phrases, sentences or clauses of this Code conflict
with this article, division 3 of article III of this chapter, article III of
the fire prevention chapter, article II of the health and sanitation chapter
and article II of the law enforcement chapter, the provisions, meaning and
intent of the specified provisions shall govern to the extent of the
inconsistency.



(Code 1965, § 4.10)



Secs. 2-263--2-285. Reserved.



DIVISION 2. FINANCE



Sec. 2-286. Divisions.



   The finance department, under the direction of the director of finance,
shall include the positions of collector and treasurer and all matters
pertaining to licensing, risk management, general government functions and
shall contain the following divisions:



   (1)   Division of water billing, which shall include collection of
all water bills, generating and issuing bills therefor and do such other
things as may be necessary therein or ordered by the village manager.



   (2)   Division of accounts, which shall include all matters
pertaining to the finances of the village except those delegated to the
village treasurer. Specifically, the division shall include:



         a.   Inspection of books. Keep accurate account books
and records and execute all warrants for the collection of special
assessments or special taxes which by law or ordinance may be directed to it,
and perform such other duties as may be imposed on it by law or the board of
trustees. The books of the division shall be open to inspection at all times
by the village manager, the president and board of trustees.



         b.   Reports to board and clerk. Make a report in
writing and under oath to the village manager of all moneys collected by it,
the account whereon collected, the balance of moneys uncollected on all
warrants in its hands, or of any other matter in connection with its office,
as often as requested by the board of trustees, and shall annually, prior to
October 31, file with the village clerk a statement, under oath, of all the
moneys collected by it during the year, the particular warrant, special
assessment or account on which collected, the balance of moneys uncollected
on all warrants in its hands, and the balance remaining uncollected at the
time of the return on all warrants which it shall have returned during the
preceding fiscal year to the village clerk. The clerk shall publish such
report as required by the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-125).



         c.   Payments to treasurer. Daily deposit all money
collected or received by it.



         d.   Financial management. Administer and monitor all
matters pertaining to purchasing and expenditures, accounts payable, accounts
receivable and payroll processing.



(MC-919, § 1, 2-24-15)



Secs. 2-287--2-310. Reserved.



DIVISION 3. LEGAL



Sec. 2-311. Duties.



   (a)   The legal department, under the direction of the village
attorney, shall counsel the village manager and board of trustees on all
legal matters affecting the village and prosecute all violations of this
Code, ordinances, and state statutes.



   (b)   The duties of the village attorney include, but are not
limited to, counsel, ordinance and Code amendment drafting, prosecution or
defense of any and all suits or actions at law or in equity, civil or
criminal, or administrative proceedings, to which the village may be a party
or in which it may be interested, or which may be brought against or by any
officer of the village on behalf of the village or in the capacity of such
person as an officer of the village.



(Code 1965, § 4.09)



Secs. 2-312--2-335. Reserved.



DIVISION 4. PUBLIC WORKS*



*Cross reference(s)--Advertising, ch. 6; alcoholic beverages, ch. 10;
amusements and entertainments, ch. 14; businesses generally, ch. 26; floods,
ch. 46; historical preservation, ch. 54; law enforcement, ch. 62; offenses
and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 70; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 74;
planning, ch. 78; secondhand goods, ch. 82; signs, ch. 86; operation of
vehicles generally, § 106-131 et seq.; vehicles for hire, ch. 118.



Sec. 2-336. Personnel.



   The department of public works shall consist of a director of public
works, assistant director of public works, engineer, general inspectors, and
a permanent labor force for normal public works maintenance, operation, and
repair work, and such other personnel as may be provided for by the president
and board of trustees from time to time.



(Code 1965, § 4.07(a))



Sec. 2-337. Director.



   The director of public works, who also may be village engineer, shall
have direct charge and control over the department of public works and shall
be responsible for the faithful and efficient conduct of the department.



(Code 1965, § 4.07(b))



Sec. 2-338. Engineer.



   The village engineer shall be a registered professional engineer.



(Code 1965, § 4.07(c))



Sec. 2-339. Divisions.



   The department of public works, under the director of public works,
shall contain the following divisions:



      (1)   Division of engineering which shall include all matters
pertaining to engineering work and shall be administered by the director of
public works or the village engineer.



      (2)   Division of streets, which shall include all matters
pertaining to the public streets and to the maintenance and operation of the
municipal garage.



      (3)   Division of utilities, which shall include those matters
pertaining to the operation and maintenance of the sanitary sewer collection
system, sewage lift stations, and other appurtenances of the sewage system,
and all activities pertaining to the operation and maintenance of the water
pumping and treatment plants and stations, the water distribution system,
water tank storage facilities, and all other appurtenances of the water
system.



      (4)   Division of landscape maintenance, which shall include
all matters pertaining to maintenance of landscaping.



      (5)   Division of fleet and building maintenance, which shall
include all activities pertaining to maintenance and operation of the village
hall and such other village-owned buildings, grounds and vehicles as the
village manager may designate.



(Code 1965, § 4.07(d))



Sec. 2-340. Construction work.



   It shall be the duty of the village engineer to prepare specifications
for the performance of any construction work, or for the purchase of any
materials of construction or mechanical equipment, whenever it is proposed
that the village should advertise for bids to contract for the same; or, in
the event specifications for construction, materials or equipment are
prepared by another, the director of public works shall make his written
recommendations thereon before bids are requested. Whenever the village
becomes a party to any such contract, the director of public works shall make
inspections as necessary to ensure the contractor's compliance with
specifications.



(Code 1965, § 4.07(e))



Sec. 2-341. Advice to Planning and Zoning Commission.



   The village engineer shall furnish engineering advice in writing to the
village Planning and Zoning Commission whenever requested to do so by the
chairman of the Planning and Zoning Commission; or in the event he finds
himself unable to do so in a particular instance, he shall recommend a
competent source for the required advice. He shall have custody of official
certified copies of the village plan, plats of dedication and other documents
establishing official grades and alignments of public streets, sanitary
sewers and storm drains, and of the zoning map.



(Code 1965, § 4.07(f))  (MC-951, § 1, 3-22-16)



Secs. 2-342—2-352. Reserved.



DIVISION 5. INSPECTION SERVICES



Sec. 2-353. Personnel.



   The inspection services division shall consist of the fire chief and
such other personnel as may be provided for from time to time by the
president and board of trustees.



(MC-919, § 1, 2-24-15)



Sec. 2-354. Duties.



   The inspection services division shall issue permits for and inspect
the construction and alteration of structures, electrical installations and
repairs, plumbing installations and repairs, and heating installations and
repairs. In addition, the division shall enforce property maintenance codes
and health regulations to promote the public health, safety, and general
welfare.



(MC-919, § 1, 2-24-15)
