ARTICLE V. BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Secs. 2-366—2-385. Reserved.



DIVISION 2. BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS



Sec. 2-386. Appointment of members.



   The village manager is hereby empowered to appoint members to the board
of local improvements of the village, with the approval of the board of
trustees. The board shall be composed of five members. Appointments to the
board shall be in accordance with the Illinois Municipal Code, section 5-3-11
(65 ILCS 5/5-3-11).



(Code 1965, § 4.19(a))



Sec. 2-387. Meetings.



   The regular meetings of the board of local improvements shall be held
at the village hall at 7:45 p.m., or as soon thereafter as may be convenient,
on the second and fourth Tuesdays of each and every calendar month, unless
there is no business to be transacted before such board. By a majority vote,
the board of local improvements may adjourn to any fixed time or subject to
call of the president of the board of local improvements. Special meetings
may be called from time to time by the president of the board of local
improvements upon giving two days' written notice to each member. If all
members are present at any special meeting, it shall be deemed to have been
regularly called although no record of the calling of the meeting appears in
the minutes.



(Code 1965, § 4.19(b))



Sec. 2-388. Secretary.



   The village clerk shall be the secretary of the board of local
improvements; however, should the clerk not be present at any meeting, the
board shall elect a secretary pro tempore to act at such meeting.



(Code 1965, § 4.19(c))



Sec. 2-389. Compensation.



   Neither the  president nor the  members  of  the board  shall
receive any salary  for  acting as such; however, the president and members
shall receive $5.00 for each special meeting attended, to be paid out of the
general fund.



(Code 1965, § 4.19(d))



Secs. 2-390--2-410. Reserved.



DIVISION 3. BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS



Sec. 2-411. Established; appointment; composition; terms.



   There is hereby established in and for the village a board of fire and
police commissioners as provided by statute. The village president, with the
consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint the board of fire and police
commissioners. The board shall consist of three members, whose terms of
office shall be three years and until their respective successors are
appointed and have qualified, except as otherwise provided by statute. No
such appointment however, shall be made by any president within 30 days
before the expiration of his term of office.



(Code 1965, § 4.20(a))



   Cross reference(s)—General penalty for Code violations, § 1-11.



Sec. 2-412. Powers.



   The board of fire and police commissioners shall have the rights and
powers and be subject to the duties provided by the state statutes.



(Code 1965, § 4.20(b))



Sec. 2-413. Appointments by board.



   The board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all officers
and members of the fire and police departments of the village, except that
the chief of police and the fire chief shall be appointed by the village
manager, deputy police chiefs shall be appointed by the police chief, and the
deputy fire chief shall be appointed by the fire chief. Nothing in this
section shall be construed to authorize the board of fire and police
commissioners to examine, appoint, promote, or in any other way deal with the
volunteer members of the fire department or reserve police officers, and such
volunteer members and reserve police officers are hereby excluded from
coverage of the board of fire and police commissioners.



(Code 1965, § 4.20(c))(MC-841, § 1, 3-8-11)



Sec. 2-414. Appointment of chiefs.



   The village manager is authorized to appoint any qualified person as
chief of police or fire chief, and is not to be restricted in such
appointment to selecting such person from those with rank in such departments.



(Code 1965, § 4.20(d))



Secs. 2-415—2-465. Reserved.



ARTICLE VI. CIVIL SERVICE



Sec. 2-466. Employment policy.



   It is hereby the declared policy of the village that:



      (1)   Employment in the village government shall be based on
merit and fitness, free from personal and political considerations.



      (2)   Just and equitable incentives and conditions of
employment shall be established and maintained to promote efficiency and
economy in the operation of the village government.



      (3)   Positions having similar duties and responsibilities
shall be compensated on a uniform basis.



      (4)   Appointments, promotions and other actions requiring the
application of the merit principle shall be based on systematic tests and
evaluations.



      (5)   High morale shall be maintained by fair administration
of this article and by every consideration of the rights and interests of
employees consistent with the best interests of the public and the village.



      (6)   Tenure of employees covered by this article shall be
subject only to good behavior, the satisfactory performance of work,
necessity for the performance of work and the availability of funds.



(Code 1965, § 5.01; MC-838, § 1, 11-9-10)



Sec. 2-467. Scope of article.



   All positions of the village are civil service positions except:



      (1)   Officers who are elected or members of boards and
commissions;



      (2)   The village manager, the assistant village manager,
administrative assistant to the village manager, heads of the police, fire,
public works, community development, and finance departments; attorneys or
special counsel, and all other persons exercising administrative or executive
discretion;



      (3)   Employees covered by a collective bargaining agreement;



      (4)   Members of the police and fire departments (except
civilian clerks);



      (5)   Volunteer personnel and personnel appointed to serve
without pay;



      (6)   Consultants and counsel rendering temporary professional
service;



      (7)   Such positions involving seasonal, part-time, temporary,
or interim employment.



(MC-838, § 1, 11-9-10)



Sec. 2-468. Administration of article.



   (a)   The personnel program established by this article shall be
administered by the village manager. The village manager or their designee
shall attend all meetings of the civil service commission; administer all the
provisions of this article and of the personnel rules; insure that the
personnel rules are regularly updated to comply with applicable laws,
regulations and court decisions; and shall recommend substantive changes to
the personnel rules as necessary.



   (b)   The board of trustees, upon recommendation of the village
manager, may contract with any qualified person or agency for the performance
of such technical services as may be desired in the establishment and
operation of the personnel program.



(Code 1965, § 5.03; MC-838, § 1, 11-9-10)



Sec. 2-469.  Civil Service Commission.



   (a)   Establishment; composition; qualifications; terms; vacancies;
compensation. A civil service commission shall be established, consisting of
three members appointed by the village president with the advice and consent
of the board of trustees. The members of the civil service commission shall
be persons in sympathy with the application of merit principles to public
employment. No member of the commission shall be employed by or be an
official of the village, nor be a member of any local, state or national
committee of a political party or an official or member of a committee in any
partisan political club or organization, nor hold or be a candidate for any
elective office. The members of the commission shall serve for a term of
three years. Vacancies occurring during a term shall be filled for the
balance of the term. Members of the commission shall serve without
compensation, but funds will be provided for reasonable and necessary
expenses. The commission shall elect its own chairman.



   (b)   Duties. The civil service commission shall:



      (1)   Advise the village manager and the board of trustees on
matters of personnel policy and problems of personnel administration.



      (2)   Represent the public interest in the improvement of
personnel administration in the village service.



      (3)   Act as an appeal body consistent with the procedures
established in this Article.



(MC-838, § 1, 11-9-10)



Sec. 2-470. Rules.



   (a) The village manager shall draft a comprehensive personnel manual
for all village employees, to include rules as may be necessary to carry out
the provisions of this article. Within the personnel manual, the village may
reserve the right to interpret, change, suspend, cancel, or dispute with
notice all or any part of its policies, procedures, and benefits at any time.



   (b)   Substantive amendments to the personnel rules affecting civil
service positions will be reviewed by the civil service commission and
approved by the board of trustees of the village. The village manager is
authorized to implement minor updates, corrections, and revisions to the
personnel manual without review by the civil service commission. The village
manager shall notify all employees of changes to the personnel rules as
required by law. Changes will be effective on the dates determined by the
village. All changes normally will be posted on employee bulletin boards and
on the village's internet page at least ten days prior to their effective
date.



(MC-838, § 1, 11-9-10)



Sec. 2-471. Classification and compensation plans.



   (a)   The village manager shall make an analysis of the duties and
responsibilities of all positions in the civil service and shall recommend to
the board of trustees a job classification plan, and from time to time,
revisions in such plan.



   (b)   The village manager shall make an analysis of the duties and
responsibilities of all positions in the civil service and shall from time to
time recommend to the board of trustees a plan of compensation which shall be
related to compensation for comparable positions in other places of public
and private employment.



(Code 1965, § 5.06; MC-838, § 1, 11-9-10)



Sec. 2-472. Appointments and promotions.



   Original appointments to vacancies and promotions in the civil service
shall be based on merit. The village manager shall make an analysis of the
duties and responsibilities of all positions in the civil service, and shall
from time to time recommend to the board of trustees a system of appointments
and promotions based upon examinations testing the ability and aptitude of
candidates for positions, which system shall contain provisions relating to
the preferences to be granted to employees having tenure and to veterans.



(Code 1965, § 5.07; MC-838, § 1, 11-9-10)



Sec. 2-473. Separations from service.



   In addition to the provisions of the Personnel Policies and Practices
Manual, the following provisions shall apply to all civil service employees:



      (1)   Tenure. The tenure of every employee shall be
conditioned on good behavior and the satisfactory performance of duties. Any
employee may be temporarily separated by layoff or suspension; or permanently
separated by resignation or dismissal.



      (2)   Reduction in force. Whenever there is lack of work or
lack of funds requiring reductions in the number of employees in a department
or division of the village government, the required number of employees shall
be laid off in the inverse order of their relative length and quality of
service, as determined by rules governing the evaluation of service. service.
In any village department temporary employees shall be laid off before
probationary employees, and probationary employees shall be laid off before
any permanent employees.



      (3)   Disciplinary action. When, in the judgment of the
village manager and department head, an employee's work performance or
conduct justifies disciplinary action short of dismissal, the employee may be
suspended without pay for a period of time of up to, but not exceeding, 30
days. A civil service employee suspended for more than five days or suspended
within six months after a previous suspension shall be entitled, upon
request, to a hearing before the civil service commission concerning the
propriety of such suspension.



      (4)   Dismissal or demotion. A permanent employee may be
dismissed or demoted whenever, in the judgment of the village manager, the
employee's work or misconduct so warrants. When the village manager decides
to take such action, he shall file with the employee written notification
containing a statement of the substantial reasons for the action. The
employee shall be notified not later than the effective date of the action.
The notice shall inform the employee that he or she shall be allowed five
working days from the effective date of the action to file an appeal with the
village manager and civil service commission and to request a hearing before
the commission.



      (5)   Hearing. If the employee files a reply and requests a
hearing within the prescribed period, the commission shall schedule a
hearing. In conducting a hearing the proceedings shall be informal, and it
shall be assumed that the action complained of was taken in good faith unless
proved otherwise. Hearings shall be conducted in compliance with the Open
Meetings Act and shall be governed by procedures established by the
commission.



      (6)   Civil Service Commission action. If the commission finds
the action of the village manager was improper, the employee shall be
reinstated to his or her former position without loss of pay, unless the
commission shall recommend a penalty less severe than that imposed by the
village manager in which case the employee shall suffer the penalty so
recommended.



      (7)   Resignation. An employee may resign by filing his
reasons with the department head or with the village manager.



(Code 1965, § 5.08) (MC-838, § 1, 11-9-10)



Sec. 2-474. Political activity.



   Employees in the civil service shall be selected without regard to
political considerations, shall not be required to contribute to any
political purpose, and shall not engage in improper political activity. The
rules shall define the scope of improper political activity.



(Code 1965, § 5.09) (MC-838, § 1, 11-9-10)



Sec. 2-475. Non-Discrimination.



   There shall be no discrimination in employment opportunities or
practices based on sex, race, national origin, age, religion, political
affiliation, sexual orientation, marital status or any other legally
protected characteristic.



(Code 1965, § 5.10) (MC-838, § 1, 11-9-10)



Secs. 2-476–2-495. Reserved.



ARTICLE VII. FINANCE



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Sec. 2-496. Fiscal year.



   The fiscal year of the village is hereby fixed and determined to have
been, and now to be from May 1 to April 30 in each year.



(Code 1965, § 4.23)



Secs. 2-497–2-515. Reserved.



DIVISION 2. CONTRACTS



Sec. 2-516. Interest of village officers or employees.



   Unless otherwise permitted by state law or authorized by the Illinois
legislature, no officer or employee of the village shall be directly or
indirectly interested financially in any contract of any kind with the
village.



(Code 1965, § 4.24(a)) (MC-664)



Sec. 2-517. Bids.



   All contracts for the making of any public improvements to be paid for
in whole or in part by special assessment shall be let to the lowest
responsible bidder, in manner and form as is prescribed by statute. All other
contracts for materials, supplies, labor or public improvements, where the
cost thereof exceeds $20,000.00 shall be let to the lowest responsible bidder
in manner and form provided in this section, except that any such contract
may be entered into without advertising for bids by a vote of two-thirds of
the trustees elected. Whenever the requirement for advertising of bids is
waived by the village board of trustees, the reason for the waiver must be
stated publicly. Acceptable reasons for waiver of the bid requirement
include, but are not limited to:



      (1)   An emergency purchase;



      (2)   Only one vendor available;



      (3)   Equipment standardization;



      (4)   The technical nature of an item makes competition
impractical; or



      (5)   Use of a joint governmental purchasing program.



   Notwithstanding the above, whenever the village has solicited bids for
motor vehicles valued at more than $15,000.00, the village board of trustees
may disregard the lowest responsible bid and instead award such bid to the
lowest responsible bidder that sells retail motor vehicles from a permanent
physical location within the village, so long as the difference between the
two bids in question is $500.00 or less, and provided that notice of this
preference has been provided as part of the bid specifications. This
paragraph shall not apply where otherwise prohibited by law or regulation, or
where any portion of the purchase amount is from non-village funds.



(Code 1965, § 4.24(b))  (MC-804, § 1, 7-22-08; MC-936, § 1, 10-13-15)



Sec. 2-518. Advertisement for bids.



   Where required and ordered by the president and board of trustees, the
village manager shall advertise by invitation or publication in newspapers or
trade journals for sealed bids for any proposed work, materials or supplies.
Such advertisement shall be inserted not less than five days, nor more than
30 days before the date set for opening bids. Such bids shall be opened by
the village manager or his designee and reported to the president and board
of trustees. The contract shall be let to the lowest responsible bidder
except as provided by section 2-517, and except that all bids may be rejected
and any advertisement shall so state. The notice for bids need give only a
general description of the work, supplies or materials, but a detailed
description and/or plans and specifications shall be on file in the village
manager's office for inspection. The advertisement may call for each bid to
be accompanied by a cashier's or certified check in an amount equal to ten
percent of the bid, to secure such bid; however, there shall be no duty on
the part of the village, or its officers, to convert the check into cash, and
the bidder shall accept all responsibility for failure of the bank to pay or
honor sums. The president and clerk or their designee shall sign any contract
authorized by the board of trustees.



(Code 1965, § 4.24(c))  (MC-804, § 1, 7-22-08)



Secs. 2-519–2-540. Reserved.



DIVISION 3. BUDGET



Sec. 2-541. Adoption of new budget procedure.



   The village hereby adopts section 8-2-9.1 through and including section
8-2-9.10 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-2-9.1  5/8-2-9.10). The
village manager shall appoint a budget officer, who shall have the authority
and responsibilities designated by such statute sections.



(Code 1965, § 4.29)



Sec. 2-542. Public inspection, notice and hearing.



   Copies of the annual budget shall be made available in printed or
typewritten form at the office of the village clerk for at least ten days
prior to the passage of the annual budget. Not less than one week after the
annual budget is available for public inspection in the office of the village
clerk, and prior to final action on the budget, at least one public hearing
shall be held on the annual budget by the village board. Notice of this
hearing shall be given by publication in a newspaper having a general
circulation in the village at least one week prior to the time of the hearing.



(Code 1965, § 4.30)



Sec. 2-543. Adoption.



   The annual budget shall be adopted by the village board before the
beginning of the fiscal year to which it applies. Passage of the annual
budget shall be deemed passage of the appropriation ordinance as required by
section 8-2-9 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-2-9).



(Code 1965, § 4.31)



Sec. 2-544. Revision.



   The village board may delegate authority to heads of municipal
departments, boards, or commissions to delete, add or change items budgeted
previously to the department, board, or commission, subject to such
limitation or requirement for prior approval by the budget officer or village
manager as the village board, upon a two-thirds vote of the corporate
authorities then holding office, may establish. By a vote of two-thirds of
the members of the corporate authorities then holding office, the annual
budget for the municipality may be revised by deleting, adding or changing
budgeted items. No revision of the budget shall be made increasing the budget
in the event funds are not available to effectuate the purpose of the
revision.



   Effective October 13, 2015 with the passage of Ordinance MC-935, the
village board hereby delegates authority to the village manager to delete,
add or change items budgeted previously to a department, board, or
commission, provided the deletion, addition, or change is valued at
$20,000.00 or less.



(Code 1965, § 4.3)  (MC-937, § 1, 10-13-15)

Article II. Administrative Adjudication of Building Code Violations

   Sec. 3-30.   Findings, Decision and Order.



   Sec. 3-31.   Review Under Administrative Review Law.



   Sec. 3-32.   Judgment on Findings, Decision, and Order.



   Sec. 3-33.   Petition to Vacate Default Order - Fee.



ARTICLE I. ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION OF
MUNICIPAL AND BUILDING CODE VIOLATIONS



Sec. 3-1. Adoption.



   The Village of Homewood hereby adopts Division 2.2 of 65 ILCS 5/1-2.2-1
et seq. in its current form and as it may be amended from time to time for
adjudication of municipal code violations.



Sec. 3-2. Definitions.



   As used in this Article I, unless the context requires otherwise:



   a)   "Code" means any municipal ordinance except for (i) building
code violations that must be adjudicated pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1 et
seq. in its current form and as may be amended from time to time, and (ii)
any offense under the Illinois Vehicle Code or a similar offense that is a
traffic regulation governing the movement of vehicles and except for any
reportable offense under Section 6-204 of the Illinois Vehicle Code.



   b)   "Hearing Officer" means a municipal employee or an officer or
agent of the Village, other than a law enforcement officer, whose duty it is
to:



      1.   Preside at an administrative hearing called to determine
whether or not a code violation exists;



      2.   Hear testimony and accept evidence from all interested
parties relevant to the existence of a code violation;



      3.   Preserve and authenticate the transcript and record of
the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing; and



      4.   Issue and sign a written finding, decision, and order
stating whether a code violation exists.



Sec. 3-3. Municipal Code Hearing Department.



   There is hereby established a Municipal Code Hearing Department in the
Village of Homewood Municipal Government. The function is to expedite the
prosecution and correction of code violations in the manner set forth in this
Article I.



   The Municipal Code Hearing Department may adjudicate any violation of a
municipal ordinance except for (i) building code violations that must be
adjudicated pursuant to Division 31.1 of 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1 et seq. in its
current form and as amended from time to time, and (ii) any offense under the
Illinois Vehicle Code or similar offense that is a traffic regulation
governing the movement of vehicles and except for any reportable offense
under Section 6-204 of the Illinois Vehicle Code.



Sec. 3-4.  Hearing Procedures Not Exclusive.



   This Article I does not preclude the Village from using other methods
to enforce the provisions of its code.



Sec. 3-5. Instituting Code Hearing Proceedings.



   When a police officer or other individual authorized to issue a code
violation finds a code violation to exist, he or she shall note the violation
on a multiple copy violation notice and report form that indicates (i) the
name and address of the defendant, (ii) the type and nature of the violation,
(iii) the date and time the violation was observed, and (iv) the names of the
witnesses of the violation.



   The violation report form shall be forwarded to the Municipal Code
Hearing Department where a docket number shall be stamped on all copies of
the report and a hearing date shall be noted in the blank spaces provided for
that purpose on the form. The hearing date shall not be less than 30 nor more
than 40 days after the violation is reported.



   One copy of the violation report form shall be maintained in the files
of the Municipal Code Hearing Department and shall be part of the record of
hearing, one copy of the report form shall be returned to the individual
representing the Village in the case so that he or she may prepare evidence
of the code violation for presentation at the hearing on the date indicated,
and one copy of the report form shall be served by first class mail to the
defendant along with a summons commanding the defendant to appear at the
hearing.



   The report form and/or summons served upon the defendant may also
provide that the defendant's appearance at the hearing shall not be required
upon payment of a $75.00 fine prior to the hearing.  Prepayment of any fine
shall constitute an admission of liability to the code violation alleged.



(MC-812, § 1, 11-25-08)



Sec. 3-6.  Subpoenas; Defaults.



   At any time prior to the hearing date, the hearing officer assigned to
hear the case may, at the request of either party, direct witnesses to appear
and give testimony at the hearing. If on the date set for the hearing the
defendant or his or her attorney fails to appear, the hearing officer may
find the defendant in default and shall proceed with the hearing and accept
evidence relevant to the existence of a code violation.



Sec. 3-7.  Continuances; Representation at Code Hearings.



   No Continuances shall be authorized by the hearing officer in
proceedings under this Article I except in cases where a continuance is
absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the defendant. Lack of
preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance. Any continuance
authorized by a hearing officer under this ordinance shall not exceed 25
days. The case for the Village may be presented by an attorney designated by
the Village or by any other municipal employee, except that the case for the
Village shall not be presented by any employee of the Municipal Code Hearing
Department. The case for the defendant may be presented by the defendant, his
or her attorney, or any other agent or representative of the defendant.



Sec. 3-8.  Hearing; Evidence.



   At the hearing a hearing officer shall preside, shall hear testimony,
and shall accept any evidence relevant to the existence or non-existence of a
code violation. The strict rules of evidence applicable to judicial
proceedings shall not apply to hearings authorized by this Article I.



Sec. 3-9.  Qualifications of Hearing Officers.



   Prior to conducting proceedings under this Article I, hearing officers
shall successfully complete a formal training program that includes the
following:



   a)   Instruction on the rules of procedure of the hearing that they
will conduct;



   b)   Orientation to each subject area of the code violations that
they will administer;



   c)   Observation of administrative hearings; and



   d)   Participation in hypothetical cases, including rules on
evidence and issuing final orders.



   In addition, every hearing officer must be an attorney licensed to
practice law in the State of Illinois for at least three years.



Sec. 3-10.  Findings, Decision and Order.



   At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a
determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing as to
whether or not a code violation exists. The determination shall be in writing
and shall be designated as findings, decision and order. The findings,
decision and order shall include (i) the hearing officer's findings of fact;
(ii) a decision of whether or not a code violation exists based upon the
findings of fact; and (iii) an order that states the sanction or dismisses
the case if a violation is not proved. A monetary sanction for a violation
under this article I shall not exceed the amount provided for in 65 ILCS
5/1-2.2 in its current form and as amended from time to time. A copy of the
findings, decision, and order shall be served on the defendant within five
(5) days after it is issued. Service shall be in the same manner that the
report form and summons are served under section 1-5 of this article I.



   Payment of any penalty or fine and the disposition of fine money shall
be in the same manner as set forth in the code, unless the corporate
authorities adopting this article I provide otherwise.



Sec. 3-11.  Review Under Administrative Review Law.



   The findings, decision and order of the hearing officer shall be
subject to review in the Cook County Circuit Court. The provisions of the
Administrative Review Law and the rules adopted pursuant thereto, shall apply
to and govern every action for the judicial review of the findings,
decisions, and order of a hearing officer under this article I.



Sec. 3-12. Judgment on Findings, Decision, and Order.



   a)   A fine, other sanction, or costs imposed, or part of any fine,
other sanction or costs imposed, remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or
the failure to exhaust, judicial review procedures under the Administrative
Review Law shall be a debt due and owing the village and, as such, may be
collected in accordance with applicable law.



   b)   After expiration of the period within which judicial review
under the Administrative Review Law may be sought for a final determination
of the code violation, the village may command a proceeding in the circuit
court of the county in which the village is located for purpose of obtaining
a judgment of findings, decision, and order. Nothing in this section shall
prevent a municipality from consolidating multiple findings, decisions, and
orders against a person in such a proceeding. Upon commencement of the
action, the village shall file a certified copy of the findings, decision,
and order, which shall be accompanied by a certification that recites facts
sufficient to show that the findings, decision, and order was issued in
accordance with this article I and the applicable municipal ordinances.
Service of the summons and a copy of the petition may be by any method
provided by Section 2-203 of the Code of Civil Procedure, or by certified
mail, return receipt requested, provided that the total amount of fines,
other sanctions, and costs imposed by the findings, decision, and order does
not exceed $2,500. If the court is satisfied that the findings, decision and
order was entered in accordance with the requirements of this article I and
the applicable municipal ordinance and that the defendant had an opportunity
for a hearing under this article I and for judicial review as provided in
this article I:



      1)   The court shall render judgment in favor of the village
and against the defendant for the amount indicated in the findings, decision,
and order, plus costs. The judgment shall have the same effect and may be
enforced in the same manner as other judgments for the recovery of money;



      2)   The court may also issue any other orders and injunctions
that are requested by the village to enforce the order of the hearing officer
to correct a code violation.



Sec. 3-13.  Petition to Vacate Default Order - Fee.



   After entry of an order finding the defendant in default and liable
pursuant to section 3-6 of this Code, the hearing officer shall not entertain
a request to vacate said default unless the defendant first pays a $50.00
administrative fee to the village. Said administrative fee shall be due when
the defendant files a request to return the matter to the administrative
hearing call.



(MC-833, § 1, 6-22-10)



Secs. 3-14—3-20.  Reserved.



ARTICLE II. ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION OF
BUILDING CODE VIOLATIONS



Sec. 3-21.  Adoption.



   The Village of Homewood hereby adopts Division 31.1 of 65 ILCS
5/11-31.1-1 et seq. in its current form and as it may be amended from time to
time for adjudication of building code violations.



Sec. 3-22.    Definitions.



   As used in this article II, unless the context requires otherwise:



   a)   "Code" means any municipal ordinance, law, housing or building
code or zoning ordinance that establishes construction, plumbing, heating,
electrical, fire prevention, sanitation or other health and safety standards
that are applicable to structures in the Village or any municipal ordinance
that requires, after notice, the cutting of weeds, the removal of garbage and
debris, the removal of inoperable motor vehicles, or the abatement of
nuisances from private property;



   b)   "Building inspector" means a full time state, county or
municipal employee whose duties include the inspection or examination of
structures or property in a municipality to determine if zoning or other code
violations exist;



   c)   "Property owner" means the legal or beneficial owner of a
structure;



   d)   "Hearing Officer" means a municipal employee or an officer or
agent of the Village, other than a building inspector or law enforcement
officer, whose duty it is to:



      1.   Preside at an administrative hearing called to determine
whether or not a code violation exists;



      2.   Hear testimony and accept evidence from the building
inspector, the building owner and all interested parties relevant to the
existence of a code violation;



      3.   Preserve and authenticate the transcript and record of
the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing; and



      4.   Issue and sign a written finding, decision, and order
stating whether a code violation exists.



Sec. 3-23. Building Code Hearing Department.



   There is hereby established a Building Code Hearing Department in the
Village of Homewood Municipal Government. The function is to expedite the
prosecution and correction of code violations in the manner set forth in this
Article II.



   The Building Code Hearing Department may adjudicate any violation of a
municipal ordinance, law, housing or building code or zoning ordinance that
establishes construction, plumbing, heating, electrical, fire prevention,
sanitation or other health and safety standards that are applicable to
structures in the Village or any municipal ordinance that requires, after
notice, the cutting of weeds, the removal of garbage and debris, the removal
of inoperable motor vehicles, or the abatement of nuisances from private
property.



Sec. 3-24. Hearing Procedures Not Exclusive.



   This Article II does not preclude the Village from using other methods
to enforce the provisions of its code.



Sec. 3-25.  Instituting Code Hearing  Proceedings.



   When a building inspector, police officer, fire department officer, or
other individual authorized to issue a code violation finds a code violation
to exist, he or she shall note the violation on a multiple copy violation
notice and report form that indicates (i) the name and address of the
defendant, (ii) the type and nature of the violation, (iii) the date and time
the violation was observed, and (iv) the names of the witnesses of the
violation.



   The violation report form shall be forwarded to the Building Code
Hearing Department where a docket number shall be stamped on all copies of
the report and a hearing date shall be noted in the blank spaces provided for
that purpose on the form. The hearing date shall not be less than 30 nor more
than 40 days after the violation is reported.



   One copy of the violation report form shall be maintained in the files
of the Building Code Hearing Department and shall be part of the record of
hearing, one copy of the report form shall be returned to the individual
representing the Village in the case so that he or she may prepare evidence
of the code violation for presentation at the hearing on the date indicated,
and one copy of the report form shall be served by first class mail to the
defendant along with a summons commanding the defendant to appear at the
hearing.



Sec. 3-26.  Subpoenas; Defaults.



   At any time prior to the hearing date, the hearing officer assigned to
hear the case may, at the request of either party, direct witnesses to appear
and give testimony at the hearing. If on the date set for the hearing the
defendant or his or her attorney fails to appear, the hearing officer may
find the defendant in default and shall proceed with the hearing and accept
evidence relevant to the existence of a code violation.



Sec. 3-27.  Continuances; Representation at Code Hearings.



   No Continuances shall be authorized by the hearing officer in
proceedings under this Article II except in cases where a continuance is
absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the defendant. Lack of
preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance. Any continuance
authorized by a hearing officer under this ordinance shall not exceed 25
days. The case for the Village may be presented by an attorney designated by
the Village or by any other municipal employee, except that the case for the
Village shall not be presented by any employee of the Building Code Hearing
Department. The case for the defendant may be presented by the defendant, his
or her attorney, or any other agent or representative of the defendant.



Secs. 3-28.  Hearing; Evidence.



   At the hearing a hearing officer shall preside, shall hear testimony,
and shall accept any evidence relevant to the existence or non-existence of a
code violation. The strict rules of evidence applicable to judicial
proceedings shall not apply to hearings authorized by this Article II.



Sec. 3-29.    Defenses to Code Violations.



   It shall be a defense to a code violation charged under this article II
if the owner, his attorney, or any other agent or representative proves to
the hearing officer's satisfaction that:



   a)   The code violation alleged in the notice does not in fact
exist, or at the time of the hearing the violation has been remedied or
removed;



   b)   The code violation has been caused by the current property
occupants and that in spite of reasonable attempts by the owner to maintain
the dwelling free of such violations, the current occupants continue to cause
the violations;



   c)   An occupant or resident of the dwelling has refused entry to
the owner or his agent to all or part of the dwelling for the purpose of
correcting the code violation.



Sec. 3-30.    Findings, Decision and Order.



   At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a
determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing as to
whether or not a code violation exists. The determination shall be in writing
and shall be designated as findings, decision and order. The findings,
decision and order shall include (i) the hearing officer's findings of fact;
(ii) a decision of whether or not a code violation exists based upon the
findings of fact; and (iii) an order that states the sanction or dismisses
the case if a violation is not proved. A monetary sanction for a violation
under this article II shall not exceed the amount provided for in 65 ILCS
5/11-31.1-11 in its current form and as amended from time to time. A copy of
the findings, decision, and order shall be served on the defendant within
five (5) days after it is issued. Service shall be in the same manner that
the report form and summons are served under section 2-5 of this article II.
Payment of any penalty or fine and the disposition of fine money shall be in
the same manner as set forth in the code, unless the corporate authorities
adopting this article II provide otherwise.



Sec. 3-31.  Review Under Administrative Review Law.



   The findings, decision and order of the hearing officer shall be
subject to review in the Cook County Circuit Court. The provisions of the
Administrative Review Law and the rules adopted pursuant thereto, shall apply
to and govern every action for the judicial review of the findings,
decisions, and order of a hearing officer under this article II.



Sec. 3-32.    Judgment on Findings, Decision, and Order.



   a)   A fine, other sanction, or costs imposed, or part of any fine,
other sanction or costs imposed, remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or
the failure to exhaust, judicial review procedures under the Administrative
Review Law shall be a debt due and owing the village and, as such, may be
collected in accordance with applicable law.



   b)   After expiration of the period within which judicial review
under the Administrative Review Law may be sought for a final determination
of the code violation, the village may commence a proceeding in the Cook
County Circuit Court for purpose of obtaining a judgment on the findings,
decision, and order. Nothing in this section shall prevent a municipality
from consolidating multiple findings, decisions, and orders against a person
in such a proceeding. Upon commencement of the action, the village shall file
a certified copy of the findings, decision, and order, which shall be
accompanied by a certification that recites facts sufficient to show that the
findings, decision, and order was issued in accordance with this article II
and the applicable municipal ordinances. Service of the summons and a copy of
the petition may be by any method provided by section 2-203 of the Code of
Civil Procedure, or by certified mail, return receipt requested, provided
that the total amount of fines, other sanctions, and costs imposed by the
findings, decision, and order does not exceed $2,500. If the court is
satisfied that the findings, decision and order were entered in accordance
with the requirements of this article II and the applicable municipal
ordinance, and that the property owner had an opportunity for a hearing under
this article II and for judicial review as provided in this article II:



      1)   The court shall render judgment in favor of the village
and against the property owner for the amount indicated in the findings,
decision, and order, plus costs. The judgment shall have the same effect and
may be enforced in the same manner as other judgments for the recovery of
money;



      2)   The court may also issue any other orders and injunctions
that are requested by the village to enforce the order of the hearing officer
to correct a code violation.



Sec. 3-33.  Petition to Vacate Default Order - Fee.



   After entry of an order finding the defendant in default and liable
pursuant to section 3-26 of this Code, the hearing officer shall not
entertain a request to vacate said default unless the defendant first pays a
$50.00 administrative fee to the village. Said administrative fee shall be
due when the defendant files a request to return the matter to the
administrative hearing call.



(MC-833, § 1, 6-22-10)



Chapter 6  ADVERTISING*



   *Cross reference(s)--Department of public works, § 2-336 et seq.



Article I. In General



   Sec. 6-1.   Posting or pasting of advertisements.



   Secs. 6-2--6-30.   Reserved.



Article II. Handbills



   Sec. 6-31.   Littering streets.



   Sec. 6-32.   Placing in automobiles.



   Sec. 6-33.   House-to-house distribution.



ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL



Sec. 6-1. Posting or pasting of advertisements.



   No person shall post or paste any advertisements, without written
permission of the owner, upon any street, bridge, fence or building, depot,
schoolhouse, church building, electric light or telephone pole or public
building or place.



(Code 1965, § 53.24)



Secs. 6-2--6-30. Reserved.



ARTICLE II. HANDBILLS



Sec. 6-31. Littering streets.



   No person shall litter any street or sidewalk in the village with any
circulars, dodgers, handbills, or other advertisements.



(Code 1965, § 53.26(a))



Sec. 6-32. Placing in automobiles.



   No person shall distribute circulars, dodgers or handbills by placing
the same in or on automobiles parked in the village, unless the same are
placed in such a manner as to prevent their being blown or carried about by
the elements.



(Code 1965, § 53.26(c))



Sec. 6-33. House-to-house distribution.



   No person shall distribute any circulars, dodgers or handbills from
house to house in the village, whether by delivering such advertisements to
the occupants of such houses, or leaving the same on the porches, mailboxes,
or other parts of such houses, or the premises thereof, unless the same are
placed in such a manner as to prevent their being blown or carried about by
the elements.



(Code 1965, § 53.26(d))



Chapter 10  ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES*



   *Cross reference(s) --General penalty for Code violations, § 1-11;
department of public works, § 2-336 et seq.



   State law reference(s) --Local control, 235 ILCS 5/4-1 et seq.



Article I. In General



   Sec. 10-1.   Interpretation of chapter.



   Sec. 10-2.   Definitions.



   Sec. 10-3.   Sales to certain persons.



   Sec. 10-4.   Access to dwelling quarters from licensed premises.



   Sec. 10-5.   Sanitary conditions.



   Sec. 10-6   Employees.



   Sec. 10-7.   Hours of sale.



   Sec. 10-8.   Local liquor control commissioner.



   Sec. 10-9.   Employment of persons under 21 years of age and of
minors.



   Sec. 10-10.   Credit sales.



   Sec. 10-11.   Refilling original packages.



   Sec. 10-12.   Minimum size container.



   Sec. 10-13.   Gifts.



   Sec. 10-14.   Removal from premises.



   Sec. 10-15.   Prohibited transactions.



   Sec. 10-16.   Intoxication.



   Sec. 10-17.   Peddling liquor.



   Sec. 10-18.   Complaint of violations.



   Sec. 10-19.   Responsibility of owner of premises.



   Sec. 10-20.   Acts of agent or employee.



   Sec. 10-21.   Responsibility of parents.



   Sec. 10-22.   Responsibility of the owner or occupant of premises
not licensed to dispense alcoholic beverages.



   Sec. 10-23.   Unobstructed view of premises.



   Sec. 10-24.   Liquor in vehicles.



   Sec. 10-25.   Possessing alcoholic liquor in public places.



   Secs. 10-26--10-50.   Reserved.
