   Sec. 10-51.   Required.



   Sec. 10-52.   Issuance restricted.



   Sec. 10-53.   Application.



   Sec. 10-54.   Classes.



   Sec. 10-55.   Contents; location.



   Sec. 10-56.   Fees.



   Sec. 10-57.   Disposition of fees.



   Sec. 10-58.   Number limitations.



   Sec. 10-59.   Duration.



   Sec. 10-60.   Nature; renewal.



   Sec. 10-61.   Change of location.



   Sec. 10-62.   Display.



   Sec. 10-63.   Revocation.



   Sec. 10-64.   Permit for Outdoor Sale of Alcoholic Beverages.



   Sec. 10-65.   Reduction in available licenses upon abandonment,
surrender, revocation, or expiration without renewal.



   Sec. 10-66.   Business entity as licensee - change in ownership or
control.



   Sec. 10-67.   Training required.



ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL



Sec. 10-1. Interpretation of chapter.



   This chapter shall be liberally construed to the end that the health,
safety and welfare of the residents of the village shall be protected, and
temperance in the consumption of alcoholic liquor shall be fostered and
promoted.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(a)1.)



Sec. 10-2. Definitions.



   Unless the context shall otherwise require, terms used in this chapter
shall have the definitions given in 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq., as amended from
time to time. Where not otherwise qualified, the term "license" or "licensee"
wherever used in this chapter means a license or licensee of the village
under this chapter.



   The term "licensed premises" as used in this Chapter shall mean only
the existing structural premises on the property owned or leased by the
licensee, and does not include outdoor cafes, beer gardens or outdoor sales
areas. Outdoor sales of alcoholic beverages are regulated in Section 10-64 of
this Chapter.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(a)2.)



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 10-3. Sales to certain persons.



   In connection with the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages to
any person under 21 years of age, any intoxicated person or any person known
to be under legal disability or in need of mental treatment, licensees shall
be subject to all regulations, prohibitions and penalties set forth in 235
ILCS 5/1-1 et seq., specifically including, but not limited to, the
restrictions, provisions and penalties of 235 ILCS 5/6-16 and 235 ILCS 5/6-20.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(l))



Sec. 10-4. Access to dwelling quarters from licensed premises.



   There shall be no access from licensed premises to dwelling quarters
except as permitted under 235 ILCS 5/6-13, as amended from time to time.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(o))



Sec. 10-5. Sanitary conditions.



   All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, or of
storage of such liquor for sale, shall be kept in full compliance with
ordinances regulating the condition of premises used for the storage or sale
of food for human consumption.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(p))



Sec. 10-6. Employees.



   No person shall employ in any premises used for the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor any person who is afflicted with or who is a carrier of any
contagious, infectious, or venereal diseases. No person who is affected with
or is a carrier of any such disease shall work in or about any premises or
engage in any way in the handling, preparation, or distribution of such
liquor.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(q))



Sec. 10-7. Hours of sale.



   No person licensed as a retailer of alcoholic liquor shall sell, permit
to be sold, or give away any alcoholic liquor between the hours of:



   (a)   1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday,
Thursday or Friday mornings;



   (b)   2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Saturday;



   (c)   2:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon on Sunday;



but subject to the following exceptions:



   (a)   Class 2 and Class 9 licensees may begin selling at 10:00 a.m.
on Sundays;



   (b)   Class 4A and 8 licensees serving meals prepared in the kitchen
of the establishment may serve alcoholic liquor at the table with such meal
between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon on Sundays; provided, however,
that any bar on the premises shall not open until 12:00 noon.



   (c)   Licensed premises may remain open for business until 2:00 a.m.
on New Year's Day.



   It shall be unlawful to have licensed premises open for business or to
admit the public to such premises during restricted hours.  This shall not
prohibit clubs from admitting members nor bowling alleys from admitting
patrons nor restaurants from admitting the public nor grocery stores licensed
to sell alcoholic liquor for off premises consumption only from admitting the
public, provided that this right to remain open for other activities shall
not grant any right to sell, permit to be sold, or to give away alcoholic
liquors during such restricted hours.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(r))  (MC-817, § 1, 6-23-09;  MC-931, § 1, 7-14-15)



Sec. 10-8. Local liquor control commissioner.



   (a)   Regulations administered. The president of the board of
trustees shall be the local liquor control commissioner and shall be charged
with the administration of the provisions of appropriate portions of this
chapter and state law, and may appoint other persons to assist him in the
exercise of these powers and responsibilities. The village board is
authorized to determine and pay compensation to the local liquor control
commissioner in consideration of the performance of his duties as local
liquor control commissioner. Such compensation shall be $1,200.00 per year,
payable quarterly.



   (b)   Powers. The local commissioner shall have the following
powers, functions and duties:



      (1)   To grant and revoke for cause all local licenses issued
to persons for premises within the village. Cause shall specifically include,
but shall not be limited to, a licensee's failure to operate the licensed
premises for a period of 30 consecutive days.



      (2)   To enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to
enter at any time upon the premises licensed under this chapter to determine
whether any of the provisions of this chapter or of the Liquor Control Act of
the state (235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.) or any of the rules or regulations adopted
by the state commission have been or are being violated, and at such times to
examine the premises of the licensee in connection there with.



      (3)   To receive complaints from any citizen of the village
that any provision of this chapter or the Liquor Control Act (235 ILCS 5/1-1
et seq.) has been or is being violated and to act upon such complaint in the
manner provided by law.



      (4)   To receive or cause to be received all local license
fees and pay same forthwith to the village treasurer.



      (5)   To examine or cause to be examined under oath any
applicant for a village license or for renewal of a license or any licensee
upon whom notice of revocation has been served, all as provided in 235 ILCS
5/4-5, as amended from time to time.



      (6)   All other powers, functions and duties given to the
local commissioner by the Illinois Revised Statutes.



      (7)   To file an administrative review action to challenge a
decision of the state liquor control commission reducing or vacating any
license revocation, suspension or fine imposed on a liquor licensee by the
local liquor commissioner.



   (c)   List of licensees. The local commissioner shall keep or cause
to be kept a complete record and file of particulars of all licenses issued
by him



(Code 1965, § 41.19(bb))  (MC-918, § 1, 2-24-15)



   State law reference(s)--Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/4-2.



Sec. 10-9. Employment of persons under 21 years of age and of minors.



   (a)   No person under 21 years of age shall draw, pour or mix any
alcoholic liquor as an employee of a licensee.



   (b)   No person under 21 years of age shall tend bar as an employee
of any licensee, except that persons 18 years of age or older may wait on
tables.



   (c)   No person under 21 years of age shall sell alcoholic package
liquor as an employee of any licensee. For purposes of this section, sale or
sell shall include, but not be limited to, the operation of the cash
register, scanning device or any other equipment used to record the purchase
of alcoholic liquor; and the receipt of money, checks, credit cards or any
other form of payment for the purchase of alcoholic liquor. The requirement
for sales personnel to be 21 years of age or older may not be avoided by
asking or permitting patrons to perform any part of the sale transaction.



   (d)   No person under 21 years of age shall possess alcoholic liquor
as an employee of a licensee other than as authorized by law.



   (e)   No licensee shall permit any of the acts prohibited in this
section.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(s)) (MC-553, § 1, 12-12-95)



Sec. 10-10. Credit sales.



   No person shall sell or furnish alcoholic liquor at retail under terms
contrary to 235 ILCS 5/6-19, as amended from time to time.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(t))



Sec. 10-11. Refilling original packages.



   No person except a manufacturer, distributor, or importing distributor
shall fill or refill, in whole or in part, any original package for alcoholic
liquor with the same or any other kind of quality of alcoholic liquor with
dilutent. It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession for
sale or retail any bottles, casks, or other container containing alcoholic
liquor except in the original package.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(u))



   State law reference(s)--Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/6-22.



Sec. 10-12. Minimum size container.



   No unmixed whiskey, unmixed rum, or unmixed gin shall be sold or
offered for sale at retail for consumption on the premises except in a
container having a minimum capacity of at least one fluid ounce and which
contains at the time of sale at least one fluid ounce of the beverage being
sold. No person licensed to sell alcoholic liquor at retail for consumption
on the premises shall use in such sales or possess in the premises any glass
or other container so constructed as to be deceptive in appearance or to
mislead the consumer as to its true capacity.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(v))



Sec. 10-13. Gifts.



   The local liquor control commissioner, his agent, members of a
committee appointed by him to assist in local control, members of the board
of trustees and police officers are prohibited from soliciting or accepting
any gift, gratuity, emolument, or employment from any licensee. Every
licensee or employee, agent or officer of such licensee is prohibited from
offering or making any such gift, gratuity, or emolument to any person
prohibited from accepting any such gift, gratuity, or emolument.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(w))



Sec. 10-14. Removal from premises.



   No person shall remove any alcoholic liquor in any container of any
kind from a premises licensed solely to sell alcoholic liquor for consumption
on the premises.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(x))



Sec. 10-15. Prohibited transactions.



   Any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of any alcoholic liquor
is prohibited because of age, or for any other reason, shall not purchase, or
accept a gift of such alcoholic liquor or have such alcoholic liquor in his
possession. All such persons shall be subject to all restrictions,
prohibitions and penalties of 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq., specifically including,
but not limited to, the restrictions, prohibitions and penalties of 235 ILCS
5/6-20.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(y))



Sec. 10-16. Intoxication.



   No person shall be in an intoxicated condition on any street, alley or
public place of the village or in any private house or place to the
disturbance of another.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(z))



Sec. 10-17. Peddling liquor.



   No person shall peddle alcoholic liquor in the village.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(aa))



Sec. 10-18. Complaint of violations.



   (a)   Any five residents of the village shall have the right to file
a complaint with the local commissioner stating that any retail licensee has
been or is violating any provisions of this section or of the Illinois Liquor
Control Act (235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.). Such complaint shall be in writing and
shall be signed and sworn to by the parties complaining. The complaint shall
state the particular provisions believed to have been violated and the facts
in detail upon which the belief is based.



   (b)   If the local commissioner is satisfied that the complaint
substantially charges a violation and that from the facts alleged there is
reasonable cause for such belief, he shall set the matter for hearing and
shall serve notice upon the licensee of the time and place of such hearing
and of the particulars charged in the complaint.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(dd))



Sec. 10-19. Responsibility of owner of premises.



   If the owner of the licensed premises or any person from whom the
licensee derives the right to possession of such premises, or the agent of
such owner or person, shall knowingly permit the licensee to use the premises
in violation of the terms of this chapter or of the applicable provisions of
the Illinois Liquor Control Act (235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.), the owner, agent or
other person shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter to the
same extent as such licensee and shall be subject to the same penalties.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(ff))



Sec. 10-20. Acts of agent or employee.



   Every act or omission constituting a violation of any provision of this
chapter or of the Illinois Liquor Control Act (235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.) by any
officer, director, manager, agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed
and held to be the act of such employer or licensee. The employer or licensee
shall be punishable in the same manner as if the act or omission had been
done or omitted by him personally.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(gg))



Sec. 10-21. Responsibility of parents.



   It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian to knowingly suffer or
permit any minor child of which he may be the parent or guardian to violate
any provision of this chapter.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(hh))



Sec. 10-22. Responsibility of the owner or occupant of premises not licensed
to dispense alcoholic beverages.



   It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of any premises,
residential or otherwise, located within the village, to knowingly allow any
person under the age of 21 years to remain on such premises while in the
possession of alcoholic liquor or while consuming alcoholic liquor in
violation of section 10-15. It shall also be unlawful for any such owner or
occupant on any such premises to knowingly sell or give alcoholic liquor to
any person under the age of 21 years or to knowingly allow alcoholic liquor
to be given to any person under the age of 21 years while on such premises,
in violation of section 10-15.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(ii))



Sec. 10-23. Unobstructed view of premises.



   The provisions of former Illinois Revised Statutes, chapter 43, section
141, shall apply to premises upon which the sale of alcoholic liquor for
consumption on the premises is licensed.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(n))



Sec. 10-24. Liquor in Vehicles.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to transport, carry, possess or
have any alcoholic liquor, as defined in 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq., as amended
from time to time, in or upon or about any motor vehicle within the Village
limits, except in the original package with the seal unbroken. 



Sec. 10-25. Possessing Alcoholic Liquor in Public Place.



   It shall be unlawful far any person to be in possession of any
alcoholic liquor,  as defined  in 235 ILCS  5/1-1  et seq., as 
amended  from time to time, on a public street or other place unless the
alcoholic liquor is in the original package and the seal unbroken, unless
such possession is on the premises of an establishment having a valid Village
liquor license.  For the purpose of this Section, a public street and/or
public place shall include, but not be limited to, all village streets,
alleys, public locations such as train stations, train walkway tunnels, train
platforms and train or bus drop off-pickup locations.  Public places also
include, but are not limited to, public sidewalks within the Village, Village
owned parking facilities and lots, common area and parking lots serving
commercial establishments, parking areas and common areas serving
multi-family residential structures, public parks, play grounds, recreation
areas and school and church parking lots and properties within Village
limits.  The prohibitions of this Section, other than age limitations for
the possession of alcohol, may be waived by the Homewood Village Board for
Homewood Days and similar special events and by the Village Manager's Office
for block party requests or specific business special events. 



Secs. 10-26--10-50. Reserved.



ARTICLE II. LICENSES*



Sec. 10-51. Required.



   (a)   No  person  shall  sell or  offer  for  sale  or
possess with intention to sell at retail in the village  any alcoholic
liquor  without a retailer's license from the village in addition to a state
license. No person shall sell or offer for sale at retail in the village any
alcoholic liquor in violation of the terms and conditions of the license or
in violation of any provision of this article or any provision of the
Illinois Liquor Control Act (235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.). The disbursement of
alcoholic liquor without a license at any gathering, party or other public or
private affair when admission is charged for entrance, whether or not an
additional charge is made for disbursement of alcoholic liquor, shall
constitute a violation of this article.



   (b)   Any business operating as a public accommodation that desires
to permit the consumption of alcoholic liquor on the business premises and
that is not licensed under the Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS 5-1-1 et
seq.) must first obtain a license from the Village prior to permitting the
consumption of alcoholic liquor on its premises. For purposes of this
Section, "public accommodation" means a refreshment, entertainment, or
recreation facility of any kind, whether licensed or not, whose goods,
services, facilities, privileges, or advantages are extended, offered, sold,
or otherwise made available to the public.



   (c)   The requirements that a village license be procured shall not
apply to physicians, dentists, pharmacists, hospitals, or churches when these
persons or institutions possess or dispense alcoholic liquor in accordance
with the provisions of 235 ILCS 5/2-1, as amended from time to time.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(b))



Sec. 10-52. Issuance restricted.



   No village retailer's license of any kind shall be issued to:



   (1)   A person, partnership or corporation declared ineligible for
license under 235 ILCS 5/6-2, as amended from time to time, or to a person,
partnership, or corporation not eligible for a state retail liquor dealer's
license.



   (2)   For use on premises adjacent to churches, schools, hospitals,
or other institutions or place of business if issuance of such license would
be contrary to 235 ILCS 5/6-11, 5/6-12 or 5/6-15, as amended from time to
time, provided that the distance restriction imposed by 235 ILCS 5/6-11(a)
shall not apply to hotels offering restaurant service, regularly organized
clubs, or to restaurants, food shops or other places where sale of alcoholic
liquors is not the principal business carried on.



   (3)   For premises to be licensed under a restaurant, hotel club or
bowling alley classification unless such premises shall fully qualify under
the definitions of such places as given in 235 ILCS 5/1-3.23  5/1-3.26, as
amended from time to time.



   (4)   For premises located in a residential zone except that this
prohibition shall not prohibit the renewal of a license issued prior to April
20, 1954, for premises so located.



   (5)   Any applicant for a liquor license or renewal of a liquor
license without verification that the licensee will have Illinois Dram Shop
insurance as specified in the Illinois Dram Shop Act (235 ILCS 5/6-21 et
seq.) during the term of the license.



   (6)   Any applicant for a liquor license or renewal of a liquor
license if the applicant has outstanding fees, fines, taxes, or debts due to
the village, including but not limited to water and sewer charges, places for
eating tax, hotel accommodations tax, or fines imposed after administrative
adjudication of a local ordinance violation. If the proposed licensee is a
corporation, limited liability company or similar entity, the term
“applicant” as used in this subsection shall include any stockholder,
member, or partner owning at least a five percent interest in the licensed
entity.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(c); MC-708 § 1(a) 10-28-2003; MC-908 § 1, 5-13-2014;
MC-946, § 1, 2-23-16)



   *Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 10-53. Application.



   (a)   An applicant for a license or for renewal of a license from
the village shall submit an application to the local liquor commissioner. All
new applications for a license shall include a nonrefundable $300.00
processing fee. The application shall be in writing, under oath, and shall be
signed by the applicant if an individual; or if the application is on the
behalf of a partnership, firm, association, club or corporation, then it
shall be signed and sworn to by at least two members of such partnership; or
by the president and secretary of such firm, club, association or corporation.



   (b)   The application shall state:



      (1)   The name, age and address of the applicant in the case
of an individual or of all persons entitled to share in the profits in the
case of a copartnership; in the case of a club or corporation, the name, date
of incorporation, the address, and objects for which it was organized; the
names and addresses of all stockholders owning five percent or more of the
stock; the names and addresses of all officers of a club; and the number of
members. A partnership applicant must furnish a copy of its existing
partnership agreement with the application. A corporate applicant must
furnish a certified copy of its article of incorporation with its application.



      (2)   The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth,
and, if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization.



      (3)   The character of the business or operation with which
the desired license is to be used and the class of license for which
application is made.



      (4)   The length of time that the applicant has been in that
business or operation and the date at which that business or operation was
started in the village and, in the case of a corporation, the date on which
its Charter was issued.



      (5)   The location and description of the premises or place of
business which is to be operated under the desired license, including a
statement of total number of service accommodations in cases where alcoholic
liquor is to be retailed for consumption on the premises except that hotels
are also required to state the number of rooms available for lodging of
guests. The



following criteria shall be employed in determining the total number of
service accommodations:



         a.   For those facilities where the general public can
legally be served upon an individual basis, and excluding only those
facilities that are always reserved for the use of organizational groups.



         b.   Each chair space at a table shall be counted as one
service accommodation.



         c.   Each 24 inches of space measured at the front edge
of a bench either at a table or not at a table shall be counted as one
service accommodation.



         d.   Each 24 inches of space measured at the outer edge
of a counter or bar shall be counted as one service accommodation.



      For those facilities always reserved for the use of
organizational groups, each 25 square feet of floor space shall be counted as
one service accommodation.



      (6)   Whether the applicant has ever made an application for a
license to retail alcoholic liquor on premises other than described in this
application, and the disposition of such application. If the number of such
applications exceeds five, only those five geographically nearest the village
need be listed.



      (7)   The applicant has never been convicted of a felony and
is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing
contained in this Code or laws of this state.



      (8)   Whether a previous license by any state or subdivision,
or by the federal government has been revoked or suspended and the reasons
therefor.



      (9)   The applicant is familiar with the laws of the United
States and of the state and of this village as they relate to retailers of
alcoholic liquors that the applicant has never violated these laws and will
not violate nor permit his employees or agents to violate any of the laws of
the United States or of the state or the ordinances of this village in the
conduct of the business for which a license is desired.



      (10)   All license holders shall require that an employee, or
member in the case of a club, be designated as the manager of the premises
where and whenever alcoholic liquor is being sold. A manager shall be
responsible for the proper conduct of the premises and adherence to this
article. Individuals specified as manager shall be named on the license
application and one of such persons shall be present at all times the
licensed premises are open for business.



      (11)   Each new application and each renewal application for a
liquor license shall include proof of current Dram Shop insurance in effect.
The licensee shall notify the Village in writing of any change in the
licensee's Dram Shop coverage during the term of the license. Failure to
maintain Dram Shop insurance shall be grounds for termination of the liquor
license.



      (12)   Each new application and each renewal application for a
liquor license shall include proof that all liquor managers named on the
license application are currently certified as having completed the Beverage
Alcohol Sellers and Servers Education and Training (BASSET) program as
required by section 10-67 of this chapter.



   In addition to the information contained in this section, the
application shall contain such other and further information as the local
liquor commissioner may prescribe by rule or regulation not inconsistent with
law.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(d)) (MC-708 § 1(b) 10-28-2003; MC-839, § 1A., 11-23-10)



Sec. 10-54. Classes.



   Licenses permitting the sale at retail of alcoholic liquor shall be of
the following classes:



      (1)   Class 1 - general. A class 1 - general license permits
the retail sale of any alcoholic liquor in the original package for
off-premises consumption and also the sale of any alcoholic liquor for
on-premises consumption, either at a counter or bar or at tables, with or
without meals.



      (2)   Class 2 - package. A class 2 - package license permits
the retail sale of any alcoholic liquor in the original package only for
off-premises consumption.



(Ord. No. 580, §1, 7-8-97)



      (3)   Class 3 - club. A class 3 - club license permits the
retail sale of any alcoholic liquor for on-premises consumption only by
members and their bona fide guests.



      (4)   Class 4 - restaurant with bar. A class 4 - restaurant
with bar license is available only to establishments which primarily serve
meals prepared in the kitchen of the establishment, having a seating capacity
for the service of meals at tables or counters for not less than 50 patrons
and permitting the retail sale of any alcoholic liquor for on-premises
consumption only, and having a bar.  A counter is hereby defined and held to
mean a facility with a top surface at normal table surface distance above the
general floor level, at which facility a patron is seated and served with a
meal. Seating capacity at the establishment's bar shall not be taken into
account in determining whether space for 50 patrons is available.



      (4A)   Class 4A - 75/25 restaurant with bar. A class 4A -
75/25 restaurant with bar license is available only to establishments which
primarily serve meals prepared in the kitchen of the establishment, having a
seating capacity for the service of meals at tables or counters for not less
than 50 patrons and permitting the retail sale of any alcoholic liquor for
on-premises consumption only, and having a bar. A counter is hereby defined
and held to mean a facility with a top surface at normal table surface
distance above the general floor level, at which facility a patron is seated
and served with a meal. Seating capacity at the establishment’s bar shall
not be taken into account in determining whether space for 50 patrons is
available.



      No more than 25% of the licensee’s gross receipts over any
12-month period shall be from the sale of alcohol. Licensees shall be
obligated, upon request, to produce sales records or other evidence
substantiating that they are in compliance with the terms of their license
concerning percentage of alcoholic beverage sales.



      (4B)   Class 4B - 75/25 restaurant with bar no video gaming. A
“class 4B - 75/25 restaurant with bar no video gaming” license is
available only to establishments which primarily serve meals prepared in the
kitchen of the establishment, having a seating capacity for the service of
meals at tables or counters for not less than 50 patrons and permitting the
retail sale of any alcoholic liquor for on-premises consumption only, and
having a bar. A counter is hereby defined and held to mean a facility with a
top surface at normal table surface distance above the general floor level,
at which facility a patron is seated and served with a meal. Seating capacity
at the establishment’s bar shall not be taken into account in determining
whether space for 50 patrons is available.



         No more than twenty- five percent (25%) of the licensee’s
gross receipts over any 12-month period shall be from the sale of alcohol.
Licensees shall be obligated, upon request, to produce sales records or other
evidence substantiating that they are in compliance with the terms of their
license concerning percentage of alcoholic beverage sales.



         No video gaming devices or coin operated amusement devices
will be allowed on the premises.



      (5)   Class 5 - restaurant without bar. A class 5 - restaurant
without bar license is available only to establishments which primarily serve
meals prepared in the kitchen of the establishment, having a seating capacity
for the service of meals at tables or counters, permitting the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor for on-premises consumption only, and having no bar.



      (5A)   Class 5A - restaurant without bar, no video gaming. A
class 5A license is available only to establishments primarily serving meals
prepared in the kitchen of the establishment, having a seating capacity for
the service of meals at tables or counters, permitting the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor for on-premises consumption only, having no bar and no video
gaming or coin-operated amusements on the premises.



      (6)   Class 6 - special license. A class 6 - special license
is a special permit for the sale of beer and wine only and may be granted
from time to time to clubs, associations and lodges organized for objects and
purposes other than the consumption of alcoholic liquor and organized for at
least two years prior to the date of application for license. Special
licenses may also permit the sale of mixed drinks upon the approval of the
village liquor commissioner.



      (7)   Class 7 - beer and wine only. A class 7 - beer and wine
only license permits the sale of beer and wine on-premise only with food
service.



      (7A)   Class 7A - 7/25 beer and wine only; on- and off-premise
consumption; video gaming prohibited. This license classification is
available only to establishments primarily engaged in serving food prepared
on-site in a fully equipped kitchen with food service seating at tables or
counters for at least 50 patrons. Retail sale of beer and wine for on- and
off-premise consumption is allowed. No more than twenty-five percent (25%) of
the licensee’s gross receipts over any 12-month period shall be from the
sale of alcohol. Licensee shall be obligated to maintain and produce, upon
request, sales records sufficient to substantiate compliance with the
limitation on alcohol sales imposed by this license classification. Video
gaming or coin operated amusement devices are not permitted.



      (8)   Class 8 - hotels and motels. A class 8 - hotels and
motels license permits the retail sale of any alcoholic liquor in the
original package for off-premises consumption. It also permits the sale of
any alcoholic liquor for on-premises consumption, either indoors or outdoors,
with or without meals, to patrons and guests of the establishment. No video
gaming is allowed. If the hotel or motel conducts business under two or more
entities with common ownership, the licensee shall only be required to
procure one license.



         Outdoor sale and consumption shall be subject to the
following limitations:



         (i)   Serving and consumption of alcoholic liquor shall
be confined to that portion of the premises (including any adjacent area
leased or licensed to the liquor licensee) as approved by the local liquor
commissioner (the “Outdoor Area”);



         (ii)   The main and principal operation of the Outdoor
Area shall be for dining purposes and food service must be available in the
outdoor dining area at all times;



         (iii)   No music of any kind may be played or broadcast
from the premises, including the Outdoor Area, before 10:00 a.m. or after
10:00 p.m.;



         (iv)   No alcoholic liquor may be removed from the
Outdoor Area unless taken inside the hotel or motel building;



         (v)   Only alcoholic liquor purchased from the licensee
may be consumed in the Outdoor Area;



         (vi)   Serving and consumption of alcoholic liquor in
the Outdoor Area shall terminate at 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday
evenings and at midnight on Friday and Saturday evenings;



         (vii)   The Outdoor Area shall be physically separated
from the remainder of the premises and from adjoining property and the public
way by a fence, barrier, or other physical demarcation as approved by the
local liquor commissioner.



         (viii)   The local liquor commissioner may waive one or
more of the above requirements, may impose additional requirements, or may
suspend or prohibit outdoor alcoholic liquor sales, as he or she deems
necessary for the public good and convenience of the village and its
residents.



         (ix)   Other than as stated above, the provisions of
Section 10-64 of this Code shall not apply.



      (9)   Class 9 - package. A class 9 - package license permits
the retail sale of beer and wine only in the original package and only for
off-premises consumption.



      (10)   Class 10 - beer and wine only. A class 10 - beer and
wine only license permits the sale of beer and wine for off premises
consumption only, but display of beer and wine within the licensed premises
must be limited to no more than twenty percent (20%) of total food and liquor
display area.



      (11)   Class 11 - market license. A class 11-market license is
a special permit for the sale of certain beers and wines during the operation
of  a seasonal market for consumption off the premises where sold and
consumption on premises as provided below for sampling. Only those beers and
wines meeting the criteria listed in Class 14 may be sampled or sold pursuant
to this license.



         The term “seasonal market” shall be defined as a
lawfully established community event and public market at which vendors sell
or offer for retail sale produce and other goods directly to the consumers.



         This license shall authorize the licensee to conduct
product tasting at a freestanding booth utilized by the licensee.  All
samples shall be consumed in the area immediately adjacent to the
freestanding booth. Samples shall be limited to an individual serving of two
ounces of wine or beer. Said product tasting shall be limited to three such
servings by any individual person on any given day of the seasonal market.
The Chief of Police is hereby delegated the right to create additional rules
and regulations to ensure that said limitation can be verified and enforced
at any such seasonal market. The licensee must provide adequate dramshop
liability insurance as required by the Illinois liquor control act, as it is
now or may hereafter be amended.



         If selling or offering to sell alcohol on village owned
property, the licensee shall indemnify and hold harmless the village from all
financial loss, damage and harm arising from the retail sale of alcohol and
product tasting during the operation of the seasonal market. The village
staff shall promulgate forms for said indemnification required hereunder.



   The license issued shall be limited to the premises specified in the
license. The boundaries of the licensed premises  and the duration of the
license shall be established by the local liquor commissioner. A single
license can cover multiple regularly recurring days throughout a season
(example: each Saturday from 9:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. from May through
October). The licensee shall maintain the premises in a neat, orderly and
safe condition, shall provide such traffic control and sanitation facilities
to protect the public health, safety, welfare and morals of the residents of
the village, and shall restore premises after expiration of the license to
its prior condition, including the removal of trash, rubbish and garbage. No
alcoholic liquor shall be brought onto the premises or consumed on the
premises other than that provided by the licensee under the terms and
conditions of this chapter.



   Payment shall be made to the village for the actual costs incurred by
the village in providing additional police personnel necessitated by improper
conduct or control by the licensee on the specific premises. Each licensee
who is to be held responsible for additional charges shall receive an
itemized invoice therefore, shall be given an opportunity to review the
charges with the liquor control commissioner, and shall thereafter promptly
pay any such additional charge determined by the commissioner to be due the
village.



      (12)   Class 12 - public accommodation.  A Class 12 - public
accommodation license permits the consumption of alcoholic liquor on the
business premises of a refreshment, entertainment or recreation facility not
licensed under the Liquor Control Act of 1934.



      (12A)   Class 12A- special public accommodation. A Class 12A
special public accommodation license permits the consumption of alcoholic
liquor during a public function conducted on the premises of a public library
or other unit of local government.



      (13)   Class 13 - public golf course.  A class 13 - public
golf course license permits the sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on
the premises of a public golf course. For purposes of this license class,
“premises” shall mean the entire golf course except the areas where motor
vehicles are regularly parked or operated, and “facility” shall mean the
clubhouse dining areas, including its banquet rooms, decks, patios, grill
room, bar, and any temporary tents erected where food is served.  A class 13
- public golf course license shall authorize the sale of alcoholic liquor
from the facility, from one or more motorized food and beverage carts, and
from a “halfway house” all for consumption on the premises. No licensee
shall permit any patron to possess alcoholic liquor on the premises which was
not acquired from the licensee.



   (14)   Class 14 - limited beer, wine and craft scotch, bourbon and
whiskey. A class 14 license permits the retail sale for on- premises
consumption of craft beer; select and fine wine; and craft scotch, bourbon,
and whiskey. Alcoholic drinks consisting of liquor combined with fruit juice
or other ingredients are prohibited. Food for on-premises consumption may be
provided. No more than two televisions and no video gaming devices, pool
tables or coin operated amusement devices are allowed on the premises.



         This license also authorizes the sale for off-premises
consumption of craft beer; select or fine wines; and craft scotch, bourbon,
and whiskey in original packaging, subject to the following restrictions:



         1.   No beer may be sold in original packaging greater
than 72 ounces in total volume per package;



         2.   No wine may be sold in original packaging greater
than 1.5 liters in volume;



         3.   No single craft scotch, bourbon, and whiskey may be
sold in original packaging less than 750 milliliters in volume.



         This license also permits the filling and sale of sealed 32
- 64 ounce containers (commonly referred to as “growlers”) of craft beer
for off-premises consumption.



         For purposes of this license class, the following
definitions shall apply:



         1.   Craft beer: beer manufactured by the holder of art
Illinois Class 1 or Class 2 Brewer’s License or a similar license issued by
another state or country,



         2.   Select or fine wine: wine produced by the holder of
an Illinois First Class Wine Manufacturer or Wine Maker license or a similar
license issued by another state or country.



         3.   Craft scotch, bourbon, and whiskey: Bourbon, scotch
or whiskey produced by the holder of an Illinois Craft Distiller license or a
similar license issued by another state or country.



         In addition to the products described above, items
available for retail sale shall be limited to beer or wine-making supplies
and accessories; items related to consumption of the products available for
retail sale such as glassware; and items that specifically promote the
licensee’s business.



   (14A)   Class 14A - craft spirits, limited beer and wine. A Class
14A license authorizes:



         (a)   retail sale of any spirits, craft or microbrew
beer, select or fine wine, for on-premises consumption only;



         (b)   retail sale of Craft Spirits, in the original
package, for off-premises consumption only;



         subject to the following restrictions:



         1.   Cocktails shall be made on premises, by hand;



         2.   No Craft Spirits may be sold in original packaging
less than 375 milliliters in volume;



         3.   Food for on-premises consumption may be provided.
No video gaming devices or coin operated amusement devices will be allowed on
the premises.



      “Craft Spirits” means spirits manufactured by an
Illinois-licensed Class 9 craft distiller.



      The terms “craft or microbrew beer, select or fine wine”
means beer or wine produced by brew pubs, Class 1 or Class 2 brewers
licensees, 1st Class wine manufacturers or 1st Class wine makers as defined
by Illinois law, or similar entities licensed outside of Illinois.



   (15)   Class 15 - beer only, no video gaming. This license
authorizes the sale of beer for on-premises consumption when ordered with
food. Video gaming or coin operated amusement devices on the licensed
premises are prohibited.



   (16)   Class 16 -brew pub. A Class 16 license permits the licensee
to engage only in those sales and ancillary activities permitted by a “brew
pub” license issued by the State of Illinois. The applicant must own or
lease the premises to be licensed. No video gaming or coin operated amusement
devices are allowed on the premises.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(e)) (MC-684, MC-738, MC-746; MC-815, § 1, 3-24-09;
MC-844, § 1, 5-10-11; MC-845, § 1, 5-10-11; MC-847, § 1, 5-24-11; MC-873,
§ 1, 7-10-12; MC-883, § 1, 11-27-12; MC-889, § 1, 5-28- 13; MC-898, § 1,
11-12-13; MC-916, § 1, 1-27-15; MC-920, § 1, 3-10-15; MC-922, § 1,
4-14-15; MC-939, § 1, 11-10-15; MC-956, § 1, 5-10-16; MC-958, § 1,
5-24-16; MC-965, § 1, 8-23-16; MC-967, § 1, 9-27-16; MC-969, § 1, 9-27-16;
MC-971, § 1-10-17)



Sec. 10-55. Contents; location.



   Licenses shall clearly indicate the class of license and the terms of
issuance, the name of the licensee, and the location of the premises.
Licenses issued under this article shall apply only to the premises described
in the application and in the license issued thereon, and only one location
shall be so described in each license.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(f))



Sec. 10-56. Fees.



   (a)   The following fee schedule for various license classes shall
prevail, and the graduation of fees among classes is intended as a reasonable
distinction as to the benefit derived by the licensee by virtue of the
revenue  obtained by use of a particular license class. Liquor license fees
are in addition to any other license or permit fees applicable to the liquor
licensee’s business.



   Class 1: $1,900.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 2: $1,600.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 3: $800.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 4: $1,500.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 4A: $1,500.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 4B: $1,500.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 5: $1,500.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 5A: $1,500.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 6: $25.00 for each license issued due and payable at the time of
issuance.



   Class 7: $1,000.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 7A: $1,000.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 8: $2,000.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 9: $1,000.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 10: $750.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 11: $25.00 for each license issued due and payable at time of
issuance.



   Class 12: $300.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 12A: $25.00 for each license issued due and payable at the time
of issuance.



   Class 13: $2,200 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 14: $1,000.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 14A: $1,000.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 15: $1,000.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.



   Class 16: $ 1,000.00 due and payable on May 1 of each year.

Sec. 10-57. Disposition of fees.



   One hundred percent of each license fee shall be credited to the
general fund of the village.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(cc))



Sec. 10-58. Number limitations.



   The number of licenses shall be limited as follows:



   (1)   Class 1 licenses shall be limited to three.



   (2)   Class 2 licenses shall be limited to ten.



   (3)   Class 3 licenses shall be limited to one.



   (4)   Class 4 licenses shall be limited to five.



   (4A)   Class 4A licenses shall be limited to three.



   (4B)   Class 4B licenses shall be limited to one.



   (5)   Class 5 licenses shall be limited to one.



   (5A)   Class 5A licenses shall be limited to one.



   (6)   There shall be no limit upon the number of class 6 licenses.



   (7)   Class 7 licenses shall be limited to one.



   (7A)   Class 7A licenses shall be limited to one.



   (8)   Class 8 licenses shall be limited to one.



   (9)   Class 9 licenses shall be limited to one.



   (10)   Class 10 licenses shall be limited to zero.



   (11)   There shall be no limit on the number of Class 11 licenses.



   (12)   Class 12 licenses shall be limited to one.



   (12A)   There shall be no limit upon the number of class 12A
licenses.



   (13)   Class 13 licenses shall be limited to one.



   (14)   Class 14 licenses shall be limited to one.



   (14A)   Class 14A licenses shall be limited to one.



   (15)   Class 15 licenses shall be limited to one.



   (16)   Class 16 licenses shall be limited to one.

Sec. 10-59. Duration.



   Every license shall terminate on April 30 next following its issuance
unless sooner revoked or suspended. The fee for a new license shall be the
annual fee reduced in proportion to the number of full months that have
expired since the last prior May 1. The fee for renewal shall be the full
annual fee. There shall be no rebate for the unexpired term of a license. An
application for renewal shall not be considered as such unless made prior to
April 30, and unless submitted with the appropriate fee. No license shall be
valid unless the proper fee has been paid.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(i))



Sec. 10-60. Nature; renewal.



   A license shall be purely a personal privilege and shall be subject to
all the limitations and privileges set forth in 235 ILCS 5/6-1, as amended
from time to time.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(j))



Sec. 10-61. Change of location.



   After a license has been granted for a particular premises, the local
liquor control commissioner, upon application by the licensee, may endorse
upon the license permission to abandon the premises thereon described and to
remove the license to other premises approved by him and described in the
endorsement. The application for transfer shall be in writing under oath and
shall fully describe the new premises. The reasons for transfer shall be
given, and it shall be shown that the new premises complies in all respects
with the requirements of this article and 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq., as amended
from time to time.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(k))



Sec. 10-62. Display.



   Every licensee shall cause his license to be framed and hung in plain
view in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(m))



Sec. 10-63. Revocation.



   The local commissioner may revoke any local license issued by the
village if he determines that the licensee has violated any provision of this
article or of the Liquor Control Act (235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.) or is more than
60 days delinquent in the payment of any outstanding debt to the village
other than water and sewer charges, including but not limited to places for
eating tax, hotel accommodations tax, amusement tax, or fines imposed after
administrative adjudication of a local ordinance violation. There shall be no
refund of license fee. These penalties shall be in addition to any other
penalties that may be assessed for conviction of violation. When any license
shall have been revoked for cause, no license shall be granted to any person
for the period of one year thereafter for the sale of alcoholic liquor on the
premises described in the revoked license.



(Code 1965, § 41.19(ee))  (MC-975, § 1, 4-15-17)



Sec. 10-64. Permit For Outdoor Sale of Alcoholic Beverages.



   a.   On application and payment of an investigation and processing
fee the holder of a Class 1, 3, 4, 4A, 5, or 7 License may be issued an
outdoor sales permit, by the Village Board.



   b.   An outdoor sales permit shall, upon issuance, entitle the
holder to sell alcoholic liquor as authorized by his/its primary
classification, outside of the permanent structure of the premises but within
the property boundaries thereof, under the following conditions:



      (i)   Access into the outdoor sales area shall be from the
permanent structure only and no access shall be permitted from a public
street, alley or sidewalk or adjoining property. Emergency exits as required
by Village Ordinances must be provided.



      (ii)   No radio, TV broadcast or music of any kind may be
played or broadcast from the outdoor area after 10:00 p.m.



      (iii)   No sales or dispensing of alcoholic liquor may be made
from the outdoor sales area or permanent structure to any person upon
adjoining property, a public street, sidewalk or alley, and no alcoholic
liquor served in an open container may be removed from the outdoor sales area
or permanent structure.



      (iv)   The outdoor sales permit shall be  prominently
displayed in the outdoor sales area and shall be subject to suspension or
revocation by the Local Liquor Commissioner in accordance with law. 



      (v)   Unless otherwise approved, the outdoor sales area shall
be surrounded by a fence 4' in height, designed and positioned so as to
separate the permittee's patrons from the general public.  The village board
may approve a lower fence or require a higher or more structurally sound
fence when initially granting or renewing an outdoor sales permit, based upon
the uses surrounding the outdoor sales area and when renewing a permit, upon
the history of sales and complaints at that outdoor location.



      (vi)   Serving and consumption of alcoholic liquor in the
outdoor sales portion of the premises shall terminate at 11:00 p.m. Sunday
through Thursday evenings and at Midnight on Friday and Saturday evenings. 
The village board may approve a later time or require an earlier time when
granting or renewing an outdoor sales permit, based upon the surrounding uses
and history of sales and complaints at that outdoor location.



      (vii)   The annual  fee for an outdoor  sales permit  shall
be $50.00. 



      (viii)   At the time of issuance or renewal of an outdoor
sales permit, the village board may waive one or more of the above
requirements and may also impose additional reasonable requirements as it
deems necessary for the public good and convenience of the residents of the
village.



      (ix)   Occupancy in the outdoor sales area shall not exceed
the maximum number of persons as determined by the Homewood Fire Department
in accordance with the Homewood Municipal Code.



      (x)   The foregoing requirements shall be  applicable to all
outdoor sales of alcohol within the village upon the passage of this Section
in Ordinance form.  Existing Class 1/3/4/5 and 7 liquor license holders
presently engaging in outdoor sales of alcohol shall be given written notice
of section 10-2, as amended, and section 10-64, shall have 60 days from the
effective date of passage of this section in Ordinance form to apply for an
outdoor sales permit.



(MC-846, § 1, 5-24-11; MC-922, § 1, 4-14-15)



Sec. 10-65. Reduction in available licenses upon abandonment, surrender,
revocation, or expiration without renewal.



   Upon the abandonment, surrender, revocation, or expiration without
renewal of any liquor license issued pursuant to this chapter, the total
number of liquor licenses permitted for the class under which the abandoned,
surrendered, revoked, or expired license was issued shall, upon the date of
such abandonment, surrender, revocation, or expiration, automatically reduce
by the number of licenses abandoned, surrendered, revoked, or permitted to
expire without renewal on that date, notwithstanding the number of such
licenses identified in Section 10-58. The local liquor commissioner or the
commissioner’s designee shall maintain a current tally of the number and
category of licenses currently authorized.



(MC-968, § 1, 9-27-16)



Sec. 10-66. Business entity as licensee - change in ownership or control.



   (a)   The following provisions shall apply to non-publicly traded
corporations, limited liability companies, limited partnerships or similar
entities issued liquor licenses within the Village. For purposes of this
section, “publicly traded” shall refer to corporations that have issued
securities that are traded on an open market.



   (b)   The sale, transfer, assignment, or gift of more than a five
percent (5%) interest in any business entity to a person or entity not listed
in the existing license application shall constitute a change in ownership
and require surrender of the current liquor license and submission of a new
application pursuant to Section 10-53 of this Code. Failure to surrender the
current license and submit a new application prior to a change in ownership
or control as defined in this paragraph shall constitute grounds to revoke
the existing liquor license.



(MC-968, § 1, 9-27-16)



Sec. 10-67.  Training required.



   (a)   All alcohol servers are required to obtain and complete a
Beverage Alcohol Sellers and Servers Education and Training (BASSET)
certification within 90 days after the alcohol server begins his or her
employment. Until obtaining BASSET certification, all newly hired alcohol
servers shall work under the supervision of a person possessing a valid
BASSET certification as required by this section.



   (b)   For purposes of this section, “alcohol servers” means
persons who sell or serve open containers of alcoholic beverages at retail
and anyone whose job description entails the checking of identification for
the purchase of open containers of alcoholic beverages at retail or for entry
into the licensed premises including all liquor managers and management
personnel at premises licensed for sale of alcoholic beverages for
on-premises consumption.



   (c)   BASSET certification shall be obtained from a program licensed
by the State of Illinois Liquor Control Commission and meeting the
requirements of 235 ILCS 5/6-27.1 and 77 Ill. Adm. Code 3500, as amended from
time to time.



   (d)   A copy of a valid BASSET certification for each alcohol server
shall be available at the licensed premises for inspection by the Homewood
Police Department, the local liquor commissioner, or his designee.



   (e)   The requirement of this section shall not apply to licensees
issued a Class 6 (special license) or a Class 11 (market license).



(MC-839, § 1B., 11-23-10; MC-930, § 1, 6-23-15)

Division 2. Motion Picture Theaters

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL



Sec. 14-1. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Miscellaneous amusements means all public shows, theatricals, a bridge
club, dance clubs and any other amusement conducted in the village.



(Code 1965, § 41.03(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 14-2. Inspections to ensure compliance with chapter.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this chapter and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.03(f))



Sec. 14-3. License--Required.



   No person shall operate or conduct any amusement which is open to the
public and for which a fee is charged, without having first secured a license
therefor; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not be
held to apply to those amusements which are specifically licensed elsewhere
in this chapter. Amusement licenses shall be granted by the board of
trustees, signed by the village president, and issued by the village manager.



(Code 1965, § 41.03(b))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 14-4. Same--Application.



   Applications for amusement licenses shall be made upon such forms as
prescribed by the village.



(Code 1965, § 41.03(c))



Sec. 14-5. Same--Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations shall be as follows:



      (1)   No person shall gamble, bet or permit any form of
gambling or betting in or on any premises used for amusement purposes unless
such activities are authorized by the laws of the State of Illinois and
regulated by the Illinois Gaming Board.



      (2)   The holder of an amusement license shall comply at all
times with all noise and noise abatement ordinances of the state and the
village, whether now in existence or hereafter adopted.



      (3)   No person conducting an amusement within the village
shall illuminate his place of amusement with floodlights or other lights
which shine or glare into or toward any private dwelling house or into any
street.



      (4)   Every portion of any building or structure in which
amusements are offered, devoted to the use or accommodation of the public,
and all outlets therefrom leading to the street, including all open courts,
corridors, stairways, exits and emergency exit stairways, shall be well and
properly lighted with electric lights during all hours while open to the
public, and shall remain lighted until the entire audience has left the
premises.



      (5)   No person conducting an amusement within the village
shall permit or gather such a crowd to witness any amusement or show as to
create a dangerous condition because of fire or other risks.



      (6)   No amusement shall be operated between the hours of
12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., unless otherwise approved by the village board.



      (7)   The holder of an amusement license shall comply with all
directions of the village manager concerning the regulation of parking and
traffic, both outside and within the licensed premises, in connection with
the amusements licensed, in order to provide maximum safety for the residents
of the village.



      (8)   It shall be the responsibility of the license holder for
an amusement to ensure that all regulations of the fire code are met.



      (9)   The board of trustees, acting under its police power for
the protection of the general welfare of the residents of the village, may
attach additional conditions not otherwise provided for in this section in
connection with the approval and issuance of any amusement license.



(Code 1965, § 41.03(d)) (MC-874, § 1, 8-14-12)



Sec. 14-6. Same--Fee.



   (a)   The license fee for miscellaneous amusements shall be as
follows:



      (1)   For those amusements operated or conducted on a fixed
premise for a period of time exceeding 100 days, the fee shall be on a square
footage basis, as described in section 26-37.



      (2)   For all other amusements, the fee shall be $75.00 per
100-day period, or less.



   (b)   In addition to the license fee prescribed for amusements, the
board of trustees may require that the premises in or on which the amusement
is conducted, is policed, and in such case may require the attendance of one
or more reserve or regular police officers or firefighters at the place of
amusement, at the expense of the licensee. The licensee shall deposit with
the village, in advance, a sufficient amount to cover the additional expense.



(Code 1965, § 41.03(e))



Sec. 14-7. Refusal to grant or renew.




   The village may refuse to grant or renew any amusement or entertainment
license governed by this Chapter if any applicant for a license or renewal of
a license has outstanding fees, fines, taxes, or debts due to the village,
including but not limited to water and sewer charges, places for eating tax,
hotel accommodations tax, or fines imposed after administrative adjudication
of a local ordinance violation. If the proposed licensee is a corporation,
limited liability company or similar entity, the term “applicant” as used
in this section shall include any stockbroker, member, or partner owning at
least a five percent interest in the licensed entity.




(MC-947, § 1, 2-23-16)



Secs. 14-8--14-30. Reserved.



ARTICLE II. ATHLETIC CONTESTS



Sec. 14-31. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Athletic contest means any race between persons or vehicles, or any
baseball, football, basketball, softball, boxing, wrestling or other athletic
contest for which the public is admitted to participate or view for a fee.



(Code 1965, § 41.04(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 14-32. License  Required.



   No person shall conduct an athletic contest without having first
secured a license therefor. However, this section shall not apply to those
athletic contests conducted by charitable, religious or not-for-profit
organizations located within the village. Athletic contest licenses shall be
granted by the board of trustees, signed by the village president and issued
by the village manager.



(Code 1965, § 41.04(b))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 14-33. Same  Application.



   Applications for athletic contest licenses shall be made upon such
forms as prescribed by the village.



(Code 1965, § 41.04(c))



Sec. 14-34. Same  Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations are as follows:



      (1)   No athletic contest shall be conducted between the hours
of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m.



      (2)   It shall be unlawful to gamble or bet at any athletic
contest, with the exception of horse racing, as sanctioned by the state
racing board.



      (3)   Every portion of the premises on which athletic contests
are conducted, including all outlets therefrom leading to the street, shall
be well and properly lighted during all hours while open to the public, and
shall remain lighted until the entire audience has left the premises.



      (4)   No unlawful conduct shall be permitted at any athletic
contest.



(Code 1965, § 41.04(d))



Sec. 14-35. Same  Fee.



   The fee for an athletic contest shall be $75.00 per 100-day period or
less. In addition to the license fee prescribed for athletic contests, the
board of trustees may require that the premises in, or on which the athletic
contest is conducted, is policed, and in such case may require the attendance
of one or more reserve or regular police officers or firefighters at the
place of the contest, at the expense of the licensee. The licensee shall
deposit with the village, in advance, a sufficient amount to cover the
additional expense.



(Code 1965, § 41.04(e))



Sec. 14-36. Inspections to ensure compliance with article.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.04(f))



Secs. 14-37--14-60. Reserved.



ARTICLE III. POOL AND BILLIARDS



Sec. 14-61. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Billiard table/pool table hall means any establishment operated for a
profit and offering the use of three or more billiard or pool tables or other
similar gaming table to the general public.



(Code 1965, § 41.06(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 14-62. License  Required.



   No person shall operate or maintain a billiard table/pool table hall
without having first secured a license therefor.



(Code 1965, § 41.06(b))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 14-63. Same  Application.



   Applications for billiard table/pool table hall licenses shall be made
upon such forms as prescribed by the village.



(Code 1965, § 41.06(c))



Sec. 14-64. Same  Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations shall be as follows:



      (1)   No billiard table/pool table hall shall operate between
the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday
or Friday mornings, nor between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. Saturday
and Sunday mornings.



      (2)   It shall be the responsibility of the licensed
proprietor to ensure that no gambling of any form is permitted or conducted
in such premises.



      (3)   In premises licensed under this article, no screen,
blind, curtain, partition, article or thing shall be permitted in the windows
or upon the doors, nor inside such premises, which shall prevent a clear view
into the interior of such licensed premises from the street, road or sidewalk
at all times. No booth, screen, partition, or other obstruction nor any
arrangement of lights or lighting shall be permitted in or about the interior
of such licensed premises which shall prevent a full view of the entire
interior of such premises from the street, road or sidewalk.



      (4)   No alcoholic beverage shall be permitted at any time on
the premises licensed under this article.



(Code 1965, § 41.06(d))



Sec. 14-65. Same  Fee.



   The annual license fee for a billiard table/pool table hall shall be on
a square footage basis, as described in section 26-37.



Sec. 14-66. Inspections to ensure article compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.06(f))



Secs. 14-67--14-85. Reserved.

(Code 1965, § 41.07(c))



Sec. 14-89. Same  Licensee regulations.

mornings, nor between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. Saturday and
