ARTICLE V. CIRCUSES AND CARNIVALS



Sec. 14-116. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Carnival means an entertainment or place of amusement with rides, games
of skill, sideshows, refreshments, or any combination of the above.



   Circus means an entertainment or place of amusement with sideshows,
rides, games of skill, refreshments, or any combination of the above, usually
including an arena enclosed within a tent for the showing of acrobats, wild
animals, and clowns.



(Code 1965, § 41.08(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 14-117. License  Required.



   No person shall conduct or operate a circus or carnival in the village
without having first secured a license therefor. Circus and carnival licenses
shall be granted by the board of trustees, signed by the village president,
and issued by the village manager.



(Code 1965, § 41.08(b))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 14-118. Same  Application.



   Applications for circus and carnival licenses shall be made upon such
forms as prescribed by the village. All applications shall be accompanied by
a certificate of insurance in the amount of $5,000,000 combined single limit
per occurrence for bodily injury and property damage naming the Village of
Homewood as an additional insured. Any applicant for a circus and/or carnival
license shall execute a hold harmless agreement and other documentation as
required by the Village prior to the issuance of such license.



(Code 1965, § 41.08(c)) (MC-680)



Sec. 14-119. Same  Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations shall be as follows:



      (1)   It shall be the responsibility of the licensee to ensure
that areas used for any circus or carnival shall be cleaned and returned to
their normal condition at the conclusion of that activity.



      (2)   No person shall gamble, bet or permit any form of
gambling or betting in or on any premises used for a circus or carnival.



      (3)   Adequate safeguards shall be placed on all rides to
protect both operators and the general public from inadvertently coming into
contact with moving parts, belts, motor gears, electrical switches and other
possible or potential hazards.



      (4)   Trash containers in adequate number shall be placed in
convenient locations for the use of the public.



      (5)   Every portion of any building or structure in which
circuses and carnivals are offered, devoted to the use or accommodation of
the public, and all outlets therefrom leading to the street, including all
open courts, corridors, stairways, exits and emergency exits, shall be well
and properly lighted with electric lights during all hours while open to the
public, and shall remain lighted until the entire audience has left the
premises.



      (6)   It shall be unlawful to permit or present any obscene,
as defined under 720 ILCS 5/11-20(b), show or exhibition at any circus or
carnival.



      (7)   No circus or carnival shall be operated between the
hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m.



(Code 1965, § 41.08(d))



Sec. 14-120. Same--Fee.



   The license fee for a circus or carnival shall be $75.00 per day. In
addition to the license fee prescribed for circuses and carnivals, the board
of trustees may require that the premises in, or on which the circus and
carnival is conducted, is policed, and in such case may require the
attendance of one or more reserve or regular police officers or firefighters
at the place of the circus and/or carnival, at the expense of the licensee.
The licensee shall deposit with the village, in advance, a sufficient amount
to cover the additional expense.



(Code 1965, § 41.08(e))



Sec. 14-121. Inspections to ensure article compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.08(f))



Secs. 14-122--14-150. Reserved.



ARTICLE VI. COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES



Sec. 14-151. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Coin-operated amusement device means any amusement machine or device
operated by means of the insertion of a coin, currency, token, or similar
object for the purpose of amusement or skill and for the playing of which a
fee is charged and any coin-operated mechanical musical device. Coin-operated
amusement device shall also include only those gambling devices sanctioned by
the Illinois Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.



(Code 1965, § 41.09(a); MC-899, § 1, 11-12-13)



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 14-152. License--Required.



   No person shall provide for public use a coin-operated amusement device
without having first secured a license therefor. Licenses shall not be
transferable from one machine to another. Any coin-operated amusement device
found operating within the village without a license may be unplugged and
tagged as not being available for public use by village officials as an
unlicensed device.



(Code 1965, § 41.09(b); MC-899, § 1, 11-12-13)



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 14-153. Same--Application.



   Applications for coin-operated amusement device licenses shall be made
upon such forms as prescribed by the village manager. One application may be
used for more than one device at the same premises, but a separate license
shall be obtained for each device. Such application shall also specify the
number of devices, a description of each device, and the name and address of
the owner of each device.



(Code 1965, § 41.09(c); MC-899, § 1, 11-12-13)



Sec. 14-154. Same--Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations shall be as follows:



      (1)   Each license shall be affixed on the face of the device
for which it is issued so that it is clearly visible upon inspection of the
device.



      (2)   No license issued under this article shall permit the
operation of any coin-operated amusement device at any place or in any manner
which will disturb the peace and quiet of persons outside the premises in
which the device is located.



      (3)   Coin-operated amusement devices shall not pay off in
money unless such devices are authorized by the laws of the State of Illinois
and licensed by the Illinois Gaming Board. The devices may grant free games
to a player upon the player reaching a certain score. The requirements for
obtaining a free game shall be clearly posted on each device. No person may
buy back, either with money or anything of value, accumulated free games. Any
mechanism located on the coin-operated amusement device to clear accumulated
games shall not be located on the outside of the machine. Coin-operated
amusement devices may grant a token for each game played which may be
redeemed for a prize of nominal value. Tokens may not be purchased, sold, or
redeemed for cash.



      (4)   No person shall wager or gamble on the playing of
coin-operated amusement devices, and the licensee shall ensure that no person
wagers or gambles on the playing of such devices located in the licensee’s
premises unless such licenses and activities are authorized by the laws of
the State of Illinois and licensed by the Illinois Gaming Board.



(Code 1965, § 41.09(d); MC-874, § 1, 8-14-12; MC-899, § 1, 11-12-13)



Sec. 14-155. Same--Fee.



   The license fee for a gambling device sanctioned by the Illinois Video
Gaming Act shall be $25 per machine per year. The license fee for all other
coin-operated amusement device shall be $75.00 per machine per year. The
proprietor of the premises on which such device is located shall be
responsible for payment of the license fee. Fees shall be due and payable
annually in advance of the coin-operated amusement device being made
available for use by the public.



(Code 1965, § 41.09(e); MC-899, § 1, 11-12-13)



Sec. 14-156. Inspections to ensure article compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as it deems necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
pertaining to the operation of coin-operated amusement devices.



(Code 1965, § 41.09(f); MC-899, § 1, 11-12-13)



Secs. 14-157--14-185. Reserved.



ARTICLE VII. ELECTRONIC GAME ROOMS



Sec. 14-186. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Coin-operated amusement devices means any amusement machine or device
operated by means of the insertion of a coin, token, or similar object for
the purpose of amusement or skill and for the playing of which a fee is
charged and any coin-operated mechanical musical device.



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



   Electronic game room means any establishment, room, or place where a
principal use is providing coin-operated amusement devices available for play
by the public.



(Code 1965, § 41.11(a))



Sec. 14-187. License--Required.



   No person shall operate or maintain an electronic game room without
having first secured a license therefor. In addition, each game machine shall
be licensed by the village as required by article VI of this chapter.



(Code 1965, § 41.11(b))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 14-188. Same--Application.



   (a)   Any person desiring an electronic game room license shall make
application therefor with the village manager or his designee. The
application shall provide the following information:



      (1)   Name, address, date of birth, drivers license number,
and social security number of all owners of the business;



      (2)   Name, address, date of birth, drivers license number,
and social security number of all partners if the business is a partnership;



      (3)   Name, address, date of birth, drivers license number,
and social security number of all officers, directors, and stock owners if
the business is a corporation; and



      (4)   The name, address, date of birth, drivers license
number, and social security number of the owners of the machines.



The application shall be referred to the police chief for investigation and
verification of the facts stated therein. The police chief shall determine
whether the applicants, or, if a partnership or corporation, any stockholder
or member of the partnership or any employee or manager has been convicted of
a criminal offense pertaining to gambling or other crime of moral turpitude
in either a state or federal court.



   (b)   If the police chief shall determine that the applicant, its
stockholders, members, employees, or managers, or any of them, have in fact
been so convicted or have engaged in a violation of a federal or state
statute or of any local ordinance pertaining to gambling or other crime of
moral turpitude within five years preceding the application, he shall report
the results of his findings to the village manager. The village manager may
then order that the license not be issued. The applicant shall have the right
to appeal to the board of trustees; provided, however, that a written appeal
is received by the village within ten days of the written findings of the
village manager having been dispatched to the applicant.



   (c)   If the village manager shall determine at any time that any
licensee is not in fact eligible by reason of any facts which would not have
made him eligible for the issuance of the original license or by violation of
the regulations pertaining to electronic game rooms, the license may be
revoked by the village manager after written notice to the licensee and the
opportunity to appear before the village manager. That notice shall specify
the violations with which the licensee is charged, and of the opportunity to
appear before the village manager. Seven days' notice of this informal
hearing shall be given the licensee. At such informal hearing, the licensee
and his attorney may present and submit evidence and witnesses in his
defense. The licensee shall have the right to appeal the village manager's
decision to the board of trustees; provided, however, that the appeal is made
within ten days of the written findings of the village manager having been
dispatched to the licensee.



   (d)   The village manager shall not issue an electronic game room
license until the applicant has obtained a special use permit or a zoning
variance as required by the zoning ordinance.



(Code 1965, § 41.11(c))



Sec. 14-189. Same--Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations shall be as follows:



      (1)   An adult manager shall be present on the premises at all
times the electronic game room is open for business.



      (2)   No cigarette machines shall be installed in the
electronic game room.



      (3)   Signs denoting curfew laws shall be posted on the
premises of the electronic game room, and the adult manager shall ensure that
persons affected by the curfew depart the electronic game room no later than
15 minutes before the curfew.



      (4)   Coin-operated amusement devices in the electronic game
room shall not pay off in money unless such devices are authorized by the
laws of the State of Illinois and licensed by the Illinois Gaming Board. The
devices may grant free games to a player upon the player reaching a certain
score or scores. The requirements for obtaining a free game shall be clearly
posted on each device. No person may buy back, either with money or any thing
of value, accumulated free games. Any mechanism located on the coin-operated
amusement device to clear accumulated games shall not be located on the
outside of the machine. Coin-operated amusement devices may grant a token for
each game played which may be redeemed for a prize of nominal value. Tokens
may not be purchased, sold or redeemed for cash.



      (5)   No person shall wager or gamble on the playing of
coin-operated amusement devices and the licensee shall ensure that no person
wagers or gambles on the playing of such devices located in the licensee’s
electronic game room unless such devices and activities are authorized by the
laws of the State of Illinois and licensed by the Illinois Gaming Board.



      (6)   Pool or billiard tables shall not be allowed in
electronic game rooms.



      (7)   No electronic game room shall operate between the hours
of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. However, if an electronic game room is an
ancillary use of an Amusement or Entertainment facility the hours of
operation shall be the same as allowed for the main use of said facility.



      (8)   No license issued under this article shall permit the
operation of any coin-operated amusement device at any place or in any manner
which will disturb the peace and quiet of persons outside the licensed
premises.



(Code 1965, § 41.11(d); MC-874, § 1, 8-14-12)



Sec. 14-190. Same--Fee.



   The annual license fee for an electronic game room license shall be on
a square footage basis as set forth in section 26-37.



(Code 1965, § 41.11(e))



Sec. 14-191. Inspections to ensure article compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as it deems necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
pertaining to the operation of an electronic game room.



(Code 1965, § 41.11(f))



Secs. 14-192--14-215. Reserved.



ARTICLE VIII. THEATERS



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Secs. 14-216--14-235. Reserved.



DIVISION 2. MOTION PICTURE THEATERS



Sec. 14-236. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Motion picture theater means any building used for the purpose of
displaying motion pictures for which an admission fee is charged.



(Code 1965, § 41.21(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 14-237. License--Required.



   It shall be unlawful to give, present or conduct any motion picture for
admission to which a fee is charged, excepting performances given solely for
the benefit of and under supervision of a religious, educational,
governmental, or charitable organization, without having first secured a
license therefor.



(Code 1965, § 41.21(b))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 14-238. Same--Application.



   Applications for motion picture theater licenses shall be made upon
such forms as prescribed by the village.



(Code 1965, § 41.21(c))



Sec. 14-239. Same--Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations shall be as follows:



      (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person to offer or present
any motion picture which is obscene under state law.



      (2)   It shall be unlawful to permit any person, except
theater employees, to remain standing in a hall or room in which a motion
picture is presented during the time of such performance.



      (3)   all buildings used for displaying motion pictures must
conform to all building and fire code regulations.



(Code 1965, § 41.21(d))



Sec. 14-240. Same--Fee.



   The annual license fee for a motion picture theater shall be on a
square footage basis, as described in section 26-37.



Sec. 14-241. Inspections to ensure division compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this division and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.21(f))



Secs. 14-242--14-265. Reserved.



DIVISION 3. THEATRICAL EXHIBITIONS



Sec. 14-266. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Theatrical exhibition means any live exhibition, entertainment, or
performance which is musical, dramatic, vaudevillian, satirical or variety in
nature, for which an admission fee is charged.



(Code 1965, § 41.33(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 14-267. License--Generally.



   (a)   Required. It shall be unlawful to give, present or conduct any
theatrical exhibition for admission to which a fee is charged without having
first secured a license therefor.



   (b)   Application. Applications for theatrical exhibition licenses
shall be made upon such forms as prescribed by the village.



(Code 1965, § 41.33(b), (c))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 14-268. Same--Licensee regulation.



   A licensee shall not permit or gather such a crowd as to create a
dangerous condition because of fire or other risks.



(Code 1965, § 41.33(d))



Sec. 14-269. Same--Fee.



   The annual license fee for a theatrical exhibition shall be on a square
footage basis, as described in section 26-37. In addition to the license fee
prescribed for theatrical exhibitions, the board of trustees may require that
the premises in or on which the exhibition is conducted, is policed and, in
such case, may require the attendance of one or more reserve or regular
police officers or firefighters at the place of such exhibition, at the
expense of the licensee. The licensee shall deposit with the village, in
advance, a sufficient amount to cover the additional expense.



(Code 1965, § 41.33(e))



Sec. 14-270. Inspections to ensure division compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this division and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.33)



Secs. 14-271--14-290. Reserved.

Sec. 14-291. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Theatrical ticket brokers means any agent, person, firm or corporation
who acts as an intermediary for the purpose of negotiating the purchase of
theatrical tickets.



(Code 1965, § 41.34(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.

No person shall operate as a theatrical ticket broker without having first
secured a license therefor.



(Code 1965, § 41.34(b))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 14-293. Same  Application.



   Applications for theatrical ticket broker license shall be made upon
such forms as prescribed by the village.



(Code 1965, § 41.34(c))



Sec. 14-294. Same  Licensee regulation.



   No theatrical ticket broker shall add more than a ten percent service
charge to the face value of any ticket.



(Code 1965, § 41.34(d))



Sec. 14-295. Same  Fee.



   The annual license fee for a theatrical ticket broker shall be $40.00.



(Code 1965, § 41.34(e))



Sec. 14-296. Inspections to ensure division compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this division and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.34(f))



Secs. 14-297--14-320. Reserved.



ARTICLE IX. PUBLIC DANCES



Sec. 14-321. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Public dance means any dance in a public hall for which an admission
fee is charged, whether sponsored by a group, a club or organization.



(Code 1965, § 41.26(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 14-322. License  Required.



It shall be unlawful to operate or conduct a public dance in the village
without having first obtained a license therefor. A public dance license
shall be granted by the board of trustees, signed by the village president
and issued by the village manager.



(Code 1965, § 41.26(b))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 14-323. Same  Application.



   Applications for public dances shall be made upon such forms as
prescribed by the village. Such application shall specify the location of the
proposed dance, the person or organization sponsoring the dance, the date of
the dance and the starting and ending times of the dance.



(Code 1965, § 41.26(c))



Sec. 14-324. Same  Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations shall be as follows:



      (1)   A licensee shall not permit any unlawful conduct at any
public dance.



      (2)   No public dance shall be conducted between the hours of
1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or Friday
mornings, nor between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. Saturday mornings,
nor between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon on Sundays.



(Code 1965, § 41.26(d))



Sec. 14-325. Same  Fee.



   The license fee for a public dance shall be $40.00 per day. In addition
to the license fee prescribed for public dances, the board of trustees may
require that the premises in or on which the dance is conducted is policed
and, in such case, may require the attendance of one or more reserve or
regular police officers or firefighters at the place of the dance, at the
expense of the licensee. The licensee shall deposit with the village clerk in
advance a sufficient amount to cover the additional expense. Such fee may be
waived by the village board of trustees, but an application must be filed.



(Code 1965, § 41.26(e))



Sec. 14-326. Inspections to ensure article compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.26(f))



Secs. 14-327--14-350. Reserved.



ARTICLE X. SHOOTING GALLERIES



Sec. 14-351. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Shooting gallery means a place maintained for profit and to give
patrons an opportunity to practice their skills by shooting guns, darts, or
other weapons at a target or object.



(Code 1965, § 41.30(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 14-352. License  Required.



   No person shall operate or maintain a shooting gallery without having
first secured a license therefor.



(Code 1965, § 41.30(b))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 14-353. Same  Application.



   Applications for shooting gallery licenses shall be made upon such
forms as prescribed by the village. Such application shall also specify make,
model and serial number of all firearms to be used.



(Code 1965, § 41.30(c)



Sec. 14-354. Same  Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations are as follows:



      (1)   No shooting gallery shall be open for business between
the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m.



      (2)   All persons present in any shooting gallery shall
conduct themselves in an orderly manner, and shall not make or cause to be
made any loud or unnecessary noise.



      (3)   It shall be unlawful to gamble or bet in any shooting
gallery.



      (4)   All premises used for shooting galleries shall be kept
in a clean and sanitary condition.



      (5)   All shooting galleries shall be conducted so as to not
endanger the life of any person.



      (6)   No minor or any intoxicated person shall be permitted on
the premises.



      (7)   No intoxicating beverage shall be permitted on the
premises.



      (8)   All targets shall be of such a design and strength so as
to provide maximum safety for the employees, patrons, and general public.



      (9)   No revolver, shotgun or pistol shall be used for target
practice, nor shall any rifle of more than .22 caliber be used. All
ammunition shall be that commonly known as "shorts" or smaller in size.
Firearms or ammunition not permitted under this article shall not be kept on
the premises.



      (10)   A manager shall be on the premises at all hours during
which a shooting gallery is open to the public.



(Code 1965, § 41.30(d))



Sec. 14-355. Same  Fee.



   The annual license fee for a shooting gallery shall be on a square
footage basis, as described in section 26-37.



(Code 1965, § 41.30(e))



Sec. 14-356. Inspections to ensure article compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.30(f))



Secs. 14-357--14-380. Reserved.

   Skating rink means any place containing a surface or area specially

(Code 1965, § 41.31(b))

   Applications for skating rink licenses shall be made upon such forms as

(Code 1965, § 41.31(c))



Sec. 14-384. Same  Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations shall be as follows:



      (1)   No unlawful conduct shall be permitted at any public
skating rink.



      (2)   No skating rink shall operate between the hours of 12:00
midnight and 6:00 a.m.



      (3)   No intoxicating beverages shall be permitted on the

(Code 1965, § 41.31(d))

(Code 1965, § 41.31(f))



Secs. 14-387  14-410. Reserved.



ARTICLE XII. RAFFLES



Sec. 14-411. Definitions.



The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context
clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Business organization means a voluntary organization composed of
individuals and businesses who have joined together to advance the
commercial, financial, industrial and civic interests of a community.



   Charitable organization means an organization or institution organized
and operated to benefit an indefinite number of the public. The service
rendered to those eligible for the benefits must also confer some benefit on
the public.



   Educational organization means an organization or institution organized
and operated to provide systematic instruction in useful branches of learning
by methods common to schools and institutions of learning which compare
favorably in their scope and intensity with the course of study presented in
tax-supported schools.



   Fraternal organization means an organization of persons having a common
interest, their primary interest of which is to both promote the welfare of
its members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as
to lessen the burdens of government by caring for those that otherwise would
be cared for by the government.



   Labor organization means an organization composed of workers organized
with the objective of betterment of the conditions of those engaged in such
pursuit and the development of a higher degree of efficiency in their
respective occupations.



   Net proceeds means the gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less
reasonable sums expended for prizes, local license fees, and other reasonable
operating expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle.



   Nonprofit organization means an organization or institution organized
and conducted on a not-for-profit basis with no personal profit inuring to
any one as a result of the operation.



   Raffle  means a form of lottery, as defined in section 28-2(b) of the
Criminal Code of 1961 (720 ILCS 5/28-2(b)) conducted by an organization
licensed under this article, in which:



      (1)   The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for
a chance, represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of
numbers or by some other medium, one or more of which chances is to designate
the winning chance; or



      (2)   The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing
or by some other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of
acts on the part of persons conducting or connected with the lottery, except
that the winning chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly
exhibited sporting contest.



   Religious organization means any church, congregation, society, or
organization founded for the purpose of religious worship.



   Veterans organization means an organization or association comprised of
members of which substantially all are individuals who are veterans or
spouses, widows, or widowers of veterans, the primary purpose of which is to
promote the general public in such a way as to confer a public benefit.



(Code 1965, § 41.36(a), (c))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 14-412. License  Required.



   No person shall conduct any raffle without having first obtained a
license therefor. Licenses issued under this article shall not be
transferable or assignable.



(Code 1965, § 41.36(b))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 14-413. Same – Issuance; organizations eligible.



   (a)   Licenses shall be issued for: single raffles to be held on a
specific date, a specified number of single raffles to be held during a
specified period not to exceed one year (multiple raffles) or a raffle
wherein one chance is entered in multiple drawings during a specified period
not to exceed one year (serial raffle).



   (b)   Licenses shall be issued only to bona fide, religious,
charitable, business, labor, fraternal, educational or veterans organizations
that operate without profit to their members and which have been in existence
continually for a period of five years immediately before making application
for a license and which have during that entire five-year period a bona fide
membership engaged in carrying out their objectives, or to a nonprofit
organization that the licensing authority determines is organized for the
sole purpose of providing financial assistance to an identified individual or
group of individuals suffering extreme financial hardship as the result of an
illness, disability, accident or disaster.



(Code 1965, § 41.36(c); MC-829, § 1, 3-23-10)



Sec. 14-414. Same  Application.



   Application for raffle licenses shall be made upon such forms as
prescribed by the village manager. The license and application for license
shall specify the area or areas within the village in which raffle chances
will be sold or issued, the time period during which raffle chances will be
sold or issued, the time or determination of winning chances, and the
location at which winning chances will be determined. The license application
shall contain a sworn statement attesting to the not-for-profit character of
the prospective licensee organization signed by the presiding officer and the
secretary of the organization. The renewal of multiple raffle licenses shall
be subject to the approval of the board of trustees.



(Code 1965, § 41.36(f))



Sec. 14-415.Same – Fee.



   (a)   The fee for each single raffle license shall be $5.00 and
shall be payable to the village prior to the issuance of any raffle license.
Each such license is valid for one raffle only.



   (b)   The annual fee for each multiple or serial raffle license
shall be $100.00 and shall be payable to the village prior to the issuance of
the multiple or serial raffle license. Each such license is valid for a
period of one year from the date of issuance.



(Code 1965, § 41.36(e); MC-829, § 1, 3-23-10)



Sec. 14-416. Limitations on aggregate retail value of prizes and merchandise
awarded.



   (a)   Single raffles. Unless otherwise authorized by the village
board, the aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise awarded by a
licensee in a single raffle shall not exceed $50,000.00. The maximum retail
value of each prize awarded by a licensee in a single raffle shall not exceed
$25,000.00. The maximum price which may be charged for each raffle chance
issued or sold for a single raffle is hereby established at $25.00. The
maximum number of days during which chances may be issued or sold prior to
the single raffle is hereby established at 90 days. The village board may
approve the issuance of a single raffle license for amounts in excess of
those prescribed in this section, but in no case shall a license be approved
for a single raffle where the aggregate retail value of all prizes or
merchandise awarded by a licensee in that raffle exceeds $150,000.00, or
where the maximum retail value of each prize awarded by a licensee in that
raffle exceeds $150,000.00, or where the maximum price which may be charged
for each raffle chance issued or sold exceeds $100.00.



   (b)   Multiple or serial raffles. The aggregate retail value of all
prizes or merchandise awarded by a licensee in a raffle which is part of a
multiple or serial raffle shall not exceed $5,000.00. The maximum retail
value of each prize awarded by a licensee in a raffle which is part of a
multiple or serial raffle shall not exceed $1,000.00. The maximum price which
may be charged for each raffle chance issued or sold in a multiple or serial
raffle is $10.00.



(Code 1965, § 41.36(d); MC-829, § 1, 3-23-10)



Sec. 14-417. Conduct of raffles.



Raffles licensed by the village are subject to the following restrictions:



      (1)   The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be
exclusively devoted to the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to
conduct that game.



      (2)   No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring
organization may participate in the management or operation of the raffle.



      (3)   No person may receive any remuneration or profit for
participating in the management or operation of the raffle.



      (4)   A licensee may rent a premise on which to determine the
winning chance in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed
under this article.



      (5)   Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the
area specified on the license and winning chances may be determined only at
those locations specified on the license. Raffle chances for a raffle
conducted as a multiple raffle may be sold only on the day of the raffle
drawing and only at the location where the winning chances will be
determined. Serial raffle chances may be sold for 90 days after the license
is issued and winning chances drawn throughout a period not to exceed 12
months from the date the license is issued.



      (6)   A licensee holding a multiple raffle license shall not
conduct a raffle more than once in any seven-day period during the term of
the license.



      (7)   No person under the age of 18 years may participate in
the conducting of raffles or chances. A person under the age of 18 years may
be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when
accompanied by his parent or guardian.



(Code 1965, § 41.36(g); MC-829, § 1, 3-23-10)



Sec. 14-418. Raffle manager.



   All operations of and the conduct of raffles licensed by the village
shall be under the supervision of a raffle manager designated by the licensed
organization. That manager shall give a fidelity bond in favor of the
organization, conditioned upon his honesty in the performance of his duties.
The village shall receive a copy of that bond. The bond shall be in an amount
equal to the aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise to be
awarded by the licensee in the raffle. The bond shall provide that notice
must be given in writing to the village not less than 30 days prior to its
cancellation. The village may waive this bond requirement by including a
waiver provision in the license issued to an organization, but only upon the
unanimous vote of all of the members of the organization to be licensed
authorizing such waiver.



(Code 1965, § 41.36(h))



Sec. 14-419. Ineligibility of certain persons.



   No raffle license shall be issued to any of the following who are
hereby deemed ineligible for such license:



      (1)   Any person who has been convicted of a felony.



      (2)   Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or
gambling promoter.



      (3)   Any person who is not of good moral character.



      (4)   Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in
subsections (1), (2) or (3) of this section has a proprietary, equitable or
credit interest, or in which such a person is active or employed.



      (5)   Any organization in which a person defined in
subsections (1), (2) or (3) of this section is an officer, director, or
employee, whether compensated or not.



      (6)   Any organization in which a person defined in
subsections (1), (2) or (3) of this section is to participate in the
management or operation of a raffle.



      (7)   Any other person or organization prohibited from
receiving such license by the state.



(Code 1965, § 41.36(i))



Sec. 14-420. Recordkeeping.



   (a)   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances
shall keep records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each
single gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All
deductions from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be
documented with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a
description of the purchased item or service or other reason for the
deduction, and the recipient. The distribution of net proceeds shall be
itemized as to payee, purpose, amount and date of payment.



   (b)   Gross receipts from the operation of raffles programs shall be
segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross
receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit
organization pursuant to license therefor issued by the state department of
revenue, and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have
separated records of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts,
expenses and net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same
person who accounts for other revenues of the organization.



   (c)   Each  organization licensed  to conduct a single raffle
shall, within one month after the raffle drawing, report to its membership
and to the village its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the
raffle, and the distribution of net proceeds itemized as required in this
article.



   Each organization licensed to conduct multiple or serial raffles shall
report quarterly to its membership and to the village its gross receipts,
expenses and net proceeds from raffles, and the distribution of net proceeds
itemized as required in this article. Such multiple or serial raffle license
reports shall be filed with the village no later than 30 days after each
three-month period of the license term.



   (d)   Records required by this article shall be preserved for three
years, and organizations shall make available their records relating to
operation of raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places.



(Code 1965, § 41.36(j); MC-829, § 1, 3-23-10)



Sec. 14-421. Revocation of license.



   If the village manager shall determine at any time that any licensee is
not in fact eligible by reason of any facts which would not have made the
licensee eligible for the issuance of the original license or by violation of
the regulations pertaining to raffles, such license may be revoked by the
village manager after written notice to the licensee and the opportunity to
appear before the village manager. That notice shall specify the violations
with which the licensee is charged and the opportunity to appear before the
village manager. The licensee must file a written request for such a hearing
with the village manager within ten days of the notice having been dispatched
to the licensee. Seven days' notice of this informal hearing shall be given
the licensee. At such informal hearing, the licensee and its attorney may
present and submit evidence and witnesses in its defense. The licensee shall
have the right to appeal the village manager's decision to the board of
trustees; provided, however, that the appeal is made within ten days of the
written findings of the village manager having been dispatched to the
licensee. Notices required under this section shall be sent by certified mail
or hand delivered to the licensee at the address provided by the licensee in
the license application.



(Code 1965, § 41.36(k))



ARTICLE XIII. TOBACCO



Sec. 14-422. Interpretation of section.



   This section shall be liberally construed to the end that the health,
safety and welfare of the residents of the village shall be protected, and
temperance in the use of tobacco products shall be fostered and promoted.



Sec. 14-423. Definitions.



   Unless the context shall otherwise require, terms used in this section
shall have the definitions given in Public Act 095-0017 (the Smoke Free
Illinois Act) 35 ILCS 143/10-1 to 10-90 et seq., and 720 ILCS 675, 680, 685
et seq., as amended from time to time. Where not otherwise qualified, the
term "license" or "licensee" wherever used in this section means a license or
licensee of the village under this section.



(MC-790, § 1, 10-9-07)



Sec. 14-424. Sales to certain persons.



   In connection with the sale or distribution of tobacco products and/or
accessories, to any person under 18 years of age, licensees shall be subject
to all regulations, prohibitions and penalties set forth in 35 ILCS 143/10-1
to 10-90 et seq., specifically including, but not limited to, the
restrictions, provisions and penalties of 720 ILCS 675, 680, 685 et seq.



Sec. 14-425. Local Tobacco Control Commissioner.



   (a)   Regulations administered.  The president of the board of
trustees shall be the local tobacco control commissioner and shall be charged
with the administration of the provisions of appropriate portions of this
section and state law, and may appoint other persons to assist him/her in the
exercise of these powers and responsibilities. The village board is
authorized to determine and pay compensation to the local tobacco control
commissioner in consideration of the performance of his.her duties as local
tobacco control commissioner.



   (b)   Powers. The local commissioner shall have the following
powers, functions and duties:



      1.   To grant and revoke for cause all local licenses issued
to persons for premises within the village. Cause shall specifically include,
but shall not be limited to, a licensee's failure to operate the licensed
premises for a period of 60 consecutive days.



      2.   To enter or to authorize any law enforcing  officer 
to  enter  at  any  time  upon the  premises  licensed  under this
section to determine whether any of the provisions of this section of the
Homewood Municipal Code and/or of the tobacco control act of the state (65
ILCS 5/11-20-3 et seq.) or any of the rules or regulations adopted by the
state commission have been or are being violated, and at such times to
examine the premises of the licensee in connection therewith.



      3.   To receive complaints from any citizen of the village
that any provision of this section of the Homewood Municipal Code and/or the
tobacco control act (65 ILCS 5/11-20-3 et seq. has been or is biing violated,
and to act upon such complaint in the manner provided by law.



      4.   All tobacco license fees shall be paid to the village
treasurer or his nominee.



      5.   To examine or cause to be examined under oath any
applicant for a village license or for renewal of a license or any licensee
upon whom notice of revocation has been served all as provided in this
section of the Homewood Municipal Code or of the Illinois tobacco control
act, 35 iLCS 143/10-1 to 10-90 et seq., and 720 ILCS 675, 680, 685 et seq.,
as amended from time to time.



      6.   All other powers, functions and duties given to the local
commissioner by the Illinois Compiled Statutes.



      7.   To  file an  administrative  review  action to
challenge a decision of the state tobacco control commission, reducing or
vacating any license revocation, suspension or fine imposed on a tobacco
licensee by the local tobacco commissioner.



   (c)   List of licensees. The local commissioner shall keep or cause
to be kept a complete record and file of particulars of all licenses issued
by him/her.



Sec. 14-426. Employment of persons under 18 years of age and of minors.



   (a)   No person under 18 years of age shall sell tobacco products
and/or accessories as an employee of any licensee, as prohibited in the state
tobacco control act 720 ILCS 675/0.01 et seq. For purposes of this section,
sale or sell shall include, but not be limited to, the operation of the cash
register, scanning device or any other equipment used to record the purchase
of tobacco products and/or accessories, and the receipt of money, checks,
credit cards or any other form of payment for the purchase of tobacco
products and/or accessories, and the receipt of money, checks, credit cards
or any other form of payment for the purchase of tobacco products and/or
accessories. The requirement for sales personnel to be 18 years of age or
older may not be avoided by asking or permitting patrons to perform any part
of the sale transaction.



   (b)   No person under 18 years of age shall possess tobacco products
and/or accessories as an employee of a licensee other than as authorized by
law.



   (c)   No licensee shall permit any of the acts prohibited in this
section.



Sec. 14-427. Credit sales.



   No person shall sell or furnish tobacco products and/or accessories at
retail under terms contrary to 35 ILCS 143/10-1 to 10-90 et seq., 235 ILCS
5/3-12 et seq., and 720 ILCS 675, 680, 685 et. seq., or the provisions of
this section of the Homewood Municipal Code, as they are amended from time to
time.



Sec. 14-428. Refilling original packages.



   No licensee shall refill in whole or in part, any original tobacco
product or accessories.



Sec. 14-429. Minimum size cigarette packaging.



   No licensee shall sell or offer for sale any quantity of cigarettes
smaller than which is packaged by the original manufacturers packaging of a
single package of cigarettes. All single packages of cigarettes must be sold
with the original manufacturers seal unbroken and with the original packaged
quantity of cigarettes intact at the time of sale. (Single packages of
cigarettes commonly packaged as 20 cigarettes and commonly referred to as "a
pack of cigarettes").



   Foreign and uncommon brands of cigarettes may be offered for sale in
packages of smaller quantities than 20 cigarettes. However, foreign and
uncommon brands of cigarettes must be sold in no smaller quantity than the
manufacturers original single package of these brands of cigarettes, and with
the original single packaging seal unbroken.



Sec. 14-430. Minimum size cigar packaging.



   No licensee shall sell or offer for sale any quantity of cigars smaller
than which is packaged by the original manufacturers packaging of a single
sale of the particular cigar.



   All single packages of cigars and/or individual sale cigars must be
sold with the original manufacturers seal unbroken and with the original
packaged quantity of cigars, (one or more), intact at the time of sale.
Cigars for individual sale must remain individually wrapped as by the
manufacturer, for sale as a single cigar.  This section shall not apply to
Retail Tobacco Stores as defined by Public Act 095-0017.



(MC-790, § 1, 10-9-07)



Sec. 14-431. Minimum size smokeless tobacco packaging.



   No licensee shall sell or offer for sale any quantity of any smokeless
tobacco product that is not in the original manufacturers packaging for
single package sale, with the original manufacturers seal unbroken and with
the original packaged quantity intact at the time of sale. Smokeless tobacco
products include, but are not limited to, any finely cut, ground, powdered,
or leaf tobacco, that is intended to be placed in the oral cavity.



Sec. 14-432. Minimum size packaging of all tobacco products and accessories.



   All tobacco products and accessories covered by Public Act 095-0017, 35
ILCS 143/10-1 to 10-90 et seq., and 720 ILCS 675, 680, 685 et seq., and this
section of the Homewood Municipal Code, shall only be offered for sale by
licensees in the original manufacturers packaging for single package sale,
with the original manufacturers seal unbroken and with the original packaged
quantity intact at the time of sale.  This section shall not apply to Retail
Tobacco Stores as defined by Public Act 095-0017.



(MC-790, § 1, 10-9-07)



Sec. 14-433. Gifts.



   The local tobacco control commissioner, his agent, members of a
committee appointed by him/her to assist in local control, members of the
board of trustees and police officers are prohibited from soliciting or
accepting any gift, gratuity, emolument, or employment from any licensee.
Every licensee or employee, agent or officer of such licensee is prohibited
from offering or making any such gift, gratuity, or emolument to any person
prohibited from accepting any such gift, gratuity, or emolument.



Sec. 14-434. Prohibited transactions.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, give away
or deliver tobacco products and or accessories to any person under the age of
eighteen (18) years. Any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of any
tobacco product and/or accessories is prohibited because of age, or for any
other reason, except as an authorized agent for compliance enforcement, shall
not purchase, or accept a gift of such tobacco products and/or accessories or
have such tobacco products and/or accessories in his/her possession. All such
persons shall be subject to all restrictions, prohibitions and penalties of
35 ILCS 143/10-1 to 10-90 et seq., and 720 ILCS 675, 680, 685 et seq., and
this section of the Homewood Municipal Code, specifically including, but not
limited to, the restrictions, prohibitions and penalties of 720 ILCS 675,
680, 685 et seq.



Sec. 14-435. Underage possession of tobacco.



   No person under the age of 18 shall be in possession of any tobacco
products any place in the village, except as an authorized agent for
compliance enforcement.



Sec. 14-436. Peddling.



   No person shall peddle tobacco products and/or accessories in the
village.



Sec. 14-437. Complaint of violations.



   (a)   Any resident of the village shall have the right to file a
complaint with the local commissioner stating that any retail licensee has
been or is violating any provisions of this section of the Homewood Municipal
Code or of the Illinois tobacco control act, 35 ILCS 143/10-1 to 10-90 et
seq., and 720 ILCS 675, 680, 685 et seq. Such complaint shall be in writing
and shall be signed and sworn to by the parties complaining. The complaint
shall state the particular provisions believed to have been violated and the
facts in detail upon which the belief is based.



   (b)   If the local commissioner is satisfied that the complaint
substantially charges a violation and that from the facts alleged there is
reasonable cause for such belief, he/she shall set the matter for hearing and
shall serve notice upon the licensee of the time and place of such hearing
and of the particulars charged in the complaint.



Sec. 14-438. Responsibility of owner of premises.



   If the owner of the licensed premises or any person from whom the
licensee derives the  right to possession of such premises, or the agent 
of  such  person,  shall  knowingly permit the  licensee  to  use 
the  premises in  violation of the terms of the applicable provisions of
this section of the Homewood Municipal Code of the Illinois tobacco control
act, 35 ILCS 143/10-1 to 10-90 et seq., and 720 ILCS 675, 680, 685 et seq.,
the owner, agent or other person shall be deemed guilty of a violation of
this section to the same extent as such licensee and shall be subject to the
same penalties.



Sec. 14-439. Signs.



   Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided for herein
shall be posted by every licensee at or near every display of tobacco
products and/or accessories and on or upon every vending machine that offers
tobacco products for sale. Each sign shall be plainly visible and shall state:



      "THE SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS TO PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN YEARS OF
AGE IS PROHIBITED BY LAW"



Sec. 14-440. Acts of agent or employee.



   Every act or omission constituting a violation of any provision of this
section of the Homewood Municipal Code or of the Illinois tobacco control
act, 35 ILCS 143/10-1 to 10-90 et seq., and 720 ILCS 675, 680, 685 et seq.,
by any officer, director, manager, agent or employee of any licensee shall be
deemed and held to be the act of such employer or licensee. The employer or
licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if the act or omission had
been done or omitted by him/her personally.



Sec. 14-441. Responsibility of parents.



   It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian to knowingly suffer or
permit any minor child of which he/she may be the parent or guardian to
violate any provision of this section of the Homewood Municipal Code or of
the Illinois tobacco control act, 35 ILCS 143/10-1 to 10-90 et seq., and 720
ILCS 675, 680, 685 et seq.



Sec. 14-442. Responsibility of the owner or occupant of premises not licensed
to dispense tobacco products and/or accessories.



   It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of any premises,
residential or otherwise, located within the village, to knowingly allow any
person under the age of 18 years to remain on such premises while in the
possession of tobacco products and/or accessories, or while using any tobacco
products in violation of section 14-435. It shall also be unlawful for any
such owner or occupant on such premises to knowingly sell or give tobacco
products and/or accessories to any person under the age of 18 years or to
knowingly allow tobacco products and/or accessories to be given to any person
under the age of 18 years while on such premises, in violation of section
14-435.



Sec. 14-443. Unobstructed view of premises.



   In premises upon which over the counter sales, and/or vending machine
sales, of tobacco products and/or accessories are permitted by license, other
than hotels, department stores, grocery stores, and drug stores, there must
be a clear unobstructed view of the tobacco sale area inside the premises,
from the street, sidewalk or parking lot adjacent to the premises.



Secs. 14-444 - 14-460. Reserved.



Sec. 14-461. License required.



   No person shall sell or offer for sale or possess with intention to
sell at retail in the village any tobacco products and/or accessories without
a retailer's license from the village, in addition to a state license. No
person shall sell or offer for sale at retail in the village any tobacco
products and/or accessories in violation of the terms and conditions of the
license or in violation of any provision of this section of the Homewood
Municipal Code or of the Illinois tobacco control act, 35 ILCS 143/10-1 to
10-90 et seq., and 720 ILCS 675, 680, 685 et seq. The disbursement of tobacco
products and/or accessories without a license at any gathering, party or
other public or private affair when admission is charged for entrance,
whether or not an additional charge is made for disbursement of tobacco
products and/or accessories, shall constitute a violation of this article.



Sec. 14-462. Issuance restricted.



   Issuance of license is restricted for premises located in a residential
zone.



Sec. 14-463. Restrictions on sales.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, give away
or deliver tobacco products within one hundred feet (100') of any school or
other building used for education or recreational programs for persons under
the age of eighteen (18) years. Furthermore, it shall be unlawful for any
person to sell, offer for sale, give away or deliver tobacco products by the
use of a drive-up or a drive-thru window.



Sec. 14-464. Vending machine restrictions.



   It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell, offer for sale, give
away, deliver, or keep with the intention of selling, giving away or
delivering tobacco products by the use of a vending machine, unless such
vending machine is equipped with a manual, electric or electronic locking
device controlled by the licensee so as to prevent its operation by persons
under the age of eighteen (18) years.



Sec. 14-465. Applications.



   (a)   An applicant for a license or for renewal of a license from
the village shall submit an application to the local tobacco commissioner.
All new applications for a license shall include a nonrefundable $100.00
processing fee. The application shall be in writing, under oath, and shall be
signed by the applicant if an individual; or if the application is on the
behalf of a partnership, firm, association, club or corporation, then it
shall be signed and sworn to by at least two members of such partnership; or
by the president and secretary of such firm, club, association or corporation.



   (b)   The application shall state:



      1.   The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of
an individual or of all persons entitled to share in the profits in the case
of a co-partnership; in the case of a club or corporation, the name, date of
incorporation, the address and objects for which it was organized; the names
and address of all stockholders owning five percent or more of the stock; the
names and addresses of all officers of a club; and the number of members. A
partnership applicant must furnish a copy of its existing partnership
agreement with the application. A corporate applicant must furnish a
certified copy of its articles of incorporation with its application.



      2.   The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth, and
if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization.



      3.   The character of the business or operation with which the
desired license is to be used and the class or license for which application
is made.



      4.   The length of time that applicant has been in that
business or operation and the date at which that business or operation was
started in the village and in the case of a corporation, the date on which
its charter was issued.



      5.   Whether the applicant has ever made an application for a
license to retail tobacco products and or accessories on premises other than
described in this application. If the number of such applications exceeds
five, only those five geographically nearest the village need be listed.



      6.   The applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is
not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing
contained in this code, the laws of this state, or the laws of the United
States.



      7.   Whether a previous license by any state or municipality,
or by the federal government has been revoked or suspended and the reason
therefore.



      8.   The applicant is familiar with the laws of the United
States and of the state and or this village as they relate to retailers of
tobacco products and/or accessories that the applicant will not violate nor
permit his employees or agents to violate any of the laws of the United
States or of the state or the ordinances of this village in the conduct of
the business for which a license is desired.



   In addition to the information contained in this section, the
application shall contain such other and further information as the local
tobacco commissioner may prescribe by rule or regulation not inconsistent
with law.



Sec. 14-466. Sale permitted by license.




   A tobacco retailer licensee shall be allowed to sell any tobacco
product and/or accessories in the original package, including sales from a
vending machine.




(MC-928, § 1, 6-9-15)



Sec. 14-467. Contents; location.



   Licenses shall clearly indicate the class of license and the terms of
issuance, the name of the licensee, and the location of the premises.
Licenses issued under this article shall apply only to the premises described
in the application and in the license issued thereon, and only one location
shall be so described in each license.



Sec. 14-468. Fees.




   The annual fee for a tobacco retailer’s license shall be $400.00, due
and payable on May 1  of each year. Tobacco retailer license fees are in
addition to any other license or permit fees applicable to the tobacco
licensee’s business.




(MC-928, § 1, 6-9-15)



Sec. 14-469. Disposition of fees.



   One hundred percent of each license fee shall be credited to the
general fund of the village.



Sec. 14-470. Number limitations.




   There shall be no limit upon the number of tobacco retailer’s
licenses.




(MC-928, § 1, 6-9-15)



Sec. 14-471. Duration.



   Every license shall terminate on April 30 next following its issuance
unless sooner revoked or suspended. The fee for a new license shall be the
annual fee reduced in proportion to the number of full months that have
expired since the last prior May. The fee for renewal shall be the full
annual fee. There shall be no rebate for the un-expired term of a license. An
application for renewal shall not be considered as such unless made prior to
April 30, and unless submitted with the appropriate fee. No license shall be
valid unless the proper fee has been paid.



Sec. 14-472. Nature; renewal.



   A license shall be purely a personal privilege and shall be subject to
all the limitations and privileges set forth in this section of the Homewood
Municipal code and of the Illinois tobacco control act, 35 ILCS 143/10-1 to
10-90 et seq., and 720 ILCS 675, 680, 685 et seq., as amended from time to
time.



Sec. 14-473. Change of location.



   After a license has been granted for a particular premises, the local
tobacco control commissioner, upon application by the licensee, may endorse
upon the licensee permission to abandon the premises thereon described and to
remove the license to other premises approved by him/her and described in the
endorsement. The application for transfer shall be in writing under oath and
shall fully describe the new premises. The reasons for transfer shall be
given, and it shall be shown that the new premises complies in all respects
with the requirements of the Homewood Municipal Code and of the Illinois
tobacco control act, 35 ILCS 143/10-1 to 10-90 et seq., and/or 720 ILCS 675,
680, 685 et seq., as amended from time to time.



Sec. 14-474. Display.



   Every licensee shall cause his license to be framed and hung in plain
view in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises.



Sec. 14-475. Suspension, fine and revocation.



   The local commissioner may suspend any local license issued by the
village and/or impose a fine not to exceed $100.00 if he/she determines that
the licensee has violated any provision of the Homewood Municipal Code or of
the Illinois Tobacco Control Act, 35 ILCS 143/10-1 to 10-90 et seq., and/or
720 ILCS 675, 680, 685 et seq. The local commissioner may revoke any local
license issued by the village if he determines that the licensee is guilty of
any such violation on three separate occasions during any twelve-month
period. In such case there shall be no refund of the license fee. These
penalties shall be in addition to any other penalties that may be assessed
for a conviction of any such violation in a court of law. When any license
shall have been revoked, no license shall be granted to any person for the
period of one year thereafter for the sale of tobacco products and/or
accessories on the premises described in the revoked license.



Secs. 14-476—14-484.  Reserved.



ARTICLE XIV. OFF-TRACK BETTING FACILITIES



Sec. 14-485. Definitions.



   The following words, terms, and phrases when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Off-track betting facility means any establishment, or portion thereof,
where inter-track or simulcast wagering is conducted under authority of the
Illinois Horse Racing Act of 1975 (230 ILCS 26/1 et seq.) If an off-track
betting facility is located within a larger establishment where food,
beverage, or similar amenities are offered, only the room or rooms where
wagering is conducted shall be considered an off-track betting facility for
purposes of this article.



   Wagering is the act of placing a bet as authorized by the Illinois
Horse Racing Act of 1975, either by tendering money to an employee of the
off-track betting facility or by use of a wagering machine. Furthermore,
wagering shall also include and the payment of any winnings from the placing
of said bets.



(MC-785, § 1, 9-11-07)



Sec. 14-486. Persons under age 21 prohibited within off-track betting
facility.



   No person shall permit any person under the age of 21 to enter or
remain upon the premises of any off-track betting facility. However, if an
off-track betting facility is located within a restaurant, this prohibition
shall not apply to employees of the restaurant while they are on duty.



(MC-785, § 1, 9-11-07)



Sec. 14-487. Posting of age restriction required.



   The property owner where any off-track betting facility is located
shall prominently post a notice at every public entrance to such facility of
the age restriction contained in this article. The notice shall state: "Entry
limited to persons 21 years of age or older," or similar language that
conveys the age limitation contained in this article.  If an off-track
betting facility is located within a larger establishment where food,
beverage, or similar amenities are offered, notice shall be placed at the
entrance to the room or rooms where wagering is conducted. If wagering is
conducted in all public rooms within a facility, such notice shall be placed
at all exterior doors of the building where the public may enter.



(MC-785, § 1, 9-11-07)



Sec. 14-488. Hours of Operation.



   (a)   No off-track betting facility shall operate between the
following hours:



      (1)   11:00 p.m. Sunday and 11:00 a.m. Monday;



      (2)   11:00 p.m. Monday and 11:00 a.m. Tuesday;



      (3)   11:00 p.m. Tuesday and 11:00 a.m. Wednesday;



      (4)   11:00 p.m. Wednesday and 11:00 a.m. Thursday;



      (5)   11:00 p.m. Thursday and 11:00 a.m. Friday;



      (6)   12:01 a.m. and 11:00 a.m. on Saturday;



      (7)   12:01 a.m. and 11:00 a.m. on Sunday.



   (b)   Upon written approval of the Village President, the off-track
betting facility may be allowed to operate beginning at 8:00 a.m. on days
when a race of national or international significance occurs.  Such approval
shall be solely within the discretion of the village and shall be limited to
no more than ten days per year.



   (c)   If an off-track betting facility is located within a
restaurant or similar facility, this shall not prohibit the restaurant from
admitting the public, provided that this right to remain open for other
activities shall not grant any right to conduct wagering during such
restricted hours.



(MC-785, § 1, 9-11-07; MC-801, § 1, 3-25-08)



Sec. 14-489. Inspections to ensure article compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(MC-785, § 1, 9-11-07)
