village manager. A new application shall be made to renew any license at its
expiration. All holders of licenses or permits shall be responsible for
reporting any changes in initial application data immediately as such occur.
Based upon initial application data, the village manager shall cause billing
of the appropriate license fee to be rendered. Additional billing due to
changes in or corrections to initial application data shall be rendered as
required and shall be retroactive to the date of such change. Forms of
licenses and permits shall be prescribed and furnished by the village manager.



(Code 1965, § 41.01(c))



Sec. 26-34. Issuance.



   (a)   Generally. All licenses or permits, unless  otherwise
designated  in  this  Code,  shall be  granted and  signed by the 
village manager or  his designee.  Any application may be ordered by the
board of trustees to be presented to and approved by the board before
issuance of a permit or license. Any applicant for a license or permit, upon
request, shall be entitled to appeal to the board of trustees in connection
with the village manager's denial of an application.



   (b)   Refusal to grant or renew. The village may refuse to grant and
renew any license:



      (1)   If the applicant, any corporate officer of the
applicant, any partner of the applicant in the activity sought to be licensed
or any agent of the applicant who will represent the applicant in connection
with the activities sought to be licensed has been convicted of a felony.



      (2)   If the business or activities sought to be licensed is
deemed to be one that would constitute a breach of the peace or a detriment;
a menace to the health, safety or welfare of the public; or a disturbance of
the peace or comfort of the residents of the village, if it were licensed.



      (3)   If the business or activities sought to be licensed
would be conducted in violation of any laws of the United States or the state
or ordinance of the village.



      (4)   If the business or activities sought to be licensed
would, if licensed, cause a reduction in value of nearby or surrounding
residential or commercially used property.



      (5)   If any applicant for a license or renewal of a license
has outstanding fees, fines, taxes, or debts due to the village, including
but not limited to water and sewer charges, places for eating tax, hotel
accommodations tax, or fines imposed after administrative adjudication of a
local ordinance violation. If the proposed licensee is a corporation, limited
liability company or similar entity, the term “applicant” as used in this
subsection shall include any stockholder, member, or partner owning at least
a five percent interest in the licensed entity.



(Code 1965, § 41.01(d))  (MC-948, § 1, 2-23-16)



Sec. 26-35. Bond.



   When a bond is required for the issuance of any license or permit, such
bond must be issued by a surety company authorized to do business in the
state and approved by the board of trustees and must be filed with the
village clerk before the license or permit is issued. The village manager may
in any case require an appropriate bond from a licensee where deemed
necessary to protect the village. If a license is denied, the bond will be
refunded.



(Code 1965, § 41.01(e))



Sec. 26-36. Investigations and inspections.



   (a)   Upon the receipt of an application for a license or permit
where ordinances of the village necessitate an inspection or investigation
before the issuance of such permit or license, the village manager shall
refer such application to the designated officer to make such investigation.
The officer charged with the duty of making the investigation or inspection
shall make a written report thereon.



   (b)   The director of community development shall make or cause to
be made an inspection in regard to licenses in the connection with the
handling of food, the preventing of nuisances, the spread of disease, and for
the protection of health. The building inspector shall make or cause to be
made all required inspections relative to the construction of buildings or
other structures. All other investigations except where otherwise provided,
shall be made by the chief of police or by some other officer designated by
the manager. Whenever inspections of the premises used for or in connection
with the operation of a licensed business, occupation or activity are
provided for or required by this Code, or are reasonably necessary to secure
compliance with any ordinance provision, it shall be the duty of the
licensee, or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected, to admit
thereto for the purpose of making the inspection any officer or employee of
the village who is authorized or directed to make such inspection at any
reasonable time that admission is requested



   (c)   Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is
reasonably necessary to ensure conformance with any ordinance provision, it
shall be the duty of the licensee of the village whose business is governed
by such provision to give to any authorized officer or employee of the
village requesting the same, sufficient samples of such material or commodity
for such analysis upon request.



(Code 1965, § 41.01(f); MC-800, § 1, 3-11-08)



Sec. 26-37. Fees.



   (a)   The fees required for a license or permit must be paid prior
to issuance of a license or permit, unless the license or permit provides
otherwise, in which case payment shall be made in accordance with the
requirements of the license or permit. If a license is not issued, the fee
will be refunded. No license fee shall be accepted for less than the full
amount due; provided, however, that the license fee for any commercial
establishment first commencing operation on or after November 1 of any year
shall be reduced by 50 percent, excluding food inspection fees established in
paragraph (b) below. Unless otherwise provided, no rebate or refund of any
license fee shall be made because of discontinuance, failure or other
operational interruption of any commercial establishment. The license fee
shall be set forth under each individual section of this chapter; provided,
however, that those businesses licensed on a square footage basis shall pay a
fee based on the following schedule:



0 - 5,000 square feet of  useable area          $100.00



Over 5,000 square feet of useable area       $200.00



   (b) Whenever a business includes a food handling operation, that
business shall pay, in addition to the fee established in paragraph (a), an
additional licensing fee equivalent to the cost of the health inspections
conducted by Cook County on the premises during the year.



(MC-825, § 1, 2-9-10; MC-914, § 1, 10-28-14; MC-926, § 1, 6-9-15)



Sec. 26-38. Terms.



   All licenses or permits issued for a fixed term stated in the license
or permit shall automatically expire at midnight of the final day of that
term of the license or permit. All annual licenses or permits not issued for
a stated fixed term shall expire on April 30 following the date of issue.



(Code 1965, § 41.01(h))



Sec. 26-39. Notice of termination.



   If a license extends beyond one month, it shall be the duty of the
village manager, 30 days prior to the termination of the license period, to
cause a written notice to be mailed to each licensee stating that a new
license will be required on the day following the expiration of his existing
license and stating also the amount of the license fee and the penalty for
failure to procure a license in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter. Failure on the part of the village manager to cause such notice to
be mailed to any such licensee shall not waive the requirement that a license
be procured, nor constitute a waiver of any provision of this article.



(Code 1965, § 41.01(I))



Sec. 26-40. Change of location.



   If any person who conducts any business under a village license, which
license designates a particular place in which such licensed business is to
be conducted, shall, before the expiration of such license, change the
location of such place of business, he shall notify the village manager in
writing of such fact at least 20 days prior to the change describing both the
new and the old location. No business shall be conducted under the authority
of such license at such new location, until written notice of such change has
been given and approved by the village manager. The village manager may
require inspections to ensure that the new premises are in compliance with
all applicable codes of the village. The fee for such transfer of location
shall be $25.00, unless otherwise specified in this chapter. (Code 1965, §
41.01(j))



Sec. 26-41.  Posting licenses.



   Every license certificate granted for the purpose of conducting any
business or which designates the particular room, store, office or place in
which such business is to be conducted shall be posted at all times in a
conspicuous place, so that the certificate may easily be seen, upon the wall
of the principal room or office of the place in which such licensed business
is carried on. No license which is not in force shall be permitted to remain
posted upon the wall or upon any part of any place of business after the
period of such license has expired.



(Code 1965, § 41.01(k))



Sec. 26-42. Recordkeeping.



   The village manager shall cause to be kept a record of every license
and permit issued, the amount of fee paid, the purpose for which such license
or permit was issued, the location where the licensed or permitted privilege
is to be exercised and the name of the licensee or person receiving the
permit.



(Code 1965, § 41.01(l))



Sec. 26-43. Condition of premises.



   No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business, and no
permit shall be issued for any thing or act, if the premises and building to
be used for the purpose do not fully comply with the requirements of the
village building, fire and  health codes.  No such license or permit shall
be issued for the conduct of any business or  performance of any act which
would constitute a violation of the zoning ordinance of the village. (Code
1965, § 41.01(m))



Sec. 26-44. Waiver of fee.



   Whenever, in the opinion of the board of trustees, it is to the best
interests of the public welfare, and the license or permit sought is for
charitable purposes or for the village or a department of the village, or
sponsored by some charitable, religious or not-for-profit association or
group of persons, the license or permit fee provided for may be waived. In no
case shall the filing of an application be waived.



(Code 1965, § 41.01)



Sec. 26-45. Suspension and revocation of licenses and permits.



   (a)   Any license or permit issued by the village may be suspended
or revoked by the village manager or board of trustees for any of the
following causes:



      (1)   Fraud, misrepresentation or incorrect statement
contained in the application for license, or made in carrying on the licensed
activity.



      (2)   Conviction of a felony or offense involving moral
turpitude by the licensee, any corporate officer of the licensee, any partner
of the licensee in the licensed business, or any agent of the licensee acting
in behalf of the licensee in connection with the licensed activity.



      (3)   Conducting such licensed activity in such  manner as 
to constitute a breach of the peace; a menace to the health, safety or
welfare of the public; or a disturbance of the peace or comfort of residents
of the village, upon recommendation of the fire chief, police chief, or other
appropriate village official.



      (4)   Expiration or cancellation of any required bond or
insurance.



      (5)   Actions unauthorized or beyond the scope of the license
granted.



      (6)   Violation of any regulation or provision of this chapter
applicable to the activity for which the license has been granted, or any
state or federal statute or administrative regulation so applicable.



      (7)   Failure to continuously comply with all conditions
required as precedent to the approval of the license and all conditions
specifically stated in the license.



      (8)   Conviction of a felony or offense involving moral
turpitude by any lessee or agent of the lessee of the licensee, if such
conviction was the result of conduct or activity occurring on the licensed
premises.



      (9)   A clear and present danger to the welfare of village
residents arising out of any violation by the licensee of this Code, its
license or permit or the statutes of the state or the United States.



   (b)   No license or permit shall be suspended or revoked, except as
provided in subsection (c) of this section until notice has been given to the
licensee, provided in this section, a reasonable time not to exceed seven
days has elapsed to enable the licensee to comply with the provisions of this
Code and applicable state statutes, and the licensee has been given the
opportunity to appear at a hearing as provided in section 26-46. Such
suspension or revocation of a license or permit may be in addition to any
fine imposed by this Code. No licensee or permit holder whose license or
permit has been revoked shall be eligible for a new license or permit during
the period for which the revoked license was originally issued.



   (c)   Anything in this section or following this section
notwithstanding, the village manager may suspend, for a period not to exceed
30 days, without prior warning, notice or hearing, any license or permit
issued under this article during the terms of such license or permit, for the
failure of any licensee or permit holder to comply with any provision of this
Code, any statutes of the state or its license or permit, relating to the
business, occupation or activity for which such license or permit was issued
if, in the judgment of the village manager, such failure constitutes a clear
and present danger to the public health or safety.



   (d)   Any licensee or permit holder whose license or permit is
suspended or revoked shall immediately discontinue the business, occupation
or activity for which the license or permit was issued. Each day the licensee
or permit holder continues to do business after a license suspension or
revocation shall constitute a separate violation of this Code.



   (e)   Any licensee or permit holder whose license or permit is
suspended may, at any time, either petition in writing the village manager or
village board for a hearing or make written application to the village
manager for reinspection for the purpose of reinstatement of the license or
permit. Any such hearing shall be held as soon as possible and shall be
conducted at a time and place designated by the village manager except that
if the license in question was one initially granted by the board of
trustees, any such hearing shall be before the board of trustees. Based upon
the record of such hearing, the village board or village manager, as the case
may be, shall make a finding and shall sustain, modify or rescind any
official notice or order considered in the hearing. A written report of the
hearing decision shall be furnished to the licensee or permit holder within
seven days after the hearing is concluded.



(Code 1965, § 41.01(o); MC-800, § 1, 3-11-08)



Sec. 26-46. Hearing—Generally.



   Hearings as to license or permit suspension or revocation shall be
conducted by the board of trustees or village manager, as appropriate, at a
time and place designated by the board of trustees or village manager.
Hearing as to any suspension or revocation of a license initially granted by
the board of trustees shall be before the board of trustees. Based upon the
record of such hearing, the board of trustees or village manager, as the case
may be, shall take whatever action is deemed appropriate within their
respective powers as found in this Code and under  the  laws of the
state.  A  written  report  of the  hearing decision shall be 
furnished  to  the licensee or permit holder within seven days of the
hearing. The license holder or permit holder may appeal from any decision of
the village manager  at any such hearing, to the board of trustees, by
giving written notice of a request for consideration by the board of trustees
of the manager’s decision. The notice must be received by the village
within seven working days from the receipt by the license holder or permit
holder of the written decision of the hearing.



(Code 1965, § 41.01(p))



Sec. 26-47. Same--Notice.



   (a)   When the board of trustees or village manager are aware of
conditions which may justify the suspension or revocation of a license or
permit and schedule a hearing in that regard, written notice of that hearing
shall be given to the licensee or permit holder. That notification shall set
forth the specific nature of the noncompliance, violation discovered or other
reason for the scheduled hearing, shall establish a specific and reasonable
period of time for the correction of such situation by the licensee or permit
holder, and shall state that failure to comply with the notice within that
time may result in the suspension or revocation of the license or permit. The
notice shall further state that the licensee or permit holder may request a
hearing before the board of trustees or village manager. If such a written
request is received by the village within the time allowed the licensee or
permit holder to comply, as provided in the notice, no action to suspend or
revoke a license shall be taken by the village until such a hearing is held.



   (b)   Any such notice shall be deemed to have been properly served
when it has been delivered personally to the licensee or permit holder or
when it has been sent by registered or certified mail, to the last known
residence or business address of the licensee or permit holder.



(Code 1965, § 41.01(q); MC-877, § 1, 9-11-12)



Secs. 26-48--26-75. Reserved.



ARTICLE III. COMMERCIAL EXHIBITIONS



Sec. 26-76. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Exhibition means displaying samples or models of merchandise in a show
which is open to the public.



(Code 1965, § 41.12(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 26-77. License--Required.



   No person shall conduct or operate any exhibition without having first
secured a license therefor.



(Code 1965, § 41.12(b))



Sec. 26-78. Same--Application.



   Applications for exhibition licenses shall be made upon such forms as
prescribed by the village.



(Code 1965, § 41.12(c))



Sec. 26-79. Same--Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations shall be as follows:



      (1)   The licensee shall be responsible to ensure that areas
used for the exhibition shall be cleaned and returned to their normal
condition at the conclusion of that activity.



      (2)   It shall be unlawful to present, exhibit or conduct any
obscene exhibition, as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-20(b).



      (3)   It shall be unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to
witness any such exhibition as to create a dangerous condition because of
fire or other risks.



      (4)   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell any
merchandise being displayed at a licensed exhibition without first having
obtained an itinerant merchant license in addition to the exhibition license.



(Code 1965, § 41.12(d))



Sec. 26-80. Same--Fee.



   The fee for an exhibition license shall be $40.00 per day. In addition
to the license fee prescribed for exhibitions, the board of trustees may
require that the premises in, or on which the exhibition is conducted, is
policed, and in such case may require the attendance of one or more reserve
or regular police officers or firefighters at the place of such exhibition,
at the expense of the licensee. The licensee shall deposit with the village,
in advance, a sufficient amount to cover the additional expense.



(Code 1965, § 41.12(e))



Sec. 26-81. Inspections to ensure compliance with article.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.12(f))



Secs. 26-82--26-105. Reserved.



ARTICLE IV. AUCTIONEERS*



*State law reference(s)--Authority to license and regulate, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1.



Sec. 26-106. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Auctioneer means an individual or person employed to sell or put up
material goods, chattel or real estate at auction for another or for himself,
regardless of who owns such property.



(Code 1965, § 41.05(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 26-107. License--Required.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct an auction in the
village or to do business as an  auctioneer, whether the goods sold are
owned by the auctioneer or not, without having first obtained a license
therefor. The provisions of this article shall not be applicable to auction
sales conducted by public officers acting under judicial order or process, or
by virtue of any power or authority contained in a mortgage or trust deed.



(Code 1965, § 41.05(b))



Sec. 26-108. Same--Application.



   Applications for auctioneer licenses shall be made upon such forms as
prescribed by the village. Such application shall include the place of such
auction and the name of any employee who is to be authorized to conduct
auctions under the authority of the license, and the location and time of
such auction.



(Code 1965, § 41.05(c))



Sec. 26-109. Same--Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations are as follows:



      (1)   Auctions shall not be conducted between the hours of
12:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m.



      (2)   All provisions of this article relating to an auctioneer
shall apply equally to any employee of an auctioneer.



      (3)   No more than two persons may conduct auctions under the
authority of any license.



      (4)   It shall be the duty of every auctioneer before
beginning an auction of any kind whatever, to state fully the terms and
conditions upon which the sale will be made and to announce to the persons
present the character, quality and description of the property offered for
sale.



      (5)   No auctioneer shall sell or offer for sale at public
auction any real or personal property at or in any place other than that
which is designated in his license.



      (6)   No real or personal property shall be sold at auction,
or shall be exposed for sale, by any person in or on any public street or
public area in the village.



      (7)   It shall be the responsibility of the licensed
auctioneer to ensure that individuals attending the auction do not trespass
on private property adjacent to the auction site.



      (8)   No auctioneer shall procure any person to make a
fictitious bid, or shall conspire with any person to make a fictitious bid,
or shall himself fictitiously raise any bids at any auction sale of real or
personal property.



      (9)   It shall be the responsibility of the licensed
auctioneer to ensure that individuals attending the auction do not obstruct
any public thoroughfare so as to endanger the safety of individuals as well
as the general public.



(Code 1965, § 41.05(d))



Sec. 26-110. Same--Fee.



   The fee for an auctioneer license shall be $40.00 per day.



(Code 1965, § 41.05(e))



Sec. 26-111. Inspections to ensure article compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.05(f))



Secs. 26-112--26-140. Reserved.



ARTICLE V. FILLING STATIONS*



   *Cross reference(s)--Traffic and vehicles, ch. 106.



Sec. 26-141. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Filling station means any store, service station, garage, lot or other
place at which equipment is provided for dispensing motor fuel to the public.



(Code 1965, § 41.13(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 26-142. License--Required.



   No person shall operate or maintain a filling station without first
having secured a license therefor.



(Code 1965, § 41.13(b))



Sec. 26-143. Same--Application.



   Applications for filling station licenses shall be made upon such forms
as prescribed by the village.



(Code 1965, § 41.13(c))



Sec. 26-144. Same--Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations shall be as follows:



      (1)   No pump shall be located within a building.



      (2)   Every filling station shall be provided with adequate
and conveniently located toilet facilities for its employees and customers,
conforming with the ordinances of the village. Toilet rooms shall be kept in
a clean condition, in good repair, and well lighted and ventilated.



      (3)   No building, structure, or part thereof shall be used in
any way so as to endanger the health or property of the employees or of the
public. The owner, lessee, tenant, occupant, or manager of any such business
shall cause all floors or other surfaces to be kept in good order and repair
and shall have suitable and convenient sanitary receptacles for receiving
wastes.



      (4)   No partially dismantled, nonoperable, or wrecked motor
vehicle shall be stored on the service station premises longer than 15 days,
except as a direct, immediate, and necessary incident to its repair.



      (5)   It shall be unlawful for any person to change the
identification marks on the engine of any car or automobile. If any
alteration or obliteration of any engine number is discovered, the village
police shall be notified immediately and the vehicle held until released by
the village police department.



      (6)   Notification shall be made immediately to the chief of
police when any motor vehicle with gunshot damage is brought to the licensed
business, giving the license number, serial number, engine number, make,
model, year, and color of the vehicle and the name, address, sex, race, and
approximate age of the person who brought the vehicle, or so much of such
information as can be obtained.



(Code 1965, § 41.13(d))



Sec. 26-145. Same--Fee.



   The annual license fee for a filling station shall be on a square
footage basis, as described in section 26-37.



(Code 1965, § 41.13(e))



Sec. 26-146. Inspections to ensure compliance with article provisions.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.13(f))



Secs. 26-147--26-175. Reserved.



ARTICLE VI. FOOD DEALERS



Sec. 26-176. Definitions.



The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context
clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Retail food establishment shall mean either a food service
establishment or a retail food store.



   Food dealer means, but shall not be limited to, any restaurant, retail
grocery, meat market, poultry market, fresh fruit and vegetable market,
delicatessen, confectionery, candy kitchen, nut store, retail bakery or other
establishment, whether fixed or mobile, where food intended for human
consumption is manufactured, produced, stored, prepared, handled,
transported, sold or is offered for retail sale.



   Food delivery vehicle means any vehicle used for the purpose of
storage, carrying or selling of any food intended for human consumption,
including beverages.



   Food vending machine means any self-service device offered for public
use which, upon insertion of a coin or token, or by other means, dispenses
unit servings of food or beverage, either in bulk or in package, without the
necessity of replenishing the device between each vending operation.



(Code 1965, § 41.14(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 26-177. License--Required.



   The issuance, suspension, and revocation of permits, licenses, or
certificates to operate retail food establishments; the prohibiting of the
sale of unsound or mislabeled food or drink; and the enforcement of this
ARTICLE VI shall be regulated in accordance with Section 26-178 of this
ARTICLE VI concerning the compliance procedures. The inspection of food
service establishments shall be regulated in accordance with the 1998 and all
subsequent editions of, or amendments to, the Illinois Department of Public
Health's publication currently title, "Food Service Sanitation Code" that are
on file with the Secretary of State. The inspection of retail food stores
shall be regulated in accordance with the 1992 and all subsequent editions
of, or amendments to, the Illinois Department of Public Health's publication
currently titled, "Retail Food Sanitation Code", that are on file with the
Secretary of State.



Sec. 26-178. Sanitation Codes.



   Three copies of each of the Illinois Department of Public Health's
publications currently titled, "Food Service Sanitation Code", and "Retail
Food Store Sanitation Code", shall be on file at the Village Clerk's office.



Sec. 26-179. Compliance Procedures -- General.



   No person shall operate a food establishment who does not have a valid
permit, license, or certificate issued to them by the Village. Only a person
who complies with the requirements of this Article VI shall be entitled to
receive or retain such a permit license, or certificate. Permits, licenses or
certificates are not transferable. A valid permit, license or certificate
shall be posted in every food establishment.



Sec. 26-180. Issuance of Permit, License, or Certificate.



   (a)   Any person desiring to operate a food establishment shall make
written application for a permit, license, or certificate on forms provided
by the Village. Such application shall include the name, address of each
application, the location and type of the proposed food establishment, and
the signature of each applicant.



   (b)   Prior to approval of an application for a permit, license, or
certificate, the Village and the Cook County Department of Public Health
shall inspect the proposed food establishment to determine compliance with
the requirements of this Article VI.



   (c)   The Village shall issue a permit, license, or certificate to
the applicant if its inspection reveals that the proposed food establishment
to determine compliance with the requirements of this Article VI.



Sec. 26-181. Suspension of Permit, License or Certificate.



   (a)   The Village may, without warning, notice, or hearing suspend
any permit, license, or certificate to operate a food establishment if the
holder of the permit, license, or certificate does not comply with the
requirements of this Article VI, or if the operation of the food
establishment otherwise constitutes a substantial hazard to the public health.



   Suspension is effective upon service of the notice required by Section
(b) of this Article VI. When a permit, license, or certificate is suspended,
food operations shall immediately cease. Whenever a permit, license, or
certificate is suspended, the holder of the permit license, or certificate
shall be afforded the opportunity for hearing within twenty (20) days of
receipt of a request for hearing.



   (b)   Whenever a permit, license, or certificate is suspended, the
holder of the permit, license, or certificate or the person in charge shall
be notified in writing that the permit, license, or certificate is, upon
service of the notice, immediately suspended and that an opportunity for
hearing will be provided if a written request for hearing is filed with the
Village by the holder of the permit, license, or certificate within ten (10)
days. If no written request for hearing is filed within ten (10) days, the
suspension is sustained. The Village may end the suspension at any time if
reasons for suspension no longer exist.



Sec. 26-182.  Revocation of Permit, License, or Certificate.



   (a)   The Village may, after providing opportunity for hearing,
revoke the permit, license, or certificate for serious or repeated violations
of any of the requirements of this Article VI or for the interference with
the Village or the Cook County Department of Public Health in the performance
of duty.



   (b)   Prior to revocation, the Village shall notify, in writing, the
holder of the permit, license, or certificate, or the person in charge, of
the specific reason(s) for which the permit, license, or certificate is to be
revoked and that the permit, license, or certificate is to be revoked at the
end of the ten (10) days following service of such notice unless a written
request for hearing is filed with the Village by the holder of the permit,
license, or certificate within such ten (10) day period, the revocation of
the permit, license, or certificate becomes final.



Sec. 26-183. Service of Notices.



   A notice provided for in this Article VI is properly served when it is
delivered to the holder of the permit, license, or certificate, or the person
in charge, or when it is sent by registered or certified mail, to the last
known address of the holder of the permit, license, or certificate. A copy of
the notice shall be filed in the records of the Village.



(MC-877, § 1, 9-11-12)



Sec. 26-184. Hearings.



   The hearings provided for in this Article VI shall be conducted by the
Village at a time and place designated by it. Any oral testimony given at a
hearing shall be reported verbatim, and the presiding officer shall make
provision for sufficient copies of the transcript. The Village shall make a
final finding based upon the complete hearing record and shall sustain,
modify, or rescind any notice or order considered in the hearing. A written
report to the hearing decision shall be furnished to the holder of the
permit, license, or certificate by the Village.



Sec. 26-185.   Application After Revocation.



   Whenever a revocation of a permit, license, or certificate has become
final, the holder of the revoked permit, license, or certificate may make
written application for a new permit, license, or certificate.



Sec. 26-186. Inspection Frequency.



   An inspection of a food establishment shall be performed at a frequency
prescribed by the Village. Additional inspections of the food establishment
shall be performed as often as necessary for the enforcement of this Article
VI.



Sec. 26-187.   Access.



   Duly authorized representatives of the Village or the Cook County
Department of Public Health, after proper identification, shall be permitted
to enter any food establishment at any reasonable time for the purpose of
making inspections to determine compliance with this Article VI. The
representatives shall be permitted to examine the records of the
establishment to obtain information pertaining to food and supplies purchase,
received, or used.



Sec. 26-189.   Correction of Violations.



   (a)   The completed inspection form shall specify a reasonable
period of time for the correction of the violations found; and correction of
the violations shall be accomplished within the period specified, in
accordance with the following provisions:



      (1)   If an imminent health hazard exists, such as complete
lack of refrigeration or sewage backup into the establishment, establishment
shall immediately cease food operations. Operations shall not be resumed
until authorized by the Cook County Department of Public Health.



      (2)   All violations of four (4) or five (5) point weighted
items shall be corrected as soon as possible, but in any event, within ten
(10) days following inspection. A follow-up inspection to confirm correction
may be conducted at the discretion of the Cook County Department of Public
Health.



      (3)   All one (1) or two (2) weighted items shall be corrected
as soon as possible, but in any event, by the time of the next routine
inspection.



      (4)   When the rating score of the establishment is less than
sixty (60), the establishment shall initiate corrective action on all
identified violations within forty-eight (48) hours. One or more
reinspections may be conducted at reasonable time intervals to assure
correction.



      (5)   In the case of temporary food establishment, all
violations shall be corrected within twenty-four (24) hours. If violations
are not corrected within twenty-four (24) hours, the establishment shall
immediately cease food operations until authorized to resume by the Cook
County Department of Public Health.



   (b)   The inspection report shall state that failure to comply with
any time limits for corrections may result in cessation of food operations.
An opportunity for hearing on the inspection findings or the time limitations
or both will be provided of a written request is filed with the Village
within ten (10) days following cessation of operations. If a request for
hearing is received, a hearing shall be held within twenty (20) days of
receipt of the request.



   (c)   Whenever a food establishment is required under provisions of
Section 26-181 to cease operations, it shall not resume operations until it
is shown on reinspection that conditions responsible for the order to cease
operations no longer exist. Opportunity for reinstatement shall be offered
within a reasonable time.



Sec. 26-190. Inspection Report Form.



   Results of inspections shall be recorded on such forms in use at the
current time by the Cook County Department of Public Health for this purpose.



Sec. 26-191. Examination and Condem-nation of Food.



   Food may be examined or sampled by the Cook County department of Public
Health as often as necessary for enforcement of this Article VI. The Cook
County Department of Public Health may, upon written notice to the owner or
person in charge, specifying with particularity the reasons therefore, place
a hold order on any food which it believes is in violation of Sections
750.100, 750.110. 760.100 or 760.110 of the Illinois Department of Public
Health's "Food Service Sanitation Code" or the "Retail Food Store Sanitation
Code", respectively, or any other section of this Article VI. The Cook County
Department of Public Health shall tag, label, or otherwise identify any food
subject to the hold order. No food subject to a hold order shall be used,
served, or moved from the establishment. The Cook County Department of Public
Health shall permit storage of the food under conditions specified in the
hold order, unless storage is not possible without risk to the public health,
in which case immediate destruction shall be ordered and accomplished. The
hold order shall state that a request for hearing may be filed within ten
(10) days and that if no hearing is requested the food shall be destroyed. If
a request for hearing is received, the hearing shall be held within twenty
(20) days after receipt of the request. On the basis of evidence produced at
that hearing, the hold order may be vacated, or the owner or person in charge
of the food may be directed by written order to denature or destroy such food
or to bring it into compliance with the provisions of this Article VI.



Sec. 26-192. Submission of Plans.



   Whenever a food establishment is constructed or extensively remodeled
and whenever an existing structure is converted to use as a food
establishment, properly prepared plans and specifications for such
construction, remodeling, or conversion shall be submitted to the Village and
the Cook County Department of Public Health for review and approval before
construction, remodeling, or conversion is begun. The plans and
specifications shall indicate the proposed layout, arrangement, mechanical
plans, and construction materials of work areas, and the type and model of
proposed fixed equipment and facilities. The Village and the Cook County
Department of Public Health shall approve the plans and specifications if
they meet the requirements of this Article VI. No food establishment shall be
constructed, extensively remodeled, or converted except in accordance with
plans and specifications approved by the Village and the Cook County
Department of Public Health.



Sec. 26-193. Pre-Operational Inspection.



   Whenever plans and specifications are required by Sec. 26-192 of this
Article VI to be submitted to the Village and the Cook County Department of
Public Health, the Village and the Cook County Department of Public Health
shall inspect the food establishment prior to the start of operations, to
determine compliance with the approved plans and specifications and with the
requirements of this Article VI.



Sec. 26-194. Procedure when infection is suspected.



   When the Cook County Department of Public Health has reasonable cause
to suspect possible disease transmission by an employee of a food
establishment, it may secure a morbidity history of the suspected employee or
make any other investigation as indicated and shall take appropriate action.
The Cook County Department of Public Health may require any or all of the
following measures:



   (a)   The immediate exclusion of the employee from employment in
food establishments.



   (b)   The immediate closing of the food establishment concerned
until, in the opinion of the Cook County Department of Public Health, no
further danger of disease outbreak exists;



   (c)   Restriction of the employee's services to some area of the
establishment where there would be no danger of transmitting disease;



   (d)   Adequate medical and laboratory examination of the employee
and of other employees and of his or their body discharges.



Sec. 26-195. Fees.



   The annual fee for a food dealer license shall be on a square footage
basis as described in Section 26-37.



   In the event a reinspection is deemed necessary by the inspector, the
cost shall be borne by the holder of the permit, license or certificate at
the rate of $75.00 per reinspection.



   The annual fee for a food delivery vehicle shall be $75.00 per vehicle.



   The annual fee for a food vending machine shall be $50.00 per
machine.(MC-766, §1, 9-12-06)



Sec. 26-196. Conditional Permit, License or Certificate.



   When structural, plumbing, electrical, ventilation, or similar such
defects exist in an established food facility that may require significant
expenditures to correct, but are not considered to be imminent health
hazards, a conditional permit, license, or certificate may be granted at the
discretion of the Village. Under no circumstances will a conditional permit,
license, or certificate be issued for more than two (2) consecutive twelve
(12) month periods. The purpose of the conditional license or permit is to
allow a reasonable period of time for correction of existing defects.



Sec. 26-197. Penalties.



   Any person violating the provisions of this Article VI shall be fined
not more than Seven Hundred Fifty Dollars ($750) for each offense, and a
separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a
violation continues.



Sec. 26-198. Injunctions.



   The Village shall have the right to enjoin any person or establishment
in the event violations occur on a continuing basis.



Secs. 26-199--26-210. Reserved.



ARTICLE VII. LAUNDRIES AND DRY CLEANERS



Sec. 26-211. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Agents for dry cleaners or laundries means any person soliciting dry
cleaning or laundry in the village, but not operating a dry cleaning or
laundry establishment therein.



   Automatic dry cleaner means any place, building, structure, room,
establishment or portion of same having within such premises one or more
automatic dry cleaning machines which are rented, leased or hired out to the
general public for a consideration and for use upon such premises.



   Dry cleaning establishment means and includes any structure, store,
building, or other place for the service of dry cleaning, wet cleaning and a
process incidental to dry cleaning, dyeing, spotting, and/or finishing any
fabric which is rendered for hire, or is sold, resold or offered for sale or
resale.



   Laundromat means any place, building, structure, room, establishment or
portion of same having within such premises one or more self service
coin-operated washing machines which are rented, leased or hired out to the
general public for a consideration and for use upon such premises.



   Laundry establishment means any place, building, structure, room,
establishment or portion of same which is used for the purpose of washing,
drying, starching or ironing shirts, dresses, collars, cuffs, or other
wearing apparel, table, bed or other household linens, towels, curtains,
draperies, bedding or other washable fabrics, for the general public.



(Code 1965, § 41.18(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 26-212. License--Required.



   No person shall operate or maintain a laundry establishment,
laundromat, dry cleaning establishment, automatic dry cleaner, or act as an
agent for dry cleaners or laundries without having first secured a license
therefor.



(Code 1965, § 41.18(b))



Sec. 26-213. Same--Applications.



   Applications for laundry establishment, laundromat, dry cleaning
establishment, automatic dry cleaner, and agent for dry cleaner licenses
shall be made upon such forms as prescribed by the village.



(Code 1965, § 41.18(c))



Sec. 26-214. Same--Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations are as follows:



      (1)   All persons licensed under this article shall comply
with all applicable provisions of the building code and fire prevention code.



      (2)   Step-by-step operating instructions shall be posted
conspicuously near each coin-operated machine provided for public use.



      (3)   Each machine used in this activity shall be inspected
daily by the licensee and at all times be properly maintained and kept in a
safe condition for public use.



      (4)   In addition to any other fire extinguishing equipment
required by law, there must be kept on the premises at all times in a
conspicuous and easily accessible place one or more portable fire
extinguishers adequate to extinguish any oil, electrical, or other fires that
might occur in connection with any machinery on the premises. Such
extinguishers shall be of a number and type prescribed or approved by the
village fire department.



      (5)   A telephone shall be maintained for public use on the
premises with the following telephone numbers prominently posted nearby:
those of the police department, fire department, and persons connected with
the business to be notified in the event of service failure or emergency.



      (6)   The area used by the public must be adequately lighted
during business hours.



      (7)   A "no loitering" sign shall be prominently displayed in
all laundromats.



      (8)   Every person engaged in such business shall provide
proper facilities and equipment for the separate handling of cleaned and
soiled articles, and no clean article shall be allowed to come in contact
with any uncleaned or soiled article of any kind at any time.



      (9)   Vapors or odors emanating from any such establishment
shall not be permitted at any time to become a nuisance to any portion of the
premises in which such establishment is located, nor to any adjoining or
nearby premises.



      (10)   There shall be present in every self-service
coin-operated establishment an attendant during all operational hours of the
establishment.



      (11)   All premises and vehicles used in connection with such
business shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and be subject to
inspection at all times.



      (12)   Maintenance areas shall be separate from customer
service areas. Customers shall not be permitted in maintenance service areas.



      (13)   Machines shall be properly installed and in such a
manner that only the fronts of the machines shall be exposed in the customer
service area.



(Code 1965, § 41.18(d))



Sec. 26-215. Same--Fees.



   The annual fee for a laundry establishment, laundromat, dry cleaning
establishment, automatic dry cleaner, and agents for dry cleaners and
laundries shall be on a square footage basis, as described in section 26-37.
The annual fee for each vehicle from which laundry is solicited or delivered
shall be $25.00 per vehicle.



(Code 1965, § 41.18(e))



Sec. 26-216. Inspections to ensure article compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.18(f))



Secs. 26-217--26-240. Reserved.



ARTICLE VIII. LODGING



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Secs. 26-241--26-260. Reserved.



DIVISION 2. HOTELS OR MOTELS*



*State law reference(s)--Authority to regulate places of public sleeping
accommodations, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-5.



Sec. 26-261. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Hotel means a building containing lodging rooms, a general kitchen and
dining room, a common entrance lobby, halls and stairway, and where lodging
rooms do not have a doorway opening directly to the outdoors, except for
emergencies, and where the lodging rooms are for rent, with or without meals,
to transient guests.



   Motel means a building containing lodging rooms having adjoining
individual bathrooms and where the lodging rooms are for rent to transient
guests.



(Code 1965, § 41.15(a); MC-856, § 1, 9-27-11)



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 26-262. License--Required.



   No person shall operate or maintain a hotel or motel within the village
without having first secured a license therefor.



(Code 1965, § 41.15(b))



Sec. 26-263. Same--Application.



   Applications for hotel or motel licenses shall be made upon such forms
as prescribed by the village.



(Code 1965, § 41.15(c))



Sec. 26-264. Same--Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations are as follows:



      (1)   All premises used for hotel or motel purposes shall be
kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and all portions of such premises
that are open for use by all guests or by the public shall be kept lighted at
all times they are so open to use.



      (2)   All such premises shall be kept heated between October 1
and May 1 to a temperature of not less than 68 degrees between the hours of
7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. and to a temperature of not less than 55 degrees at
all other hours.



      (3)   Each hotel or motel proprietor shall keep or cause to be
kept a register of guests as required by state law. Such registration shall
indicate the name and address of each guest, the dates of entrance and
departure and the make and license number of each vehicle, and shall be
available for inspection at any time.



      (4)   Each public sleeping unit shall have a complete bathroom
including flush toilet, sink, bath or shower.



      (5)   It shall be unlawful for a licensee to lease, rent, or
otherwise furnish a room to a person less than 21 years of age.



      (6)   It shall be unlawful for any person to rent, lease, or
otherwise furnish a room to a person of legal age for less than 24 hours or
for more than seven  days.



(Code 1965, § 41.15(d); MC-856, § 1, 9-27-11)



Sec. 26-265. Same--Fee.



   The annual fee for a hotel or motel license shall be on a square
footage basis, as described in section 26-37.



(Code 1965, § 41.15(e))



Sec. 26-266. Inspections to ensure division compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this division and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.15(f))



Secs. 26-267--26-290. Reserved.



DIVISION 3. ROOMINGHOUSES



Sec. 26-291. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Roominghouse means any building or portion of a building containing
lodging rooms which accommodate persons who are not members of the licensee's
family, and where lodging rooms or meals, or both, are provided for
compensation.



(Code 1965, § 41.27(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 26-292. License--Required.



   No person shall operate or maintain a roominghouse without having first
secured a license therefor.



(Code 1965, § 41.27(b))



Sec. 26-293. Same--Application.



   Applications for roominghouse licenses shall be made upon such forms as
prescribed by the village. Such application shall specify whether or not
meals are served to the boarders.



(Code 1965, § 41.27(c))



Sec. 26-294. Same--Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations are as follows:



      (1)   All premises shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition.



      (2)   There shall be at least one bathroom equipped with water
closet, shower or tub, and separate lavatory facilities for each four
residents on the premises.



      (3)   If meals are prepared and/or served, all food
preparation and handling shall be in compliance with the regulations
governing food dealers as set forth in article VI of this chapter.



      (4)   It shall be the responsibility of the licensed
proprietor of each roominghouse to ensure that the roominghouse is in
compliance with all fire code regulations.



(Code 1965, § 41.27(d))



Sec. 26-295. Same--Fee.



   The annual fee for a roominghouse shall be on a square footage basis,
as described in section 26-37.



(Code 1965, § 41.27(e))



Sec. 26-296. Inspections to ensure division compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this division and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.27(f))



Secs. 26-297--26-320. Reserved.



ARTICLE IX. NURSING HOMES



Sec. 26-321. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Nursing home means any institution, place or residence used for the
reception or care for a period longer than 24 hours of three or more persons
who are dependent or not capable of properly caring for themselves, and shall
be understood to include homes for the aged or infirmed, orphan asylums,
refuges, shelters, and rehabilitation centers.



(Code 1965, § 41.22(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 26-322. License--Required.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, partnership, venture,
association or corporation to regulate the treatment and control of
dependent, neglected and delinquent children or to open, conduct, manage or
maintain any nursing home within the corporate limits of the village without
first obtaining a license therefor.



(Code 1965, § 41.22(b))



Sec. 26-323. Same--Application.



   Applications for nursing home licenses shall be made upon such forms as
prescribed by the village. Such application shall specify the purpose for
which it is to be opened, maintained or conducted; the accommodations for the
inmates thereof; the nature and kind of care, instructions or benefits given
or proposed to be given therein; the name and address of the officials
owning, conducting, managing or maintaining such home; the name of the
superintendent or person in charge of such home; and the name and address of
the chief physician or surgeon, or the names and addresses of the board of
physicians or surgeons attending therein if there is such a board.



(Code 1965, § 41.22(c))



Sec. 26-324. Same--Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations are as follows:



      (1)   No drug of any nature shall be disposed of in such a way
as to allow the general public to gain access to it.



      (2)   All nursing homes shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition.



      (3)   All food preparation and handling shall be in compliance
with the regulations of food dealers as set forth in article VI of this
chapter.



      (4)   In addition to any other requirements of this article, a
nursing home shall comply with the minimum requirements established by the
state department of public health under the Nursing Home Care Act, 210 ILCS
45/1-101 et seq.



(Code 1965, § 41.22(d))



Sec. 26-325. Same--Fee.



   The annual fee for a nursing home shall be on a square footage basis,
as described in section 26-37.



(Code 1965, § 41.22(e))



Sec. 26-326. Inspections to ensure article compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.22(f))



Secs. 26-327--26-350. Reserved.



ARTICLE X. WEAPONS DEALERS



Sec. 26-351. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Deadly weapon means any pistol, dagger, stiletto, billie, derringer,
dirk or any other object of similar nature which can be concealed on the
person.



(Code 1965, § 53.18(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 26-352. License required; fee.



   No person shall engage in the business of selling or sell or give away
any deadly weapon without a license. Application for the license shall be
made on such forms as are provided by the village manager. The chief of
police shall verify all application data and shall approve or disapprove each
application based upon the facts of such investigation of the applicant. The
annual license fee for the sale of deadly weapons is $200.00.



(Code 1965, § 53.18(b))



Sec. 26-353. Sale procedure.



   (a)   Report of sale, exchange or gift; contents. Each person
licensed to sell deadly weapons shall report each sale, exchange or gift made
under the authority of his license to the chief of police within 24 hours of
each such transaction. The report shall contain the date of the transaction;
the name, age and address of purchaser; the permit to purchase number; a full
and complete description of the deadly weapon involved; and the reason given
for possession of the deadly weapon. Such report shall be legible and correct
for every transaction and shall be delivered to the chief of police within
the time limit specified in this subsection.



   (b)   Register; form. In addition to the individual transaction
report to the chief of police, each licensee shall maintain a register of all
weapons sold, loaned, rented or given away by the licensee. Such register
shall be kept open for inspection by the police department at all reasonable
times during business hours. The register shall be in substantially the
following form:



         a.   Date of Sale



         b.   Purchase Permit Number



         c.   Serial No. of  Weapon



         d.   Name, Address, Age of Purchaser



         e.   Description of Weapon



         f.   Purpose for Purchase of Weapon



         g.   Price of Weapon



   (c)   Display. It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit for
sale in display windows or on counters or in any other public manner any
deadly weapon; or to advertise by signs, posters, cards or similar devices
the sale of any such deadly weapons. Securely locked interior counter or wall
display cases shall be allowed.



(Code 1965, § 53.18(c))



Sec. 26-354. Purchase permit; application; issuance; fee.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase or receive any deadly
weapon which can be concealed on the person without first obtaining a permit
so to do from the chief of police. Application for such permit shall be made
on such forms as are provided by the village manager. The chief of police
shall verify all application data and shall approve or disapprove each
application based upon the facts of such investigation of the applicant. No
permit shall be issued to any minor or to any person previously convicted of
any felony. The fee for a permit to purchase a deadly weapon shall be $2.00.
A permit to purchase shall cover but one weapon only.



(Code 1965, § 53.18(d))



Sec. 26-355. Gunsmiths—License required; application; issuance; fee.



   No person shall engage in the business of repairing any pistol,
revolver, derringer or other firearm which can be concealed on the person
without a license. Application for the license shall be made on such forms as
are provided by the village manager. The chief of police shall verify all
application data and shall approve or disapprove each application based upon
the facts of such investigation of the applicant. The annual license fee for
gunsmithing is $50.00; provided, however, that a person licensed under the
provisions of section 26-352 shall not be required to pay the additional fee
for engaging in the business of gunsmithing.



(Code 1965, § 53.18(e))



Sec. 26-356. Same—Report.



   Each person licensed as a gunsmith shall report the receipt of each
firearm for repair to the chief of police within 24 hours of such receipt.
The report shall contain the date of receipt; the name, address, age,
physical description and occupation of the owner of the firearm; a full and
complete description of the firearm to be repaired; and a summary of the
repairs required. Such report shall be legible and correct for each repair
and shall be delivered to the chief of police within the time limit specified
in this section. (Code 1965, § 53.18(f))



Secs. 26-357—26-380. Reserved.



ARTICLE XI.  MASSAGE BUSINESSES



Sec. 26-381. Definitions.



   For the purpose of this Article, the following words and phrases shall
have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section.



   (a)   Licensee. The person or entity to whom a license has been
issued to own or operate a massage establishment as defined herein.



   (b)   Massage or Massage Therapy means a system of structures
palpation or movement of the soft tissue of the body.  The system may
include, but is not limited to, techniques such as effleurage or stocking and
gliding, petrissage or kneading, tapotement or percussion, friction,
vibration, compression, and stretching activities as they pertain to massage
therapy.  These techniques may be applied by a licensed massage therapist
with or without the aid of lubricants, salt or herbal preparations,
hydromassage, thermal massage, or a massage device that mimics or enhances
the actions possible by human hands.  The purpose of the practice of
massage, as licensed under this Act, is to enhance the general health and
well-being of the mind and body of the recipient.  "Massage" does not
include the diagnosis of a specific pathology.  "Massage" does not include
those acts of physical therapy or therapeutic or corrective measures that are
outside the scope of massage therapy practice.



   (c)   Massage Establishment. Any establishment having a fixed place
of business where any person, firm, association or corporation engages in or
carries on, or permits to be engaged in or carries on any of the activities
mentioned in subsection (b) of this Section.



   (d)   Massage Therapist, Massagist, Masseur or Masseuse (herein
collectively called "Massage Therapist"). Any person who, for any
consideration whatsoever, engages in the practice of massage as defined
herein. 



   (e)   Patron. Any person who received a massage under such
circumstances that it is reasonably expected that he or she will pay money or
give any other consideration therefor. 



   (f)   Person. Any individual, partnership, firm, association,
limited liability company, joint stock company, corporation or combination of
individuals of whatever form or character. 



   (g)   Recognized Schools. The term "Recognized Schools" is construed
and deemed to mean any school which meets any one or more of the following
requirements:



      (1)   A State Approved School operating according to state
regulations which has a current license, approval, accreditation and/or
certification from the state in which it is located and provides an entry
level Massage training program of a minimum of 500 hours of in-class work and
100 hours of clinical training.



      (2)   A massage school program accredited/approved by the
Commission on Massage Therapy Accreditation (COMTA).



   (h)   Recognized Training. Recognized training shall mean:



      (1)   A certification from the National Certification Board
for Therapeutic Massage and Bodywork (NCBTMB).



      (2)   Professional membership in (not associate membership)
the American Massage Therapy Association  Schools offering correspondence
courses and not requiring actual class attendance shall not be deemed
"recognized schools."



   (i)   Sexual or Genital Area.  Genitals, pubic area, anus, or
perineum of any person, or the vulva or breasts of a female.



(MC-795, § 1, 12-11-07)



Sec. 26-382.  License Required.



   (a)   No person, firm or corporation shall operate any establishment
or utilize any premises in the Village as, or for, a massage business unless
and until, there first has been obtained a license for such establishment or
premises from the Village, in accordance with the terms and provisions of
this Article.



   (b)   This section shall apply to all massage or massage type
activities whether identified as massage, accupressure or by some other
nomenclature. 



Sec. 26-383.  Exemptions.



   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following
individuals while engaged in the personal performance of the duties of their
respective professions, and to the following businesses and entities:



   (a)   Physicians, surgeons, chiropractors, osteopaths, or physical
therapists who are duly licensed to practice their respective professions in
the State of Illinois. 



   (b)   Illinois Licensed Practical Nurses, Registered Nurses,
hospitals, or nursing homes while administering massages in the normal course
of their medical duties. 



   (c)   Barbers and beauticians who are duly licensed under the laws
of this State, except that this exemption shall apply solely to the massaging
of the neck, face, scalp and hair of the customer or client for cosmetic or
beautifying purposes.



   (d)   A business registered in the Village where massage therapy is
not the primary occupation conducted at that location, and each massage
therapist has obtained a State of Illinois license.



   (e)   A governmental entity such as a park district where massage
therapy is available on premises, provided each massage therapist has
obtained a permit under Section 26-385 of this Article. 



   (f)   State of Illinois Certified Massage Therapist.



   (g)   State of Illinois Certified Cosmetologists engaging in massage
of a person's hands or feet or face.



Sec. 26-384.  Application for Massage Establishment License.



   Every applicant for a license to maintain, operate, or conduct a
massage establishment shall file an application under oath with the Village
upon a form provided by the Village Clerk and pay a nonrefundable application
fee of $100.00.  The application, once accepted, shall be referred to the
Police Department for investigation of the applicant's character and
qualification.  Copies of the application shall within five (5) days also be
referred to the Building Inspector and the Director of Community
Development.  They shall within thirty (30) days inspect the premises
proposed to be operated as a massage establishment and shall make written
verification to the Village Clerk concerning compliance with the codes and
ordinances of the Village that they administer. Upon issuance of the license,
the application fee shall satisfy the first annual license fee requirement.
Each application shall contain the following information:



   (a)   A definition of service to be provided.



   (b)   The location, mailing address and all telephone numbers where
the business is to be conducted. 



   (c)   The name and residence address of each applicant (hereinafter
all provisions which refer to applicant include an applicant which may be a
corporation, limited liability company or partnership and include all persons
whose names are required to be given under this section (c)).



      (1)   If applicant is a corporation or limited liability
company, the names and residence addresses of each of the officers and
directors of said corporation or company and of each stockholder owning more
than ten percent (10%) of the stock of the corporation or company, and the
address of the corporation or company itself, if different from the address
of the massage establishment. 



      (2)   If applicant is a partnership, the names and residence
addresses of each of the partners including limited partners, and the address
of the partnership itself, if different from the address of the massage
establishment.



   (d)   The two (2) previous addresses immediately prior to the
present address of the applicant, and the dates of residence or operation at
such addresses. 



   (e)   Proof that the applicant if an individual, is at least
eighteen (18) years of age.



   (f)   Proof that the applicant currently carries Professional
Liability Insurance in an amount no less than One Million Dollars
($1,000,000.00) per occurrence.



   (g)   Individual or partnership applicant's height, weight, color of
eyes and hair, and sex. 



   (h)   Copy of identification such as driver's license and/or social
security card. 



   (i)   One current front-face portrait photograph of the applicant at
least two (2) inches by two (2) inches and a complete set of applicant's
fingerprints which shall be taken by the Chief of Police or his designee. 
If the applicant is a corporation, one current front-face portrait photograph
at least two (2) inches by two (2) inches of all officers and managing
agents' fingerprints which shall be taken by the Chief of Police or his
designee.  If the applicant is a partnership, one current front-face
portrait photograph at least two (2) inches by two (2) inches in size of each
partner, including a limited partner in said partnership, and a complete set
of each partner or limited partner's fingerprints which shall be taken by the
Chief of Police or his designee.



   (j)   Business, occupation or employment and employment address of
the applicant for the three (3) years immediately preceding the date of
application.



   (k)   The massage or similar business license history of the
applicant; whether such person, in previously operating in this or another
Village or State, has had a business license revoked or suspended, the reason
therefor, and the business activity or occupation subsequent to such action
of suspension or revocation. 



   (l)   All criminal convictions, including the dates of convictions,
nature of the crimes and place convicted. 



   (m)   The name and address of any massage business or other
establishment owned or operated by any person whose name is required to be
given in Subsection (c) of this Section wherein the business or profession of
massage is carried on. 



   (n)   A description of any other business to be operated on the same
premises or on adjoining premises owned or controlled by the applicant.



   (o)   Authorization of the Village, its agents and employees to seek
information and conduct an investigation into the truth of the statements set
forth in the application and the qualifications of the applicant for the
license. 



   (p)   Such other identification and information reasonably necessary
to discover the truth of the matters hereinbefore specified as required to be
set forth in the application.



   (q)   The names, current addresses and written  statements of  at
least  three  (3) bonafide permanent residents of the United States that
the applicant is of good moral character.  If the applicant is able, the
statement must first be furnished from residents of the Village, then the
County, then the State of Illinois and lastly from the rest of the United
States.  These references must be persons other than relatives and business
associates, and should state the nature of the acquaintance with the
Applicant. 



   Upon completion of the above provided form and the furnishing of all
foregoing information the Village Clerk shall accept the application, for the
necessary investigations.  The holder of a massage establishment license
shall notify the Village Clerk of each change in any of the data required to
be furnished by this Section within ten (10) days after such change occurs.
Prospective new massage employees shall not be employed until each has
received a massage therapist's license from the State of Illinois.



(MC-800, § 1, 3-11-08)



Sec. 26-385.  Issuance of License for a Massage Establishment.



   The Village shall issue a license for a massage establishment for a
massage establishment described in this chapter are met, unless it finds:



   (a)   The correct license fee has not been tendered to the Village,
and in the case of a check or bank draft, honored with payment upon
presentation.



   (b)   The operation, as proposed by the applicant, if permitted,
would not comply with all applicable laws, including, but not limited to, the
Village's building, zoning, life safety and health regulations. 



   (c)   The  applicant, if  an individual; or any of the
stockholders holding more than ten percent (10%) of the stock of the
corporation or interest in a limited liability company, any of the officers
and directors, if the applicant is a corporation or limited liability
company; or any of the partners, included limited partners, if the applicant
is a partnership or the manager or other person principally in charge of the
operation of the business, have been convicted of any of the following
offenses if committed within the State of Illinois, or convicted of an
offense without the State of Illinois that would have constituted any of the
following offenses.



      An offense involving the use of force or violence upon the person
of another that amounts to a felony.



      An offense involving sexual misconduct.



      An offense involving narcotics, dangerous drugs or dangerous
weapons that amounts to a felony. 



      An offense against the person of another that amounts to a felony.



   The Village may issue a license to any person convicted of any of the
crimes described in Subsections (1), (2) or (3) of this Section if it finds
that such conviction occurred at least five (5) years prior to the date of
the application and that applicant has had no subsequent felony convictions
of any nature and no subsequent misdemeanor convictions for a crime or crimes
mentioned in this Section. 



   (d)   The applicant has knowingly made any false, misleading, or
fraudulent statement of fact in the application or in any document required
by the Village in conjunction therewith. 



   (e)   The applicant has had a massage business, massage therapist,
or other similar permit or license denied, revoked, or suspended by the
Village or any other State or local agency within five (5) years prior to the
date of application. 



   (f)   The applicant, if an individual, or any of the officers and
directors, if the applicant is a corporation or limited liability company; or
any of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a
partnership; or the manager or other person principally in charge of the
operation of the business, is not over the age of eighteen (18) years.



Sec. 26-386. Approval or Denial of Application.



   The Village shall act to approve or deny an application for a license
within a reasonable period of time and in no event shall the Village act to
approve or deny said fully completed license later than 90 days from the date
that said application was accepted by the Village.  Every license issued
pursuant to this Article will terminate at the expiration of the Village's
fiscal year. 



Sec. 26-387. Renewal of Massage Establishment License.
