junior colleges, colleges, and universities which have been granted a
certificate of recognition by the Illinois State Board of Education, pursuant
to Illinois State Statutes.  Also includes any satellite or branch facility
of same.



   Streets means the surface, the airspace above the surface, and the area
below the surface of any public street, highway, lane, path, alley, sidewalk,
boulevard, drive, bridge, tunnel, park, parkways, waterways, or other public
right-of-way including public utility easements or rights-of-way, and any
temporary or permanent fixtures or improvements located thereon now or
hereafter held by the Village which shall entitle the Village and the Grantee
to the use thereof for the purpose of installing and maintaining the
Grantee's cable television system.



   Subscriber means any person who legally receives the basic subscriber
service and/or any one or more of such other services as may be provided by
the Grantee's cable television system, and who does not further distribute
such service(s).



   Surety means one who undertakes to pay money or perform other acts in
the event that his principal fails do so.



   Trap means a passive device used to block a channel or channels from
being received by a cable subscriber (negative trap), or used to remove an
interfering carrier from a channel that a subscriber wants to receive
(positive trap).



   Travel Costs include, but are not limited to, air fare, car rental,
mileage expense, gasoline, parking, tolls, lodging, meals, tips, business
calls and communications, taxi and limo service.



   Trunk (Trunk Line) means the main distribution lines leading from the
headend of the cable television system to the various areas where feeder
lines (cables) are attached to distribute signals to the subscribers.



   Two-way Service means a service provided over a cable system capable of
transmitting signals simultaneously in two directions, upstream and
downstream, in either a subsplit, midsplit, or high split configuration. 
Two-way service is not necessarily interactive.



   Upstream Channel means the direction from the subscriber terminals to
the headend.



   Video Dial Tone means a common carrier access and transport network
service for video information.



   Video Compression means the compression of a digitized signal that is
transmitted from the satellite uplink to the cable system headend where it is
transmitted to the subscriber's converter/terminal.



(Code 1965, §43.03)



   Cross Reference - Definitions generally, § 1,2)



Sec. 28-4.  Grant of authority.



   (a)   Requirement of a franchise:  No person shall construct,
install, maintain, or operate a cable television system within the Village,
or within any other public property of the Village, unless a franchise has
first been obtained pursuant to this Chapter, and unless such franchise is in
full force and effect, or a person or entity has received authorization to
offer or provide cable or video service from the Illinois Commerce Commission
pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-401.  Such franchise shall not take the place of
any other license or permit which may be legally required of the Grantee in
order to conduct such a business, or construct or install buildings,
structures, facilities, or equipment within the Village.



   (b)   Franchise applications:



      (1)   The application for a cable television franchise, other
than an application for a renewal of a cable television franchise, shall be
submitted to the Village in such written form as may be required by the
Village.  The Village may request such facts and information the Village
deems appropriate in the application form. The application shall include at a
minimum:



         a.   A clear description of the identity of the
applicant, including a copy of FCC Registration Statement;



         b.   Specifications and plans of the proposed cable
system, including identification of trunk line locations;



         c.   A legal description and/ or clear identification of
the area intended to be serviced by the Applicant;



         d.   Projected financial pro forma for  a period of ten
years showing system revenue, and costs of operation;



         e.   Proof of financial support for the system build as
evidenced by a letter from a lending institution and/ or other financial
entity,



         f.   A list of other franchises held by the applicant
identified by state, city and the date of franchise expiration;



         g.   A detailed description of the customer service and
technical support operations; and



         h.   Representations that the general partner, any
principal or partner, or principal stockholder (i.e., an entity that owns 10
percent or more of the stock) has never been convicted of a crime involving
moral turpitude, and is not presently under indictment charging such a crime;
the applicant and/or its parent corporation is not, and has not been, a party
to litigation, or cause of action, in any court of law or initiated
proceeding by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the FCC, or any other
governmental body, or administrative agency relevant to the holding of any
franchise agreement, or actions of the applicant in any business endeavor. If
any portion of this representation can't be given, a complete explanation
shall be included with the application.



      (2)   An application fee of $7,500 shall accompany the
application or a franchise agreement.  The application fee is non-refundable
to the extent that the costs incurred by the Village in reviewing,
evaluating, and acting upon the application shall be deducted from the
application fee.  Costs and fees shall include, but not be limited to,
attorneys, consultants, accountants, and other outside professionals.



      (3)   After receiving applications for a franchise, the
Village Board, after considering the technical, financial, and legal
qualifications of the applicants; and such other information as to the
applicants' service and performance in other franchise areas, may grant one
or more nonexclusive franchises creating a right to construct and operate a
cable television system within the public rights-of-way of the Village.  No
provision of this Chapter shall be deemed, or construed, as to require the
Village Board to grant a franchise.



      (4)   An applicant to whom the Village Board grants a
non-exclusive franchise shall, in addition to the fee specified in Section
28-04(b)(2) above, pay to the Village at the time the Grantee files the
written instrument specified in the franchise agreement, an amount to be
determined compensating the Village for all direct, reasonable, costs and
fees incurred by the Village in granting the franchise in excess of the fee
required by Section 28-04(b)(2) above.



   (c)   GRANT OF FRANCHISE:



      (1)   The Village may grant a non-exclusive franchise for all
or part of any defined portion of the Village.  The Franchise Area shall be
the corporate boundaries of the Village as they exist from time to time.



      (2)      a.   In the event that the Village grants a
franchise to construct, operate, maintain, and reconstruct a System within
the Franchise Area, said franchise shall constitute both a right and an
obligation to provide the services of a System as required by the provisions
of this Chapter and franchise agreement.



         b.    Any franchise granted under the provisions hereof
shall be consistent with federal laws and regulations, state laws and
regulations to the extent constitutionally required, and local chapters and
regulations, as from time to time enacted and amended.  In the event of
conflict between the terms and conditions of the franchise agreement and any
such statutory standards, the statutory requirements shall, without
exception, control the interpretation of the franchise agreement. 
Amplification and clarification of statutory requirements found in the
franchise agreement shall not be considered a conflict.



         c.    In accepting the franchise, the Grantee
acknowledges that its rights under the Chapter and the franchise are subject
to the police power of the Village to adopt and enforce general chapters
necessary to the safety and welfare of the public; and the Grantee agrees to
comply with all applicable general laws and ordinances enacted by the Village
pursuant to such power.



         d.   A renewal or transfer of a franchise shall be
conducted as provided in this Chapter under Sections 28-08 and 28-09,
respectively.



      (3)   No System shall be allowed to occupy or use the streets
in the Franchise Area other than in accordance with this Chapter and a
franchise granted pursuant hereto.



      (4)   A franchise granted pursuant to this Chapter may be
modified, from time to time, by mutual agreement of the parties, at the
request of either party to provide for enhancements and advances in
technology that would be of benefit to the residents of the Village or the
grantee. Said requests for review of the requested modification shall not be
unreasonably withheld by either the Grantee or the Grantor.



      (5)   The Village may grant one or more franchises or may
decline to grant any franchise.



      (6)   The Chapter and franchise agreement shall be
administered by the Village Board, and/or an Agent or Agency as appointed by
the Village.  The Village shall notify the Grantee of the person responsible
for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of the Chapter and
franchise agreement upon the signing of the franchise agreement and at such
time as the Village Board appoints another agent or agency.



      (7)   Nothing in this Chapter shall prohibit the Village from
regulating any Grantee or other entity  to the extent that such Grantee or
entity  provides any communication service other than cable service, whether
offered on a common carrier or private contract basis and to the extent the
Village is not prohibited from such regulation under State law.



      (8)   All reports, documentation, and testing procedures
required by this chapter, or the franchise agreement, shall be at the
Grantee's expense unless otherwise provided in this Chapter or franchise
agreement.



   (d)   Term of the franchise:  The term of the franchise shall be as
established in the franchise agreement and shall take full effect and be in
full force from and after acceptance by the Franchisee as provided for in
this Chapter and in the franchise agreement;  and the same shall continue in
full force and effect for the term specified in the franchise agreement
unless otherwise terminated or revoked as allowed pursuant to the provisions
of this Chapter.



   (e)   Non-exclusive franchise agreement:  No franchise granted
pursuant to this Chapter shall give an exclusive right to the Grantee and
every such franchise shall be deemed to reserve the right to grant other
franchises to use and occupy the public ways of the Village for cable
television, or any other purpose, on the same terms or substantially
equivalent terms and conditions as those of any existing cable television
franchise.



   (f)   Surety or guaranty agreement required:  The Village may
require that a Grantee whose formation is by partnership, be it a limited or
general partnership, provide a surety or guaranty agreement which establishes
that the parent company of one, or all general partners, accepts liability
for the debt and performance of the partnership upon the partnership's
default.



   (g)   Voluntary surrender of the franchise agreement:  In the event
that the Grantee voluntarily surrenders the franchise agreement prior to
renewal, in effect terminating the grant of authority expressed in Section
28-04 of the Chapter, the Village may assess liquidated damages as provided
for in the franchise agreement.  A transfer of the franchise shall not be
considered a voluntary surrender.



(Code 1965, §43.04(a-c))  (MC-807, § 1, 8-12-08)



Sec. 28-5.  Notice.



   (a)   Requirements for notice:



      (1)   Except as provided in Sections 28-06, 28-08(c), and
28-12(a)(2), the Village will not take any final action involving the
modification, renewal, revocation or termination of the Grantee's franchise
unless the Village has: (1) called a meeting for such purpose; (2) advised
the Grantee in writing, at least thirty (30) days prior to such meeting, as
to time, place, and purpose; and (3) provided a notice prior to the meeting
in a newspaper of general circulation within the Village.  The Grantee and
any interested person shall be entitled to be heard at such meeting.



      (2)   Grantor's notice to the Grantee for violation of the
provisions of this Chapter or the franchise agreement shall be in accordance
with the requirements under said Sections in the Chapter and/or the franchise
agreement.



   (b)   Service of notice:



      (1)   Grantee shall serve written notices and written
responses to the Grantor by certified mail.



      (2)   Written notice to the Grantee shall be served by the
Grantor by either certified mail or as otherwise provided by law.



(Code 1965, §43.05 (a,b))



Sec. 28-6.  Modification of the Franchise Agreement:



   (a)   Modification:



      (1)   The Grantor may amend the franchise agreement, upon
application of the Grantee, under the terms and conditions as set forth in
Section 625 of the Cable Act of 1984, as amended from time to time.



      (2)   The Grantee may apply to the Village for a modification
of the requirements in a franchise, on a condition other than the
demonstration of commercial impracticability. The Village may consider said
request for modification if the Grantee can demonstrate that the modification
would enable the Grantee to provide service in a more efficient, effective,
or economical manner to the subscribers and the Village;  and the Village
may grant said modification.  Nothing in this provision shall require the
Village to modify the franchise agreement.



      (3)   The Grantor may, with good cause, request that the
Grantee modify the franchise agreement whenever the Village concludes that
such modification  will result in subscribers and/or  Grantor being served
in a more efficient, effective, or economical manner by the Grantee.  Upon
notice  to the Grantee  and the opportunity to confer, Grantor may adopt 
reasonable modifications of the Grantee's franchise relating solely to
matters of health, safety or welfare.



      (4)   Notwithstanding Section C of this Chapter, the Grantor
may modify this Chapter under its police powers in accordance with the
authority granted under Illinois and federal law.



   (b)   Costs and fees of modification process:  Unless otherwise
stipulated in the Franchise Agreement, each party to a request for any 
modification of the franchise agreement shall be responsible for all of its
costs related to the modification review or implementation process.



(Code 1965, §43.06(a,b))



Sec. 28-7.  Performance evaluation sessions.



   (a)   Schedule:



      (1)   The Village and the Grantee shall, upon election of the
Village, hold Performance Evaluation Sessions within a reasonable time period
preceding, or immediately after, the first, third, and sixth anniversary
dates of the signing of the franchise agreement; and thereafter every three
years until the expiration of the franchise agreement; or as may be required
under state and federal law.



      The Grantor shall be solely responsible for notifying the Grantee
no later than thirty (30) days prior to the anniversary date for the review
period that a date for the Performance Evaluation is to be set by the Village
and no notice by the Village to the Grantee shall be required.  The Village
shall notify the Grantee within thirty (30) days of Grantee's notice as to
the Village's intent to conduct the Performance Evaluation and a date for the
evaluation.



      (2)   Special evaluation sessions may be held at any time
during the term of the franchise at the request of the Village or the Grantee
upon thirty (30) days written notice to the other.



   (b)   Provision of information:  During a review and evaluation by
the Village, the Grantee shall fully cooperate with the Village and shall
provide such information and documents as the Village may need, in its
determination, to reasonably perform its review.



   (c)   Topics:  Topics discussed at any scheduled session, or
special evaluation session, may include the examination of any condition or
requirement of the franchise agreement, judicial and FCC rulings, the
Grantee's responsiveness to the community's needs and interests, and other
topics as determined by the Village. The Grantee may also suggest topics to
be discussed.



   (d)   Notice:



      (1)   All evaluation sessions shall be open to the public and
announced in a newspaper of general circulation in accordance with the notice
provisions of Section 28-07(a)(1) above. No such newspaper notice shall be
required as to any adjourned sessions.



      (2)   Subscribers will be notified of all evaluation sessions
by text announcement on the local origination channel and/or access channels
of  the system, for two weeks prior to the Performance Evaluation Session. 



   (e)   System or component testing required:



      (1)   If at any time during its review, the Village determines
that reasonable evidence exists of inadequate cable system performance, it
may require the Grantee to perform tests and analyses directed toward the
suspected inadequacies. The Grantee shall fully cooperate with the Village in
performing such testing and shall prepare results and a written report signed
by the system manager and the person conducting the testing, if requested,
within thirty (30) days after the notice to test.  Such reports shall
include the following information:



         a.   The nature of the complaint or problem which
precipitated the special tests;



         b.   What system component was tested;



         c.   The equipment used and procedures employed in
testing;



         d.   The method, if any, in which such complaint or
problem was resolved;



         e.    The name and the qualification of the person(s)
assigned to conduct the tests; and



         f.   Any other information pertinent to said tests and
analysis which may be required.



      (2)   The Grantee may use its own qualified staff to conduct
such tests as may be required herein.  The Village may reasonably require
that the tests be supervised by a technical consultant experienced in cable
television.  Should the Village determine that one or more tests be
re-administered, the Village may engage a technical consultant.



      (3)   The Village's rights under this Section shall be limited
to requiring tests, analysis, and reports covering specific subjects and
characteristics based on a substantial number of complaints or other
reasonable evidence when and under such circumstances as the Village has
reasonable grounds to believe that the complaints or other evidence require
the tests be performed to protect the public against substandard cable
service.



(Code 1965, §43.07(a-e))



Sec. 28-8.  Franchise renewal.



   (a)   Notice by grantee:  The Grantee shall be solely responsible
for providing written notice to the Village that the Grantee wishes to renew
the cable television franchise agreement not less than thirty (30) months
before the expiration of the franchise agreement.



   (b)   Review of the grantee:



      (1)   Upon receipt of the franchise renewal request, or as
otherwise determined by the Village, the Village shall conduct a review of
the Grantee's performance under the present terms and conditions of the
franchise agreement, and shall consider the future communication needs and
interests of the entire community as expressed for the present and for the
future term of a renewed franchise agreement.  The Village and the Grantee
shall abide by any federal or state law, that in addition to this Chapter,
governs the conduct of a cable television franchise renewal.



      (2)   The Village may require that the Grantee respond to a
RFP, or provide to the Village a proposal that sets outs the services and
technical specifications to be provided during the new franchise term.  Upon
issuance of the RFP, the Grantee shall not submit a proposal for service
prior to a date determined by the Village.  The Village may, or may not
consider a proposal submitted



by the Grantee prior to the issuance of the RFP.  Notwithstanding, prior to
the Village's issuance of a RFP, the Grantee may submit a proposal under
Section 626 paragraph H of the Cable Act along with a written notice  that
the proposal is being submitted under paragraph H  (the informal proposal).



      (3)   The Village may hear any interested persons during a
session called for the purpose of determining the renewal of the franchise
agreement, and the Village may determine whether or not the Grantee did
reasonably comply with the terms and conditions imposed by the ordinance and
current franchise agreement.



      (4)   If the Village determines that the Grantee is in
substantial compliance with the terms and conditions of the current franchise
agreement, and that the Grantee's proposal for future service meets the
community's needs and interests, the Village may renew the Grantee's
franchise agreement for a specific term.



   (c)   Compliance with terms and conditions:  The Village may
require that any substantial non-compliance issues be resolved to the
satisfaction of the Village prior to any negotiation of the renewed franchise
agreement.



   (d)   Assessment to not renew the franchise agreement:  The Village
may, upon the completion of its investigation, and upon submittal of a
proposal from the Grantee, issue a preliminary assessment that the franchise
should not be renewed.  Upon said assessment, the Village and the Grantee
shall follow the procedures in Section 626 of the Cable Act, as amended from
time to time.



   (e)   Recouping of village expenses, costs, and fees: Upon
determination of renewal, the Grantee and the Village may agree to a
discharge of expenses and costs in the franchise agreement in an exhibit
titled, AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE PARTIES FOR THE PAYMENT OF CERTAIN EXPENSES AND
COSTS.



(Code 1965, §43.08(a-e))



Sec. 28-9.  Transfer of the franchise agreement.



   (a)   Franchise as a trust and privilege: A franchise granted under
this Chapter shall be a privilege to be held in personal trust by a
Grantee.  It shall not be assigned, transferred, sold, or disposed of, in
whole or in part, by voluntary sale, sale and leaseback, merger,
consolidation, exchange of stock, by provision of a management agreement, or
otherwise, or by forced or involuntary sale, without prior consent of the
Village expressed by resolution and then only on such conditions as may
herein be prescribed.  Any sale, transfer, or assignment not made according
to the procedures set forth in this Chapter shall be considered a substantial
violation. The sale, transfer, or assignment in bulk of the major part of the
tangible assets of the Grantee's system  shall be considered an assignment
and shall be subject to the provisions of this Section.



   (b)   Approval of village required:



      (1)   Prior approval of the Village shall be required where
ownership, or control of more than twenty percent (20%) of the right of
control of the Grantee is acquired during the term of the franchise in any
transaction, or series of transactions, by a person or group of persons
acting in concert, none of whom owned or controlled twenty (20%) percent or
more of such right of control, singularly or collectively on the effective
date of the franchise.  By its acceptance of this franchise, the Grantee
specifically grants and agrees that any such acquisition occurring without
prior approval of the Village shall render the franchise void.  A change in
the general partner of a limited partnership, if the franchise is held by a
limited partnership, shall not be considered a transfer provided that the
general partner continues to be an affiliate, or subsidiary, or the parent
company of the Grantee; nonetheless, the Village shall still be notified of
said change of the general partner at least thirty (30) days prior to the
change.



      (2)   No such consent shall be required for a transfer in
trust, mortgage, or other instrument of hypothecation, in whole or in part,
to secure an indebtedness except when such hypothecation shall exceed
seventy-five percent (75%) of the fair market value of the property used by
the Grantee in the operation of its cable television system.  Prior consent
of the Village shall be required, expressed by resolution, for such transfer
and said consent shall not be withheld unreasonably.



      (3)   A transfer of stock shall be considered a transfer of
the ownership of the company.



      (4)   Grantee shall file  with the Village as requested a
copy of its State Domestic Corporation Annual Report or equivalent as
specified in the franchise agreement.



      (5)   Transfer of ownership shall also be governed by the
Cable Act, Section 617, as amended from time to time.



   (c)   Notice:  Whenever any transfer subject to Village approval
under this Chapter is proposed, the Grantee shall provide the Village with
reasonable notice of the intent to transfer and shall provide the Village
with all information requested by the Village in its investigation of the
transfer. The Grantee shall provide to the Village complete information
setting forth the nature, terms, conditions and all other pertinent details
of such proposed transfer. The Grantee shall meet with the Village to resolve
any violations of the franchise agreement prior to the transfer. 
Furthermore, no approval of the transfer shall be granted unless all monies
accruing to the Village as of the date of the transfer, whether by way of
fees, penalties, damages or otherwise, have first been paid in full.  Upon
the full disclosure of information required by the Cable Act and by the
Village in the determination of the qualification of the transfer candidate,
the Village shall then consider the application for a transfer consistent
with the requirements of the Act.



   (d)   Information required:  The proposed buyer of the cable system
shall provide such evidence to the Village as to qualify the applicant as
being financially, technically, and legally capable.  The Village may
require financial pro forms and letters from the lending institution
verifying funding for the acquisition and operation of the cable system. 
The proposed buyer shall agree, in writing, to comply with all the terms and
conditions of the franchise agreement and Chapter.



   (e)   Surety or guaranty agreement required:



      (1)   The Village may require that a Grantee whose formation
is by partnership, be it limited or general, provide a surety or guaranty
agreement which establishes that the parent company of one, or all general
partners, accepts liability for the debt and performance of the partnership
should the partnership default.  This may also be required by the Village
for transfers to non-related buyers of the system or to transfers to a
subsidiary or affiliate company, corporation, or partnership of the current
Grantee.



      (2)   The Village may require that the transfer applicant post
a bond, or letter of credit, in addition to, or higher than that which is
specified in the original franchise agreement should the applicant's
circumstances so warrant.



   (f)   Modification and renegotiation:  The Village maintains the
right, at the time of the transfer application, to seek modifications to the
franchise agreement that the Village deems will benefit the needs and
interests of the community.



   (g)   Village rights not waived:  The consent of the Village to any
sale, transfer, lease, trust, mortgage or other instrument of hypothecation
shall not constitute a waiver or release of any rights of the Village under
this Chapter and the franchise.



(Code 1965, §43.09(a-g))



Sec. 28-10.  Franchise forfeiture and termination.



   (a)   Conditions:



      (1)   In addition to all other rights and powers retained by
the Village under the franchise, or otherwise, the Village reserves the right
to forfeit and terminate the franchise and all rights and privileges of the
Grantee hereunder in the event of a substantial breach of its terms and
conditions.  A substantial breach by the Grantee shall include, but shall
not be limited to the following:



         a.   Violation of any material provision of the
franchise or any material rule, order, regulation or determination of the
Village made pursuant to the franchise; or



         b.   Attempt to evade any material provision of the
franchise or practice any fraud or material deception  upon the cable
television system subscribers or upon the Village government; or



         c.   Failure to provide the services defined in the
franchise agreement; or



         d.   Failure to begin or complete system construction or
system line extension in accordance with the terms of the franchise
agreement; or



         e.   Failure to restore system wide service after
twenty-four (24) consecutive hours of deliberately interrupted service,
except when approval of said interruption is obtained from the Village; or in
the event of a natural disaster;  or



         f.   Material misrepresentation of fact in the
application for or negotiation of, or renewal of the franchise; or



         g.   Frequent and material violations by the Grantee of
any orders or rulings of any regulatory body having jurisdiction over the
Grantee relative to its franchise; or



         h.   Repeated failure to pay the franchise fee in
accordance with Section 28-12(b) of the Chapter and in accordance with the
terms of the franchise agreement;  or



         i.   The Grantee applies to any tribunal for the
appointment of a trustee or receiver for any substantial part of the assets
of the Grantee, or commences any proceedings relating to the Grantee under
any bankruptcy, reorganization, insolvency, readjustment of debt, assignment
for the benefit of creditor, dissolution or other liquidation law of any
jurisdiction, or any such application is filed, or any such proceeding is
commenced, against the Grantee, and the Grantee indicates its approval,
consent or acquiescence, or an order entered appointing such trustee or
receiver or adjudicating the Grantee bankrupt or insolvent, or approving the
petition in any such proceeding, and such order remains in effect for
forty-five (45) days.



      (2)   The foregoing shall not constitute a substantial breach
if the violation occurs but it is without fault of the Grantee or occurs as a
result of circumstances beyond its direct control such as war, civil
disturbance, natural catastrophe and other acts of God, or failure of timely
receipt of licenses from utility companies.  The Grantee shall not be
excused by mere economic hardship nor by misfeasance or malfeasance of its
directors, officers, or employees.



      (3)   The Village may make a written demand that the Grantee
comply with any such provision, rule, order, or determination under or
pursuant to this franchise.  If the violation continues for a period of
thirty (30) days, or as otherwise stipulated in the Chapter or franchise
agreement, following receipt of the written demand without written proof that
the corrective action has taken or is being actively and expeditiously
pursued, the Village may consider terminating the cable system franchise
provided that the Village shall cause to be served upon the Grantee a notice,
in accordance with Section 43.05 of the Chapter, that the Village is to
consider the issue of termination, a written notice of intent to request
termination and the time and place of the meeting.



      (4)   The Village Board, or its duly designated representative
shall hear and consider the issue and shall hear any person interested
therein, and the Village Board shall determine in its discretion whether or
not any violation by the Grantee occurred.



      (5)   If the Village Board shall determine the violation by
the Grantee was the fault of the Grantee and within its control, the Board
may, by resolution, declare that the franchise of the Grantee shall be
forfeited and terminated unless there is compliance within such period as the
Board may fix, such period shall not be less than ten (10) days, provided
that no opportunity for compliance need be granted for fraud or willful,
material misrepresentation.



      (6)   The issue of forfeiture and termination shall be
considered by the Village Board at the expiration of the time set for the
Grantee to have returned to compliance in accordance with paragraph 5.  The
Board may within thirty (30) days of the end of the compliance period
terminate the franchise forthwith upon finding that the Grantee has failed to
achieve compliance or may extend the compliance period at the Board's
discretion, or may continue its deliberations for an additional thirty (30)
day period.  The Village Board shall make known its decision to the Grantee
through a written instrument.



      (7)   The Board may establish a set time by which the Grantee
shall remove, or abandon all, or a portion of, the tangible assets of its
system from the Village's right-of-ways and from subscriber's homes or may
direct the Grantee to sell the cable system at the fair market value with no
value allocated to the franchise itself.  If the Village revokes the
franchise for cause and seeks to acquire ownership of the cable system, or
effects to transfer the ownership of the system to another person, it shall
do so at an equitable price.



   (b)   Removal of cable plant:  The Grantee shall apply for and
obtain such encroachment permits, licenses, authorizations or approvals and
pay such fees and deposit such security as required by the applicable
Chapters of the Village or by state statute, or as required by the Village
Board, shall conduct and complete the removal in compliance with all such
applicable ordinances, and shall restore the streets to the same condition as
prior to the work of the removal commenced.  The work of removal shall be
completed not later than one year following the date of expiration or
termination of the franchise, unless some other date has been set by the
Village Board in its notice to the Grantee;  otherwise the Village may
complete such work through and by its employees or through a contractor(s)
selected by the Village and charge the expense thereof against the security
deposit, letter of credit, and/or construction bond required to be provided
by the Grantee.



   (c)   Additional rights of the village:  The termination or
forfeiture of the Grantee's rights under a franchise shall in no way affect
any other rights the Village may have under the franchise or under any
provision of law.



(Code 1965, §43.10(a-c))



Sec. 28-11.  Continuation of service.



   (a)   Provision of service:



      (1)   For a reasonable time, in the period between expiration,
cancellation, revocation, or termination of the franchise and the transfer of
the cable system pursuant to the Chapter, the Grantee shall continue to
provide operations service and customer service to the public as if the
franchise were still in effect.



      (2)   The Grantee shall act as a trustee for its successor in
the interest of the cable franchise and provide a financial accounting during
the interim period. The Grantee shall hold the franchise as a trustee for the
successor and shall not sell or otherwise dispose of any of the systems'
assets nor shall the Grantee make any physical, administrative, or
operational changes that, without the express written consent of the Village,
would tend to:



         a.   Degrade the quality of the service to subscribers,



         b.   Decrease gross revenues, or



         c.   Materially increase expenses.



      (3)   In the event the Grantee fails or refuses to operate the
system in accordance with the terms of the Chapter and franchise agreement,
the Village shall have the option to institute legal proceedings to name a
successor trustee to operate the system.



   (b)   Authority to continue to operate the cable system:



      (1)   In the event of expiration or revocation of the
franchise agreement, this Section shall not be construed to give the Grantee
any vested right, or authority of franchise.  The right of the Grantee under
such circumstances shall exist only on a day-to-day basis until the transfer
or sale is effected.



      (2)   As full compensation for its ownership interests during
this interim period, the Grantee shall be entitled to receive a reasonable
profit during the period between the expiration or revocation of the
franchise, as the case may be, and the transfer of the Grantee's assets to
the Village or a successor.



      (3)   The Grantee shall be liable for all the costs of
operating and maintaining the system in the event that the Village must
assume the day to day operation of the cable system.  In addition, the
Village, or its representative, shall place the profit, if any, from the
operation of the system during this period in an interest bearing account
until such time as all proceedings against the Grantee have been adjudicated.



(Code 1965, §43.11(a,b))



Sec. 28-12.  Franchise fee.



   (a)   Provision of a franchise fee:



      (1)   As compensation for the franchise granted herein, the
Grantee shall pay to the Village a  franchise fee in an annual amount of
five (5%) percent of Gross Revenues as defined in Section 28-03 and Section
28-12(c).



      (2)   To the extent permitted by law and in accordance
therewith, franchise fees in excess of five percent may be collected by the
Village after thirty (30) days written notice to the Grantee, or as otherwise
may be detailed in the franchise agreement.  The recomputed percentage will
be an automatic modification to this Chapter Section after the expiration of
the thirty day (30) notice.  Any such increase in the franchise fee shall
not be considered a rate increase by the Grantee for the purpose of
subscriber notification.



   (b)   Payment of the franchise fee:



      (1)   Franchise fees are to be paid quarterly and not later
than sixty (60)  days following the last day of the quarter.  Franchise
fees are to be mailed by certified mail, or may be hand delivered, to the
Village Treasurer's office.



      (2)   Each franchise fee payment shall be accompanied by a
financial statement, as attached as Exhibit A to the franchise agreement,
that clearly defines the subscriber count and gross revenues for the quarter
said payment is rendered. The financial statement shall be signed by the
Grantee's controller, or other employee knowledgeable as to the accuracy of
the figures used in the computation and the corresponding payment to the
Village.



      (3)   Any franchise fee which remains unpaid after the date
specified in the Chapter shall be delinquent and shall thereafter accrue
interest at the maximum rate permitted by law in the State of Illinois, until
fully paid.  The costs incurred by the Village in obtaining a judgment,
including attorney's fees and court costs, for the unpaid balance of the
franchise fees, as set forth in Section 28-12(b) of the Chapter, shall be
borne by the Grantee.



      (4)   No acceptance of any payment shall be construed as an
accord that the amount paid is, in fact, the correct amount, nor shall such
acceptance of payment be construed as a release of any claim which the
Village may have for further or additional sums payable under the provisions
of this Section.



      (5)   Upon termination of the Franchise at the expiration of
the term provided thereof, or otherwise, the Grantee shall continue to make
quarterly statements and certifications and annual reports as provided in
this Section until such time as all payments due the Village under this
Chapter have been paid and accounted for to the reasonable satisfaction of
the Village.



   (c)   Gross revenue calculations:



      (1)   For purposes of the Gross Revenue calculation, the
phrase "financial interest" as used in this Chapter shall include but not be
limited to:



         a.   Any contract in which the Grantee is to receive a
percentage of the revenues and/or a percentage of the net income of the other
party to the transaction by reason of the activities encompassed by said
contract;



         b.   Any debt relationship in which the Grantee as
debtor borrows funds at a rate more advantageous than that generally
available to similarly situated entities of similar credit worthiness;



         c.   Any debt relationship in which the Grantee as
creditor receives a rate of interest exceeding that which would otherwise be
paid by a similarly situated debtor of similar credit worthiness;



         d.   Any option or warrant to purchase the stock or
other equity interest in an entity, or in an entity related to an entity,
which generates revenues arising from or attributable to the operation of the
System;



         e.   Any debt relationship which has conversion
privileges to a form of equity of the nature described in the preceding
paragraph.



      (2)   For purposes of the Gross Revenue calculation, the
phrase "arising from or attributable to operation of the System" as used in
this Chapter shall include but not be limited to:



         a.   Any activity, product or service which generates
revenue of any type whatsoever and which is offered to the subscribers of the
System by means of the System or any related service;



         b.   Any activity, product or service in the production
or provision of which any of  the assets of the System including but not
limited to cable, production facilities, and administrative facilities, are
included.



   (d)   Audit requirements/financial reviews:



      (1)   The Grantee shall file with the Village an annual 
statement and the parent audited report within one hundred and twenty (120)
days after the closing of the Grantee's books. The audited report shall be
prepared by a Certified Public Accountant and shall clearly show the yearly
total gross revenues by category and accumulated total and the number of
subscribers upon which the franchise fee was based.  In the event that the
Grantee's fiscal year is other than the calendar year, the Grantee shall
notify the Village, in writing, of the period which constitutes its fiscal
year.  If no annual audited statement is prepared, the Grantee shall provide
other annual financial reports as required in the franchise agreement.



   The certified public accountant will certify the accuracy of the
Franchise Fee payments made within the preceding twelve (12) months
thereto.  Said certification shall be prepared in accordance with generally
accepted accounting standards as established by the Financial Accounting
Standards Board.



      (2)   The Village shall have the right to inspect the
Grantee's income records, worksheets, journals, general ledgers, notes,
financial statements, tax returns, and other such financial records as may be
necessary and appropriate to verify the accuracy of the franchise fee
payments.  The Village may use its own personnel or may hire an outside
Certified Public Account to conduct an audit or "Agreed Upon Procedures"
financial review to recompute and verify the franchise fee payment and
compliance with the financial terms of this Chapter.



      (3)   The Village shall provide the Grantee with thirty (30)
days notice of the Village's intent to inspect the financial records of the
Grantee:



         a.   Grantee shall comply with the Village's request and
shall make available, at a reasonable location acceptable to the Village, all
the financial records reasonably requested by the Village so that the Village
might complete its inspection;



         b.   Unless otherwise specified in the Franchise
Agreement, if  it is not reasonably possible for the Grantee to provide
certain specified records or documents at a location determined by the
Village, than the Village may send its representative to the location where
the Grantee houses said records. Village's reasonable travel expense shall be
borne entirely by the Grantee;



         c.   Any additional amount due to the Village as a
result of the Village's financial inspection shall be paid within thirty (30)
days following written notice to the Grantee by the Village which notice
shall include a copy of the financial report. A delinquent payment of the
recomputed amount shall accrue interest in the same manner as a delinquent
franchise fee payment.



      (4)   The cost of the financial review, or financial
inspection, shall be borne by the Grantee if it is properly determined that
the Grantee's annual payment due to the Village for the preceding year, or
the year under investigation, has been underpaid by five (5%) percent or more.



   (e)   Identification of the franchise fee on the subscriber billing
statement:  At such time as the Grantee identifies the franchise fee on the
subscriber's billing statement, the Grantee shall indicate that said fee is
not a new fee, or an increase in the program service fee, that has been
imposed by the Village.  Grantee shall provide a copy of the text to the
Village prior to its receipt by the public to ensure compliance with
applicable law.



(Code 1965, §43.12(a-e))



Sec. 28-13.  Inspection and maintenance of grantee's books and records.



   (a)   Maintenance of records:



      (1)   All financial records of the Grantee with respect to
subscribers, subscriber revenues, and plant and equipment costs associated
with the system facilities shall be allocated  as though the system were a
separate business enterprise.  In the event that the Grantee is a
partnership, the Grantee shall provide separate financial records for all
subscriber revenues and may provide an aggregate financial record for
franchise plant and equipment costs.



      (2)   Unless otherwise specified in the Franchise Agreement, 
all financial, customer service, and operations records of the Grantee shall
be maintained at the local office, or at any other of the Grantee's
facilities that is no more than seventy-five (75) miles from the central
office of the Village Hall.  To the extent that the Grantor identifies
certain records which the Grantee may not reasonably maintain at the local
office, or at the nearest location within the seventy-five mile limitation,
the Grantee may make those records available at another location identified
by the Grantee, providing that the Grantee shall be responsible for all
reasonable travel costs incurred by the Village, or its agent, in the
Village's inspection of the books and records.



      (3)   The Grantee shall maintain the records of subscriber
complaints, system outages, telephone system logs or records, system
technical tests results, CLI testing results, and other records that will
assist the Village in its review of the Grantee's compliance with the Chapter
and franchise agreement until the completion of each of the Grantee's
Performance Evaluation Sessions.  The Village may reasonably request that
certain documents be held for a longer period upon ten (10) days written
notice to the Grantee.



   (b)   Records and reports provided to the village:



      (1)   Subject to the privacy provisions of the Cable
Communications Policy Act of 1984, Grantee shall maintain records of customer
service complaints and technical service  records and shall provide same to
the Village in a manner consistent with the Grantee's management information
system capabilities.



      (2)   The Grantee shall upon request notify the Village in a
written  summary report of the status of all complaints received by the
Grantee and which remain open.



      (3)   Upon request, the Grantee shall provide the Village with
a quarterly report of phone statistics identified by month, for all phone
lines for customer service and technical repair.



      (4)   Upon request, Grantee shall prepare quarterly summary
reports of all service calls and repairs; and a summary of system outages.
The original service call reports and outage logs completed by the technician
shall be retained until the completion of the next Performance Evaluation
Session.



      (5)   Grantee shall, upon request of the Village, provide a
copy of the results of technical tests that are required by the FCC in 47 CFR
Part 76 Subpart K, and as it may be amended from time to time.  It shall be
a requirement under this Chapter to conduct such tests in the manner
prescribed in  47 CFR Part 76 Subpart K.



   (c)   Listing of franchise agreements granted:  The Grantee shall
upon request provide a list of all franchises held by the Grantee in the
State of Illinois within fifty (50) miles of the Village as of the date the
Grantee signs the Village's franchise agreement and  shall upon request
provide an updated list at each Performance Evaluation Session.



   (d)   Reporting of filings or communications:  The Grantee shall,
at the time of filing, provide the Village with a topical list of all
petitions, documents, applications, reports, and communications filed or
submitted by or on behalf of the Grantee with the Securities and Exchange
Commission, the FCC, or any governmental agency or entity having jurisdiction
with respect to the Grantee's cable television business directly affecting
the Grantee's franchise with the Village.  At the request of the Village,
the Grantee shall provide the Village, at no cost, with a copy of any of the
identified documents that the Village deems would be in its interest to
obtain.



   (e)   Annual filing of ownership, rules, terms, regulations: At
times upon request, Grantee shall also file with the Village:



      (1)   A list of the general partners owning five (5%) or more
interest in the partnership whether directly or indirectly; or if a
corporation, the Grantee shall file a list of all its directors, officers and
shareholders owning directly or indirectly five (5%) percent or more of the
stock



      (2)   Copies of all current rules, regulations, terms, and
conditions established, or imposed by the Grantee, in connection with the
establishment, construction, operation, and maintenance of the cable
television system operated under this Chapter. 



      (3)   In the event that there has been no change from the
prior year for the documents described herein, the Grantee shall file a
letter with the Village so stating.



(Code 1965, §43.13(a-e))



Sec. 28-14.  Rates.



   (a)   Universal rates:



      (1)   Rates for all subscribers of basic cable service shall
be uniform throughout the Franchise Area. The Grantee may offer bulk billing
discounts for cable television programming services.  The Grantee shall not,
with regard to fees and rates, discriminate or grant any preference or
advantage to any person; provided, however, that the Grantee may establish
different rates for different classes of subscribers or users based upon cost
of service differentials; provided that the Grantee not discriminate between
any subscribers or users of the same class. Grantee is not prohibited from
offering discounted rates to senior citizens or economically disadvantaged
subscribers.



      (2)   To the extent consistent with law,  the Grantee may
waive, reduce, or suspend installation fees or cable  service fees in a
nondiscriminatory manner for a reasonable period of time as each segment of
the cable system is activated; or during limited promotion (marketing)
periods.



      (3)   No Grantee shall enter into any agreement with a
subscriber which imposes any charge following disconnection of all services.
Grantee may charge for reconnection and subsequent monthly, or periodic
charges, and those charges shall be no greater than charges for new
customers.  This Section shall not prevent a Grantee from refusing service
to any person because Grantee's prior accounts with that person remain due
and owing.



      (4)   Grantee shall not offer  a traditional cable service
which requires more than three (3) months advance payment.



      (5)   The Grantee shall be required to apprise, in writing,
each new subscriber of all applicable fees and charges for providing cable
television service.



      (6)   The Grantee shall, by written correspondence, notify the
Village and each subscriber of a rate increase thirty (30) days prior to the
activation of said increase.  Upon request of the Village, the Grantee shall
appear at a Village Board meeting to apprise the Board of the necessity of
said rate increase.



   (b)   Rates for non-ambulatory, visually, and hearing impaired
subscribers: To the extent consistent with law, rates for devices for
non-ambulatory, visually impaired, or hearing impaired persons that allow
them to receive the cable television service  including such devices as, but
not limited to, remote controls, closed captioned decoders, Braille reading
materials and Braille channel identification devices, shall be no more than
the actual cost of the device; In any event, the rental fee for the device
shall be no more than the same, or similar device, offered to the general
cable subscriber. The Grantee shall offer the non-ambulatory, visually
impaired, or hearing impaired subscriber the option of buying the device at
the Grantee's cost, including any allowable profit, plus the actual cost of
delivery to the subscriber.



   (c)   Regulation of rates and fees:



      (1)   To the extent permitted by law, the Village hereby
expressly  exercises the right:



         a.   To approve the rates which the Grantee charges its
subscribers for basic service and the rates for such other services as
Village may hereafter be permitted to regulate by law.  The Grantee shall
not deny, delay, interrupt or terminate cable communications facilities to
subscribers or users because Village denies a request for a rate increase,
provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed to limit the
Grantee's right to seek judicial review of such action.



         b.   To require that no rate, fee or charge of any kind
shall be charged or collected from subscribers by the Grantee for basic
service or other municipally regulated services without the  authorization
of the Village.  Violation of this Section shall subject the Grantee to the
provisions of Sections 28-22 and 28-23, and shall be deemed to be a material
breach of any Franchise Agreement and shall subject the Grantee to all
remedies and penalties prescribed therein and herein and to all other
remedies, legal and equitable, which are available to the Village.



         c.   To require that the Grantee annually file with the
Village a full schedule of all subscriber and user rates and all other
charges including, but not limited to, pay TV, leased channel and discrete
services, made in connection with the cable communications system.  Said
rate schedules shall be amended whenever such rates change.



            (i)   All rates shall be published and on file
with the Village.



            (ii)   The Grantee shall not discriminate in the
assessment, levy, charge, imposition or collection of rates on the basis of
age, race, creed, color, religion, national origin, sex or marital status.
The rate structure shall be uniform throughout the  franchise territory in
which cable service is provided over the system.



         d.  To require that nothing in this chapter shall be
construed to prohibit the reduction or waiving of charges in conjunction with
promotional campaigns for the purpose of attracting subscribers or users, or
the discounting of  rates for seniors or other classes of customers.



         e.   To allow the Grantee to require all subscribers to
pay for basic service not more than two (2) months in advance. The Grantee
shall require no other advancement of payment for basic service, provided,
however, that nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit an advancement of
payment for installation of cable communication services.



         f.   To require that the Grantee follow Federal
Communications Commission rules with respect to employment of nominal charges
for installation, changes in service and service cancellations. These rules
currently include provisions protecting subscribers from charges for changes
in service tiers for 30 days after Grantee notice of re-tiering or a rate
increase.



         g.   To allow the Grantee to disconnect the subscriber's
service outlet, upon ten (10) days written notice, in the event that a
subscriber fails to pay as properly due and owing a fee or charge.



         h.   To require that the Grantee establish and conform
to the following policy regarding refunds to subscribers and users:



            (i)   If the Grantee collects a deposit or advance
charge on any service or equipment requested by a subscriber or user, the
Grantee shall provide such service or equipment within thirty (30) days of
the collection of the deposit or change or it  shall refund such deposit or
change within five (5) days thereafter.



               (a)   Nothing in this section shall be
construed to relieve the Grantee of any responsibility to subscribers or
users under any contractual agreements into which it enters with them.



               (b)   Nothing in this section shall be
construed as limiting the Grantee's liability for fines or penalties which
may be imposed under this Chapter or any agreement awarded in accordance
herewith for violation or breach of any of their provisions.



               (c)   Nothing in this section shall be
construed to limit the Grantee's liability for damages because of its failure
to provide the service for which the deposit or charge was made.



            (ii)   In the event that a subscriber terminates
basic service during the first twelve (12) months of service because of the
failure of the Grantee to render the service in accordance with the
requirement set forth in this Chapter or in any agreement awarded in
accordance herewith, the Grantee shall refund to such subscriber an amount
equal to the initial applicable installation or reconnection charge paid by
the subscriber.



               (a)   In the event that such subscriber has
made an advance payment the amount so advanced shall be refunded to such
subscriber by the Grantee.  Nothing in this provision shall be construed to
relieve the Grantee of any liability established under any other provision of
this Chapter or any agreement awarding a Franchise in accordance herewith.



            (iii)   In the event that a subscriber terminates
basic service prior to the end of a pre-paid period, the pro-rata portion of
any pre-paid subscriber fee which represents payment for services which are
no longer to be rendered shall be refunded promptly, but in no case more than
sixty (60) days after receipt of the request for termination.



            (i)   To require that the Grantee not charge a
converter security deposit greater than such converter's actual cost to the
Grantee.



            (i)   Any converter security deposit collected by
the Grantee shall be returned to the subscriber twenty-four (24) months after
the installation of such converter, or upon termination of service by the
subscriber and return of such converter undamaged with allowance for
reasonable wear and tear and payment of any outstanding balance due and
payable, whichever occurs first.



      (2)   Whenever Grantee requests a rate increase pursuant to
Section 28-14(c)(1), the Village shall have thirty (30) days from the date
such rate increase is requested to either approve said increase, or to toll
the review for an additional  90 days or  120 days or other such period as
provided under Federal Communications Commission rules.  If no action is
taken within the thirty (30) day period or the tolled period, the increase
shall be deemed to have been approved.  If the Village tolls the request for
further review, the proposed rate increase shall be suspended during the
review period, but in no event shall such proposed increase be suspended
longer than the maximum permitted under the 1992 Act and Federal
Communications Commission rules.  Grantee shall have all further legal
remedies available to it by law should the Village deny the proposed rate
increase or approve only a partial rate increase.



   (d)   Collection of user taxes and fees by the grantee:  To the
extent permitted by law, upon request of the Village, the Grantee shall list
on the billing statement, and collect for the Village, any tax or user fee
imposed by the Village.  The method of collection of the tax or user fee and
the payment of the collected tax or user fee back to the Village shall be
determined by the Village in cooperation with the Grantee at such time as a
tax or user fee is imposed.



   (e)   Option to impose a municipal tax:  The Village may enact a
tax, fee, or assessment of general applicability on the Grantee or the
Grantee's services.



(Code 1965, §43.14(a-e))



Sec. 28-15.  Consumer protection and customer service provisions.



   The Grantee shall be subject to all requirements of the Cable and Video
Customer Protection Law as provided by Article IV of this Chapter.



(Code 1965, §43.15(a-c))  (MC-807, § 1, 8-12-08)



Sec. 28-16.  Program of services.



   (a)   Broad categories of service:



      (1)   The Grantee shall offer broad categories of programming
services designed to meet the needs and interests of the public at large, the
local government, and subscribers.



      (2)   The Grantee shall provide on the basic tier at least one
Illinois commercial broadcast television channel (station) that provides the
community with Illinois specific news, weather, and information.



      However Grantee shall not be required to comply with Section
28-16(a)2 if prohibited from doing so by the FCC or if said requirement is in
conflict with the Grantee's must-carry or re-transmission contracts with
local broadcasters.  This provision of the Chapter shall be subject to Sec.
614 of the Cable Act.



      (3)   The Grantee shall provide the subscriber and the Village
with thirty (30) days advance written notice of any change in channel
assignment, or in the video programming service provided over any channel.



(Code 1965, §43.16(a))



Sec. 28-17.  Technical requirements.



   (a)   Channel capacity:  Each Grantee shall, at minimum:



      (1)   Develop and operate a system with the technological
capabilities specified in the applicable Franchise Agreement, similar
standards being adhered to therein for similar technical applications, and
the community needs and interests ascertained under the Act being addressed
where possible;



      (2)   Agree to modify the capabilities referred to in Section
28-17(a)(1), in accordance with industry-accepted changes in cable
technology, as may be specified in the applicable Franchise Agreement; and



      (3)   Agree to add such system capability provisions to the
System and the Franchise Agreement as may, from time to time, be permitted by
law and agreed to by both parties.



   (b)   Channel activation:  Upon completion of the system build, or
rebuild, the Grantee shall provide a minimum number of activated channels in
accordance with system design requirements and a channel activation schedule
as described in the franchise agreement.



   (c)   Additional service requirements:



      (1)   The system shall be designed to provide community
isolated P.E.G. access channels, and upstream and downstream channel capacity
on the subscriber and institutional network and the franchise agreement may
also provide  for pay-per-view and interactive services.



      (2)   The system shall be engineered to allow subscribers to
purchase premium, or per channel programming, without having to subscribe to
a service tier higher than the basic tier in accordance with applicable law.



   (d)   FCC technical requirements: The Grantee's cable system shall,
at a minimum, meet the FCC's Rules For Cable Television technical standards,
provided, however, that nothing contained herein shall be construed to
prohibit the Grantee from proposing to comply with more rigid technical
performance requirements, in which event the Grantee's application of said
standards shall be incorporated by reference in the franchise agreement, and
will be binding on the Grantee.



   (e)   Industry and manufacturer technical standards and
specifications::  The Grantee shall make a good faith effort to maintain and
operate the cable system within the specifications by the manufacturer for
the systems major components;  and within cable industry accepted
maintenance and operations parameters for like size cable systems.



   (f)   Rights reserved to the village to adopt technical standards:



      (1)   The Village hereby reserves the right to amend this
Chapter to incorporate technical standards which may exceed those established
by the FCC, when and if said right is granted to the Village through federal
or state law.



      (2)   Every franchise award pursuant to this Chapter shall be
subject to such reserved power whether or not expressly conditioned thereon.



   (g)   Program lock-out device:  The Grantee's system shall have the
capability of allowing the subscriber to lock out a channel, or number of
channels, at the discretion of the subscriber.  To the extent consistent
with any applicable rate regulations or other provisions of law, there shall
be no charge for this device or its installation.



   (h)   Standby power:  The Grantee's system shall have standby power
at the headend and as technically appropriate along the trunkline and/or at
the amplifiers in accordance with industry standards.



   (i)   Grounding of sytem components and subscriber drops:



      (1)   Grounding of all cable plant and subscriber drops shall
be in accordance with the latest version of the National Electrical Safety
Code, the National Electric Code, local Chapter and any additional provision
for grounding required by the Grantee's pole lease agreements with the
utilities as any of these documents may be amended from time to time.



      (2)   Service provided in a mobile home park shall be in
accordance with Article 550 of the National Electrical Code as may be amended
from time to time.



      (3)   In instances where cable television plant has been
installed on privately owned poles, Grantee shall adhere to the safety
provisions of the National Electrical Safety Code as amended from time to
time.



   (j)   Pole lease agreements:



      (1)   Grantee shall secure pole lease agreements with the
utilities where applicable.



      (2)   Grantee shall provide to the Village a copy of its pole
lease agreements within thirty (30) days of the request of the Village.



   (k)   Twenty-four hour operation:  The system shall be designed and
shall be maintained to provide twenty four hour continuous operation.



   (l)   System tests and monitoring:



      (1)   Not later than forty-five (45) days after any new, or
substantially rebuilt, portion of the system is made available for service to
subscribers, technical performance tests shall be conducted by the Grantee to
demonstrate compliance with FCC technical standards and the technical
requirements of this Chapter and franchise granted pursuant to this Chapter.



      (2)   System monitoring test points shall be established in
the franchise agreement.  The Village may require periodic testing to be
made at the test points.



      (3)   The Grantee's system shall be electronically swept at
least once a year.



      (4)   The Grantee shall comply with the FCC's CLI testing
requirements and shall immediately provide the Village with a copy of an FCC
order that requires the Grantee to desist service upon any channel found to
be in excess of the signal leakage allowed under FCC rules and regulations.



   (m)   Interference with non-subscribers or public safety
communications: The system shall be operated in such a manner as to avoid
causing interference with reception of off-air television and radio signals,
mobile telephones, amateur radio, and public safety communications.



   (n)   Signal/service interruptions:  The signal provided over the
subscriber network may be interrupted for emergency purposes and may be
interrupted for routine maintenance in accordance with the provisions of
Section 28-19(b).



   (o)   Uniform and strong signals:  The Grantee, through the system,
shall provide uniform, strong, signals which are free from any significant
distortion and interference.  The system shall produce, for reception on
subscriber's receivers, which are in good working order, a picture which is
free from any significant interference, distortion, or ghosting which would
cause any material degradation of video or audio quality.



(Code 1965, §43.17(a-o))



Sec. 28-18.  Public, educational, and governmental access facilities and
services.



   (a)   Access channels:



      (1)   Every System franchised pursuant to the provisions of
this Chapter shall provide for Public, Educational and Governmental Access
pursuant to the Act, and the applicable Franchise Agreement.



      (2)   Nothing contained in this Chapter shall be construed to
limit the ability of the Grantee to make payments in support of the use of
Public, Educational and/or Governmental access, additional to any payments
otherwise required therefor under this  Chapter or the Franchise
Agreement.  However, such additional payments hereunder are expressly not a
requirement of any Franchise granted hereunder and shall in no event be
considered in the calculation of Franchise Fees pursuant to this Chapter.



      (3)   Use of facilities for Public, Educational and
Governmental Access upon the System shall be made available as provided by
law, under the conditions and in the manner provided by rules required
hereinbelow, in connection with the production of that Public, Educational
and Governmental Access programming cablecast upon the System.  The Grantee
shall accept and cablecast such Public, Educational and Governmental access
programming upon the System as shall be provided to the Grantee by all
persons and entities, under terms described in the Franchise Agreement.  To
the extent permitted by the Act, the Grantee shall allow all persons and
entities desiring to cablecast Public, Educational or Governmental Access
programming to produce and distribute such programming upon  the System.



      (4)   Grantee shall make all reasonable efforts to coordinate
the cablecasting of Public, Educational and Governmental Access programming
upon the System with such programming as is cablecast upon other Systems
within the community.



      (5)   Grantee shall have the right as described in the Act to
seek use of allocated but unused Public, Educational, and Governmental Access
channel capacity for carriage of other signals  as permitted by the Act,
provided the Grantee notifies the Village and any other affected legal
parties at least sixty (60) days in advance of its intent to re-program said
access channels.  The Village reserves the right to review the Grantee's
notification and to determine whether existing or planned Public,
Educational, and Governmental Access uses may be harmed.  The Village
further reserves the right to recapture access channel capacity upon
determination at any subsequent time that there is sufficient demand and
community need to restore access capacity, with due notice to the Grantee. 
Grantee will restore said capacity within sixty (60) days, or any other
reasonable length of time determined by the Village.



   (b)   Access facilities:



      (1)   Grantee shall provide, as may be required in the
franchise agreement, an access studio, editing suite, modulators, and
associated television production and editing equipment to allow for the
cablecasting of live and taped programming; and provide for automated
playback of videotapes.  Grantee may also be required to provide a fully
equipped mobile van for the production of on site remote productions.



      (2)   Grantee shall provide subscriber/institutional network
drops and outlets to all user buildings and facilities identified in the
franchise agreement. The exact number of drops and outlets to be provided in
each facility and building shall be addressed in the franchise agreement.



      (3)   Access facilities, equipment, and services shall be made
accessible to disabled individuals in a non-discriminatory manner as required
by law. Grantee shall assure that said individuals shall be given reasonable
technical and physical assistance which will provide them the opportunity to
fully utilize and take advantage of the access facilities, services and
equipment.



   (c)   Alternative provision of access facilities and services:



      (1)   In lieu of providing some, or all, of the access
facilities and services required under this Chapter, the Grantee may, upon
approval of the Village and at the Village's option, provide a sum agreed to
in the franchise agreement for the Village to apply towards the provision of
access service and facilities.



      (2)   In the event that there is more than one franchise area,
or more than one cable operator within the corporate limits, all franchisees
shall contribute in an equitable manner through construction, provision of
equipment, cooperative training efforts, or monetary funds for the provision
of access facilities and services, rather than cause a duplication of
facilities which the Village may deem to be unnecessary.



   (d)   Training of users:  Grantee shall provide the initial
training of users of the access channels and facilities.  Additional staff
support may be provided for in the franchise agreement.



   (e)   Voluntary monetary contribution:  Nothing in this Chapter
shall prohibit the Grantee from making voluntary monetary contributions for
the provision and support of access in addition to the requirements of this
Chapter



(Code 1965, §43.18(a-e))



Sec. 28-19.  Construction.



   The Grantee shall be subject to all requirements of Chapter 94, Article
VI of this code, "Construction of Utility Facilities in the Public
Rights-of-Way."



(Code 1965, §43.19(a-o))  (MC-807, § 1, 8-12-08)



Sec. 28-20.  Service to all residents, businesses, and institutions.



   (a)   Extension of service to residences and businesses within the
franchise area:



      (1)   Unless otherwise provided for in the franchise
agreement, the franchise area shall be the current and future corporate
boundaries of the Village.  Service shall be extended to one hundred percent
(100%) of the dwelling and commercial units within twelve (12) months of the
effective date of the franchise granted hereunder, unless an exception to the
100 percent extension of service is granted in the franchise agreement.



      (2)   For the purpose of renewal, Grantee shall confirm that
it has extended service as required hereunder or by its franchise agreement
before  expiration of the current franchise.



   (b)   Line extensions to new development areas or annexed territory:
Grantee shall extend the system and make service available in new development
areas within the Village or such areas newly annexed to the Village. Grantee
shall design, construct and operate the system in newly annexed areas of the
Village, or in newly established subdivisions, or platted units, whichever
first occurs, provided that Grantee shall not be required to service a new
residential subdivision until such time as fifty (50%) percent of the homes
per linear mile in such subdivision, or in any platted unit of the
subdivision, have been occupied;  or within twelve (12) months of the first
occupation in that subdivision or platted unit. Grantee shall extend service
to newly annexed or constructed areas upon recognition that said area exists
or within ninety (90) days of written notification from the Village.



   (c)   Waiver of line extension:  Grantee may seek a waiver of line
extension to commercial business units located in isolated locations, if the
Grantee can establish that the provision of said service would be financially
burdensome. The Village will not unreasonably deny said waiver.



   (d)   Delays in construction:  If Grantee is delayed at any time in
the progress of construction or the furnishing of cable service to any
dwelling unit, commercial business unit, or government building or school, by
labor disputes, weather conditions precluding construction activity, any
unreasonable delays caused solely by the Village, reasonable disputes with
utility companies, or other causes beyond the Grantee's control, the time
elements set forth in Section 19 and/or in the franchise agreement shall be
extended provided that:



      (1)   Grantee notifies the Village in writing no more than
seven (7) days after the occurrence of the delay;



      (2)   The Village acknowledges to Grantee that such delay is
considered beyond the control of the Grantee; and



      (3)   The Grantee and the Village mutually agree upon a time
for the completion of the construction or activation of service.



   Any delay beyond the terms of the time line for extending cable service
