ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL



Sec. 50-1—50-30.  Reserved.



ARTICLE II. HEALTH DIVISION



Sec. 50-31. Duties.



   The health division, under the direction of the director of community
development, shall be responsible for the enforcement of all public health
regulations of this chapter and otherwise responsible for supervision and
control of village public health activities and programs.



(Code 1965, § 4.08(a); MC-800, § 1, 3-11-08)



Sec. 50-32. Personnel.



   Within annual budgetary appropriations authorized by the president and
board of trustees, the director of community development may appoint
sanitarians, environmentalists and inspectors to aid in the enforcement of
public health and other appropriate sections of this chapter. The director of
community development shall perform the duties of sanitarian and
environmentalist in the absence of personnel to assume such duties. One
person may hold the title of sanitarian and environmentalist at the same time.



(Code 1965, § 4.08(b); MC-800, § 1, 3-11-08)



Secs. 50-33—50-60.  Reserved.



ARTICLE III.  CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER



Sec. 50-61. Duties and powers.



   In addition to other duties prescribed by this chapter, it shall be the
duty of the code enforcement officer to execute and enforce all statutes of
the state, provisions of this Code, and rules and regulations relating to
health, and to take such other action as is necessary for the promotion and
improvement of the public health, not inconsistent with the foregoing
statutes, ordinances, rules and regulations.



(Code 1965, § 21.02(a); MC-800, § 1, 3-11-08)



Sec. 50-62.  Building inspector.



   It is made the duty of the building inspector to administer and enforce
the provisions of building ordinances pertaining to health and sanitation.



(Code 1965, § 21.02(b))



Sec. 50-63.  Hearings on violations.



   When it appears that any state statute or provision of this chapter
relating to health or any rule or regulation has been violated, the code
enforcement officer shall cause notice of such fact to be given to the person
concerned, who shall be given an opportunity to be heard concerning such
alleged violation.



   The notice shall specify the date, hour and place of hearing, and the
hearing shall be private. If, after such hearing, the code enforcement
officer shall believe the ordinance or regulation has been violated, he shall
cause the violator to be prosecuted.



(Code 1965, § 21.02(c); MC-800, § 1, 3-11-08)



Secs. 50-64—50-90.  Reserved.



ARTICLE IV. NUISANCES



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Sec. 50-91. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Nuisance means any thing, act, occupation or condition which shall
continue for such length of time as to:



      (1)   Substantially injure or endanger the    comfort,
health, repose, safety or welfare of the public;



      (2)   In any way render the public insecure in life or in the
use of property; or



      (3)   Constitute public indecency under 720 ILCS 5/11-9 or
obscenity under 720 ILCS 5/11-20(b).



(Code 1965, § 21.06(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 50-92.  Creation, maintenance or permitting.



   No person shall create, erect, cause, maintain or permit a nuisance
within the village, outside the village limits, or within the jurisdiction of
the village, as provided by the Illinois Compiled Statutes.



(Code 1965, § 21.05)



Sec. 50-93.  Enumeration.



   The following are declared to be nuisances and are strictly prohibited:



      (1)   Food. The sale or offering for sale to the public of
decayed, harmfully adulterated, polluted or unwholesome food or drink.



      (2)   Dead animals. Carcasses of animals, birds or fowl not
buried or otherwise disposed of in a sanitary manner within 24 hours after
death.



      (3)   Accumulations. Accumulations of trash, rubbish, rotting
lumber, animal or vegetable matter, bedding, or any material including that
in which flies, mosquitoes, disease-carrying insects, rats or other vermin
may breed, either inside or outside of a residence or other structure.



      (4)   Stagnant water. Stagnant water in which mosquitoes,
flies or other insects can multiply.



      (5)   Smoke and fumes. The escape of smoke, soot, cinders,
noxious acids, fumes, gases, fly ash or industrial dust in such quantities as
to endanger the health of persons of ordinary sensibilities or to threaten or
cause substantial injury to property.



      (6)   Water pollution. The pollution of any public well or
cistern, stream, lake, canal or body of water, by sewage, industrial wastes
or other substances.



      (7)   Foul odors. Any use of property, substances  or
things  emitting or causing any foul, offensive, noisome, nauseous, noxious,
or disagreeable odors, effluvia or stenches extremely repulsive to the
physical senses of ordinary persons which annoy, discomfort, injure or
inconvenience the health of any appreciable number of persons  within the
village.



      (8)   Abandoned wells. Abandoned wells not securely covered or
secured from public use.



      (9)   Keeping of animals. The keeping of any animals in an
unclean manner, or the keeping of any offensive animals, or the continued
presence of rats or other vermin.



      (10)   Privies. Any disposition of human excreta outside the
sewage system unless permitted by the village manager.



      (11)   Disorderly houses. Disorderly houses, bawdy houses,
house of ill fame, gambling houses and buildings or structures kept or
resorted to for the purpose of prostitution, promiscuous sexual intercourse
or gambling.



      (12)   Repeated violations. Any place or premises where
village ordinances or state laws relating to public health, safety, peace,
morals or welfare are continuously or repeatedly violated.



      (13)   Dead, damaged, diseased, or overgrown trees and
plants.  Those trees or plants that are dead, damaged, diseased, or that
have grown to such an extent that they obscure or obstruct access to a
building's doors, stairwells, fire escapes or similar access points, or that
are causing structural damage to a building or its component parts. Dead
trees or plants located within areas zoned as "public lands/open space" as
defined in the Homewood Zoning Ordinance that do not pose a danger to the
public or property of another are hereby excluded from this definition.



      (14)   Visual obstructions. Trees, hedges, billboards, or
other obstructions which prevent persons driving vehicles on the streets from
obtaining a clear view of traffic when approaching an intersection or
pedestrian crosswalk, or which obstruct the illumination from a public
streetlight, or as may be regulated by the zoning regulations of the village.
Also, in residential districts, as defined by the zoning ordinance,
plantings, structures or gradings of less than eight feet in height or
greater than two feet in height, (above the centerline of the street),
placed, planted, erected or maintained so as to protrude into or over any
public right-of-way within 45 feet from the corner of two intersecting street
lines or located in that portion of a required front yard or side yard
adjoining a street situated within 45 feet of the lot corner formed by the
intersection of two intersecting street lines.



      (15)   Overhanging trees. Limbs of trees which project over a
public sidewalk less than eight feet above the surface thereof or less than
ten feet above the surface of a street. Any willow tree within 100 feet of a
public drain or sewer.



      (16)   Weeds.  All grasses, annual plants and vegetation,
other than trees or shrubs provided; however, this term shall not include
cultivated flowers and gardens, nor shall it include grasses, annual plants
and vegetation located on publicly owned property located in areas zoned as
"public lands/open space" as defined in the Homewood Zoning Ordinance.



      (17)   Fireworks; exception. All use or display of fireworks
except as provided by the laws of the state and ordinances of the village.



      (18)   Unsafe buildings. All buildings or structures so old,
dilapidated or out of repair as to be dangerous, unsafe, unsanitary or
otherwise unfit for human use.



      (19)   Wires. All wires over streets, alleys or public grounds
which are strung less than 15 feet above the surface of the street or ground.



      (20)   Sound devices; exception. The operation of any sound
device or instrument which casts sound upon any street or public place,
unless approved by the village manager.



      (21)   Noise.  No person shall cause or permit the emission
of sound beyond the boundaries of his property any noise that unreasonably
interferes with the enjoyment of life or with any lawful business or activity
in violation of 415 ILCS 5/24, as amended from time to time.



(MC-679)



      (22)   Interference with or obstruction of public or village
rights-of-way. Interference with or obstruction of public streets, alleys,
sidewalks, crosswalks and village easements and rights-of-way, and all
excavations in or under the same, and navigable bodies of water, except as
permitted by this Code or which, although made in accordance with this Code,
are kept or maintained for an unreasonable length of time after the purpose
thereof has been accomplished.



      (23)   Excavations. Open and unguarded pits, wells,
excavations or unused basements freely accessible from any street, alley or
sidewalk.



      (24)   Refrigerators. Abandoned refrigerators or iceboxes, or
other containers capable of trapping a child inside, from which the doors and
other covers have not been removed or which cannot be opened from the inside
by pushing only.



      (25)   Other acts declared by ordinance or statute. Any act or
omission declared a nuisance by the village board, any other section of this
Code or by the Illinois Compiled Statutes.



      (26)   Graffiti. Any unauthorized inscription, word, figure,
design, symbol or combination or collection thereof, which is marked, etched,
scratched, painted, drawn or printed on any structural component of any
building, structure, or other facility, privately or publicly owned,
regardless of the nature of the material of that structural component.
Persons observing graffiti shall report their observation to the village
police department within 24 hours. Graffiti shall be removed no later than 72
hours from the date of service of notice, as provided in section 50-94.



      (27)   Sound Amplifying Devices.  Unauthorized use of any
sound amplifying device as prohibited by this Chapter.



      (28)   Donation Boxes. All donation boxes as prohibited by
this chapter.



(Code 1965, § 21.06) (MC-810, § 1, 10-14-08; MC-842, § 1, 3-22-11)



Sec. 50-94. Abatement.



   (a)   Notice to abate.  If the village manager or the  inspecting
officer of  the  village determines that a nuisance exists on private
property, the village manager shall cause a notice to be served on the owner,
or, if the owner cannot be found, on the occupant or person causing,
permitting or maintaining  such  nuisance, and  to post a copy of the
notice on the premises. Such notice shall direct the owner, occupant or
person causing, permitting or maintaining such nuisance to abate or remove
such nuisance within such time as is designated in the notice and shall state
that unless such nuisance is so abated, the village will cause the same to be
abated and will charge the costs to the owner, occupant or person causing,
permitting or maintaining the nuisance.



   (b)   Abatement by village. If the nuisance is not abated within the
time provided or if the owner, occupant or person causing the nuisance cannot
be found, the village manager shall cause the abatement or removal of such
nuisance.



   (c)   Summary abatement. If any nuisance is an immediate danger to
public health or safety, or if the nuisance exists on public property, it
shall be summarily abated by the village.



   (d)   Cost of abatement. The cost of abating a public nuisance by
the village shall be collected as a debt from the owner, occupant or person
causing, permitting or maintaining the nuisance, and if the notice to abate
the nuisance has been given to the owner, such cost shall be assessed against
the real estate as other special taxes are assessed.



(Code 1965, § 21.07)



Sec. 50-95. Minimum temperatures at certain times for commercial or office
premises; penalty for violation of section.



   The owner of any premises that is let for commercial or office use
shall maintain or cause to be maintained a minimum temperature of 68 degrees
Fahrenheit from 7:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. and a minimum of 50 degrees
Fahrenheit from 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. from October 1 of each year to May 15
of the succeeding year. In the absence of the property owner, any person
designated as managing agent of such premises shall have the same
responsibility. Upon conviction of a violation of this section, the minimum
fine shall be $50.00, plus court costs. Each day that the required minimum
heating requirements are not met shall be a separate violation of this
section.



(Code 1965, § 21.11)



Sec. 50-96. Penalty for maintenance of nuisance.



   Any person who causes, permits or maintains a nuisance, or who fails to
abate a nuisance as directed by a notice from the village manager, shall be
subject to the penalty provided for in section 1-11. Such penalty shall be in
addition to any liability for the cost of abating the nuisance.



(Code 1965, § 21.10)



Sec. 50-97.  Sound Amplification Devices.



   (a)   Definitions.  For the purpose of this chapter, whenever the
following terms appear in this chapter, they shall have the following
meaning, unless a different meaning is clear from the context:



      Sound Amplifying Device – means any device including, but not
limited to self-contained portable handheld music or sound amplification or
reproduction equipment, AM/FM radio receiver, personal or portable audio or
video player, phonograph record, magnetic tape, any electronically
synthesized sound or the human voice;



      Plainly Audible – Plainly audible means any sound that can be
detected by a person using his or her unaided hearing faculties.  As an
example, if the sound source is a portable or personal vehicular sound
amplification or reproduction device, the enforcing officer need not
determine the title of the song, specific words, or the artist performing the
song. The detection of the rhythmic bass component of the music is sufficient
to constitute a plainly audible sound.



   (b)   Noise Prohibited. 



      (1)   Between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. no driver
of a motor vehicle within this village shall operate or permit operation of
any sound amplification device, which can be heard outside the vehicle from
75 or more feet when the vehicle is either being operated or parked, unless
such system is being operated to request assistance or warn of a hazardous
situation.



      (2)   Between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. no driver
of any motor vehicle within this village shall operate or permit operation of
any sound amplification system, which can be heard outside the vehicle when
the vehicle is either being operated or parked, unless such system is being
operated to request assistance or warn of a hazardous situation.



      (3)   Between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. any sound
amplifying device shall not be operated on public property or a public right
of way in such manner to be plainly audible at a distance of 75 feet in any
direction from the sound-amplifying device.  Between the hours of 10:00 p.m.
and 8:00 a.m. any sound amplifying device shall not be operated on public
property or public right-of-way in such a manner to be plainly audible at a
distance of 25 feet in any direction from the sound-amplifying device.



      (4)   Between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m., unless a
permit has been issued, it shall be unlawful to use or operate a sound
amplifying device on private property in such a manner that it is plainly
audible at a distance of 100 feet in any direction from the sound amplifying
device.



      (5)   Between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., unless a
permit has been issued, it shall be unlawful to operate a sound-amplifying
device on private property in such a manner that would be plainly audible at
a distance of 50 feet in any direction from the sound-amplifying device. 



   (c)   Permits – Application.  Anyone desiring to use or operate a
sound amplification device beyond the limits stated in 50-97 (b)(4) and (5)
above, must make application to the chief of police or his designee for a
sound amplification permit.  Such application shall state whether live or
recorded sound will be amplified and if live, the names and addresses of the
performers shall be provided.  The chief of police or his designee shall
issue a permit to anyone who applies for the same.  Each permit is valid
only during the time specified in the permit.  Each permittee shall comply
with all the terms of this Code and shall be responsible for seeing that the
sound amplifying device is used or operated in accordance therewith.



   (d)   Terms of Permit. 



      (1)   The permit shall be in effect only from 10:00 a.m. to
10:00 p.m. local time Sunday through Thursday and 10:00 a.m. to 12:00
midnight Friday, Saturday and holidays.



      (2)   The sound amplification device shall not produce plainly
audible sound beyond 200 feet from the device.



      (3)   The permit shall not allow plainly audible sound within
50 feet of a school or a house of worship during the hours they are in
session or within 50 feet of a hospital or nursing home at any time.



   (e)   Exemptions.  The provisions of this Section shall not apply
to emergency vehicles, warning or anti-theft devices, units of government,
carillons and authorized entertainment performed during "Homewood Days" or
other publicly sanctioned events.



Sec. 50-98.  Donation boxes.



   (a)   Definitions. For the purpose of this section, whenever the
following terms appear, they shall have the following meaning unless a
different meaning is clear from the context:



      (1)   Donation box. Any receptacle or container located
outside of an enclosed building designed, intended, or used for collection
and storage of donated items or materials.



      (2)   Paper recycling box. A donation box specifically
designed for the collection and temporary storage of paper products to be
recycled.



   (b)   Donation boxes prohibited. No person shall place, use or allow
the installation or operation of a donation box within the village. The
owner, lessee, or other person or legal entity in control of the property
where a donation box is maintained in violation of this chapter and the owner
or operator of said box shall each be liable for any violation of this
section.



   (c)   Paper recycling boxes allowed in limited circumstances. Paper
recycling boxes shall be exempt from the prohibitions of this section only if
they meet all of the following criteria:



      (1)   The box is no larger than six feet in height and 25
square feet in ground area;



      (2)   The box is located on the premises of a church, school,
or other nonprofit or governmental entity that receives proceeds from the
recycling of paper products deposited in the box;



      (3)   No more than two boxes shall be located on any one
parcel;



      (4)   The box location shall not create a safety hazard. Such
hazards shall include, but not be limited to, the placement within 100 yards
of any place where flammable liquids or gases are stored; or placement where
the donation box interferes with vehicular or pedestrian circulation;



      (5)   The box shall be located on a paved surface;



      (6)   The box shall not be located: in the public
right-of-way; in any required front or side yard; in any parking space
required by Section 11 of the Homewood Zoning Ordinance; or within five feet
of a fire hydrant;



      (7)   The box and surrounding area shall be maintained in a
tidy and clean manner; no materials shall be allowed to accumulate outside of
the box;



      (8)   The box shall be kept in good repair with appropriate
means of closure to prevent loose material from overflowing or blowing away;



      (9)   The box shall be emptied regularly.



   (d)   Paper recycling boxes - permit required. Entities desiring to
locate a paper recycling box on their property must first obtain a permit
from the community development department. The application for a permit shall
include the following information:



      (1)   Proof of the applicant's tax-exempt status (not required
for governmental entities);



      (2)   Site plan indicating the location of the box;



      (3)   Name and contact information for the box owner;



      (4)   Name and contact information for the person to be
available during regular business hours who will be responsible for
compliance with this section;



      (5)   Photograph or picture of the box to be installed.



(MC-842, § 1, 3-22-11; MC-852, § 1, 8-23-11)



Secs. 50-99—50-120.  Reserved.



DIVISION 2. MOSQUITO NUISANCES



Sec. 50-121.  Open excavations.



   All open excavations, including the removal of topsoil, except those
excavations or topsoil removals that are referred to in sections 50-122,
50-123 and 50-124, must either provide for complete self-drainage, or if
self-drainage is not provided, then the following conditions must be met:



      (1)   A minimum water depth of four feet shall be maintained
at all times.



      (2)   All  shorelines within  the  zone  of water level
fluctuation shall be constructed and maintained on a slope of four feet
horizontal to one foot vertical, or steeper, and where such sloping may
result in the creation of a hazardous or dangerous condition, the provision
of fencing, exit ramps or stairs, ladders or other safety devices may be
required.



      (3)   The topmost berm around such excavation shall be
constructed and maintained to permit ready access of, and shall be
continuously available to, light vehicles for the purposes of mosquito
control.



      (4)   Provision shall be made for prompt and adequate control
of all aquatic vegetation and the removal of debris and floatage below the
topmost berm.



(Code 1965, § 21.08(a))



Sec. 50-122. Building construction.



   All open excavations or removal of topsoil necessary or incidental to
the construction or installation of building, structures or other fixed works
shall be excluded from the provisions of section 50-121; provided, however,
that if such necessary or incidental excavations or areas of topsoil removal
are not completely covered within a period of one year after commencing the
excavation or removal of topsoil, then such excavation shall be made
self-draining or shall be backfilled within 30 days after notification, as
provided for in section 50-129.



(Code 1965, § 21.08(b))



Sec. 50-123. Ditches and culverts.



   All  ditches and  culverts  shall  be  constructed so that they
are completely self-draining, and all ditches, culverts and natural
watercourses shall be maintained free of debris and other obstructions.



(Code 1965, § 21.08(c))



Sec. 50-124. Septic tanks.



   All septic tanks and seepage systems shall be installed in accordance
with the specifications and requirements of the village current at the time
of installation.



(Code 1965, § 21.08(d))



Sec. 50-125. Ponds and lakes.



   All ponds, lakes or other artificial impoundments shall be constructed
and maintained in a manner to conform with the provisions of section 50-121.



(Code 1965, § 21.08(e))



Sec. 50-126. Containers.



   All artificial containers and water holding devices so placed that they
may hold water for a period of five days or longer, unless such containers or
devices are tightly covered or screened to prevent the entry of mosquitoes,
constitute a public nuisance. No person shall maintain on his premises
unscreened or uncovered containers or other water holding devices under
conditions that permit mosquito larvae or pupae to develop. All such
uncovered or unscreened containers or other water holding devices shall be
completely drained or the water therein changed at intervals of not more than
five days between April 1 and October 25, or effective insecticides must be
applied to all exposed water surfaces at intervals of not more than five days
during such period. The failure to maintain such containers or devices free
of mosquito larvae or pupae during such period constitutes a violation of
this division.



(Code 1965, § 21.08(f))



Sec. 50-127. Weeds.



   All weeds and underbrush, as well as weeds otherwise injurious to
public health or welfare because of the dissemination of pollen or otherwise,
are hereby declared to be a public nuisance. In addition to the cutting
requirements of section 114-32, all such plants shall be cut, pulled,
destroyed or chemically sprayed with an effective chemical weedkiller by the
owner or person in control of such plot of ground at least twice a year, once
between May 15 and June 15 and once between July 1 and August 1, of each
year. The failure to cut, pull, destroy or chemically spray such plants
within each such designated period shall constitute a violation of this
division. This section shall not apply to publicly owned sites being
maintained in a natural condition.



(Code 1965, § 21.08(g))



Sec. 50-128. Excavation permit.



   A permit shall be obtained from the building inspector or village
engineer for each excavation, construction or installation referred to in
sections 50-121—50-125. Drawings and other information pertaining to
compliance with the requirements of this division may be required in
application for the permit, in addition to the requirements of any other
provisions of this chapter.



(Code 1965, § 21.08(h); MC-800, § 1, 3-11-08)



Sec. 50-129. Notice to comply.



   When the owner or person in control of any property fails to comply
with sections 50-126—50-128, the building inspector or code enforcement
officer shall immediately serve written notice upon such owner or person to
obtain compliance therewith. The notice shall stipulate the time allowed for
full and complete compliance, and each day of failure to comply with the
notice after the time stipulated therein is elapsed shall constitute a
separate offense.



(Code 1965, § 21.08(I); MC-800, § 1, 3-11-08)



Secs. 50-130—50-150. Reserved.



ARTICLE V. SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES



Sec. 50-151. Definitions.



   All definitions contained in the Smoke Free Illinois Act (410 ILCS 82/1
et seq.) as amended from time to time, are hereby adopted by reference.



(MC-868, § 2, 3-13-12)



Sec. 50-152. Adoption by reference.



   The following sections of the Smoke Free Illinois Act are hereby
adopted by reference as if fully restated herein:



   Sec. 15. Smoking in public places, places of employment, and
governmental vehicles prohibited. (410 ILCS 82/15)



   Sec. 20. Posting of signs; removal of ashtrays. (410 ILCS 82/20)



   Sec. 25. Smoking prohibited in student dormitories. (410 ILCS 82/25)



   Sec. 30. Designation of other nonsmoking areas. (410 ILCS 82/30)



   Sec. 35. Exemptions. (410 ILCS 82/35)



   Sec. 70. Entrances, exits, windows, and ventilation intakes. (410 ILCS
82/70)



(MC-868, § 2, 3-13-12)



Sec. 50-153. Violations.



   (a)   A person, corporation, partnership, association or other
entity who violates Section 15 of the Act (adopted by reference) shall be
fined pursuant to this Section. Each day that a violation occurs is a
separate violation.



   (b)   A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited
under Section 15 of the Act shall be fined $100 for a first offense and $250
for each subsequent offense. A person who owns, operates, or otherwise
controls a public place or place of employment that violates Section 15 of
the Act shall be fined $250 for each violation.



(MC-868, § 2, 3-13-12)

ARTICLE II. LANDMARK DESIGNATION



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Sec. 54-31. Declaration of policy and intent of article.



   It is hereby found and declared that in the village the movements and
shifts of population and the changes in residential, commercial and
industrial use and customs tend to threaten with disappearance areas, places,
buildings, structures, works of art and other objects having a special
historical, community or aesthetic interest or value and whose preservation
and continued utilization are necessary and desirable to sound community
planning and the welfare of the residents of this village. The authority
provided in section 54-32 is directed to such ends, and the use of such
rights and powers as provided in section 54-32 for the preservation and
continued utilization of such property is hereby declared to be a public use
essential to the public interest of this village.



(Code 1965, § 19.01)



Sec. 54-32. Authority to designate.



   (a)   Village board. The village board shall have the power to
provide for official landmark designation by ordinance of areas, places,
buildings, structures, works of art and other objects having a special
historical, community or aesthetic interest or value. In connection with such
areas, places, buildings, structures, works of art or other objects so
designated by ordinance, whether owned or controlled privately or by any
public body, to provide special conditions; to impose regulations governing
construction, alterations, demolition and use; to deny application for
building demolition permits and building permits to add to, modify, or remove
a portion of any such landmark building; and to adopt other additional
measures appropriate for their preservation, protection, enhancement,
rehabilitation, reconstruction, perpetuation, or use, which additional
measures may include, but are not limited to, the authority given to all
municipalities by 65 ILCS 5/11-48.2-2.



   (b)   New or special commission. The village board may at any time,
by ordinance, create a new or special commission, board or department or
designate an existing commission, board or department to administer the
powers and purposes described in subsection (a) of this section in lieu of
the village board or as an advisory assistant to the village board, in
accordance with the authority found in 65 ILCS 5/11-48.2-3.



(Code 1965, § 19.02)



Sec. 54-33. Procedure.



   Any individual or group of individuals wishing to have a site
designated as an official landmark shall make application to the village on a
form to be developed by the village staff. The village board may also
initiate such application on its own motion. The application shall describe
the site to be designated and shall include a detailed statement of the
reasons why the applicant believes the site should be designated as an
official landmark. Each such application shall be scheduled for informal
review at a public meeting of the village board. At the conclusion of that
informal review, if the village board believes that the application merits
further consideration, they shall schedule a public hearing, at which time
testimony may be given for and against such designation. At the conclusion of
that public hearing, the village board may either deny that application,
instruct the village attorney to draft the necessary ordinance establishing
the property as an official landmark, refer the matter for additional study
or advice, or take any other action authorized by 65 ILCS 5/11- 48.2-1 et
seq. When designating any property as an official landmark, the village board
shall support that designation with findings of fact based upon testimony
given at such public hearing.



(Code 1965, § 19.03)



Sec. 54-34. Notice.



   No action taken by the village under this article directing a private
owner to do or refrain from doing any specific thing, or refusing to permit a
private owner to do some specific thing he desires to do, in connection with
property designated by ordinance under this article, shall be taken by the
village except after due notice to such owner and opportunity for such owner
to be heard at the public hearing required under section 54-33. The
expression "due notice" shall mean a minimum of 15 days' written notice to
the actual owner of record of the subject property. Such notice shall either
be hand delivered or mailed by certified or registered mail. The 15- day
period shall begin to run from the date the notice is delivered to the owner
of record or the date the notice is deposited by either certified or
registered mail in the United States mail, addressed to the owner of record
at his place of residence. If the address of one or more owners of the
subject property cannot be located by the village, notice of the public
hearing may be given to any such owner by publication of the time and place
of the hearing and the purpose of the hearing, including the commonly known
address and legal description of the subject property, in a newspaper of
general circulation within the village, at least 15 days prior to the public
hearing.



(Code 1965, § 19.04)



Sec. 54-35. Criteria.



   In determining whether property should be given an official landmark
designation, the village board, or any other commission, board or department
acting under the authority of this article, shall consider the following
criteria and shall also consider any additional justification for granting or
denying an application under this article as found in the application itself
or as established or suggested by the public hearing required to be held
under this article:



      (1)   The site has major architectural or aesthetic
significance to the community.



      (2)   The site is representative of the distinguishing
characteristics of an architectural type, style, method of construction or of
local materials or craftsmanship.



      (3)   The site is the work of or associated with a national or
locally known architect or builder.



      (4)   The site is an example of a particular style in terms of
detail, material and/or workmanship with little or no alteration to the
original structure.



      (5)   The site has a strong association with the life or
activity of a person or persons who have contributed to or participated in
the historical events of the nation, state or community.



      (6)   The site is associated with an antiquated use due to
technological or social change in the nation, state or community.



      (7)   The site is or has been in the past the residence of a
prominent national figure.



      (8)   The site is representative of a historical era in the
development of this village.



(Code 1965, § 19.05)



Sec. 54-36. Final notice to property owner.



   Should the village board adopt an ordinance designating a property as
an official landmark, a certified copy of that ordinance shall be furnished
to the property owner within ten days after its effective date. Failure of
the property owner to receive such ordinance within the ten-day period shall
not invalidate the force and effect of that ordinance. This section shall be
satisfied by personal delivery or by the depositing of the certified copy in
the United States mail by either certified or registered mail within the
ten-day period, addressed to the owner at his last known place of residence
or business or, if not known, then in care of the address of the landmark
property itself.



(Code 1965, § 19.06)



Sec. 54-37. Appeals.



   An appeal from the final decision of the village board under this
article shall be taken directly to a court of competent jurisdiction in the
manner prescribed in the Administrative Review Law (735 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.).



(Code 1965, § 19.08)



Secs. 54-38--54-60. Reserved.



DIVISION 2. CONSTRUCTION, ALTERATION AND DEMOLITION



Sec. 54-61. Definitions.



The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall
have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context
clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Alteration means any act or process which changes one or more of the
exterior features of the property and improvements which have been designated
for preservation under this division.



   Construction means any act or process which requires a building permit.



   Demolition means any act or process which destroys or removes, in whole
or in part, an improvement which has been designated for preservation under
this division.



   Exterior features means the architectural character, the general
composition and the general arrangement of the exterior of an improvement,
including the kind, color and texture of building materials and the type and
character of windows, doors, light fixtures, signs, fences and appurtenant
elements visible from public streets and thoroughfares.



(Code 1965, § 19.07(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 54-62. Scope of division.



   No alterations, interior construction which affects structural members,
exterior construction, or exterior demolition may be performed on property
and improvements which have been designated as official landmarks under this
article, unless first approved by the village board.



(Code 1965, § 19.07(b))



Sec. 54-63. Approval procedure.



   The approval procedure shall be as follows:



      (1)   Application; contents. Applications for alterations,
interior construction which affects structural members, exterior construction
or demolition of official landmarks shall be filed with the village manager
on forms provided by the village. The applicant shall furnish such
information, plans, specifications and other documents as the village manager
or village board may reasonably request in connection with the application.



      (2)   Review by village board; public hearing; notice. The
village board shall review such application within 30 days of its having been
filed with the village manager and shall approve the request if it finds that
the proposed work is in accordance with the applicable criteria established
in section 54-64. Should the village board determine that the proposed work
is not in accordance with such criteria, then it shall schedule a public
hearing to be held within the next 60 days. The applicant shall be notified
in writing of the time, date, place and purpose of such hearing by certified
mail, properly addressed to the applicant at the address given on the
application. Notice of that public hearing shall also be given by certified
mail to the owners of record as shown on the tax assessor's most recent
rolls, of property within 250 feet in each direction of the subject landmark.
All such notices shall be mailed not more than 30 days nor less than ten days
in advance of such hearing. Also, notice shall be published at least once not
less than 15 days, nor more than 30 days, in advance of such hearing in a
paper of general circulation in the village. The hearing may be continued
from time to time without further notice.



      (3)   Public hearing; record. At that public hearing the
applicant, all notified property owners and all other interested parties
shall be allowed to speak. A record of the proceeding shall be made and
maintained by the village clerk.



      (4)   Decision. The village board shall render a decision to
approve, deny or modify the applicant's request on the basis of the criteria
established in section 54-64 within 30 days after the conclusion of the
public hearing. The village board's decision shall be in writing and shall
include findings of fact in support of such decision. A copy of the decision
shall be mailed to the applicant.



      (5)   Approval or denial. If the proposed work is approved, no
change may be made in that proposed work without the submission of a new
application. If the proposed work is denied, the same application shall not
be resubmitted within the next 12 months, except upon the written request of
an applicant indicating the incorporation of changes in plans and
specifications as may have been recommended by the village board.



(Code 1965, § 19.07(c))



Sec. 54-64. Approval criteria.



   The village board shall consider, where applicable, the following
criteria in determining whether or not proposed work, including demolition,
is compatible and appropriate:



      (1)   Whether the proposed work will highlight or positively
enhance any exterior feature of the property and improvements.



      (2)   Whether any new improvements will have a positive effect
and harmonized with the external appearance of neighboring improvements.



      (3)   The extent and process of any proposed demolition and
subsequent changes in landscaping.



      (4)   Whether the proposed work will result in the maintenance
or addition of site landscaping and other vegetation.



      (5)   A report from the building inspector in the state of
repair and structural stability of the improvement under construction.



      (6)   Any changes in the essential character of the area which
would occur as a result of approval of the application.



      (7)   Whether the proposed work is in accordance with the
Secretary of the Interior's Standards for Rehabilitation as found in 36 CFR
67, as amended from time to time.



      (8)   Whether the proposed work conforms to any design
criteria or other specific guidelines which the village board may later adopt.



      (9)   If the proposal is for complete demolition:



         a.   Whether, applying the criteria of section 54-35,
the village would suffer an irreparable loss.



         b.   Whether there are other structures in the community
having the same or similar historical background or whether the subject
property is unique.



         c.   Whether the proposed new use of the subject
property is permitted under the village's zoning ordinance.



(Code 1965, § 19.07(d))



Sec. 54-65. Economic hardship.



   (a)   In addition to the criteria established in this division for
approval of construction, alteration and demolition of official landmarks, at
any public hearing held as required in section 54-63(2), the village board
shall also consider any evidence of economic hardship presented by the
applicant or on behalf of the applicant. Evidence of economic hardship, as a
minimum, should consist of an affidavit signed by or on behalf of the
applicant and should specify the following:



      (1)   The amount paid for the property, the date of purchase
and the party from whom purchased (including a description of the
relationship, if any between the owner and the person from whom the property
was purchased).



      (2)   The assessed value of the land and improvements thereon
according to the two most recent assessments.



      (3)   Real estate taxes for the previous two years.



      (4)   Annual debt service, if any, for the previous two years.



      (5)   All appraisals obtained within the previous two years by
the owner or applicant in connection with his purchase, financing or
ownership of the property.



      (6)   Any listing of the property for sale or rent, and the
price asked.



      (7)   Any consideration by the owner as to profitable adaptive
uses for the property.



      (8)   If the property is income- producing, the annual gross
income from the property for the previous two years, itemized operating and
maintenance expenses for the previous two years, and annual cash flow, if
any, during the same period.



   (b)   If the village board finds that, without approval of the
proposed work, the owner of the subject property would be deprived of all
reasonable beneficial use of or return from the subject property, then the
application shall be delayed for a period not to exceed six months. During
this delay period, the village board shall seek to determine a reasonably
beneficial use or a reasonable economic return for the subject property, or
to otherwise preserve the subject property and improvements. Such plans may
include, but are not limited to, a relaxation of the provisions of this
article.



   (c)   If at the end of the six-month period, the village board has
determined that without approval of the proposed work the owner of the
subject property would be deprived of all reasonable beneficial use or return
from the property, then the village board shall approve the proposed work. If
the village board finds otherwise, it shall issue, deny or modify the
requested application as authorized by this division.



(Code 1965, § 19.07(e))
