ARTICLE II. COMMUNITY RELATIONS COMMISSION*



   *Cross reference(s)--Administration, ch. 2.



Sec. 58-31. Creation; composition.



   There is hereby created a village community relations commission which
shall consist of nine members appointed from the community at large by the
president with consent and approval of the village board of trustees.



(Code 1965, § 10.19; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-32. Method of appointment; terms; officers; quorum.



   Members shall be appointed and removed by the president, with the
consent of the village board of trustees. In the first instance, members
shall be appointed for a term of three years, for a term of two years and a
term of one year. Thereafter, each member appointed shall serve for a term of
three years or until his successor is duly appointed and qualified, or until
he is removed. The president shall designate one of the members of the
commission to be its chairman and one its vice-chairman. Any five members of
the commission shall constitute a quorum.



(Code 1965, § 10.20; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-33. Duties and powers.



   The commission, with the assistance of the village attorney, shall have
and exercise, with respect to all real property and with respect to all
persons subject to division 2 of article III of this chapter, the power to:



      (1)   Assist in the elimination of unlawful real estate
practices in violation of article III of this chapter.



      (2)   Act to ensure to persons living, working or desiring to
live in the village, or in any particular real property, opportunity to
purchase, lease or occupy without discrimination because of a person's race,
color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual
orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge status,
source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



      (3)   Receive and investigate charges alleging unlawful real
estate practices.



      (4)   Issue subpoenas necessary for the administration and
enforcement of article III of this chapter.



      (5)   Seek conciliation of, hold hearings on, and make
findings of fact with respect to any such charge.



      (6)   Recommend the issuance of orders subject to approval of
the village board and to publish its findings of fact and recommend orders in
accordance with the provisions of article III of this chapter, after
submission to the village board.



      (7)   Render from time to time, but not less than every 12
months, a written report to the president and board of trustees of its
activities, which written reports shall be made public after submission to
the president and board of trustees.



      (8)   Adopt, after approval of the president and board of
trustees, such rules and regulations as may be necessary or desirable to
carry out the purpose and policy of division 2 of article III of this chapter.



      (9)   Study such matters as may be referred to it by the
president and board of trustees.



      (10)   Advise and make reports and recommendations on such
matters to the president and board of trustees.



      (11)   Assist the village government in such other community
relations matters as may arise from time to time.



(Code 1965, § 10.21; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Secs. 58-34--58-55. Reserved.



ARTICLE III. DISCRIMINATION*



   *State law reference(s)--Fair housing, 65 ILCS 5/11-11.1-1.



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Secs. 58-56--58-75. Reserved.



DIVISION 2. FAIR HOUSING



Sec. 58-76.  Purpose and declaration of policy of division.



   It is hereby to be the policy of the village to secure to all persons
living and/or working or desiring to live and/or work in the village a fair
opportunity to purchase, lease, rent, occupy, improve, repair or maintain
real estate without discrimination based on a person's race, color, sex, age,
religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital
status, parental status, military discharge status, source of income, gender
identify, or housing status. This policy is established in the exercise of
the village's regulatory powers for the protection of the public safety, for
the health, morals, safety, and welfare of the persons residing and working
in the village, and for the maintenance and promotion of commerce, industry
and good government in the village.



(Code 1965, § 10.01; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-77.  Construction of division.



   This division shall be construed according to the fair meaning of its
terms and shall be liberally construed to further the purposes and policy
stated in Section 58-76 and the special purposes of the particular provision
involved. 



(Code 1965, § 10.02; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-78.  Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Appraisal means an estimate or opinion of the value of a specified
parcel of real estate made in a business context in connection with the sale,
rental, financing, or refinancing of the parcel or with any other real estate
related transaction, whether the appraisal is oral or written, or transmitted
formally or informally.



   Commission means the community relations commission.



   Commission panel or panel means a panel, comprised of three or more
members of the commission, designated by the chairman of the commission, to
investigate and to attempt to conciliate a charge filed or made under section
58-94.



   Familial status means one or more individuals who have not attained the
age of 18 years being domiciled with:



      (1)   A parent or other person having legal custody of such
individual or individuals; or



      (2)   The designee of such parent or other person having such
custody, with the written permission of such parent or other person.



   The protections afforded against discrimination on the basis of
familial status shall apply to any person who is pregnant or is in the
process of securing legal custody of any individual who has not attained the
age of 18 years.



   An individual with a disability means a person who:



      (1)   Has a physical or mental impairment that substantially
limits one or more ''major life activities";



      (2)   Has a record of such an impairment; or



      (3)   Is  regarded  as  having  such an impairment.



   Lease means and includes sublease, assignment, and rental and includes
any contract to do any of the foregoing.



   Lending institution means any bank; insurance company; savings and loan
association; other person in the business of obtaining, arranging or
negotiating loans or guarantees as agent or broker; and any person in the
business of buying or selling loans or instruments for the payment of money
which are secured by title to or a security interest in real estate.



   Military status means a person's status on active duty in the armed
forces of the United States.



   National origin means the place in which a person or one of his
ancestors was born.



   Owner means any person who holds legal or equitable title to, or owns
any beneficial interest in, any real property or who holds legal or equitable
title to shares of, or holds any beneficial interest in, any real estate
cooperative which owns any real property.



   Person means and includes one or more individuals, partnerships,
associations or organizations, labor organizations, labor unions, joint
apprenticeship committees, or union labor associations, corporations, the
state and its instrumentalities, political subdivisions, units of local
government, legal representatives, trustees in bankruptcy or receivers.



   Purchase means any contract to purchase.



   Real estate agent means any real estate broker, any real estate
salesman, and any other person who, as employee or agent or other engages in
the management or operation of any real property.



   Real estate broker or salesman means a person, whether licensed or not,
who, for or with the expectation of receiving a consideration, lists, sells,
purchases, exchanges, rents, or leases real property, or who negotiates or
attempts to negotiate any of these activities, or who holds himself out as
engaged in these.



   Real estate transaction includes the sale, exchange, rental or lease of
real property, and also includes the brokering or appraising of residential
real property and the making or purchasing of loans or providing other
financial assistance:



      (1)   For purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing or
maintaining a dwelling; or



      (2)   Secured by residential real estate.



   Real property means any buildings, structures, real estate, lands,
tenements, leaseholds, interests in real estate cooperatives, condominiums,
and hereditaments, corporeal and incorporeal, or any interest therein within
the village limits.



   Sale means any contract to sell, exchange, or to convey, transfer or
assign legal or equitable title to or a beneficial interest in real property.



   Unfavorable military discharge means discharge from the Armed Forces of
the United States, their reserve components or any National Guard or Naval
Militia which are classified as RE-3 or the equivalent thereof, but does not
include those characterized as RE-4 or "dishonorable."



(Code 1965, § 10.03; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 58-79. Discriminatory terms.



   It shall be an unlawful practice and a violation of this division for
any owner or other person to sell, lease, rent, advertise, appraise, or
provide brokerage services for real property or to deny or limit services or
facilities in connection with the sale, rental, lease, advertisement,
appraisal, or brokerage of real property or in the sale of insurance for real
property based on a person's race, color, sex, age, religion, disability,
national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental
status, military discharge status, source of income, gender identity, or
housing status.



(Code 1965, § 10.04 ; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-80.  Prohibited sale, rental, and lease conduct.



   It shall be an unlawful real estate practice and a violation of this
division for any person to:



      (1)   Refuse to sell, rent, or lease real estate after a bona
fide offer has been made, or to refuse to negotiate for the sale, rental, or
lease of any real property because of the race, color, sex, age, religion,
disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status,
parental status, military discharge status, source of income, gender
identity, or housing status of any party to such sale or lease, or of any
person using or occupying or intending to use or occupy such real property or
of any person using or occupying any real property in the area in which such
real property is located.



      (2)   Discriminate in the terms, conditions, or privileges
relating to the sale, rental, or lease of real estate, or in the provision of
services or facilities in connection with sales, rentals, or leases, because
of a person's race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin,
ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military
discharge status, source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



      (3)   Engage in any conduct relating to the provision of real
estate which otherwise makes unavailable or denies real estate to persons
because of a person's race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national
origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status,
military discharge status, source of income, gender identity, or housing
status.



      (4)   Represent to any person because of race, color, sex,
age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation,
marital status, parental status, military discharge status,  source  of
income, gender identity, or housing status that real estate is not available
for sale, rental, or lease when such real estate is, in fact, available.



      (5)   Provide inaccurate or untrue information about the
availability of real estate for sale, rental, or lease because of a person's
race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin ancestry, sexual
orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge status,
source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



      (6)   Deny access to or membership or participation in, or to
discriminate against any person in his access to or membership or
participation in, any multiple-listing service, real estate brokers'
association, or other service organization or facility relating to the
business of selling, renting, or leasing real estate, or to discriminate
against any person in the terms or conditions of such access, membership or
participation, because of race, color, sex, age, religion, disability,
national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental
status, military discharge status, source of income, gender identity, or
housing status.



      (7)   Restrict or attempt to restrict the choices of a person
by word or conduct in connection with seeking, negotiating for, buying,
renting, or leasing of real estate because of the person's race, color, sex,
age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual  orientation, 
marital status, parental status, military discharge status, source of income,
gender identity, or housing status, so as to perpetuate, or tend to
perpetuate, segregated housing patterns, or to discourage or obstruct choices
in a community, neighborhood or development.



      (8)   Engage in any conduct relating to the provision of real
estate or of services and facilities in connection therewith that otherwise
makes unavailable or denies real estate to persons because of race, color,
sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual
orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge status,
source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



(Code 1965, § 10.05; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-81.  Advertisements.



   (a)   It shall be an unlawful real estate practice and a violation
of this division for any person to make, print or publish, or cause to be
made, printed or published, any notice, statement or advertisement with
respect to the sale, rental, or lease of real estate which indicates any
preference, limitation or discrimination because of race, color, sex, age,
religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital
status, parental status, military discharge status, source of income, gender
identity, or housing status, or an intention to make any such preference,
limitation or discrimination. The prohibitions in this section shall apply to
all oral or written notices or statements.



   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person engaging in the making,
printing, or publishing of real estate notices, statements, or advertisements
to refuse to make, print, or publish such an advertisement or to require
different charges or terms for such notice, statement, or advertisement
because of race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin,
ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military
discharge status, source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



(Code 1965, § 10.06; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-82.  Signs and notices.



   It shall be an unlawful real estate practice and a violation of this
division for any person to post or erect, or cause any person to post or
erect, any sign or notice upon any real property, indicating an intent to
sell or lease any real property in a manner that is unlawful under this
division.



(Code 1965, § 10.07; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-83.  Refusal of offers.



   It shall be an unlawful real estate practice and a violation of this
division for any real estate agent or other person to refuse to receive or to
fail to transmit a bona fide offer for the purchase, sale, exchange, rental,
or lease of any real property because of the race, color, sex, age, religion,
disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status,
parental status, military discharge status, source of income, gender
identity, or housing status of the person making such offer. 



(Code 1965, § 10.08; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-84. Discrimination because of disability.



   (a)   It shall be an unlawful real estate practice and a violation
of this division to:



      (1)   Discriminate in the sale, rental, or lease, or to
otherwise make unavailable or deny, real estate to any buyer, renter, or
lessee because of a disability of:



         a.   That buyer, renter, or lessee;



         b.   A person residing, working, or using or intending
to do so in that real estate after it is so sold, rented, or leased, or made
available; or



         c.   Any person associated with that person.



      (2)   Discriminate against any person in the terms,
conditions, or privileges of the sale, rental, or lease of real estate, or in
the provision of services or facilities in connection with such real estate,
because of a disability of:



         a.   That buyer, renter, or lessee;



         b.   A person residing, working, or using or intending
to do so in that real estate after it is so sold, rented, or leased, or made
available; or



         c.   Any person associated with that person.



      (3)   Subject to the limitations of section 58-93(i),  to 
make  an  inquiry to determine whether an applicant for real estate, a
person intending to reside or work in that real estate after it is so sold,
rented, leased, or made available, or any person associated with that person,
has a disability or to make inquiry as to the nature or severity of a
disability of such a person.



   (b)   Nothing in this section shall require that real estate be made
available to an individual whose tenancy would constitute a direct threat to
the health or safety of other individuals or whose tenancy would result in
substantial physical damage to the property of others.



   (c)   It shall be unlawful real estate practice and a violation of
this division for any person to refuse to permit, at the expense of a
disabled person, reasonable modifications of existing premises occupied or to
be occupied by a disabled person, if the proposed modifications may be
necessary to afford the disabled person full enjoyment of the premises. In
the case of a rental or lease, the landlord may, where it is reasonable to do
so, condition permission for a modification on the renter or lessee agreeing
to restore the interior of the premises to the condition that existed before
the modification, reasonable wear and tear excepted. The landlord may not
increase for disabled persons any customarily required security deposit.
However, where it is necessary in order to ensure with reasonable certainty
that funds will be available to pay for the restorations at the end of the
tenancy, the landlord may negotiate as part of such a restoration agreement a
provision requiring that the tenant pay into an interest bearing escrow
account, over a reasonable period, a reasonable amount of money not to exceed
the cost of the restorations. The interest in any such account shall accrue
to the benefit of the tenant. A landlord may condition permission for a
modification on the renter or lessee providing a reasonable description of
the proposed modifications as well as reasonable assurances that the work
will be done in a workmanlike manner and that any required building permits
will be obtained.



   (d)   It shall be an unlawful real estate practice and a violation
of this division for any person to refuse to make reasonable accommodations
in rules, policies, practices, or services, when such accommodations may be
necessary to afford a disabled person equal opportunity to use and enjoy real
estate, including public and common use areas.



(Code 1965, § 10.09; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-85.  Discrimination in lending.



   (a)   It shall be an unlawful real estate practice and a violation
of this division for any person or other entity whose business includes
engaging in real estate-related transactions to discriminate against any
person in making available loans or other financial assistance or to impose
different terms or conditions on such loans or other financial assistance for
real estate, or which is to be secured by real estate, because of race,
color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual
orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge status,
source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



   (b)   It shall be an unlawful real estate practice and a violation
of this division for any person or entity engaged in the purchasing of loans
or other debts or securities which support the purchase, construction,
improvement, repair or maintenance of real estate, or which are secured by
real estate, to refuse to purchase such loans, debts, or securities, or to
impose different terms or conditions for such purchases, because of race,
color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual
orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge status,
source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



   (c)   It shall be unlawful for any person or entity engaged in the
making of loans or in the provision of other financial assistance relating to
the purchase, construction, improvement, repair or maintenance of real estate
or which are secured by real estate to impose different terms or conditions
for the availability of such loans or other financial assistance because of
race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry,
sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge
status, source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



   (d)   This section does not prevent consideration, in the purchasing
of loans, of factors justified by business necessity, including requirements
of federal law, relating to a transaction's financial security or to
protection against default or reduction of the value of the security.



(Code 1965, § 10.10; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-86.  Appraisals.



   (a)   No person engaged in the business of making real estate
appraisals shall discriminate against anyone in making available such
services or in imposing different terms, costs, or conditions because of
race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry,
sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge
status, source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



   (b)   No person shall make or use an appraisal of real property in
connection with the sale, rental, lease, or financing of such real property
where the person knows or reasonably should know that the appraisal
improperly takes into consideration race, color, sex, age, religion,
disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status,
parental status, military discharge status, source of income, gender
identity, or housing status.



(Code 1965, § 10.11; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-87.  Insurance.



   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person or entity engaged in the
business of issuing property, title, or mortgage insurance for real estate to
discriminate against any person in making available property, title, or
mortgage insurance or to impose different terms, costs, or conditions in
connection with the issuance of the insurance because of race, color, sex,
age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation,
marital status, parental status, military discharge status, source of income,
gender identity, or housing status.



   (b)   This section does not prevent consideration, in the making
available or issuing of property, title, or mortgage insurance, factors
justified by business necessity. 



(Code 1965, § 10.12; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-88.  Interference, coercion, or intimidation.



   (a)   It shall be illegal and a violation of this division for any
person to coerce, intimidate, threaten, or interfere with any person in the
exercise or enjoyment of, or on account of that person having exercised or
enjoyed, or on account of that person having aided or encouraged any other
person in the exercise or enjoyment of, any right granted or protected by
this division.



   (b)   No person shall:



      (1)   Coerce a person, either orally, in writing, or by other
means, to deny or limit the benefits provided that person in connection with
the sale or rental of real estate or in connection with a real estate-related
transaction because of race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national
origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status,
military discharge status, source of income, gender identity, or housing
status.



      (2)   Threaten, intimidate, or interfere with persons in their
enjoyment of real estate owned, rented, or leased by such persons because of
the race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry,
sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge
status, source of income, gender identity, or housing status of such persons
or because of the race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national
origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status,
military discharge status, source of income, gender identity, or housing
status of visitors or associates of such persons.



      (3)   Threaten an employee or agent with dismissal or an
adverse employment action, or taking such adverse employment action, for any
effort to assist a person seeking access to the sale or rental of real estate
or seeking access to any real estate-related transaction, because of the
race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry,
sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge
status, source of income, gender identity, or housing status of that person
or of any person associated with that person.



      (4)   Intimidate or threaten any person because that person is
engaging in lawful activities designed to make other persons aware of, or
encouraging such other persons to exercise, rights granted or protected by
this division.



      (5)   Retaliate against any person because that person has
made a complaint, testified, assisted, or participated in any manner in a
proceeding under this division. 



(Code 1965, § 10.13; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-89.  Representation.



   (a)   It shall be an unlawful real estate practice and a violation
of this division for any person, for the purpose of inducing any other person
to enter into a real estate transaction with such real estate agent, his
principal or his agent, or other person to:



      (1)   Represent that a change has occurred, will occur or may
occur with respect to race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national
origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status,
military discharge status, source of income, gender identity, or housing
status in the composition of the owners or occupants in any block,
neighborhood or area in which the real property (which is the subject of the
real estate transaction) is located;



      (2)   Represent that a change with respect to the race, color,
sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual
orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge status,
source of income, gender identity, or housing status in the composition of
the owners or occupants in any block, neighborhood or area will result in the
lowering of property values, or in an increase in criminal or antisocial
behavior, or in a decline in the quality of schools, in such blocks,
neighborhood or area; or



      (3)   Induce or attempt to induce, for profit, a person to
sell, rent, or lease real estate by representations regarding the entry or
prospective entry into the neighborhood of a person or persons of a
particular race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin,
ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military
discharge status, source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



   (b)   In establishing a discriminatory housing practice under this
section it is not necessary that there was in fact profit as long as profit
was a factor for engaging in the blockbusting activity. 



(Code 1965, § 10.14 ; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-90.  Restrictive covenants.



   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this division for any person to:



      (1)   Make or enter into an oral agreement or a written
instrument relating to real property which purports to forbid or restrict the
conveyance, encumbrance, occupancy, sale, lease, or rental thereof on the
basis of race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin,
ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military
discharge status, source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



      (2)   Make or enter into a condition, restriction or
prohibition, including a right of entry or possibility of reverter, which
directly or indirectly limits the use or occupancy of real property on the
basis of race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin,
ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military
discharge status, source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



      (3)   Insert in a written instrument relating to real property
a provision which violates the purpose and declaration of this division or to
honor or attempt to honor such a provision in the chain of title.



(Code 1965, § 10.15; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-91.  Other violations.



   It shall be an unlawful real estate practice and violation of this
division for any person to:



      (1)   Aid, abet, incite, or coerce a person to engage in an
unlawful practice.



      (2)   Deliberately and knowingly refuse examination of copies
of any listing of real property in the village to any person because of race,
color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual
orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge status,
source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



      (3)   Enter into a listing agreement which prohibits the
inspection, sale, lease or occupancy of real property to any person because
of race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry,
sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge
status, source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



      (4)   Act or undertake to act with respect to any real
property the disposition of which is prohibited to any person because of
race, color, sex, age, religion, disability, national origin, ancestry,
sexual orientation, marital status, parental status, military discharge
status, source of income, gender identity, or housing status.



      (5)   Willfully interfere with the performance of a duty or
the exercise of a power by the commission or one of its members or
representatives.



      (6)   Willfully obstruct or prevent a person from complying
with the provisions of this division or an order issued under this division. 



(Code 1965, § 10.16; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-92.  Coverage.



   The provisions of this division shall apply, respectively, to every
real estate agent, appraiser, and insurance agent who, within the village,
performs any real estate-related function but does not maintain an office or
place of doing business within the village, and to every real estate agent,
lending institution, appraiser, insurance agent, and anyone else involved in
real estate-related transactions who maintains an office or place of doing
business within the village; provided, however, that the provisions of this
division shall not be so construed as to prohibit a real estate broker or
real estate agent on behalf of the owner, from inquiring into and reporting
upon qualifications of any prospective buyer or tenant with respect to
limitations or exclusions other than those of race, color, sex, age,
religion, disability, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital
status, parental status, military discharge status, source of income, gender
identity, or housing status. 



(Code 1965, § 10.17; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-93.  Limitations.



   (a)   Nothing in this division shall require an owner to offer real
property to the public at large before selling or renting it, providing he
complies with all other provisions of this division. Nor shall this division
require an owner or his agent to offer real property for sale or lease to any
person if the owner or his agent has reasonable cause which can be
substantiated to believe that such person is not negotiating for the purchase
or lease of such real property in good faith, nor shall this division be
deemed to prohibit owners from giving preference to prospective tenants or
buyers for any reason other than race, color, sex, age, religion, disability,
national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental
status, military discharge status, source of income, gender identity, or
housing status.



   (b)   Nothing in this division regarding familial status shall apply
to housing:



      (1)   Intended for, and solely occupied by, persons 62 years
of age or older; or



      (2)   Intended and operated for occupancy by at least one
person 55 years of age or older per unit, providing that the housing facility
has significant facilities and services specifically designed to meet the
physical or social needs of older persons or the housing facility is
providing important housing opportunities for older persons.



   (c)   Nothing in this division shall prohibit religious
organizations, associations, or societies,  or  any  nonprofit 
institution or organization operated, supervised or controlled by or in
conjunction with a religious organization, association, or society, from
limiting the sale, rental, lease or occupancy of dwellings which it owns or
operates for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the same religion,
or from giving preference to such persons, unless membership in such religion
is restricted because of race, color or national origin.



   (d)   Nothing in this division shall prohibit a private club, not in
fact open to the public, which, incident to its primary purpose or purposes,
provides lodgings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial
purpose, from limiting the rental or occupancy of such lodgings to its
members or from giving preference to its members.



   (e)   Nothing in this division shall prohibit conduct against a
person because such person has been convicted by any court of competent
jurisdiction of the illegal manufacture or distribution of a controlled
substance as defined in section 102 of the Controlled Substances Act (21 USC
802).



   (f)   Nothing in this division, other than the prohibitions against
discriminatory advertising, shall apply to:



      (1)   The sale or rental of any single-family house by an
owner, provided the following conditions are met:



         a.   The owner does not own or have any interest in more
than three single-family houses at any one time; and



         b.   The real estate is sold, rented, or leased without
the use of a real estate broker, agent, or salesperson or the facilities of
any person in the business of selling or renting real estate.



      (2)   Rooms or units in dwellings containing living quarters
occupied or intended to be occupied by no more than four families living
independently of each other, if the owner actually maintains and occupies one
of such living quarters as his residence. As used in this section, the term
"dwelling unit" means one or more rooms which are arranged, designed, or used
as living quarters for one family or one individual. The term "owner"
includes the spouse of the owner and also one having equitable title under a
land trust.



   (g)   Nothing in this division shall prohibit financial institutions
from considering sound underwriting practices in contemplation of any loan to
any person. Such practices shall include:



      (1)   The willingness and the financial ability of the
borrower to repay the loan.



      (2)   The market value of any real estate or other item of
property proposed as security for any loan.



      (3)   Diversification of the financial institution's
investment portfolio.



   (h)   Nothing in this division shall prohibit a person engaged in
the business of furnishing appraisals to real property to take into
consideration factors other than race, color, sex, age, religion, disability,
national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, marital status, parental
status, military discharge status, source of income, gender identity, or
housing status.



   (i)   Nothing in section 58-90 shall apply to a limitation of use on
the basis of religion of real property held by a religious institution or
organization or by a religious or charitable organization operated,
supervised, or controlled by a religious institution or organization, and
used for religious or charitable purposes.



   (j)   Nothing in section 58-84 shall prohibit the following
inquiries, provided these inquiries are made of all applicants, whether or
not they have disabilities:



      (1)   Inquiry into an applicant's ability to meet the
requirements of ownership or tenancy;



      (2)   Inquiry to determine whether an applicant is qualified
for a dwelling available only to persons with disabilities or to persons with
a particular type of disability;



      (3)   Inquiry to determine whether an applicant for a dwelling
is qualified for a priority available to persons with disabilities or to
persons with a particular type of disability;



      (4)   Inquiring whether an applicant for a dwelling is a
current illegal abuser or addict of a controlled substance; or



      (5)   Inquiring whether an applicant has been convicted of the
illegal manufacture or distribution of a controlled substance.



(Code 1965, § 10.18; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-94.  Charges; conciliation.



   (a)   Any person aggrieved in any manner by an alleged violation of
any provision of this division may file with the commission a written
verified charge setting forth that grievance. The village clerk is hereby
authorized to accept such charges and forward them to the commission. The
charge shall state the name and address of the complainant, the name and
address of the person against whom the charge is brought, if known to the
complainant, and the alleged facts surrounding the alleged violation. Such
charge shall state the name and address of all persons believed to have
knowledge concerning the alleged facts. The commission shall provide a
printed form of charge for the use of aggrieved persons.



   (b)   The charge shall be accompanied by a filing fee of $25.00
which shall be deposited with the village treasurer. If, in accordance with
the procedures set forth in this section, the commission or a panel of the
commission shall determine that probable cause does exist for the allegations
of the charge, or if the alleged violation or charge is disposed of by
conference, conciliation or persuasion, or if any of the charges alleged in
the charge are sustained, the village treasurer, upon recommendation of the
commission, shall return the filing fee to the complainant. If it is
determined that probable cause does not exist for the allegations of the
charge, or the charges alleged in the charge are not sustained, the filing
fee shall be retained by the village.



   (c)   After filing of any charge, the commission shall, within 30
days thereafter, acknowledge to the complainant that the charge has been
received, serve a copy of the charge on the party charged, and the chairman
of the commission shall designate a panel to make a prompt investigation in
connection therewith.



   (d)   Within 100 days after receipt of the complaint, that panel
shall prepare a written report of its investigation for the commission and
shall determine, in writing, either that "probable cause exists for the
allegations of the charge" or that "probable cause does not exist for the
allegations of the charge." If it is impracticable to complete the
investigation within 100 days, the complainant and the charged party shall be
notified, in writing, of the reasons for not doing so. If such panel shall
determine that probable cause does exist, the panel shall set a time and date
for a meeting, and at such meeting, the panel or any member thereof shall
interview the complainant and the person against whom the charge has been
directed and shall attempt to resolve the charge by all proper methods of
conciliation and persuasion. The relief provided for in section 58-96(b) and
section 58-98 may be sought during conciliation. The conciliation agreement
may provide for binding arbitration of the dispute arising from the charge.
Arbitration may award appropriate relief as provided for in this division.
The aggrieved person and the respondent may, in the conciliation agreement,
limit the types of relief that may be awarded under binding arbitration. All
conciliation agreements must be approved by the village only after the
village determines that the aggrieved person and those charged agree to the
relief provided for in the conciliation agreement and the provisions of the
conciliation agreement adequately vindicate the public interest. If at any
time within 60 days after the date of filing of the charge such panel shall
determine that such attempts at conciliation would not be in furtherance of
the objectives of this division, the commission shall thereupon proceed
promptly to a full hearing of the charge in accordance with section 58-95. 



(Code 1965, § 10.22; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-95.  Hearings by commission.



   (a)   Such hearing shall be conducted by the commission upon due and
reasonable notice to all parties. The commission shall have power to
administer oaths and to take sworn testimony. All parties named in the charge
shall be entitled to be represented by counsel and shall have the right to
call witnesses on their own behalf and to cross examine witnesses. Closed
meetings may be held as permitted by 65 ILCS 5/11-11.1-1 et seq.



   (b)   Within 30 days after the completion of such hearing, the
commission shall render a written report of that hearing to the village
board. That report shall contain a copy of the charge filed, a summary or
transcript of testimony heard and evidence presented, and shall contain the
commission's findings and recommendations as to disposition of the charges.



(Code 1965, § 10.23; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-96.  Enforcement of division.



   (a)   At the conclusion of any proceeding held under section 58-95,
if a majority of the commission finds that an owner, real estate agent or
other person complained of has committed prohibited action under this
division, the commission shall be empowered to recommend to the village board
that the village board order such owner, real estate agent or other person to
cease and desist from such practice, upon such terms as shall be deemed
necessary and proper by the village board for the enforcement of this
division.



   (b)   At the conclusion of any proceeding held under section 58-95,
if a majority of the commission finds that an owner, real estate agent or
other person complained of has committed a prohibited act under this
division, the commission shall be further empowered to recommend to the
village board, that the village board direct the village attorney to do any
one or more of the following:



      (1)   Institute and prosecute proceedings in a court of law
against the owner, real estate agent or other person, to obtain a conviction
of a violation of this division.



      (2)   Petition or institute proceedings with the appropriate
regulatory body for the purpose of causing the regulatory body to revoke,
suspend or refuse to renew the license granted by such regulatory body to any
real estate broker, real estate salesperson, insurance agent, or appraiser
found by a court of law to have violated any provision of this division.



      (3)   Upon conviction by a court of law of any violation of
this division by any person in the course of performing under a contract or
subcontract with the state or any political subdivision or agency thereof, or
with the United States of America or any agency or instrumentality thereof,
to petition or institute proceedings with such contracting agency for the
purpose of causing it to terminate such contract or any portion thereof,
either absolutely or on condition of compliance with the provisions of this
division.



      (4)   Cause a complaint to be filed with the Equal Employment
Opportunity Commission and/or the state department of human rights.



      (5)   Seek provisions for the public interest such as, but not
limited to:



         a.   Elimination of discriminatory real estate practices;



         b.   Prevention of future discriminatory real estate
practices;



         c.   Remedial affirmative activities to overcome
discriminatory real estate practices;



         d.   Reporting requirements; and



         e.   Monitoring and enforcement activities.



      (6)   Any other actions or proceedings which the village board
determines appropriate.



(Code 1965, § 10.24 ; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-97. Limitation of time to file charges.



   Any charge filed under this division with the commission must be filed
within one year after the alleged discriminatory practice occurred or
terminated, or the charge shall be barred.



(Code 1965, § 10.25; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-98.Remedies.



   Any person aggrieved in any manner by the violation of any provision of
this division who has exhausted the remedies provided in sections 58-94 and
58-95 may apply to any appropriate administrative agency or court of
competent jurisdiction for relief from such violation as the law may allow. 



(Code 1965, § 10.26; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)



Sec. 58-99. Notices and documents.



   All notices and documents required by this division to be served by the
commission or by the village board shall be delivered personally or shall be
mailed by certified mail or registered mail.



(Code 1965, § 10.27; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10; MC-877, § 1, 9-11-12)



Sec. 58-100. Fines.



   Any person who violates any provision of this division shall be fined
not less than $300.00 and no more than $750.00 for each violation. 



(Code 1965, § 10.28; MC-828, § 1, 3-9-10)

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL



Secs. 62-1--2-30. Reserved.



ARTICLE II. POLICE DEPARTMENT*



   *Cross reference(s)--Administration, ch. 2.



Sec. 62-31. Members.



   The police department shall consist of a chief of police, deputy police
chief/s, sergeants, patrol officers and such other personnel as may be
provided for from time to time by the president and board of trustees.  All
of the above comprise the police department and are hereby designated
employees of the village.



(Code 1965, § 4.05(a)) (MC-673; MC-799, § 1, 2-26-08)



Sec. 62-32. Appointments and promotions.



   All full-time paid members of the police department, with the exception
of the chief and deputy chief/s, shall be appointed, promoted and removed by
the board of fire and police commissioners of the village, as provided by
state statute or as otherwise provided in a collective bargaining agreement.



(Code 1965, § 4.05(d)) (MC-673; MC-799, § 2, 2-26-08)



Sec. 62-33. Duties.



   It shall be the duty of the members of the police department to enforce
this Code, the ordinances of the village, and all statutes and laws effective
in the village, and to preserve order and prevent infractions of the law and
to arrest violators of the law.



(Code 1965, § 4.05(e))



Sec. 62-34. Chief of police.



   (a)   Head of department. The chief of police shall be ex-officio
village marshal and the administrative head of the police department, and
shall perform such duties as are prescribed in this article or as may be
ordered by the village manager.



   (b)   Duties of the chief. The chief of police shall have direct
charge and control over the police department, and shall be responsible for
the faithful and efficient conduct of the operation of the department. The
chief of police shall be qualified through training and experience to
administer the police department and command its personnel. He shall be
responsible for the enforcement and maintenance of law and order. He shall
have custody of all apparatus and property pertaining to the department and
shall be responsible for the maintenance thereof. He need not be a member of
the police department nor a resident of the village at the time of his
appointment.



   (c)   Keeper of jail. The chief of police shall be keeper of the
village jail and shall have custody of all persons incarcerated therein and
of all property pertaining thereto. Under supervision of the village manager
he shall purchase food necessary for the sustenance of prisoners, and shall
keep and make a monthly report of expenditures to the village manager.



   (d)   Recordkeeping.  The chief of  police shall  keep or cause
to  be kept  a record of arrests in a book to be provided for that purpose,
with the name, age, sex, description, nativity, offense, and disposition of
case, noting the police officer making the arrest and person signing the
complaint. He shall also keep a record of all accidents coming within his
knowledge. He shall make such reports concerning the activities of his
department as may be required by statute or ordinance.



   (e)   Additional offices. If deemed expedient, the chief of police
may hold any one or more additional village offices and perform the duties of
such offices.



(Code 1965, §§ 4.05(b), 6.01)



Sec. 62-35.  Chief to be custodian of records.



   The chief of police shall be the custodian of all records of the police
department.



(Code 1965, § 4.05(f))



Sec. 62-36.  Appointments, Deputy Police Chiefs.



   The Chief of Police shall have the authority to appoint two (2) deputy
police chiefs.



   (a)   Exempt rank.  The deputy police chief position shall be an
exempt rank immediately below that of Chief of Police.



   (b)   Eligibility for Appointment.  The deputy police chief may be
appointed from any ranks of sworn, full-time officers of the Village of
Homewood Police Department provided that he or she has at least five (5)
years of full-time service as a police officer in the Village of Homewood
Police Department.



   (c)   Term of Service.  The deputy police chief shall serve at the
discretion of the Chief of Police, and, if removed from said position, shall
revert to the rank held immediately prior to the appointment to the deputy
police chief position.



(MC-799, § 3, 2-26-08)



Sec. 62-37.  Duties of officers other than chief.



   Deputy police chiefs and sergeants shall have the responsibilities and
perform the duties as determined by the chief of police.



(Code 1965, § 4.05(c); MC-799, § 4, 2-26-08)



Sec. 62-38.  Rules and regulations.



   The police chief shall promulgate rules and regulations for the
operation of the department which are not inconsistent with this article.
Such rules and regulations shall be subject to the approval of the village
manager.



(Code 1965, § 6.02)



Sec. 62-39. Resisting an officer.



   No person shall knowingly resist any member of the police department or
reserve or special police officer, in the discharge of his duty, or in any
way interfere with, hinder or prevent such discharge of duty, or offer or
endeavor so to do; nor in any manner assist any person in custody of any
member of the police force to escape or attempt to escape, nor rescue or
attempt to rescue any person in custody.



(Code 1965, § 6.04)



Sec. 62-40. Seizure of gaming devices.



   Any  member of  the  police  department may  seize any 
instrument,  device, or  thing used  for  the  purpose  of  gaming 
or gambling,  and all  instruments,  devices or things  shall  be 
destroyed  or  demolished  under the supervision of the chief of police,
and all moneys confiscated. It shall be the duty of the police department to
suppress gaming and gambling houses, lotteries and fraudulent devices or
practices for the purpose of gaming or obtaining money or property.



(Code 1965, § 6.06)



Sec. 62-41. License inspections.



   Unless otherwise provided by ordinance, the police department shall
make regular and periodical checks to ascertain whether business, vehicle,
dog, liquor, and other licenses required have been procured, and shall
regularly inspect all places of business required to have a village license,
to see that such places of business are being operated according to the
ordinances and laws in force, and in a manner so as to protect public health,
safety and morals, and to promote the general welfare of the village and its
inhabitants.



(Code 1965, § 6.08)



Sec. 62-42. Serving process.



   Any member of the police department shall be authorized to serve writs,
summons, warrants and other process, except where prohibited by statute or
law.



(Code 1965, § 6.09)



Sec. 62-43. Preservation and inspection of records.



   All records and original reports shall be preserved in the office of
the chief of police and shall be accessible to any officer of the village,
but shall not be open to inspection by the public unless permission is
secured from the village manager, village attorney or chief of police.



(Code 1965, § 6.10)



Sec. 62-44. Duty to prosecute.



   All officers, reserve officers or special police making arrests shall
attend court as witnesses and otherwise assist in the prosecution of the
offender.



(Code 1965, § 6.11)



Sec. 62-45. Duties on election days.



   It shall be the duty of all regular police officers, and special or
reserve police on duty, to preserve order at the polls on election days, but
no such officer, whether on or off duty, shall electioneer or interfere for
or against any candidate at such election.



(Code 1965, § 6.12)



Sec. 62-46. Auxiliary police.



   (a)   The village president, with the advice and consent of the
village board, may appoint, for a term to expire at the end of the then
fiscal year, such auxiliary police as may be deemed advisable. Auxiliary
police officers are also hereby designated reserve officers. Auxiliary police
officers, when on duty, shall have all of the powers authorized by the
Illinois Compiled Statutes. Identification symbols worn by auxiliary police
officers shall be different and distinct from those used by members of the
regular police department, as may be approved from time to time by the chief
of police.



   (b)   Auxiliary officers shall be on duty only as ordered by the
chief of police, shall be subject to discharge by either the village
president or village manager at any time without cause, and shall be paid
such salary or compensation while on duty as may be fixed from time to time
by the president and board of trustees. Upon removal from office, they shall
return their star, commission, and all village property to the chief of
police.



(Code 1965, § 6.13)



Sec. 62-47. Jail.



   (a)   Established. Sufficient and appropriate space now located on
the village property located on the north side of Chestnut between Dixie
Highway and Harwood Avenue is hereby established as the village jail.



   (b)   Incarceration. Any person lawfully arrested for violation of
any law of the United States or state or of any provision of this Code or
other ordinance of the village may be incarcerated in the village jail until
he furnishes proper bail or can be given a hearing before a magistrate or
judge, or is lawfully transferred to another place of incarceration or
otherwise lawfully released.



(Code 1965, § 6.14)



Sec. 62-48. Police pension fund.



   (a)   Established. There shall be a police pension fund established
in the village, as provided by statute.



   (b)   Board of trustees; membership; terms; meetings. The board of
trustees of the fund shall consist of five members: Two shall be appointed by
the village president; two shall be elected by the members of the police
department; and one shall be elected by the beneficiaries of the pension
fund. Each member shall serve for two years and elected members shall be
selected in the manner provided by 40 ILCS 5/3-128, as amended from time to
time. Members appointed or elected to fill vacancies shall serve for the
unexpired portion of the term in which the vacancy occurs. The board of
trustees shall meet at least quarterly as provided by statute, and shall hold
such additional meetings as may be called by the president of the board.



   (c)   Deposits. There shall be deposited in the pension fund the
sums allowed or required by statute.



   (d) Management, investments and control. It shall be the duty of the
members of the board to manage, invest and control the police pension fund
and all monies pertaining thereto and to pay beneficiaries, as provided by
statute. (Code 1965, § 6.15)



Sec. 62-49. Probationary police officers.



   (a)   All original appointments to the police department shall be
subject to a probationary period commencing upon the date an officer first
reports for work with the department and continuing for a period of 12 months
after the probationary officer has successfully completed all the
requirements of the police department’s field training program. In
addition, the probationary period shall be extended for those periods of time
a probationary employee, for whatever reason, is unable or unavailable to
perform his assigned duties.



   (b)   Probationary employees may be summarily dismissed by the board
of fire and police commissioners and are not entitled to the protection
afforded to other fulltime officers by statute or fire and police commission
rules.



(MC-841, § 3, 3-8-11)



Sec. 62-50. Residency requirements.



   Commissioned police personnel subject to the jurisdiction of the fire
and police commission may reside outside the corporate limits of the village
at the time of original appointment and while serving in such capacity.



(Code 1965, § 6.17)



Sec. 62-51. Bail processing fee.



   Any person arrested for violating a bailable municipal ordinance or a
state or federal law shall pay a $20 fee for bail processing. This fee shall
be in addition to the required bail and shall be paid before the arrestee is
released on bail.



(MC-870, § 1, 4-24-12)



Sec. 62-52. Request for hearing.



   (a)   An individual may request, in writing within 30 days of the
imposition of the bail processing fee, a hearing.



   (b)   The chief of police or his designee shall conduct the hearing.



   (c)   The hearing shall be informal, not subject to the formal rules
of evidence, and may be conducted over the phone.



   (d)   If, after the hearing, the chief of police or his designee
determines that imposition of the bail processing fee was proper, the village
shall retain the fee previously collected.



   (e)   If there is a determination that imposition of the bail
processing fee was improper, then the chief of police shall order that the
fee be refunded.



   (f)   The individual may appeal the decision of the chief of police,
or his designee, by requesting, in writing, within 14 days of the decision,
an administrative hearing as set forth herein.



(MC-887, § 1, 3-26-13)



Sec. 62-53. Appeal - administrative hearing.



   (a)   Upon the timely written request by the individual who has been
charged the bail processing fee, a hearing on the lawfulness of the
imposition of the bail processing fee shall be conducted in conjunction with
the administrative hearing section of this Code, Section 3-1 et seq.



   (b)   Any sworn or affirmed report prepared in the performance of a
law enforcement officer’s duties sufficiently describing the circumstances
leading to the individual’s arrest and processing shall be admissible prima
facie evidence of probable cause and the individual’s liability, unless
rebutted by clear and convincing evidence.



   (c)   If after the hearing, the hearing officer finds that
imposition of the bail processing fee was proper under the terms of this
article, the hearing officer may enter a written order finding the individual
liable for the bail processing fee.



   (d)   If the individual requests a hearing but fails to appear at
the hearing, the hearing officer may enter a default order finding the
individual liable for the bail processing fee.



   (e)   If, after hearing, the hearing officer finds that imposition
of the bail processing fee was improper, then the hearing officer shall order
that the village refund the fee to the individual.



(MC-887, § 1, 3-26-13)



Secs. 62-54--62-75. Reserved.



ARTICLE III. CITATIONS



Sec. 62-76. Compliance citations.



   (a)   The police officer may, in lieu of the issuance of a local
ordinance complaint, in the first instance issue a compliance citation:



      (1)   Advising the person that he has violated a specific Code
section.



      (2)   Requesting him to make payment in an amount applicable
to said alleged violation as set forth in section 62-78; as settlement of the
violation claim.



   (b)   Other village officers responsible for enforcing village codes
such as, but not limited to, building inspectors, code enforcement officers,
fire department inspectors and community service officers may also issue
compliance citations and/or local ordinance complaints for violations of
regulations dealing with matters under their jurisdiction.



(Code 1965, § 55.05; MC-800, § 1, 3-11-08)



Sec. 62-77. Same--In respect to municipal code violations; enumeration of
subjects.



   Compliance citations may be issued in respect to any of the following
subjects regulated by this Code:



      (1)   Regulating and licensing dogs, but excluding any
violation of Division 5 of Chapter 18 of this Code regulating dangerous dogs;



      (2)   Regulating and licensing businesses;



      (3)   Regulating the storing, burning or disposal of refuse;



      (4)   Regulating the use of bicycles;



      (5)   Regulating and licensing cats;



      (6)   Regulating the use of skateboards, roller skates,
coasters, sleds, or other toy vehicles; and



      (7)   Water conservation measures.



(Code 1965, § 55.02)



Sec. 62-78. Compliance citations--Payment.



   (a)   Any person, pursuant to the issuance of a compliance citation,
who is accused of a violation of certain sections of the Homewood Municipal
Code as described in this article may settle and compromise that citation by
paying to the village a fee of $25.00 and showing proof of the correction of
the violation within ten days from the date such alleged violation was
committed or by paying to the village the sum of $50.00 subsequent to the
ten-day period and prior to 30 days thereafter.



(Code 1965, § 55.01)



   (b)   Payment shall be made in accordance with the instructions
contained in the compliance citation, at the police department, where a
receipt shall be issued for the money so received and said funds shall be
promptly remitted to the village treasurer to be credited to the proper
municipal fund.



(Code 1965, § 55.07)



Sec. 62-79. Same--Failure to pay citation.



   If the person accused of the violation does not pay the citation, a
local ordinance citation or notice to appear will be issued for that
violation, and that person shall then be subject to the general penalties set
forth in this Code.



(Code 1965, § 55.03)



Sec. 62-80--62-82. Reserved.



Sec. 62-83. Liability of owner of vehicle.



   The fact that an automobile or motor vehicle which was illegally
operated or parked is registered with the secretary of state, in the name of
the alleged violator; or, in the alternative, if a vehicle sticker issued by
a municipality has been issued in the name of and to the alleged violator,
such facts shall be considered prima facie proof that the alleged violator
was in control of or was the operator of the automobile or motor vehicle at
the time of such alleged violation.



(Code 1965, § 55.09)



Sec. 62-84. Removing notice of traffic violation from vehicle.



   It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the driver of the
vehicle to which a traffic violation notice is attached, to remove the
traffic violation notice from the vehicle.



(Code 1965, § 55.10)



Sec. 62-85. Violations of refuse regulations.



   Whenever the village code enforcement officer observes a violation of
this Code in respect to regulating the storing and dispose of refuse or in
respect to regulating the burning of refuse, the code enforcement officer
may, in lieu of the filing of a complaint in court, or in lieu of the
issuance of a compliance warning citation issue to the alleged violator a
violation citation:



      (1)   Advising such person that he has violated a specific
Code section;



      (2)   Requesting him to make payment in an amount applicable
to the alleged violation as set forth in section 62-78 as settlement of the
violation claim; and



      (3)   Informing him that upon failure to so settle, a
complaint will be filed in the county circuit court charging him with such
violation.



(Code 1965, § 55.11; MC-800, § 1, 3-11-08)



Chapter 66  MANUFACTURED HOMES AND TRAILERS*



*Cross reference(s)--Buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; floods, ch.
46; planning, ch. 78; solid waste, ch. 90; streets, sidewalks and other
public places, ch. 94; subdivision regulations, ch. 98; traffic and vehicles,
ch. 106; utilities, ch. 110; zoning regulations, App. A.



Article I. In General



   Secs. 66-1--66-30.  Reserved.



Article II. Trailer Coach Parks



   Sec. 66-31.   Definitions.



   Sec. 66-32.   License--Required.



   Sec. 66-33.   Same--Application.



   Sec. 66-34.   Same--Fee.



   Sec. 66-35.   Administration and required facilities.

operation.
