ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL



Secs. 74-1--74-25. Reserved.



ARTICLE II. SOLICITORS



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Sec. 74-26. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Registered solicitor means any person who has obtained a valid
certificate of registration as provided in this article, and which
certificate is in the possession of the solicitor while engaged in soliciting.



   Residence means every separate living unit occupied for residential
purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of building or
structure.



   Soliciting means any one or more of the following activities:



      (1)   Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods,
wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, services of any kind, character or
description whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever;



      (2)   Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application
or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or character;



      (3)   Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines,
periodicals, newspapers, and every other type of or kind of publication; or



      (4)   Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money,
clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any
charitable or nonprofit association, organization, corporation, or project.



(Code 1965, § 13.01)



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 74-27. Village policy.



   It is hereby declared to be the policy of the village board that the
occupants of the residences in this village shall make the determination of
whether solicitors shall be, or shall not be, invited to their respective
residences.



(Code 1965, § 13.05)



Sec. 74-28. Notice regulating soliciting.



   Every person desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided
by the regulations pertaining to soliciting contained in this article, shall
comply with the following directions: Notice of the determination by the
occupant of giving invitation to solicitors, or the refusal of invitation to
solicitors, to any residence, shall be given in the manner following:



      (1)   A weatherproof card, approximately three inches by four
inches in size, shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the
residence, indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the
applicable words, as follows:



      Only solicitors registered in Homewood, Illinois invited," or "no
solicitors invited."



      (2)   The letters shall be at least one-third of an inch in
height. For the purpose of uniformity, the cards shall be provided by the
chief of police to persons requesting such cards, at cost.



      (3)   Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient
notice to any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence
of the information contained thereon.



(Code 1965, § 13.06)



Sec. 74-29. Obedience to signs required.



   It shall be the duty of every solicitor upon going upon any premises in
the village upon which a residence is located to first examine the notice
provided for in section 74-28, if any is present, and be governed by the
statement contained on the notice. If the notice states, "only solicitors
registered in Homewood, Illinois invited," then the solicitor not possessing
a valid certificate of registration as provided in this article shall
immediately and peacefully depart from the premises. If the notice states "no
solicitors invited," then the solicitor, whether registered or not, shall
immediately and peacefully depart from the premises.



(Code 1965, § 13.07)



Sec. 74-30. To depart upon request of occupant.



   Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited
or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when
requested to do so by the occupant.



(Code 1965, § 13.07)



Sec. 74-31. Uninvited soliciting.



   It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance
for any person to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any
door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the
attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an
audience with the occupant and engage in soliciting, in defiance of the
notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the provisions of
section 74-28.



(Code 1965, § 13.08)



Sec. 74-32. Hours.



   It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance
for any person, whether registered under this article or not, to go upon any
premises and ring the doorbell, go near any door of a residence located
thereon, rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other manner
calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence for the
purpose of securing an audience with the occupant and engage in soliciting
prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 7:00 p.m. of any weekday or Saturday, or at any
time on a Sunday or on a state or national holiday.



(Code 1965, § 13.09; MC-905, § 1, 3-25-14)



Sec. 74-33. Identification.



   Every person who solicits within the village, including those who have
received a waiver under section 74-55, unless excused by the village manager,
as provided in this article, shall wear the identification card supplied by
the village. The card identifies the organization as a permitted solicitor
and shall be worn on the outer clothing of the solicitor in a conspicuous and
clearly visible manner. The identification document identifies the
organization as a permitted solicitor and shall be made available by the
solicitor upon request. The village manager may, upon written request, waive
the requirements of this section in favor of any person who will solicit in a
commonly recognizable uniform such as the girl scout uniform, boy scout
uniform, little league uniform, etc. Should the village manager deny such a
request, the president and board of trustees, upon separate written request
to them, may grant such waiver.



(Code 1965, § 13.11) (MC-682)



Sec. 74-34. Information disclosure by a professional fundraiser during course
of solicitation to the public.



   In any solicitation to the public by residential solicitors for a
charitable organization by a professional fundraiser or professional
solicitor:



      (1)   The public member shall be promptly informed that the
solicitation is being made by a paid professional fundraiser or solicitor if
such disclosure is requested by the person solicited.



      (2)   If the professional fundraiser employs or uses a
contract which provides that it will be paid or retain a certain percentage
of the gross amount of each contribution or shall be paid an hourly rate for
solicitation, or the contract provides the charity will receive a fixed
amount or a fixed percentage of each contribution, the professional
fundraiser and person soliciting shall disclose to persons being solicited
the percentage amount retained or hourly rate paid to the professional
fundraiser and solicitor pursuant to the contract, and the amount or the
percentage to be received by the charitable organization from each
contribution, if such disclosure is requested by the person solicited.



      (3)   Any person or professional fundraiser, professional
solicitor soliciting charitable contributions from the public on behalf of a
public safety personnel organization shall not misrepresent that they are in
fact a law enforcement person, firefighter, or member of the organization for
whom the contributions are being raised and if requested by the person
solicited they shall promptly provide their actual name, the exact legal name
of the organization with which they are employed and its correct address, as
well as, the exact name of the charitable organization.



Secs. 74-35--74-50. Reserved.



DIVISION 2. REGISTRATION



Sec. 74-51. Certificate--Required; qualifications.



   (a)   Every person desiring to engage in soliciting from persons in
residences within this village, is hereby required to make written
application for a certificate of registration, as provided in this division.



   (b)   Organizations soliciting donations must be registered with the
state as a nonprofit, charitable, educational, religious, fraternal,
veterans' or labor organization.



   (c)   Organizations soliciting donations must furnish financial
information for the last three years. This information shall include a
breakdown showing how donations are spent, i.e., fundraising costs,
administrative costs, etc. The village will make this information available
for public inspection.



(Code 1965, § 13.02)



Sec. 74-52. Same--Application.



   Application for a certificate of registration shall be made upon a form
provided by the chief of police of this village and filed with the clerk or
his designee between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m., Monday through
Friday. Each applicant shall truthfully furnish in full, under oath, the
information requested on the form provided by the chief of police. Each
applicant must complete that form in the clerk's office and have his
signature witnessed by an employee of the clerk's office.



(Code 1965, § 13.03)



Sec. 74-53. Records; numbering of applications and certificates; issuance to
certain persons prohibited.



   (a)   The clerk shall cause to be kept in his office an accurate
record of every application received and acted upon, together with all other
information and data pertaining thereto and all certificates of registration
issued under the provisions of this article, and of the denial of
applications. Applications for certificates shall be numbered in consecutive
order as filed, and every certificate issued, and any renewal thereof, shall
be identified with the duplicate number of the application upon which it was
issued.



   (b)   No certificate of registration shall be issued to any person
who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the
state or any other state or federal law of the United States within five
years of the date of the application, nor to any person who has been
convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article.



(Code 1965, § 13.03)



Sec. 74-54. Issuance and revocation of certificate.



   (a)   The clerk, after consideration of the application and all
information obtained relative thereto, shall deny the application if the
applicant does not possess the qualifications for such certificate as
required in this division. Endorsement shall be made by the clerk upon the
application of the denial of the application. When the applicant is found to
be fully qualified, the certificate of registration shall be issued
forthwith. The determination to issue or deny registration shall be made in
each case within 48 hours, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays after a
complete application under section 74-53 has been filed with the office of
the clerk.



   (b)   Any certificate of registration issued under this division
shall be revoked by the clerk if the holder of the certificate is convicted
of a violation of any of the provisions of this article, or has made a false
material statement in the application, or otherwise becomes disqualified for
the issuance for the certificate of registration under the terms of this
article. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice shall be given by
the clerk to the holder of the certificate in person or by certified U.S.
mail, addressed to his residence address set forth in the application.



   (c)   Immediately upon the giving of such notice the certificate of
registration shall become null and void.



   (d)   The certificate of registration shall state its expiration
date.



(Code 1965, § 13.04)



Sec. 74-55. Exemptions.



   The village manager may, upon written request, waive the registration
requirements of sections 74-51, 74-52 and 74-53 for designated times and
dates to organizations seeking to solicit for civic, religious, political,
patriotic, philanthropic or eleemosynary purposes. Should the village manager
deny such a request, the president and board of trustees, upon separate
written request to them, may grant such waiver.



(Code 1965, § 13.10)



Secs. 74-56--74-75. Reserved.



DIVISION 3. RIGHT-OF-WAY SOLICITORS



Sec. 74-76.  Street solicitation prohibited.



   It is unlawful for any person to solicit employment, business,
contributions or sales of any kind, or to collect moneys for the same or any
one of the same, from the driver or any occupant of any vehicle traveling
upon any street, roadway or highway within the village limits.



   Notwithstanding the above, village law enforcement personnel and
firefighters may solicit charitable donations on public roadways from passing
motorists on behalf of a charitable organization provided that the charitable
organization first complies with all requirements of Public Act 97-692 (65
ILCS 5/11-80-9). applications for charitable solicitation pursuant to this
paragraph shall be made in writing on forms to be provided by the village
manager and shall be submitted to the office of the village manager. The
village may impose reasonable conditions on such solicitation in writing
consistent with the intent of Public Act 97-692 and based upon articulated
public safety concerns.



(MC-834, § 1, 6-22-10; MC-876, § 1, 8-28-12)



Secs. 74-77--74-95. Reserved.



ARTICLE III. ITINERANT MERCHANTS



Sec. 74-96. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Indoor itinerant merchant means an itinerant merchant who conducts
business wholly indoors.



   Itinerant merchant means any person engaged in any temporary business
of selling goods, wares, merchandise, or service from a stationary location
within the village who hires, uses, leases, or occupies all or part of any
structure or vacant lot for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares,
merchandise, or service on a temporary basis for a period of time not
exceeding 100 days. The person so engaged shall not be relieved from
complying with the provisions of this article merely by reason of associating
temporarily with, or by conducting such transient business in connection with
any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer.



   Outdoor itinerant merchant means an itinerant merchant who conducts
business either wholly or partially outdoors.



(Code 1965, § 41.16(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.; Zoning Ordinance
9.3.B.1



Sec. 74-97. License--Required.



   No person shall operate as an itinerant merchant without having first
secured a license therefor as prescribed in this section.



(Code 1965, § 41.16(b))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 74-98. Same--Application.



   An application for an itinerant merchant license shall include the
following information:



      (1)   The names, addresses and phone numbers of the persons
who will manage the applicant's business during the time it is proposed to be
conducted in the village;



      (2)   The length of time for which the license is desired;



      (3)   Location from where the goods, wares, merchandise, and
services will be sold;



      (4)   A statement of the nature, character and quality of the
goods, wares, merchandise, or service to be sold or offered for sale by the
applicant in the village; and whether the goods, wares, or merchandise are
proposed to be sold from stock in possession or by sample, by direct sale, or
by taking orders for future delivery;



      (5)   Written consent from the owner or person in control of
the property where the itinerant merchant proposes to locate giving
permission for the business activity proposed by the applicant and for the
time sought for the license;



      (6)   State retail occupation number; and



      (7)   Such other information as deemed reasonably appropriate
by the village manager or his designee to fulfill the purpose of this article
in the protection of the public good.



(Code 1965, § 41.16(c))



Sec. 74-99. Same--Issuance.



   Applications from proposed indoor itinerant merchants shall be reviewed
and, upon a determination that the application is complete and upon payment
of the license fee, the license shall be issued by the village manager or his
designee. Applications from proposed outdoor itinerant merchants shall be
forwarded to the Planning and Zoning Commission and be processed in
accordance with the zoning ordinance. Upon approval by the Planning and
Zoning Commission and upon payment of the license fee, the license shall be
issued by the village manager or his designee.



(Code 1965, § 41.16(d))  (MC-951, § 1, 3-22-16)



Sec. 74-100. Same--Prohibition against transfer.



   No license issued under this article may be assigned, sold or
transferred to any other person.



(Code 1965, § 41.16(e))



Sec. 74-101. Same--Exhibition.



   Itinerant merchants are required to conspicuously exhibit their
licenses at all times while doing business at the licensed location.



(Code 1965, § 41.16(f))



Sec. 74-102. Same--Suspension or revocation.



   (a)   The license issued pursuant to this article may be suspended
or revoked by the village manager or his designee, after giving notice and
the opportunity for an informal hearing to the licensee, for any of the
following causes:



      (1)   Any false or fraudulent statement in the license
application;



      (2)   Any violation by the licensee or an employee thereof of
any law, ordinance or condition of license;



      (3)   Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made by
the licensee or an employee thereof in connection with the sale of
merchandise;



      (4)   Conducting the licensed business in the village in an
unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or
a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. Notice of
hearing for possible suspension or revocation of a license shall be given in
writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time
and place of hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid to the
licensee at his last known address, at least five days prior to the hearing
date. The licensee and village manager may mutually agree to a revised
hearing date. A written result of the hearing shall be mailed to the
licensee; or



      (5)   Conviction by the licensee of any crime involving moral
turpitude.



(Code 1965, § 41.16(g))



Sec. 74-103. Same--Appeal of suspension or revocation.



   Any person aggrieved by the decision of the village manager or his
designee in denying the issuance of a license, or in connection with the
suspension or revocation of a license once issued, may appeal such decision
to the village board, by filing a notice of appeal with the village manager
within ten calendar days after the village manager's notice of denial or
notice of the result of a suspension or revocation hearing has been mailed to
the applicant. The notice shall contain a written statement of the grounds
for the appeal. The village board shall set the time and place for the
appeal, and notice of the time and place of that hearing shall be given to
the petitioner by mail, postage prepaid, at his last known address, at least
five days prior to the hearing. The decision of the village board shall be
final.



(Code 1965, § 41.16(h))



Sec. 74-104. Same--Fee.



   The fee for an itinerant merchant license shall be $75.00 per 100
consecutive day-period or less. For outdoor itinerant merchant licenses, this
fee shall be in addition to the fee for an administrative variance, as
provided for in section 1210 of the village zoning ordinance.



(Code 1965, § 41.16(j))



Sec. 74-105. Inspections to ensure article compliance.



   The village manager or his designee may inspect any premises or
location used as a base of operation for any itinerant merchant licensed
under this article as often as necessary to ensure compliance with this
article and all other ordinances relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.16(i))



Secs. 74-106--74-135. Reserved.



ARTICLE IV. PEDDLERS AND CANVASSERS



Sec. 74-136. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Canvasser means any person who travels from place to place within the
village by foot or other conveyance distributing product samples,
advertisements, leaflets or any item of similar nature for the purpose of
commercial activities and solicitation of funds or who, for any reason,
contacts citizens of the village without request, invitation or appointment.



   Peddler means any person who, going from place to place within the
village, shall sell, offer for sale, sell and deliver, barter or exchange any
goods or merchandise and rendering immediate delivery thereof.



(Code 1965, § 41.25(a)) (MC-683)



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 74-137. License--Required.



   No person shall operate as a peddler or canvasser without having first
secured a license therefor.



(Code 1965, § 41.25(b))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 74-138. Same--Application.



   (a)   Applications for peddler and canvasser licenses shall be made
upon such forms as prescribed by the village. Such application shall specify
the number of vehicles to be used, if any, the permanent address of licensee,
the type of merchandise to be sold and shall be the same form and require the
same information as that required for solicitor's certificates of
registration in article II of this chapter.



   (b)   All peddlers and canvassers must supply the village with their
state retail occupation tax number.



   (c)   All statements made by the applicant upon the application or
in connection therewith shall be under oath.



   (d)   The chief of police may require every such applicant to submit
to fingerprinting by the police department of this village.



   (e)   The village clerk shall cause to be kept in his office an
accurate record of every application received and acted upon, together with
all other information and data pertaining thereto and all licenses issued
under the provisions of this article, and of the denial of applications.
Applications for licenses shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed,
and every license issued, and any renewal thereof, shall be identified with
the duplicate number of the application upon which it was issued.



   (f)   Each application shall be reviewed and processed by the chief
of police or his designee. Processing and review, whenever possible, shall be
completed within five business days from the date of the application.



   (g)   No license shall be issued to any person who has been
convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state or any
other state or federal law, within five years of the date of the application;
to any person who has been released from incarceration in a federal or state
penal institution within five years of the date of the application if any
weapon was used by the applicant in the perpetration of such felony; if one
or more persons were injured as the result of that act; if the felony was a
violent crime which threatened or resulted in physical harm to others; or if
the conviction resulted from the applicant's efforts to swindle, obtain money
under false pretenses or was committed while the applicant was in the process
of soliciting or calling on persons while going door-to-door. No license
shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any
provisions of this article, nor to any person whose license issued under this
article has previously been revoked as provided in this section.



(Code 1965, § 41.25(c))



Sec. 74-139. Same--Issuance and revocation.



   (a)   The chief of police, after consideration of the application
and all information obtained relative thereto, shall deny the application if
the applicant does not possess the qualifications for such license as
required in this article. Endorsement shall be made by the chief of police
upon the application of the denial of the application. When the applicant is
found to be fully qualified, the chief of police shall approve the
application, and the license shall be issued forthwith by the village clerk.



   (b)   Any license issued under this article shall be revoked by the
chief of police or village clerk if the holder of the license is convicted of
a violation of any of the provisions of this article, or has made a false
material statement in the application, or otherwise becomes disqualified for
the issuance for the license under the terms of this article. Immediately
upon such revocation, written notice shall be given by the chief of police or
village clerk to the holder of the license in person or by certified U.S.
mail addressed to his residence address set forth in the application.



   (c)   Immediately upon the mailing of such notice, the license shall
become null and void.



   (d)   The license shall state the expiration date and shall in no
case be valid for a period in excess of 90 days from the date of issuance.



(Code 1965, § 41.25(d))



Sec. 74-140. Same--Fee.



   The fee for each peddler and canvasser license shall be $8.00 per
person, per day.



(Code 1965, § 41.25(j))



Sec. 74-141. Same--Permit badges.



   (a)   The village clerk shall cause a permit badge to be issued upon
the approval of each peddler or canvasser application. Such permit badge
shall be no less than four inches in diameter, and each shall bear an
identifying number. The permit badge shall be prominently displayed upon the
person of every peddler and canvasser during the hours such activity is being
conducted within the village.



   (b)   Upon completion of individual activity within the village,
such peddler or canvasser shall surrender the permit badge to the village
clerk's office.



   (c)   The village clerk shall maintain a register of the issuance of
such permit badges. Such register shall, by permit badge number, contain
complete and accurate information concerning each person and the purpose and
anticipated duration of the approved activity.



(Code 1965, § 41.25(e))



Sec. 74-142. Duty to obey signed premises and depart at request of occupant.



   It shall be the duty of every peddler and canvasser not to enter upon
any premises where a sign is prominently displayed saying, "no peddlers or
canvassers invited" and to immediately and peacefully depart from such
premises as soon as such sign is observed. Any peddler or canvasser who has
gained entry to any residence or other structure, whether invited or not,
shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to
do so by the occupant.



(Code 1965, § 41.25(f))



Sec. 74-143. Uninvited peddling and canvassing in defiance of notices.



   It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance
for any person to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any
door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the
attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an
audience with the occupant thereof and engage in peddling or canvassing in
defiance of any notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the
provisions of this article.



(Code 1965, § 41.25(g))



Sec. 74-144. Hours.



   It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance
for any person, whether registered under this article or not, to go upon any
premises and ring the doorbell or near any door of a residence located
thereon, or rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other
manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence,
for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant and engage in
peddling or canvassing prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 7:00 p.m. of any weekday
or Saturday, or at any time on a Sunday or on a state or national holiday.



(Code 1965, § 41.25(h); MC-905, § 1, 3-25-14)



Sec. 74-145. Miscellaneous regulations.



   Additional regulations governing peddling and canvassing are as follows:



      (1)   It shall be illegal for any peddler or canvasser to
sell, or offer for sale, any goods, merchandise, articles or things other
than those specified in the application.



      (2)   No peddler or canvasser shall conduct business on public
property.



      (3)   All holders of such licenses shall refrain from
trespassing upon private and public properties except on designated walks and
paths, and shall restrict the delivery of merchandise, pamphlets and material
to receptacles designated for such deliveries.



      (4)   Peddlers dispensing food, beverages or confections shall
be in full compliance with all applicable provisions of this Code regulating
restaurants and food handlers. All foods, beverages and confections dispensed
from a vehicle shall, unless packaged by the manufacturer at an approved
location, be dispensed by a person from the interior of the vehicle, the cab
or driver's compartment of which is partitioned from the food, beverage or
confection processing or preparation area.



      (5)   No person shall distribute circulars, dodgers or
handbills in such a manner that such materials may be blown or carried about
by the elements.



(Code 1965, § 41.25(i))



Sec. 74-146. Inspections to ensure compliance with article.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.25(k))



Sec. 74-147. Exemptions.



   The village manager may, upon written request, waive the registration
requirements of this article for designated times and dates to organizations
seeking to solicit for civic, religious, political, patriotic, philanthropic
or eleemosynary purposes. Should the village manager deny such a request, the
president and board of trustees, upon separate written request to them, may
grant such waiver.



(Code 1965, § 41.25(l))



Sec. 74-148. Identification.



   Every person who acts as a peddler or canvasser within the village,
including those who have received a waiver under section 74-147, unless
excused by the village manager as hereinafter provided, shall wear the
identification card supplied by the village. Such card identifies the person
as a permitted peddler or canvasser and shall be worn on the outer clothing
of the peddler or canvasser in a conspicuous and clearly visible manner. The
village manager may, upon written request, waive the requirements of this
section in favor of any person who will peddle or canvass in a commonly
recognizable uniform such as the girl scout uniform, boy scout uniform,
little league uniform, etc. Should the village manager deny such a request,
the president and board of trustees, upon separate written request to them,
may grant such waiver.



(Code 1965, § 41.25(m))



Chapter 78  PLANNING*



   *Cross reference(s)--Department of public works, § 2-336 et seq.;
buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; environment, ch. 38; fire

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL



Secs. 78-1--78-25. Reserved.



ARTICLE II. PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION*



   *Cross reference(s)--Administration, ch. 2.



Sec. 78-26. Purpose of article; creation of Commission.



   In order that adequate provisions be made for the preparation of a
comprehensive plan for the guidance, direction and control of the growth and
development within the village, and to fulfill the additional duties detailed
in section 2.2 of the Homewood Zoning Ordinance, the existing Plan Commission
and Zone Board of Appeals is dissolved and a Planning and Zoning  Commission
is hereby created under authority of the Illinois Municipal Code



(65 ILCS 5/11-12-4; 11-12-5; 11-13-3(f) - (g)).
(MC-951, § 1, 3-22-16)



Sec. 78-27. Membership; terms.



   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall consist of seven (7) members.
Of the initial seven commission appointees, one shall be appointed for one
year, one for 2 years, 1 for 3 years, one for 4 years, one for 5 years, one
for 6 years, and one for 7 years, the successor to each member so appointed
to serve for a term of 5 years.



(MC-951, § 1, 3-22-16)



Sec. 78-28. Powers and duties.



   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall have all power and duties
previously exercised by the Plan Commission or Zone Board of Appeals,
including the powers and duties set forth in Article 11 of the Illinois
Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-12-4 et seq.), the Homewood Zoning Ordinance,
and as set forth in chapter 98 and other applicable provisions of the
Homewood Municipal Code.



(MC-951, § 1, 3-22-16)



Sec. 78-29. Public improvements; consideration.



   The village manager shall furnish the Planning and Zoning Commission
for its consideration a copy of all provisions of this chapter, other
ordinances, plans and data relative to public improvements of any nature. The
Planning and Zoning Commission may report in relation thereto if it deems a
report necessary or advisable, for consideration by the board of trustees.



(MC-951, § 1, 3-22-16)



Secs. 78-31--78-60. Reserved.



ARTICLE III. COMPREHENSIVE PLAN



Sec. 78-61. Contents.



The official comprehensive plan of the village shall consist of the following:



      (1)   The "Comprehensive Village Plan" prepared in 1958 by
Carl L. Gardner and Associates, including the official maps contained therein.



      (2)   The zoning regulations published in Appendix A to this
Code.



      (3)   The subdivision regulations set forth in chapter 98 of
this Code.



      (4)   Such other provisions of this Code or ordinance or
regulations of this village relating to streets, alleys, public grounds and
sewers, water supply and distribution and other improvements specified in the
Illinois Municipal Code,  sec. 11- 12-5 (65 ILCS 5/11-12-5).



(Code 1965, § 31.02(a))



Sec. 78-62.  References include parts.



Any reference in this Code or any other ordinances of the village to the
"official plan," the "official comprehensive plan," the "village plan" or any
combination of these terms, shall be taken to mean and include all of such
plans.



(Code 1965, § 31.02(b))



Sec. 78-63. Compliance with required for all public improvements.



   No plat of subdivision, plan for the construction or layout of streets,
or work involving laying sewer or water mains or other improvements regulated
by the official comprehensive plan, shall be approved unless the same
complies fully with the requirements of the official comprehensive plan.



(Code 1965, § 31.02(c))



Secs. 78-64--78-90. Reserved.



ARTICLE IV. BUSINESS DISTRICTS*



   *Cross reference(s)--Businesses generally, ch. 26.



Sec. 78-91. Proposals to designate.



   The village board may, on its own initiative, or at the recommendation
of the economic development committee, village staff or others, propose the
designation of areas within the village as business districts and approve
specific plans for business districts pursuant to the Business District
Development and Redevelopment Act, 65 ILCS 5/11-74.3- 1 et seq. (the "Act")
and this article.



(Code 1965, § 20.01)



Sec. 78-92. Authority of village board.



   The village board shall have the authority designated by the Act and by
this article.



(Code 1965, § 20.02)



Sec. 78-93. Plans.



   Prior to designation of an area as a business district, the village
shall develop a specific plan to maintain or revitalize the area, to provide
opportunities to develop or redevelop the area, and/or to attract sound and
stable commercial growth to the area.



   Such proposed business district plan should conform to the
comprehensive plan of the village. The plan shall be made available for
public inspection prior to fixing the time and place for public hearings to
consider the designation of an area as a business district of the village and
final approval of the plan.



(Code 1965, § 20.03)



Sec. 78-94. Public hearings.



   (a)   Required. Prior to the designation of an area within the
village as a business district, the village board shall conduct at least two
public hearings pursuant to public notice as provided in this section to
consider whether the designation of an area as a business district of the
village and the approval of a specific business plan for the area is
reasonably necessary, essential, advantageous, appropriate, desirable or in
the public interest to ensure opportunities for development or redevelopment,
to attract sound and stable commercial growth or to maintain, revitalize or
enhance the tax base of the area within the village.



   (b)   Notice. Notice of the village board public hearings shall be
given by publication at least once not less than ten days prior to the
hearing in a newspaper of general circulation within the village. Notice by
mailing shall be given by depositing the notice, postage prepaid, in the
United States mail addressed to the person in whose name the general real
estate taxes for the last preceding year were paid for all parcels of real
estate located within the proposed area, not less than ten days prior to the
time set for the public hearing. If taxes for the last preceding year were
not paid, the notice shall be sent to the person last listed on the tax rolls
prior to that year as the owner of such property.



   (c)   Filing of objections. At the public hearings any interested
person, including all persons owning real property located within the
proposed business district, may file written objections to and may be heard
orally in respect to any issue embodied in the public hearing notice.



   (d)   Hearing and preliminary determination of protests and
objections. The village board shall hear and preliminarily determine all
protests and objections at the first public hearing. Village staff as
designated by the village manager shall also attend this hearing. The public
hearing may be adjourned to another date without further notice other than a
motion entered upon the minutes fixing the date, time and place of its
reconvening.



   (e)   Recommendations for designation of business district; final
determination of protests and objections; approval of specific plan. Within
30 days after final adjournment of the public hearing, or as otherwise
approved by the village board, the village staff shall submit its written
recommendation to the village board as to the designation of the proposed
business district, the determination of all protests and objections made at
the public hearing, and the approval of a specific plan for the business
district.



(Code 1965, § 20.04)



Sec. 78-95. Second public hearing.



   (a)   Consideration of area to be designated. Prior to the
designation of a business district, the village board shall conduct at least
one additional public hearing pursuant to public notice as provided in this
section to consider the designation of an area as a business district of the
village.



   (b)   Notice. Notice of the second public hearing shall be given by
publication at least once not less than ten days prior to the hearing in a
newspaper of general circulation within the village. Notice by mailing shall
be given by depositing the notice, postage prepaid, in the United States mail
addressed to the person in whose name the general real estate taxes for the
last preceding year were paid for all parcels of real estate located within
the proposed area, not less than ten days prior to the time set for the
public hearing. If taxes for the last preceding year were not paid, the
notice shall be sent to the person last listed on the tax rolls prior to that
year as the owner of such property.



   (c)   Filing of objections. At the public hearing any interested
person, including all persons owning real property located within the
proposed business district, may file written objections to and may be heard
orally in respect to any issues embodied in the public hearing notice.



   (d)   Hearing and final determination of protests and objections.
The village board shall hear and finally determine all protests and
objections at the public hearing. The public hearing may be adjourned to
another date without further notice other than a motion entered upon the
minutes fixing the date, time and place of its reconvening.



   (e)   Deletion of territory from proposed district. At the public
hearing or during a regular meeting of the village board following final
adjournment of the public hearing, the village board may delete territory
from the proposed business district. Thereafter, territory may be deleted as
provided in section 78-99.



(Code 1965, § 20.05)



Sec. 78-96. Public hearing notices.



   (a)   For the purposes of sections 78-94 and 78-95, a public hearing
notice shall include:



      (1)   The date, time and place of the public hearing.



      (2)   The boundaries of the area by approximate street
location and by legal description.



      (3)   A notification that a specific plan for the business
district is on file with the village clerk and available for public
inspection and that designation of the area as a business district and
approval of the plan will be considered at the public hearing.



      (4)   A notification that all interested persons will be given
an opportunity to be heard at the hearing and to file written objections
regarding the proposed business district and any issues embodied in the
notice.



   (b)   Notice of the separate public hearings to be held by the
village board may be combined into a single notice, provided such combined
notice is published and mailed not less than ten days prior to the first
hearing date in accordance with section 78-94.



(Code 1965, § 20.06)



Sec. 78-97. Designation.



   After the final adjournment of the public hearings provided in sections
78-94 and 78-95, the village board may, by ordinance, designate the area
described in the public hearing notices, or a part of such area, as a
business district of the village and approve a specific plan for the business
district.



(Code 1965, § 20.07)



Sec. 78-98. Implementation of plans.



   In addition to all other powers conferred by law, the village board
shall have the following powers for the planning, execution and
implementation of business district plans:



      (1)   Approve all development and redevelopment proposals for
a business district.



      (2)   Exercise the power of eminent domain for the acquisition
of real and personal property for the purpose of a development or
redevelopment project.



      (3)   Acquire, manage, convey or otherwise dispose of real and
personal property acquired pursuant to the provisions of a development or
redevelopment plan.



      (4)   Apply for and accept capital grants and loans from the
United States and the state, or any instrumentality of the United States or
the state, for business district deve- lopment and redevelopment.



      (5)   Borrow funds as it may deem necessary for the purpose of
business district development and redevelopment, and in this connection issue
such obligation or revenue bonds as it shall deem necessary, subject to
applicable statutory limitations.



      (6)   Enter into contracts with any public or private agency
or person.



      (7)   Sell, lease, trade or improve such real property as may
be acquired in connection with business district development and
redevelopment plans.



      (8)   Employ all such persons as may be necessary for the
planning, administration and implementation of business district plans.



      (9)   Expend such public funds as may be necessary for the
planning, execution and implementation of the business district plans.



      (10)   Establish by ordinance or resolution procedures for the
planning, execution and implementation of business plans.



      (11)   Create a business district development and redevel-
opment commission to act as agent for the village for the purposes of
business district development and redevel- opment.



      (12)   Such other powers as may hereafter be granted the
village pursuant to the Act, or other applicable law.



(Code 1965, § 20.08)



   (a)   The boundaries of a business district may be enlarged, but
only after notice and hearing as provided in sections 78-94, 78-95 and 78-96,
such notice to be served in the original area of the business district and in
any areas proposed to be added to the business district, except that where
the area to be added represents less than five percent of the total land area
of the original business district, the notice by mailing requirement shall be
limited only to the area to be added and not to the original business
district.



   (b)   An area may be deleted from a business district, but only
after notice and hearing as provided in section 78-95, such notice to be
served in the original area of the business district and in any areas
proposed to be deleted from the business district. An area shall not be
deleted if the area will, as a result, cease to be security for any bonded
indebtedness issued to implement the business district plan.



(Code 1965, § 20.09)



Sec. 78-100 --78-119.  Reserved.



ARTICLE V. APPEARANCE CODE



Sec. 78-120.  Title.



   This article, including any regulation hereafter adopted, shall be
hereafter known, cited and referred to as the “Homewood Appearance Code.”



(Code 1965, § 12.01)



Sec. 78-121.  Intent and purpose.



   This Homewood appearance code is adopted for the following purposes:



   (a)   To promote the public health, safety, morals, comfort and
general welfare of the citizens of this village.



   (b)   To enhance the values of property throughout this village.



   (c)   To protect and to stabilize the general appearance of 
buildings, structures, landscaping and open areas, in the multiple dwelling,
business, public lands and manufacturing zoning areas of this village.



   (d)   To ensure adequate light, air and privacy for property in the
multiple dwelling, business, public lands and manufacturing zoning areas of
this village.



   (e)   To encourage and promote acceptability, attractiveness,
cohesiveness and compatibility of new buildings, developments, moved
buildings, remodeling and additions so as to maintain and improve the
established standards of property values throughout the village.



(Code 1965 § 12.02)



Sec. 78-122. Appearance commission: creation and term of office.



   There is hereby created an appearance commission, to consist of seven
members appointed by the village president with the approval of the board of
trustees. Commission members shall be appointed for three-year terms. 
However, all commission members serve at the pleasure of the village board.



(MC-952, § 1, 3-22-16)



Sec. 78-123. Qualification.



   All members of the appearance commission shall be residents of the
village and shall serve without compensation.  In making the appointments to
the commission, the president shall seek to appoint as members persons who
are recognized as  knowledgeable in matters of aesthetic judgment by virtue
of training, education and experience, (such as architects, landscape
architects, real estate appraisers, ecologists and land planners) and
possessing qualities of impartiality and broad judgment.  The members of the
commission shall, before entering into their official duties, severally take
the oath of office prescribed by law for village officials.  No member of
the commission shall participate in discussions or vote on requests for a
recommendation for approval from any client he is serving, or from any
business of which he is an owner, corporate officer, agent or employee.



Sec. 78-124.  Chairman.



   The village president, with the approval of the board of trustees,
shall appoint one of the members to serve as chairman.  The chairman shall
have power to administer oaths.



(Code 1965, § 12.05)



Sec. 78-125.  Vacancies.



   Vacancies on said commission shall be filled for the unexpired term of
the member whose place has become vacant, in the same manner in which
original appointments are required to be made.



Sec. 78-126.  Meetings, quorum records.



   Meetings of the appearance commission shall be held at the call of the
chairman, and shall be called whenever an application for a recommendation
for approval is submitted for consideration, or as otherwise required under
78-127. Four members shall constitute a quorum.  An affirmative or negative
vote of at least four members is needed for approval or denial.  The
chairman shall be entitled to be counted in determining a quorum and to vote
as a member.  All meetings shall be open to the public.  The commission
shall keep minutes of its proceedings and shall keep records of its
examinations and other official action.  The commission may adopt its own
rules of procedure not inconsistent with this chapter.



(MC-952, § 1, 3-22-16)



Sec. 78-127.  Powers and duties. 



The appearance commission shall have the following powers and duties:



   (a)   To hold public hearings on and make recommendations for an
appearance plan as provided in section 78-128.



   (b)   To consult with and cooperate with the Planning and Zoning
Commission, other village departments, and any other municipal or
governmental bodies on matters affecting the appearance of the village.



   (c)   To study exterior design drawings, landscape and site plans
and materials for any proposed public works or public improvements excluding
public infrastructure projects having no changes to landscaping or site
improvements, and to make recommendations to the board of trustees or village
manager as to the architectural or aesthetic aspects thereof.



   (d)   To hold hearings, when required, on the issuance of
recommendation for approval, as provided in section 78-132 and to issue or
deny such recommendation for approval in accordance with said section.



   (e)   To hold hearings on new signs, replacement pole signs, and for
sign variations.



(MC-951, § 1, 3-22-16)



Sec. 78-128.  Appearance plan.



   The appearance commission members shall, within six months after their
appointment, prepare a proposed appearance plan to apply to the multiple
family, business, public lands and manufacturing zoning areasof the village,
and are authorized to seek the advice and counsel of local qualified
professionals in the fields of architecture, ecology, and land planning in
the creation of the appearance plan.  Said appearance plan shall be based on
the intent and purposes of this chapter, as set forth in section 78.121.



   Said plan shall be intended as the standard, or guideline for future
physical developments, in said zoning districts, and should consider, amongst
other features:



   (a)   The external architectural features of  proposed buildings
and landscaping and site planning thereof.



   (b)   Existing village ordinances and provisions of  “The
Homewood Village Code” as amended, as to, but not limited to, zoning,
building, subdivision, trees and shrubs; provided however, nothing in said
appearance plan shall conflict with, modify or alter any provisions of the
zoning or subdivision ordinances of the village.



   (c)   The appearance commission shall continuously review the
appearance plan and make written recommendations for revisions to the village
board no less than  every four years .



Sec. 78-129.  Public hearing.



   After agreeing on a proposed appearance plan, the commission shall hold
a public hearing thereon.  A copy of the proposed plan shall be on file
during regular business hours at the office of the village clerk in the
village hall for public inspection at least 7 days prior to that public
hearing and at all times after its adoption.  Notice of the public hearing
shall be made as required by the Illinois Open Meetings Act.  The hearing
may be adjourned from time to time.  Within 30 days after final adjournment
of the hearing, the commission shall recommend a final appearance plan to the
board of trustees.



(MC-896, § 1, 10-8-13)



Sec. 78-130.  Adoption by board of trustees.



The board of trustees shall thereafter  at a public meeting consider the
proposed plan and if it so desires may adopt the same in whole or in part,
with or without change.  Adoption of the appearance plan shall be by
ordinance. 



Sec. 78-131.  Amendments.



   The appearance plan may be amended, by the board of trustees after
receiving a recommendation from the appearance commission regarding a
proposed amendment. The appearance commission shall make a recommendation as
to amendments only after holding a public hearing after notice as set forth
in section 78-129 hereof.



Sec. 78-132.  Regulatory powers of commission over external architectural
features of buildings and structures.



   (a)   When a building permit or other permit required under the
ordinances of the village is requested for the erection, construction,
alteration or repair of any building or structure other than a single family
residence building, no such building permit or other permit shall be issued
by the building inspector except upon the granting of a recommendation for
approval by the appearance commission.  The foregoing requirement shall not
preclude the issuance of a building permit without such recommendation, if
the building inspector determines that no external architectural feature, as
defined in section 78-128,is involved in the work for which the building
permit is sought. 



   No permit required under the ordinances of the village shall be issued
to allow the moving of any structure or building whether industrial,
commercial or residential, including single family and multi-family onto any
lot in the village except upon the granting of a recommendation for approval
by the appearance commission. 



   (b)   Recommendation for approval - when required.  When a proposed
building or development must be reviewed by the Planning and Zoning
Commission  the petitioner shall be assigned to appear before the appearance
commission at the earliest possible date, but subsequent to any required
hearing before  the Planning and Zoning Commission.



   (c)   Recommendation for approval -  preliminary consideration. 
The appearance commission shall, at the written request of a prospective
applicant for a recommendation for approval, give consideration to
preliminary exterior drawings, elevations, sketches, landscape and site plans
and materials on a specific project before a formal application is filed, and
shall provide such advice, counsel, suggestions and recommendations on
matters pertaining to aesthetics as they may deem necessary to guide said
prospective applicant in the development of a plan which would comply with
the requirements and purposes of the appearance plan. The commission shall
act in an advisory capacity only, with regard to preliminary plans, and shall
provide consultation only on projects for which preliminary drawings and
materials are furnished by a prospective applicant, and shall not participate
in the development of the basic concept, plans or drawings.



   All hearings on preliminary plans are to be public, and are to be held
in accordance with the provisions and requirements established in section
78-132(d) (final hearings).



   Upon finding that the preliminary exterior drawings, sketches,
landscape and site plans and materials are appropriate to, or compatible
with, the character of the immediate neighborhood, and will tend to effect
the general purposes of the appearance plan, the commission shall issue a
preliminary approval.  Said approval will be irrevocable, and makes the
issuance of the recommendation for approval mandatory upon application,
unless the final presentation does not substantially comply in all respects
with the preliminary presentation upon which the preliminary recommendation 
was based.



   If the appearance commission is unwilling to grant a preliminary
recommendation, the applicant can either return with modified plans to secure
the preliminary recommendation or he may return with modified plans for final
approval.  If he elects to seek a final hearing, he may present additional
evidence at that time.



   (d)   Recommendation for approval - final hearings.  Upon the
filing of an application for building permit for which a  recommendation for
approval is or may be required under this section, the building inspector
shall  transmit said application to the appearance commission.  The fact
that an application for a recommendation for approval  has been filed shall
not be cause for the building inspector to delay the review of plans relating
to the building and zoning aspects of the project, while said application is
pending.  The said commission shall, within 15 days fix a reasonable time
for a hearing and give a written 5 day notice thereof to the applicant. 
Notice of that hearing shall be made as required by the Illinois Open
Meetings Act.



   Upon such hearing the commission shall consider the application for 
building permit, and if necessary receive additional evidence from the
applicant or his agent or attorney and from village personnel or other
persons as to whether the external architectural features of the proposed
building or structure comply with the appearance plan.  All testimony given
at such hearing shall be under oath.



   (e)   Action of appearance commission.  If preliminary
consideration has not been requested under the terms and provisions of
section 78-132(c), prior to making its decision the commission may make
recommendations to the applicant as to changes in the exterior drawings,
sketches, landscaping, site plans and materials which in the judgment of the
commission would tend to effect the general purposes of the appearance plan.



   The commission shall make its decision and shall issue to the building
inspector a recommendation for approval, unless the commission finds that the
said plan does not conform to the appearance plan and/or that the proposed
building or structure will be inappropriate to, or incompatible with, the
character of the immediate neighborhood and cause substantial depreciation in
property values.  If preliminary hearings have been held on the project for
which application is being made, and preliminary recommendation has been
issued by the commission as provided in section 78-132 (c), the commission
shall issue a recommendation for approval  immediately, provided that the
final drawings, plans and materials as presented substantially comply in all
respects with the preliminary presentation upon which the preliminary
recommendation  was based.



   (f)   Appeal from appearance commission.  Appeal of any decision or
action of the appearance commission under this section may be taken to the
village board.  Such appeal shall be initiated by a written request to the
village manager asking that the matter be placed on the village board's
agenda for consideration.  Such request must be received by the manager no
later than 30 days after the date of the decision appealed from.



(MC-896, § 1, 10-8-13; MC-951, § 1, 3-22-16)



Sec. 78-133  Follow-up by building inspector.  



   Upon the granting of a recommendation for approval, the exterior
drawings, elevations, sketches, landscape and site plans, renderings and
materials upon which said recommendation for approval was granted shall be
turned over to the building inspector, whose responsibility shall be to
determine, from time to time as the project is in progress, and finally upon
its completion, that there has been progress and finally upon its completion,
that there has been no substantial unauthorized deviation from the
presentation upon which the recommendation for approval  was originally
granted.  Any substantial unauthorized deviation shall be cause for the
building inspector to halt construction of a project which is not
substantially as shown in the sketches, plans and other material submitted
and on which the recommendation for approval was approved.  If a project is
otherwise completed but some phases of the appearance plan have not been
completed, a developer may with the approval of the director of public works
deposit sufficient funds in escrow to complete the project, and obtain a
temporary certificate of occupancy.  That escrow shall be in a form
acceptable to the village.



Chapter 82  SECONDHAND GOODS*



   *Cross reference(s)--Department of public works, § 2-336 et seq.;
businesses, ch. 26; health and sanitation, ch. 50; peddlers and solicitors,
ch. 74; solid waste, ch. 90.
