ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL



Secs. 82-1--82-60.  Reserved.



ARTICLE II. SECONDHAND GOODS DEALERS*



   *State law reference(s)--Authority to regulate, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3.



Sec. 82-61. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Secondhand dealer means any person dealing in the sale of used
merchandise, including antique dealers.



(Code 1965, § 41.29(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 82-62. License--Required.



   No person shall operate or conduct a secondhand store in the village
without having first obtained a license therefor. No person operating a
secondhand store shall do business as a pawnbroker without having obtained a
pawnbroker's license in addition to the secondhand dealer's license.



(Code 1965, § 41.29(b))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 82-63.  Same--Application.



   Applications for secondhand dealer licenses shall be made upon such
forms as prescribed by the village. Such application shall also specify the
names and addresses of all employees.



(Code 1965, § 41.29(c))



Sec. 82-64. Same--Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations are as follows:



      (1)   It shall be the duty of every secondhand dealer to
report to the police immediately when he is in receipt of any article which
he shall have reason to believe to be stolen or lost.



      (2)   No secondhand dealer shall sell any revolver, pistol,
blackjack or sawed-off shotgun.



      (3)   No secondhand dealer shall employ a minor to assist him
in his business.



      (4)   Every secondhand dealer doing business in the village
shall keep a record of every article purchased by him for retail, setting
forth an accurate description of the article purchased, the price paid
therefor, and the name and residence of the person from whom such purchase
was made. This record shall be open for inspection by any police officer at
any time during business hours. This provision shall not apply to charitable,
religious or not-for-profit organizations.



(Code 1965, § 41.29(d))



Sec. 82-65. Same--Fee.



   The annual fee for a secondhand dealer license shall be on a square
footage basis, as described in section 26-37.



(Code 1965, § 41.29(e))



Sec. 82-66. Inspections to ensure article compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.29(f))



Secs. 82-67--82-95. Reserved.



ARTICLE III. PAWNBROKERS



Sec. 82-96. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Pawnbroker  means every person or company engaged in the business of
receiving property in pledge or as security for money or other thing advanced
to the pawner or pledger.



(Code 1965, § 41.24(a))



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 82-97. License--Required.



   No person shall operate or conduct the business of pawnbroker without
having first obtained a license therefor. No pawnbroker shall conduct the
business of a secondhand dealer without a secondhand dealer's license, in
addition to his pawnbroker's license.



(Code 1965, § 41.24(b))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 82-98. Same--Application.



   Applications for pawnbroker licenses shall be made upon such forms as
prescribed by the village. Such application shall also state the number of
employees intended to be engaged, and their names, addresses, and ages.



(Code 1965, § 41.24(c))



Sec. 82-99. Same--Licensee regulations.



   (a)   Every pawnbroker and loan broker shall keep a standard record
book that has been approved by the sheriff of the county in which the
pawnbroker does business, in which shall be written in ink, at the time of
each and every loan or taking of a pledge, an accurate account and
description, in the English language, of all the goods, articles and other
things pawned or pledged; the amount of money, value or thing loaned thereon;
the time of pledging the same; the rate of interest to be paid on such loan;
and the name and residence of the person making such pawn or pledge. Such
entry shall include the serial number or identification number of items
received which are required to bear such number. Every pawnbroker shall also
record in his book, an accurate account and description, in the English
language, of all goods, articles and other things purchased or received for
the purpose of resale or loan collateral by the pawnbroker from any source,
not in the course of a pledge or loan; the time of such purchase or receipt;
and the name and address of the person or business which sold or delivered
such goods, articles, or other things to the pawnbroker. No entry in such
book shall be erased, mutilated or changed.



   (b)   Every pawnbroker shall require two forms of identification to
be shown him by each person pledging or pawning any goods, articles or other
things to the pawnbroker. One of the two forms of identification must include
his residence address. These forms of identification shall include, but not
be limited to, any of the following: driver's license, social security card,
utility bill, employee or student identification card, credit card, or a
civic, union or professional association membership card.



   (c)   No pawnbroker shall receive as a pledge or purchase any
revolver, pistol, blackjack or sawed-off shotgun, and no pawnbroker shall
display in his window or shop any such weapons for sale.



   (d)   No pawnbroker shall have any business dealings as a pawnbroker
with any minor.



   (e)   It shall be the duty of every pawnbroker to report to the
police any article pledged with him, or which is sought to be pledged with
him, if he shall have reason to believe that the article was stolen or lost,
and found by the person attempting to pledge it in the case of a lost article.



   (f)   No pawnbroker's license shall be issued to any person who is a
minor, nor shall a licensed pawnbroker employ a minor to assist him in his
business.



(Code 1965, § 41.24(d))



Sec. 82-100. Same--Fee.



   The annual fee for a pawnbroker license shall be on a square footage
basis, as described in section 26-37.



(Code 1965, § 41.24(e))



Sec. 82-101. Inspections to ensure article compliance.



   The village may make such inspections as may be necessary to ensure
compliance with the provisions of this article and all other ordinances
relating thereto.



(Code 1965, § 41.24(f))



ARTICLE IV. RESIDENTIAL SALES



Sec. 82-102. Purpose of article.



   This article is intended to regulate all sales of merchandise to the
general public from residences within the village, including, without
limitation, all so-called garage sales, rummage sales, auction sales, estate
sales and moving sales, hereafter collectively called "residential sales,"
but excluding any proposed sale of a single item of real or personal property.



(Code 1965, § 15.01)



Sec. 82-103. Limitation on sales.



   No person shall conduct more than two residential sales for a total of
two days within the village during any one calendar year. Also, no more than
two residential sales for a total of two days shall be permitted from any one
residence during any one calendar year.



(Code 1965, § 15.02)



Sec. 82-104. Permit required.



   No person, including owners, tenants, residents, auctioneers or sales
persons shall conduct a residential sale unless the village has first issued
a permit for such sale. A sale permit will be issued upon payment of a $2.00
administrative fee. This permit shall be clearly displayed and visible at all
times during the residential sale for which it is issued.



(Code 1965, § 15.03)



Sec. 82-105. Use of public property.



   Public property, including sidewalks, parkways and streets, shall not
be used for display of merchandise at any residential sale.



(Code 1965, § 15.04)



Sec. 82-106. Signs.




No more than two (2) garage sale signs may be posted within the public right-
of-way and no more than one (1) may be posted in front of the resident’s
home where the garage sale is being conducted.





   Each sign shall not exceed four (4) square feet in surface area and not
exceed three (3) feet in overall height from the ground to the top of the
garage sale sign.





   Signs must be posted no earlier than the first sale date and removed
within four (4) hours after the final sale date. Each sign must have the
exact date, address, and permit number posted on the signs. Signs posted in
the public right-of-way must be on an arterial street leading into your
subdivision or street where the sale is to be conducted.





   Signs must be freestanding and not attached to any utility pole, street
sign, structure or traffic control sign. No attention attracting devices such
as pennants, streamers, balloons, inflatable shapes, banners, flashing lights
or other illumination shall be attached to the garage sale signs or placed in
the public right-of-way.





   Garage sale signs are prohibited from being placed at or on signalized
stop light intersections within the Village of Homewood, including all state,
county and township intersections with signals





(Code 1965, § 15.05)




Sec. 82-107.  Hours.




   Residential sales shall be conducted only between the hours of 9:00
a.m. through 7:00 p.m.




(Code 1965, § 15.06)



Sec. 82-108.  Disturbance of peace or nuisance.



   The issuance of a permit by the village for a residential sale shall
not constitute a defense to any charge of disturbing the peace, nuisance or
other unlawful behavior resulting from the conduct of any residential sale.



(Code 1965, § 15.07)



Chapter 86  SIGNS*



   *Cross reference(s)--Department of public works, § 2-336 et seq.;
buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; businesses, ch. 26; house
numbering, § 94-166 et seq.



   Sec. 86-1.   Definitions.



   Sec. 86-2.   Administration of chapter.



   Sec. 86-3.   Violations; enforcement.



   Sec. 86-4.   Permitted and nonpermitted signs.



   Sec. 86-5.   Signs on residential properties.



   Sec. 86-6.   Signs of certain charitable, educational and similar
organizations.



   Sec. 86-7.   Business signs.



   Sec. 86-8.   Temporary signs.



   Sec. 86-9.   Temporary subdivision advertising signs.



   Sec. 86-10.   Pennants, or banners or inflatable signs.



   Sec. 86-11.   Construction requirements.



   Sec. 86-12.   Inspections.



   Sec. 86-13.   Nuisances.



   Sec. 86-14.   Maintenance.



   Sec. 86-15.   Removal of certain signs.



   Sec. 86-16.   Unsafe and unlawful signs.



   Sec. 86-17.   Exemptions and zoning restrictions.



   Sec. 86-18.   Building and electrical codes.



   Sec. 86-19.   Permits and fees.



   Sec. 86-20.   Variations.



   Sec. 86-21.   Legal nonconforming signs.



   Sec. 86-22.   Grievance procedure.



 



   Table 86.1.   Pole signs.



Sec. 86-1.  Definitions.



   The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Canopy and awning, fixed means any hood, canopy or awning made of
cloth, other flexible material or metal with metal frames attached to a
building, and carried by a frame, either supported or not supported from the
ground or sidewalk.



   Canopy and awning, retractable means any hood, canopy or awning made of
cloth, other flexible material or metal with metal frames attached to a
building, and so erected as to permit its being retracted when not in use.



   Center, integrated means a building, series of attached buildings or
separate buildings under single ownership or management or having contractual
agreements between the separate buildings' owners.



   Marquee means any fixed hood, constructed of metal or other
noncombustible material, supported solely by and extending from the building
to which it is attached.



   Sign means a name, identification, description, display, or
illustration which is affixed to, or painted on, or represented directly or
indirectly, upon a building, structure, billboard or parcel of land; and
which directs attention to an object, product, place, activity, person,
institution, organization, or business.  Each display surface of a sign
shall be considered to be a separate sign.  The word "sign" does not include
the following:



      (1)   Any sign of the United States, state or municipal
corporation;



      (2)   The flag, emblem of insignia of a nation, governmental
unit, school or religious group;



   (3)   Signs located completely within an enclosed building with no
display surface visible from the building exterior; provided, however, that
the provisions of this chapter regulating flashing and moving signs shall
apply to all signs in any way visible from the building exterior;



   (4)   Paper signs affixed to the interior of the window of a
building for a period of less than 30 days that do not cover more than 25% of
the total window area of the facade where they are exhibited;



      (5)   Identification and addresses of establishments on
awnings, marquees, or buildings;



      (6)   Street or house number signs not exceeding 1½ square
feet in area;



      (7)   Directional signs or instructional signs conveying
directions or instructions for the safety or convenience of the public
(vehicular or pedestrian) or necessary for the operation of the premises and
not exceeding three square feet in area;



   Sign, advertising means a sign which directs attention to a business,
commodity, service or entertainment conducted, sold or offered upon premises
other than where such sign is located or to which it is affixed.



   Sign, blade means a sign attached to a wall in a perpendicular manner.



   Sign, business means a sign which directs attention to a business or
profession conducted, or to a commodity, service or entertainment conducted,
sold or offered upon the premises where such sign is located or to which it
is affixed.



   Sign, changeable copy/reader board means a sign, or portion thereof,
with characters, letters or illustrations that can be changed or rearranged
without altering the face or the surface of the sign.  A sign on which the
only copy that changes is an electronic or mechanical indication of time or
temperature shall be considered a "time and temperature" portion of a sign
and not a changeable copy sign for purposes of this ordinance.  All messages
for changeable copy/reader board signs shall be limited to the business to
which the sign is attached and/or public service announcements. 



   Sign, flashing means any illuminated sign on which the artificial light
is not maintained stationary or constant in intensity and color at all times
when such sign is in use.  For the purpose of this chapter, any moving
illuminated sign, excluding scrolling light messages on a changeable
copy/reader board sign, shall be considered a flashing sign.



   Sign, gross surface area of means the entire area covered by the sign
consisting of the area comprised within a single continuous perimeter
enclosing the extreme limits of its display area, and in no case passing
through or between any adjacent elements of it; but such perimeter shall not
include any structural elements lying outside the display area of the sign.



   Sign, ground or monument means a sign supported by uprights, columns or
braces placed in the ground and not attached to any building.  Ground or
monument signs shall not exceed eight (8) feet above grade in height. 



   Sign, historical plaque means a commemorative plaque placed by a
recognized federal, state or local historical agency depicting and
identifying a building's contribution to the field of architecture, or a
building or site's contribution to the life of an individual, or as being
representative of an historical event or an era of development in the
village.  Such plaque shall not exceed four (4) square feet in area and
shall be affixed flat against a building, or if a vacant site, shall be
permanently mounted on a pole or other suitable support.



   Sign, pole means a sign, mounted or otherwise attached, to a steel
column or other suitable material placed in the ground, the bottom of which
is no less than eight (8) feet above grade. Pole signs shall conform to the
restrictions in table 86-1. 



   Sign, temporary means a sign, banner, bunting, pennant, valance or
advertising display to be displayed for a limited period.



   Sign, wall means a sign attached, applied to, painted or placed against
the exterior front, rear or side wall of any building, with an exception in
section 86-4(b).



   Sign, window means signs, regardless of material, placed inside or upon
a window with a display surface visible from the building exterior.



(MC-909, § 1, 6-24-14; MC-913, § 3, 9-23- 14; MC-954, § 1, 4-12-16)



Sec. 86-2. Administration of chapter.



   It shall be the responsibility of the village manager or his designee
to administer this chapter.



Sec. 86-3. Violations; enforcement.



   It shall be unlawful to display any sign in violation of the provisions
of this chapter.  Each day of any such violation shall constitute a separate
offense under this chapter.  Any person who owns or manages a building or
premises and any occupant thereof who displays a sign shall comply with the
provisions of this chapter.  The village manager or his designee is hereby
designated and authorized to enforce this chapter.



Sec. 86-4.  Permitted and nonpermitted signs.



   (a)   The following types of signs only are permitted signs within
the standards set out in this chapter:



      (1)   Ground or monument signs;



      (2)   Wall signs;



      (3)   Pole signs; 



      (4)   Temporary signs;



      (5)   Marquees;



      (6)   Fixed canopies and awnings;



      (7)   Retractable canopies and awnings;



      (8)   Window signs not exceeding 25% of the total window area
of the facade where they are exhibited;



      (9)   Historical plaques;



      (10)   Advertising signs on bus shelters;



      (11)   Changeable copy/reader board signs; and



      (12)   Blade signs.



   (b)   Nonpermitted signs shall include:



      (1)   Signs on fences or on walls which are not a part of a
building or structure;



      (2)   Flashing signs, which are illuminated signs (whether
stationary, revolving, or rotating) which contain any flashing lights or
lights creating an illusion of movement, except those signs which display
time and temperature information only.



      (3)   Moving signs, which are signs which flutter, undulate,
swing, rotate, oscillate, or otherwise move by natural or artificial means. 
Pennants,  banners and inflatable signs are specifically included within the
definition of moving signs with an exception cited in section 86-10;



      (4)   Advertising signs except for temporary subdivision
advertising signs as provided in section 86-9 and bus shelter advertising
signs authorized by section 86-4 (a)(10);



      (5)   Signs painted on building walls which face or are
visible from a public right-of-way;



      (6)   Signs which project more than 24 inches into a public
right-of-way;



      (7)   Pole signs in the B-1 Central Business zoning district;



      (8)   Changeable copy/reader board signs in the B-1 Central
Business zoning district; and



      (9)   Any sign not included as a permitted sign.



      (10)   Illuminated tubing, rope lights and string lights,
including neon, LED, and incandescent, used to outline, stripe, highlight, or
decorate portions of commercial buildings or building elements such as doors,
windows or awnings, except:



         a.   Lights temporarily displayed in connection with a
civic, patriotic, or religious holiday, provided they are removed within 14
days after the holiday; and



         b.   Lights permanently affixed to a commercial building
as an element of an overall architectural concept.



(MC-909, § 1, 6-24-14; MC-913, § 3, 9-23- 14; MC-954, § 1, 4-12-16)



Sec. 86-5.  Signs on residential properties.



   No sign shall be displayed on buildings or premises, or that portion
thereof used for residential purposes, regardless of the zoning district in
which it is located, or on any vehicles parked on such property for more than
24 hours where such vehicle is readily visible to the general public, except
for the following permitted signs:



      (1)   One nameplate sign not exceeding 144 square inches in
area, which may be combined with a street or house sign.



      (2)   Noncommercial and nonilluminated signs behind or affixed
to windows or doors.



      (3)   In the case of apartment houses for more than two (2)
units, there shall be permitted, in addition to the foregoing and in addition
to any other signs permitted by reason of any commercial use of the first
floor, one identification wall sign not exceeding five square feet in area
indicating the name of the building and/or the ownership or management of
such building.



      (4)   Multi-family complexes which have more than eight (8)
units shall be permitted one identification ground sign no larger than 50 sq.
ft. and six (6) feet in height.



      (5)   Temporary signs permitted under section 86-8.



Sec. 86-6.  Signs of certain charitable, educational and similar
organizations.



   No sign shall be displayed on the building or premises of a private
educational, philanthropic, civic or charitable institution or organization
or any private club, except for temporary signs permitted under section 86-8
and except for the following permitted signs:



   (a)   Identification signs, identifying the name and/or nature of
the institution or organization.



   (b)   Bulletin board signs, being structures of a permanent nature
but having changeable words or figures.



   The total area of all signs on the premises of each such institution or
organization shall not exceed 50 square feet in area, and no one sign shall
exceed 30 square feet in area.



Sec. 86-7 Business signs.



   Business signs of any type not prohibited by section 86-4 may be
displayed on any property used for business or manufacturing purposes,
subject to the following limitations and regulations:



      (1)   Where a sign is illuminated by light reflected upon it,
direct rays of light shall not beam upon any part of an existing residential
building, nor into a residential district, or into a street.  A sign located
in direct line of vision of a traffic signal shall not have red, green or
amber illumination. In the B-1 Central Business zoning district, ground or
monument signs shall only be externally illuminated by lighting hardware
mounted on the sign that reflects light directly on the sign from above.



      (2)   The total permitted gross surface area of all signs for
a single building shall not exceed 2.5 times in square feet the total
building frontage expressed in linear feet, up to a maximum of 500 square
feet for a building with one frontage, 800 square feet for a building with
two frontages, and 1000 square feet for a building with three or more
frontages.  If a single building is designed for occupancy by more than one
business use and is so used, the formula to be applied in ascertaining the
permitted gross surface area for each individual establishment shall be based
on the formula set out in this subsection.  The owner of the building shall
then be responsible for negotiating with all tenants in the building, the
amount of signage allowable for each business. Exception: In the B-1 Central
Business zoning district the total permitted gross surface area of all signs
for a single building shall not exceed two times in square feet the linear
footage of a building up to a maximum of 400 square feet of signage for any 
one use.



      (3)   No wall or blade sign shall project more than 24 inches
into a public right-of-way, and any such sign shall be limited in height to
the height of the building or 30 feet above grade at the base of the
building, whichever is lower.  The sign shall be no lower than 9 ft. above
grade. Exception: In the B-1 Central Business zoning district, the height of
a blade sign shall be limited to two feet below the roof line of the building.



      (4)   Any permanently installed sign entirely separate from
any structure, located entirely upon private property and not projecting into
a public right-of-way and otherwise in conformance with all requirements of
this chapter shall not be higher than 28 feet above grade. 



      (5)   Signs which are not embodied as part of the soft or
pliable material of an awning or canopy and which project from a building in
excess of six inches or over a public right-of-way shall have the lowest
portion no less than nine feet above grade, immediately below the sign.



      (6)   A unified shopping center or integrated center in single
ownership or control may erect only one pole sign to serve the shops therein
in addition to the individual signs allowed by this chapter.  Such sign
shall conform to the standards in table 86-1.



      (7)   Blade signs shall not exceed six square feet in area,
shall be no more than either three feet in length or three feet in width and
shall project no more than three feet from the face of the building.



      (8)   Ground or monument signs shall not exceed eight feet in
height. Exception: In the B-1 Central Business zoning district, ground or
monument signs shall not exceed five feet in height and 20 square feet in
area.



(MC-913, § 3, 9-23-14)



Sec. 86-8. Temporary signs.



   In addition to signs otherwise permitted by this chapter, the following
temporary signs shall be permitted, so long as such temporary signs are
otherwise in conformity with this chapter:



      (1)   Real estate signs (non-illuminated), advertising the
sale or lease of the premises on which they are maintained, not exceeding
10  square feet in area for residential properties and 32 square feet in
area for commercial properties.  Only one sign per lot or premises is
permitted, except that on corner lots one such sign may face each street. 
Such signs shall be removed immediately upon sale or lease of the premises. 
Said signs must be located on private property.



      (2)   Architect-contractor signs.  One sign of an architect
and/or contractor not exceeding 10 square feet in area may be displayed on a
premises located in any residence district established by the village zoning
ordinance, as amended, and one such sign not exceeding 20 square feet on a
premises located in any business or manufacturing district established by the
village zoning ordinance where new construction or remodeling work is in
progress, to be removed immediately upon completion of such work.  In an
area zoned for commercial or industrial use where the property on which
construction or remodeling is in progress, one contractor-architect's sign
may be erected on each street frontage said property abuts.  Such signs may
not be located closer than eight feet from the property line or one-half the
distance between the property and the building lines, whichever is less.



      (3)   Decorations displayed in connection with civic,
patriotic or religious holidays.



      (4)   Flags, emblems and signs of political, civic,
philanthropic or education organizations temporarily displayed for
noncommercial purposes.  Said signs must be located on private property
unless placed by federal, state or municipal government and shall not be
located on property zoned as public land or within 100 feet of a polling
place.



      (5)   Political campaign signs not exceeding 32 square feet in
area for each premise. These signs shall be confined within private property
with the permission of the property owner.



(MC-848, § 1, 5-24-11)



Sec. 86-9. Temporary subdivision advertising signs.



   The village manager or his designee, when requested in writing, may
mitigate the provisions of this chapter regarding advertising signs on a
temporary basis only in accordance with  the following provisions for the
purpose of encouraging rapid and competitive sale of new subdivision
development within the village.



      (1)   Temporary means an indefinite length of time which shall
terminate upon sale of 90 percent of all available parcels included in the
platted subdivision.



      (2)   Onsite allowance.  One sign shall be allowed for
advertising the subdivision.  The surface area cannot exceed 32 square feet
in area and 8 feet in height above grade.



      (3)   Authorization. All temporary subdivision sign location
requests shall be reviewed by the village manager and authorized by letter.



      (4)   Removal.  All permitted subdivision signs shall be
removed when required by this section.



Sec. 86-10.  Pennants, or banners or inflatable signs.



   (a)   The village manager or his designee, when requested in
writing, may mitigate the provisions of this chapter prohibiting pennants,
banners and inflatable signs, but on a temporary basis only in accordance
with the following provisions:



      (1)   Definition. Temporary means no more than two one-week
periods.



      (2)   Authorization. Authorization for pennants, banners and
inflatable signs shall be in writing signed by the village manager or his
designee, and shall state the number of days such use is to be permitted. No
such authorization shall be given more than once per quarter in a calendar
year for a specific location.



      (3)   Conditions. Authorization for inflatable signs shall be
subject to, the following conditions:



         a.   The signs must be anchored to the ground;



         b.   The signs must be placed so as not to diminish the
number of customer parking spaces in a parking lot;



         c.   The signs must not obstruct vehicle or pedestrian
ways.



      (4)   Fees. The fee for any pennant, banner or inflatable sign
erected without prior approval shall be $50.00.



      (5)   Removal. All authorized pennants, banners and inflatable
signs shall be removed at the expiration of such authorization. Pennants,
banners and inflatable signs erected without prior approval shall be
immediately removed upon notification by the village.



(MC-954, § 1, 4-12-16)



Sec. 86-11.  Construction requirements.



   (a)   Date of erection, name of permittee and voltage to be on
sign.  Every sign hereafter erected shall have painted in a conspicuous
place thereon, in legible letters, the date of erection, the name of the
permittee, and the voltage of any electrical apparatus used in connection
therewith.



   (b)   Wind pressure and dead load requirements.  Any sign shall be
designed and constructed to withstand a wind pressure of not less than 30
pounds per square foot of net surface area; and shall be constructed to
receive dead loads as required in the building code and other ordinances of
the village.



   (c)   Fireproof construction.  No sign of which the majority of the
display area is within four feet of any building or which is greater than 18
square feet in area shall be constructed at any location within the village
limits unless the face is constructed of noncombustible material.



   (d)   Obstruction to doors, windows or fire escapes.  No sign,
retractable canopy or awning shall be erected, relocated or maintained so as
to prevent free ingress to, or egress from, any door, window or fire
escape.  No sign, retractable canopy or awning of any kind shall be attached
to a standpipe or fire escape.



   (e)   Signs not to constitute traffic hazards.  In order to obtain
and secure reasonable traffic safety, it shall be unlawful for any person to
erect or maintain any sign, retractable canopy or awning in such a manner as
to obstruct free and clear vision, or as to distract the attention of the
driver of any vehicle by reason of the position, shape, color or intensity
thereof.  Pursuant to the foregoing, no sign, retractable canopy or awning
shall be erected or maintained in such manner as to be likely to interfere
with, obstruct the view of, or be confused with any authorized traffic sign,
signal or device.  Accordingly, no sign, retractable canopy or awning shall
make use of the words "stop," "go," "look," "slow," " danger," or any other
similar word, phrase, symbol, or character, or employ any red, yellow,
orange, green or other colored lamp or light, in such a manner as to
interfere with, mislead, or confuse traffic.



Sec. 86-12.  Inspections.



   The village shall make inspections of signs as it deems necessary, and
for this purpose has the right during business hours to enter upon the
premises where a sign is maintained.  If it is found that a sign is out of
repair, unsafe, or nonconforming to this chapter, the owner shall be notified
in writing of the condition, and if the owner does not remedy the sign within
30 days from the time of the service of the notice, the building inspector
shall act in accordance with section 86-16.



Sec. 86-13.  Nuisances.



   Any sign displayed in violation of this chapter is hereby deemed a
public nuisance.  Any sign, retractable canopy or awning which is
immediately dangerous to persons or property in its existing condition, or
which is declared to be a fire hazard by the village fire chief or his
nominee is hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be abated as such.



Sec. 86-14.  Maintenance.



   All signs, retractable canopies and awnings shall be kept and
maintained in a safe, neat and orderly condition and appearance, and shall be
repainted or otherwise maintained periodically by the permittee to prevent
corrosion or deterioration caused by weather or age, and to keep the same in
safe, neat and orderly condition and appearance.



Sec. 86-15.  Removal of certain signs.



   Any sign, retractable canopy or awning and nonconforming sign structure
now or hereafter existing, which advertises a business no longer being
conducted, or a product no longer being sold, shall be taken down and removed
by the owner, agent or person having the beneficial use of the building,
structure or premises upon which such sign may be found, within 30 days after
receipt of written notice by the village to so act.  Upon failure to comply
with such notice within the time specified in such order, the building
inspector is hereby authorized to cause removal of such sign.  Any expense
incident thereto shall be paid by the owner, agent or person having
beneficial use of the building, structure or premises to which such sign is
attached.



Sec. 86-16.  Unsafe and unlawful signs.



   If the building inspector shall find that any sign, retractable canopy
or awning is unsafe or insecure or is a menace to the public, has been
constructed, erected, or is being maintained in violation of the provisions
of this chapter, he shall give written notice of such finding to the
permittee of the same.  If the permittee fails to remove or alter the sign,
retractable canopy or awning so as to bring it into compliance with the
standards established by this chapter within 30 days after receipt of such
notice, such sign, retractable canopy or awning may be removed by the village
at the expense of the permittee.  If, upon reasonable and diligent search,
the permittee cannot be found so that the notice described in this section
cannot be given, then the village may remove the sign, retractable canopy or
awning or, in the alternative, may send written notice of the building
inspector's finding to the owner of the building, structure or premises.  If
the owner then fails to remove or alter the sign, retractable canopy or
awning so as to bring it into compliance with the standards established by
this chapter within 30 days after receipt of such notice, such sign,
retractable canopy or awning may be removed by the village at the expense of
the owner.  The village may cause any sign, retractable canopy or awning
which the building inspector finds to be an immediate peril to persons or
property to be removed summarily and without notice.



Sec. 86-17.  Exemptions and zoning restrictions.



   The provisions of this chapter regulating the location, placement,
gross surface area, projection, height limitation and number of signs or
other advertising structures shall be subject to and may be further
restricted by any applicable provision of the present or hereafter adopted
zoning ordinance of the village including provisions therein relating to
nonconforming structures and uses.



Sec. 86-18.  Building and electrical codes.



   All signs erected or constructed shall conform to all technical and
structural requirements of the village building and electrical codes.



Sec. 86-19.  Permits and fees.



   (a)   A permit shall be obtained from the building inspector on
written application therefore, by any person seeking to construct, erect or
maintain any sign over three square feet in area, except for temporary
nonstructural signs.  Such application shall be accompanied by plans and
specifications which show the size, character, material, location, bracing,
anchorage, support, means of attachment and other structural characteristics
thereof, and of its frame and mounting.  Prior to the issuance of a permit,
the application plans and specifications shall be approved by the building
inspector.



   (b)   No permit shall be issued if the building inspector shall
determine that the sign will constitute a hazard to traffic or the public by
reason of obstruction of view, distraction, or endangering the safety of
persons using public property.  Any permit required elsewhere in this code
for electrical work in connection with any sign must be obtained in addition
to the sign permit provided for in this section.



   (c)   A $50.00 nonrefundable application fee shall be charged at the
time of filing a request for a sign permit.  Upon approval, the fee for a
permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall be $0.50 per square foot of the
gross surface area of each sign.  The fee for any reinspection of the sign
shall be $50.00.



   (d)   The building inspector shall examine or cause to be examined
all applications for permits and amendments thereto within a reasonable time
after filing.  If the building inspector is satisfied that the proposed work
conforms to the requirements of this chapter and all laws and ordinances
applicable thereto, the building inspector shall issue a permit therefor as
soon as practicable.



Sec. 86-20. Variations.



   Upon an application or permit to construct or alter or maintain any
sign which does not conform to the regulations of this chapter, upon a
finding by the village board that a particular hardship does exist, the
village board may grant a variation in the application of the regulations of
this chapter but in harmony with the general purposes and intent of this
chapter. 



Sec. 86-21.  Legal nonconforming signs.



   Signs which were erected on or before July 27, 2004 and no longer
conform shall be subject to the following provisions:



      (1)   The size, shape, context, wording and appearance of such
sign shall not be changed or altered unless necessary to comply with this
chapter, as amended.



      (2)   A nonconforming sign which is destroyed or damaged by
fire or other casualty to the extent that the cost of restoration will exceed
50 percent of the construction cost of a comparable new sign shall not be
restored unless the sign conforms to all current requirements of this
chapter.  If such damage or construction is less than 50 percent of the
construction cost of a comparable new sign, all repairs shall be completed
within 180 days from the date of the partial destruction.  If such damage or
destruction is less than 50 percent of the construction cost of a comparable
new sign and repair construction is not completed within 180 days from the
date of partial destruction, then the damaged nonconforming sign shall not be
restored unless the sign is made to conform to all current regulations of
this chapter.



      (3)   Such signs shall be properly maintained as required by
this chapter, but authorized maintenance shall not include the right to
change or alter the size, shape, context, wording or appearance of such sign.



Sec. 86-22.  Grievance procedure.



   Should a petitioner be aggrieved by a decision of the village manager
in his enforcement of this chapter, a subcommittee of the village board shall
hear the petitioner's request for relief.  The subcommittee shall be
composed of two village board trustees and the chairman of the appearance
commission.

Chapter 90  SOLID WASTE*



   *Cross reference(s)--Environment, ch. 38; fire prevention and
protection, ch. 42; floods, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 50;
manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 66; planning, ch. 78; secondhand goods,
ch. 82; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 94; traffic and
vehicles, ch. 106; sanitary sewers, § 110-66 et seq.



   State law reference(s)--Authority to provide for disposal, 65 ILCS
5/11-19-5.



Article I. In General



   Sec. 90-1.   Definitions.



   Sec. 90-2.   Accumulation of refuse.



   Secs. 90-3--90-30.  Reserved.

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL



Sec. 90-1. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Garbage means rejected food wastes and every waste accumulation of
animal, fruit or vegetable matter used or intended for food and such paper as
may necessarily be used for wrapping.



   Refuse means all solid waste of a community, including garbage, ashes,
rubbish, dead animals, paper, sweepings, and solid market and industrial
wastes.



   Rubbish means such matter as ashes, cans, metalware, glass, crockery,
paper, boxes, rags and old clothing, wood, grass clippings, dirt, sweepings,
leaves, weeds or litter of any kind.



(Code 1965, § 26.01)



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 90-2. Accumulation of refuse.



   (a)   Owner responsibility to effect removal; establish cleanliness.
The owner, occupant or lessee of any premises in the village shall cause to
be removed from such premises all refuse and shall keep such premises at all
times free and clean from any accumulation of refuse, in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter.



   (b)   Exception; composts. Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit an
owner, occupant or lessee of a premises from establishing and operating a
backyard compost according to the following restrictions:



      (1)   Such compost shall be located only in the rear yard of a
premises and shall not be located in a natural drainage swale or other
location which obstructs the natural flow of water. As used in this section,
the term "rear yard" shall mean the portion of the yard on the same lot with
the principal building, located between the rear line of the building and the
rear lot line. If a compost is located on an easement or right-of-way and the
village must remove the compost to perform work in the easement or
right-of-way, the village shall not be responsible for restoring the compost.
The compost and any related appurtenances may occupy no more than 0.75
percent of the total square footage of the rear yard or 32 square feet,
whichever is less.



      (2)   A backyard compost permitted under this section may
contain only:



         a.   Woody yard waste material which has been chipped to
properly compost;



         b.   Leaves, grass clippings, shrubbery cuttings, and
other materials accumulated as the result of the care of lawns, shrubbery,
vines and trees;



         c.   An acid reducing agent such as lime, wood ash, or
rock phosphate; and



         d.   Straw or sawdust.



      (3)   Food wastes, other than uncooked fruit and vegetable
material, and any other refuse which may attract nuisances such as rodents
are specifically prohibited from being placed in a backyard compost. The
backyard composts may contain yard waste generated only from the premise on
which the backyard compost is located.



      (4)   The owner, occupant or lessee of a premises which has a
backyard compost shall be responsible for operating the compost in such a
manner that:



         a.   It does not allow offensive odors to escape from
the premises on which it is located;



         b.   It does not attract rodents or other animals;



         c.   Open or exposed compost piles are no higher than
four feet;



         d.   Debris, matter, or material from the compost will
not escape upon another person’s property nor upon any public right-of-way;
and



         e.   It does not otherwise create a nuisance.



(Code 1965, § 26.02)



Secs. 90-3--90-30. Reserved.



ARTICLE II. COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL



Sec. 90-31. Disposing of refuse.



   (a)   No person shall dispose of or place any refuse in any street,
alley, or any other public right-of-way within the village; nor shall any
person dispose of or place any refuse on private property, whether owned by
such person or not, within the village, unless the refuse shall be enclosed
in a suitable container as described in section 90-32. However, any person
who immediately disposes of such refuse upon his own premises in an
incinerator constructed in accordance with the terms of this article, or
through home garbage grinders into sewers or in a backyard compost in
accordance with section 90-2(b) shall not be required to place refuse in any
such container.



   (b)   All refuse deposited for pickup at the curb area shall be so
deposited no sooner than 24 hours prior to the scheduled collection time, and
the refuse containers shall be removed from the curb area within eight hours
after collection.



(Code 1965, § 26.03)



Sec. 90-32. Refuse storage.



   (a)   Household. All household refuse shall be stored in containers
that will prevent the scattering of the refuse by animals, wind or other
cause, and the escape of odors. All containers shall be kept in a sanitary
condition so as not to attract nuisances such as insects or rodents. All
containers shall have adequate handles or bails to facilitate collection.
Refuse may be set out for collection in plastic or paper bags if done in such
a manner as to prevent scattering of the refuse by animals, wind or other
cause.



   (b)   Yard rubbish. Except for branches which shall be securely tied
in bundles no longer than four feet and weighing no more than 60 pounds each,
all yard rubbish shall be stored in durable, disposable plastic or paper bags
weighing no more than 60 pounds each, when full, or in containers specified
in subsection (a) of this section. This requirement shall not apply to yard
rubbish which is being composted in a backyard compost in accordance with
section 90-2(b).



   (c)   Institutional, commercial and industrial garbage; rubbish
intended for recycling. All institutional, commercial and industrial garbage
shall be stored in durable metal rust-resistant, nonabsorbent, liquid tight
and easily washable containers with closefitting covers and adequate handles
or bails to facilitate collection. Except for bulky rubbish, such as large
empty wooden and cardboard boxes and rubbish intended for collection as part
of a recycling program, institutional, commercial and industrial rubbish
shall be stored in durable metal containers with closefitting covers. Rubbish
intended for collection as part of a recycling program shall be stored in
containers that will prevent the scattering of the rubbish by animals, wind,
or other cause and the escape of odors. Cardboard boxes must be flattened and
placed beside the container.



   (d)   Container care. Containers as described in this section shall
be provided by and kept clean and in good repair by the owner, occupant or
lessee of any premises in the village. Such containers shall be kept covered
at all times except during the process of depositing refuse or emptying the
contents of the container.



   (e)   Location of stored refuse. All refuse shall be stored inside,
alongside or behind the principal or accessory building out of view from the
street in a neat and orderly manner. In multi- family, commercial,
institutional, industrial, areas where a refuse enclosure is provided,  the
refuse shall be stored inside the refuse enclosure.



(Code 1965, § 26.04; MC-879, § 1, 10-23-12)



Sec. 90-33. Refuse burning.



   (a)   Outdoor burning; prohibited generally. With the exception of
fires in outdoor receptacles designed and used for cooking food, the outdoor
burning of leaves, brush, trimmings from trees or bushes, vegetable matter,
wood, paper or other combustible debris, refuse, waste, rubbish, garbage, or
any other material on any property, public or private, from any sources
whatsoever within the corporate limits of the village is prohibited. Upon
notice to and permission granted by the village fire chief, the village,
under the direction of the fire chief, may:



      (1)   Burn fires in conjunction with holidays and festive
celebrations;



      (2)   Burn dead or diseased vegetation or similar debris when
no other method of disposal is feasible;



      (3)   Burn fires set and attended by personnel of the village
fire department in the course of duty or training.



   (b)   Exception; burning permits for ceremonial fires. However, the
village fire chief may issue burning permits for ceremonial fires to the
President of the Black Bear Lodge Association, Izaak Walton Memorial Park,
Homewood, Illinois upon written request, provided:



      (1)   There shall be no more than eight ceremonial fires
during the period April 1 through October 31 in any calendar year, with no
more than two such fires in any month;



      (2)   All ceremonial fires shall be maintained under adult
supervision in an area that can safely contain the fire without danger to
surrounding areas or structures;



      (3)   Only dry wood allowing a minimum of smoke and
particulate matter shall be used.



(Code 1965, § 26.05)



   (c)   Exception; use of outdoor fireplaces: The use of outdoor
fireplaces shall be permitted, provided:



      (1)   Outdoor fireplaces shall be self-contained,
manufactured, non-combustible units, supported off the ground by
non-combustible legs, and shall be provided with a tight-fitting protective
screen and/or lid which are to be used whenever the fireplace is in
operation.  Also permitted are approved, fixed, permanent masonry fire pit
structures.  Not permitted are barrels, half-barrels, drums or similarly
constructed devises;



      (2)   Fuel used shall be only dry wood, producing a minimum of
smoke and particular matter;



      (3)   Outdoor fireplace use shall be operated at all times
under adult supervision;



      (4)   Outdoor fireplace use shall be conducted in an area that
does not present a danger to surrounding areas, structures or vehicles. 
Outdoor fireplaces shall not be used within twenty (20) feet of any building,
structure, building overhang or vehicle;



      (5)   Outdoor fireplace use shall be contingent upon
compliance with Village of Homewood Municipal Code, Chapter 50 Health and
Sanitation, particularly that section relating to nuisances. If, upon
inspection, it is determined by a fire or police official that a nuisance is
being created, the operator may be directed to extinguish the fire. 



Sec. 90-34. Frequency of collection.



   (a)   Household refuse. All household refuse shall be set out for
collection according to the following schedule:



      (1)   Garbage shall be set out for collection at least once
each week.



      (2)   Rubbish shall be set out for collection at least once
each week.



   (b)   Institutional, commercial and industrial refuse. All
institutional, commercial and industrial refuse shall be collected according
to the following schedule:



      (1)   Garbage shall be collected daily except Sunday.



      (2)   Rubbish shall be collected at least once each week.



(Code 1965, § 26.06)



Sec. 90-35. Lien for cost of removal of garbage and debris.



   For the purpose of this Section, “debris” shall have the same
meaning as “rubbish” as found in Section 90-1 of this Code. When the
owner of private property located within the Village, after reasonable
notice, refuses or neglects to remove garbage, debris and graffiti, the
Village may remove such garbage, debris and graffiti from that private
property and may collect from the property owner the reasonable cost of such
removal, except in the case of graffiti. This cost shall be a lien upon the
real estate affected superior to all subsequent liens and encumbrances,
except tax liens, if within 60 days after such cost and expense is incurred
the village files notice of lien in the Office of the Recorder of Deeds of
Cook County, Illinois.  Every lien recorded pursuant to this section shall
include an additional $50.00 charge to recover the costs expended by the
village in preparing said lien, plus the actual recording cost as determined
by the Cook County Recorder of Deeds.



(MC-703, 8-12-03; MC-818, § 1, 6-23-09)



Sec. 90-36--90-50.  Reserved



ARTICLE III. SCAVENGERS



Sec. 90-51.  Contract service.



   In its discretion, the board of trustees may ask for and accept bids
from a private contractor for the collection of refuse in the village. If
such contract is entered into, the contract shall be subject to the
regulations of the board of trustees as to the manner and method of
collection and disposal of garbage and rubbish, and no other private person
shall be permitted to furnish such service in the village.



(Code 1965, § 41.28(a))



Sec. 90-52.  Limited scavenger license.



   Limited scavenger license is hereby created to allow the holder to
deliver and remove roll-off dumpsters and their contents from private
property. Such licenses shall be in addition to the scavenger licenses
authorized by section 90-57 and shall not authorize the holder to provide
regular curbside garbage, rubbish or refuse collection and disposal services
to residential or commercial customers. Holders of scavenger licenses
authorized by section 90-57 shall be allowed to deliver and remove roll-off
dumpsters and their contents from private property without purchase of an
additional license. Limited scavenger licenses shall be limited to five.



(MC-823, § 1, 1-12-10)



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 90-53.  Equipment.



   (a)   Vehicles used for the collection or disposal of garbage, or of
refuse containing garbage shall have liquid tight, enclosed metal bodies of
easily cleanable construction, shall be cleaned at sufficient frequency to
prevent nuisance of insect breeding, and shall be maintained in good repair.



   (b)   All public or private vehicles used for the collection or
disposal of rubbish may have open bodies, provided that suitable provisions
are made to prevent the scattering of rubbish.



(Code 1965, § 41.28(c))



   (c)   All privately-owned vehicles used for collection of rubbish or
recycled materials within the village must have on file with the village a
copy of the vehicle's currently valid certificate of safety as required by
Chapter 13 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/13-100 et al.) as
amended. (MC-782)



Sec. 90-54.  License--Required.



   No person shall engage in the business of collecting or disposing of
refuse unless licensed by the village as a scavenger. No person, unless
licensed by the village as a scavenger, shall collect or remove any item
placed in a curbside collection recycling container as a part of the
village's curbside recycling program or any item placed in a container
clearly marked with the word "recycle" or a form thereof and the warning
"unauthorized removal of items prohibited."



(Code 1965, § 41.28(d))



   Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 90-55.  Same--Application.



   (a)   Applications for scavenger and limited scavenger licenses
shall be made upon such forms as prescribed by the village. The application
shall provide the following information:



      (1)   Name, address and social security number of all owners
of the business;



      (2)   Name, address and social security number of all partners
if the business is a partnership;



      (3)   Name, address and social security number of all officers
and directors if the business is a corporation, and the name, address and
social security number of any person or entity owning five percent or more of
the stock of the corporation;



      (4)   Copy of the most recent business balance sheet;



      (5)   List of all equipment and other assets to be used in the
operation of the business, specifying if the business is the owner, lessee or
contract purchaser of such equipment;



      (6)   The name, address and phone numbers of at least two
financial references, two character references and two references as to the
quality of service performed in other municipalities;



      (7)   Location of dumping sites;



      (8)   Location of main office and all other business offices
of the applicant;



      (9)   A statement as to whether any owner, partner, corporate
officer or director has ever been convicted of the commission of a felony
under the laws of the state or any other state or federal law of the United
States. If so, the case name, and number, court, nature of the charge and
sentence awarded.



   (b)   In addition, the applicant shall furnish such additional
information as the village manager may deem necessary to process the
application or the village board may require after reviewing the application.
The village manager shall forward the application to the village board, and
that board shall approve or deny such license application on the basis of the
information furnished in the original application, any additional information
furnished to the village board at its request, and on the basis of the
applicant's proven history of successful collection and disposal of refuse in
the village or elsewhere.



   (c)   Once a license is obtained, annual application for renewal of
that license may be granted by the village board on the basis of an affidavit
by an owner, partner, or chief corporate officer that the facts as shown in
the original license application are unchanged, if such is the case, or by
such an affidavit detailing whatever changes have occurred since the original
application, in connection with the business. The village board may at any
time ask for additional facts, hold a hearing in connection with any license
application, or hold a hearing in connection with any license application or
affidavit submitted to it under this article. Any false material statement in
such application or affidavit shall be grounds for immediate revocation of
such license by the village board.



(Code 1965, § 41.28(e))



Sec. 90-56.  Same--Transfer.



   A scavenger business license once issued shall not be transferable. If
a licensed scavenger business is sold, the existing license is automatically
terminated, and the new owner must apply for a new license. This section
shall apply also in the case of any sale or transfer of a majority interest
of a corporation holding a scavenger license.



(Code 1965, § 41.28(f))



Sec. 90-57.  Same--Licensee regulations.



   Licensee regulations are as follows:



      (1)   In order to ensure the proper control and maintenance of
public health standards, the village hereby limits the number of business
licenses for the collection and disposal of refuse to three.



      (2)   No license shall be issued under the provisions of this
article unless the applicant for such license has first submitted proof of
insurance in the form of a certificate or memorandum of insurance issued by
an insurer duly authorized to issue such policies in the state. Such
insurance shall be written by a company acceptable to the village board. Such
certificate or memorandum shall show that the applicant for a license has
public liability insurance covering his operation within the village, shall
show the date of expiration of such insurance, and shall certify that the
insurance shall not be canceled without at least ten days' notice to the
village manager. Upon cancellation or expiration without renewal of such
insurance, the license issued under this article to the insured shall be
void. Such insurance shall be in the amount of not less than $500,000.00 for
personal injuries, including accidental death to any one person, and in an
amount not less than $1,000,000.00 for each such occurrence and, as to
property damage, no less than $250,000.00 for each occurrence. Such
certificates shall expressly provide that they apply to all equipment used by
the licensee in his business operation within the village, including owned
equipment, leased equipment and equipment being purchased under contract.



      (3)   No license shall be issued under the provisions of this
article unless the applicant for such a license shall agree, in writing, to
hold the village harmless from any and all claims, suits, damages, or loss of
use resulting from the applicant's business operations in the village. Also,
the licensee's insurance coverage shall include an endorsement covering the
hold harmless agreement in favor of the village.



      (4)   No license shall be issued under the provisions of this
article unless the applicant for such license has submitted proof that all
vehicles to be used within the village have been issued a valid certificate
of safety as required by Chapter 13 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS
5/13-100 et al.) as amended. The applicant shall provide copies of each
vehicle's certificate of safety at the time the application is made, and
shall have a continuing duty to provide such certificates if the vehicles to
be used within the village change after the license is issued. (MC-782)



      (5)   Each license shall require that the licensee offer
curbside recycling service in single-family residential areas where the
licensee operates. The licensee shall be responsible for furnishing
collection containers to each household and replacing those containers as
necessary, collecting the recyclable items, sorting the items for sale to
recycling centers, transporting and selling the items to recycling centers,
and returning to the village the proceeds from the sale of the recyclables in
accordance with a formula established by the board of trustees.



      (6)   Each licensee shall offer and make available a curbside
pickup service for landscape waste to all of its customers. For the purposes
of this section, landscape waste shall mean all accumulations of grass or
shrubbery cuttings, leaves, tree limbs and other materials accumulated as a
result of the care of lawns, shrubbery, vines and trees.



      (7)   In addition to and separate from the curbside recycling
service required in subsection (5) of this section, each licensee shall offer
and make available to all of its other customers a recycling service for
commodities which have economically viable markets as may be determined by
the state department of energy and natural resources. At least annually, each
licensee shall notify its customers not participating in the recycling
program of the availability of such service. The requirements of this
subsection shall become effective on September 1, 1991.



      (8)   Each licensee shall be required to report to the
village, no less than annually, the volumes of each material collected
through any recycling program either required by this section, or otherwise
offered by the licensee. Collected yard waste volumes shall also be included
in this report.



(Code 1965, § 41.28)



   State law reference(s)--Powers of state department, 415 ILCS 20/6.



Sec. 90-58.  Same--Fees.



   The annual fee for a scavenger license shall be $500.00. The annual fee
for a limited scavenger license shall be $300.00.



(Code 1965, § 41.28(h); MC-823, § 2, 1-12-10)

   *Cross reference(s)--Buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; fire

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL



Sec. 94-1. Names of streets.



   All streets of the village shall be known and designated by the names
applied thereto, respectively, on the map of the village kept on file in the
office of the village clerk. The street names designated on such map shall
continue to be the names of streets, unless and until changed by ordinance of
the board of trustees.



(Code 1965, § 8.01)



Sec. 94-2. Reports of defects.



   It shall be the duty of every village official or employee to report to
the director of public works every defect observed in any public street,
alley, sidewalk or other public place.



(Code 1965, § 8.02)



Sec. 94-3. Protection during repairs.



   Warning signs, lights and barricades shall be placed and maintained by
the person or party performing the work whenever any excavation, construction
or repair work is in progress in any public street, alley, sidewalk or other
public place in the village, whether such work is done by the village or
private individuals. Such signs, lights and barricades shall be maintained
until the surface has been restored so as to be fit for public use. No person
shall interfere with or remove any such signs, lights or barricades without
the permission of the director of public works.



(Code 1965, § 8.03)



Sec. 94-4. Deposits in streets and public places.



   (a)   No person shall deposit on any street, sidewalk, alley or
public place any material which may be harmful to the pavement or sidewalk or
any waste material, or anything which might in any way cause injury to any
person, animal or vehicle. This subsection shall not be construed to restrict
the rights of contractors to occupy portions of the street in compliance with
this chapter.



   (b)   No person shall shovel, push or in any manner deposit snow or
ice onto any street, sidewalk, alley or public place.



   (c)   No person shall knowingly employ, cause, permit or authorize
any third party to commit any of the acts prohibited by this section.



(Code 1965, § 8.05)



Sec. 94-5. Merchandise on sidewalks.



   It is lawful to deposit merchandise on any sidewalk for the purpose of
delivering the merchandise to a residence or place of business, from a place
of business or residence. No such merchandise shall be so deposited as to
reduce the usable width of the sidewalk to less than five feet, and no such
merchandise shall be permitted to remain on such sidewalk for longer than
one-half hour.



(Code 1965, § 8.06)



Sec. 94-6. Sales on streets or sidewalks.



   No person shall use any public street or sidewalk as a place of
business from or on which to make sales or conduct a private business. This
section shall not apply to cab drivers or expressmen, properly licensed, or
prohibit any merchant from placing his goods, wares or merchandise in front
of his store on that portion of the sidewalk lying between the building line
and a line parallel and three feet distant from the building line. If there
is no established building line, the building line for the purpose of this
section shall be that line of the building furthest extended toward the
street. In no case shall the usable width of the sidewalk be reduced to less
than five feet.



(Code 1965, § 8.07)



Sec. 94-7. Advertising on streets and sidewalks.



   No person shall print or paint any advertisements on the pavement of
any street or sidewalk, or post any bills or placards on any poles or other
structures located on any public street or sidewalk.



(Code 1965, § 8.08)



Sec. 94-8. Placing material on or against streetlights.



   No person shall place any material upon or against any public lamp,
electric bulb or globe or lamppost without the prior consent of the director
of public works.



(Code 1965, § 8.09)



Sec. 94-9. Missiles; foreign matter.



   No person shall cast, throw, or propel any missile or foreign matter on
any street, alley or public place, or throw or deposit any glass, nails,
tacks or other similar articles on any street, sidewalk or alley.



(Code 1965, § 8.10)



Sec. 94-10. Awnings and canopies.



   (a)   All awnings extending into any portion of a street shall be
covered with cloth or other light



and pliable substance, securely attached to the building and properly
supported without posts by iron or other metallic fastenings and supports,
shall be elevated at least seven feet at the lowest part above the top of the
sidewalk, and shall not project over the sidewalk to an extent three-fourths
of the width of the sidewalk, so as to leave the sidewalk wholly unobstructed
thereby. No such awning shall be constructed of or repaired with wood, either
wholly or in part.



   (b)   No person shall maintain any rigid canopy which extends over
any public street, alley or sidewalk.



(Code 1965, § 8.11)



Sec. 94-11. Cellar or vault doors.



   No person shall keep or leave open any cellar door, area, or vault
grating, or other cover, in any street, alley or sidewalk, or suffer the same
to be kept or left open, unless it is protected by an attendant or suitable
guard railing in such a manner as to avoid endangering life or limb.



(Code 1965, § 8.12)



Sec. 94-12. Encroachments.



   No person shall construct or maintain any building, fence or structure
which encroaches on any public street, alley, sidewalk, crosswalk or village
easement. Any such encroachment is declared to be a nuisance and may be
abated as provided in section 50-94.



(Code 1965, § 8.13)



Sec. 94-13. Laying of pipe in streets.



   (a)   Permit required. No pipe, conduit, wire or cable, nor any
pavement, sidewalk, or other like improvement shall be laid or maintained in,
under or upon any street, alley, sidewalk, easement or public place, except
improvements constructed under special assessment proceedings, unless a
permit authorizing the same has been issued by the director of public works.



   (b)   Location of gas pipes. Any gas pipes when placed in any public
street or alley shall be laid so that there will be no interference with
sewers or water pipes. Before any pipes are laid, permission must be secured
from the village manager and the gas pipes must be placed in a portion of the
street or alley as may be directed by the village manager.



   (c)   Map to be filed. Every person that lays any pipe, conduit,
wire or cable in any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public place,
shall make and file with the village manager an accurate map, showing the
exact location of every line of pipe laid by it, which map shall be
accessible for public inspection, and shall be kept constantly revised to
show any changes or additions.



(Code 1965, § 8.15)



Sec. 94-14. Occupation of streets for building purposes.



   (a)   Permit required. No person doing construction work or repairs
shall occupy the streets without a permit therefor, which permit shall be
issued by the director of public works upon the payment of a fee of $25.00.



   (b)   Time and space occupied. The limit of time of occupation shall
be subject to control of the director of public works. The building materials
shall never occupy more than one-third of the street pavement, nor more than
is authorized by the permit. During the construction, no person shall mix
mortar, concrete or other building material upon the surface of any sidewalk
or pavement. The sidewalks shall be at all times passable, or a temporary
alternate sidewalk shall be made.



   (c)   Restoration of streets and sidewalks. The property owner or
building contractor shall deposit a sum of $500.00 with the village clerk to
guarantee repair of such sidewalks, streets or alleys as may be damaged. The
building contractor and the property owner shall be liable jointly and
severally for all damage done to public property. No deposit is required of a
public utility company.



(Code 1965, § 8.16(a), (b), (d))



Sec. 94-15. Trimming or removal of trees.



   No person shall, without a permit from the village, cut, break, injure,
trim, repair, treat, spray, plant or remove any trees or shrubs or portions
thereof planted or growing in any public street, parkway or other public
place in the village; or injure, misuse or remove any device set for the
protection of any trees or plant in any public street or parkway in the
village. Any person desiring for any lawful purpose to cut, prune, trim,
repair, treat, spray or plant any trees or shrubs or portions thereof, in any
public street or public parkway of the village, or remove any such therefrom,
shall apply to the village manager for a permit to do such work. If, in the
judgment of the village manager, the desired work appears to be necessary or
beneficial, and if the proposed method is such as the manager approves, he
shall issue a written permit for such work without charge. Any work done
under such written permit must be performed in accordance with the terms of
such permit.



(Code 1965, § 8.19)



Sec. 94-16. Protection of public trees.



   (a)   No person shall, without a permit from the village, place or
maintain upon the ground of any public street or parkway within the village,
any stone, cement or other material or substance in such manner as may
obstruct the free access of air and water to the roots of any tree in any
such highway or parkway. Unless otherwise provided for in such permit, there
must be maintained about the base of the trunk of each shade tree in the
public highways and parkways of the village at least ten square feet of open
ground for a tree of three inches in diameter, and for every two inches of
increase of such diameter, there must be an increase of at least one square
foot of open ground.



   (b)   During the erection, repair, alteration or removal of any
building or structure within the village, or the construction of any public
or local improvement, it shall be unlawful for the person in charge of such
work to leave any tree situated in a public street or other public place in
the vicinity of such building, structure or improvement without such good and
sufficient guards or protectors and such protection and covering of its
roots, as shall prevent injury to the tree or the trunk or roots of such tree
arising out of or by reason of such work.



(Code 1965, § 8.20)



Sec. 94-17. Wires attached to trees.



   No person shall, without a permit from the village, attach or keep
attached to any tree in any public street or parkway in the village, or to
the guard or stake intended for the protection of such tree, any rope, wire,
sign or any other device.



(Code 1965, § 8.21)



Sec. 94-18. Planting trees.



   No person shall plant any cottonwood, willow, Carolina Poplar, soft
maple trees, or any tree having thorns in the public parkways, streets or
other public places of the village.



(Code 1965, § 8.18)



Sec. 94-19. Obstruction of fire hydrants, wall hydrants and fire department
connection devices due to snow removal operations.



   (a)   No person shall shovel, move or remove snow in such a manner
as to block access to fire hydrants, wall hydrants to buildings or fire
department connection devices for buildings protected by automatic sprinkler
systems. No person shall cause any such hydrant or device to be concealed or
otherwise rendered unusable as the result of the shoveling, moving or
removing of snow.



   (b)   Whenever such fire hydrants, wall hydrants or connection
devices are located on property used for industrial or commercial purposes or
multifamily dwellings, including condominiums, no property owner, managing
agent or shopping center manager or other person in charge shall permit any
such fire hydrant, wall hydrant or connection device to be concealed or
otherwise rendered unusable as the result of the shoveling, moving or
removing of snow. Upon receiving notice of such condition, verbal or written,
from the fire chief or his designee, such owner, managing agent or shopping
center manager shall, within four hours of such notice, cause such snow to be
removed.



(Code 1965, § 8.26)



Sec. 94-20. Adopt-a-street program.



   (a)   Authorization; definition. An adopt-a-street program to allow
private citizens to voluntarily support municipal antilitter efforts by
allowing groups to adopt a section of highway along village rights-of-way for
the purpose of litter collection is hereby created. The village's director of
public works is hereby assigned the responsibility for administering the
adopt-a-street program. As used in this section, litter shall mean any
