   The fines and penalties set forth in this section shall be uniformly
applied for each violation of any applicable village ordinance. The village
hereby adopts by reference all current and future local standing, parking or
condition of vehicle ordinances, and those provisions of  Illinois Compiled
Statutes governing the standing, parking, or condition of vehicles, for its
enforcement and adjudication within the geographical boundaries of the
village and in those areas subject to off-street parking agreements.



(Code 1965, § 58.14; Ord. No. MC-547, § 1, 7-25-95;  MC-695)



Sec. 106-65. Debt to village.



   Any fine, penalty or part of any fine or any penalty assessed in
accordance with the provisions of this division and remaining unpaid after
the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, administrative remedies created
under this division and the conclusion of any judicial review procedures
shall be a debt due and owing the village and, as such, may be collected in
accordance with the applicable law. Payment in full of any fine or penalty
resulting from a standing, parking, or compliance violation shall constitute
a final disposition of that violation.



(Code 1965, § 58.15; Ord. No. MC-547, § 1, 7-25-95)



Sec. 106-66. Judgment.



   The traffic compliance administrator shall, following the expiration of
the period within which administrative or judicial review may be sought for a
final determination of violation, take all necessary actions, execute all
required documents and appoint or retain any individual or agency deemed
appropriate to obtain a judgment against and collect moneys from the persons
who have been assessed fines or penalties which remain unpaid and have become
a debt due and owing the village in accordance with the provisions of this
division and 625 ILCS 5/11-208.3 by:



      (1)   Filing a complaint in the circuit court praying for the
entry of a judgment against the person for whom a final determination of
standing, parking, or compliance regulation violations liability has been
made.



      (2)   Nothing shall prevent the village from consolidating
multiple final determinations of standing, parking, or compliance regulation
violations liability in an action in the circuit court against an individual.



      (3)   Pursuing all available remedies, allowed by law, to
collect money judgments. The complaint filed by the traffic compliance
administrator or individual or agency on behalf of the village seeking entry
of a judgment against an individual for unpaid fines and/or penalties
pursuant to a final determination of standing, parking, or compliance
regulation violations shall have appended:



         a.   A certified copy of the final determination of the
standing, parking, or compliance regulation violations.



         b.   A certification that recites facts sufficient to
show that the final determination of standing, parking, or compliance
regulation violations was issued in accordance with this division and 625
ILCS 5/11-208.3.



(Code 1965, § 58.16; Ord. No. MC-547, § 1, 7-25-95)



Secs. 106-67--106-70. Reserved.



DIVISION 3. AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEM



Sec. 106-71.  Definitions.



   Automated traffic law enforcement system means a device within the
village with one or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with a
red light signal to produce recorded images of motor vehicles entering an
intersection against a steady or flashing red signal indication in violation
of Section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code ("Code"), 625 ILCS 5/11-306,
or similar violation of the Village of Homewood Municipal Code ("Municipal
Code").



   Disregarding a traffic control device means failure to stop and remain
stopped before an intersection that is controlled by a red signal as provided
for in Section 11-306 of the Code.



   No turn on red means failure to stop and remain stopped, and not
proceeding to turn right at, an intersection controlled by both a sign
indicating "No turn on red," or other similar language, and a red signal as
provided for in Section 11-306 of the Code.



   Recorded images means images produced by the automated traffic law
enforcement system, which consist of either two or more photographs; two or
more microphotographs; two or more electronic images; or, a video recording
showing the motor vehicle and, on at least one image or portion of the
recording, clearly identifying the registration plate number of the motor
vehicle.



   Traffic Compliance Administrator means the person appointed as such
through section 106-57 who shall have power to adopt, distribute and process
automated traffic law violation notices and other notices required by this
article, collect money paid as fines and penalties, operate the automated
traffic law enforcement system, and make certified reports to the Secretary
of State as required by this article.



(MC-811, § 1, 10-28-08)



Sec. 106-72.  Violations.



   It shall be a violation of this division for a vehicle to disregard a
traffic control device or turn on red in violation of Section 11-306 of the
Code.



(MC-811, § 1, 10-28-08)



Sec. 106-73.  Notice of violation.



   (a)   When the automated traffic law enforcement system records a
motor vehicle entering an intersection in violation of section 106-72, the
village shall issue a written notice of violation to the registered owner or
lessee of the vehicle, which shall be delivered by U.S. mail within 30 days
after the Illinois Secretary of State notifies the village of the identity of
the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, and in no event later than 90
days following the violation. The village shall only be required to notify a
lessee if the leasing company/lessor provides the lessee's name by an
affidavit and a copy of the lease within 60 days of the notice's issuance. If
the driver information is not provided within 60 days, the leasing
company/lessor may be found liable. If any notice to an address is returned
as undeliverable, a second notice shall be sent to the last known address
recorded in a United States Post Office approved database of the owner or
lessee of the cited vehicle. The second notice shall be made by first class
mail postage prepaid.



   (b)   A notice of violation associated with an automated traffic law
violation shall require a review of the associated recorded image by the
traffic compliance administrator, who shall inspect the image and determine
whether the motor vehicle was being operated in violation of section 106-72,
or whether one of the defenses enumerated in section 106-77 is visibly
applicable upon inspection. Upon determination that the recorded image
captures a violation and that no defense applies, the notice of violation
shall be served upon the registered vehicle owner in the manner provided for
above. The traffic compliance administrator shall retain a copy of all
violation notices, recorded images and other correspondence mailed to the
owner of the vehicle. Each notice of violation shall constitute evidence of
the facts contained in the notice and is admissible in any proceeding
alleging a violation of the above-noted statutory and local provisions and
shall be prima facie evidence of a violation, subject to rebuttal on the
basis of the defenses established in this division.



   (c)   The notice of violation shall include the following
information:



      (1)   The name and address of the registered owner or lessee
of the vehicle, as indicated by the records of the Secretary of State, or, if
such information is outdated or unattainable, then the last known address
recorded in a United States Post Office approved database;



      (2)   The make (only if discernable) and registration number
of the motor vehicle involved in the violation;



      (3)   The violation charged;



      (4)   The location where the violation occurred;



      (5)   The date and time of the violation;



      (6)   A copy of the recorded images;



      (7)   The amount of the civil penalty and the date by which
the penalty should be paid (21 days from the date of issuance) and a
statement that the payment of the fine shall operate as a final disposition
of the violation;



      (8)   A statement that a failure to pay the civil penalty by
the date noted may result in an additional late fee being assessed against
the owner or lessee;



      (9)   The amount of the late fee;



      (10)   A statement that the failure to pay by the date
specified or to contest liability in a timely manner will result in a final
determination of liability and may result in the suspension of driving
privileges for the registered owner of the vehicle;



      (11)   A statement that the recorded images constitute prima
facie evidence of a violation;



      (12)   A statement that the person may elect to proceed by
paying the fine or challenging the charge in court, by mail or by
administrative hearing; and



      (13)   A statement of how an administrative hearing may be
requested.



(MC-811, § 1, 10-28-08)



Sec. 106-74.  Hearing.



   (a)   The owner of a vehicle being operated in violation of this
division may request a hearing by the respond-by date on the notice of
violation (21 days from the date of issuance), to challenge the evidence or
set forth an applicable defense. The notice of violation shall constitute
evidence of the facts contained in the notice and is admissible in any
proceeding alleging a violation of this section. The notice of violation
shall be prima facie evidence of a violation, subject to rebuttal on the
basis of the defenses established in this division.



   (b)   The owner's failure to appear at the hearing will result in a
finding of liability. In the event of a failure to appear, a "Findings,
Decision and Order" letter will be sent to the owner. The owner's failure to
pay the amount by the date specified in that letter will result in a final
determination.



(MC-811, § 1, 10-28-08)



Sec. 106-75.  Administrative adjudication.



   All automated traffic law violations described in this section will be
adjudicated by the hearing officer appointed pursuant to Chapter 3, Article I
of the Municipal Code. Hearing procedures set forth in said Chapter 3,
Article I shall apply to hearings conducted pursuant to this division, except
that if hearing procedures set forth in this division conflict with the
procedures set forth in said Chapter 3, Article I, the procedures of this
division shall apply.



(MC-811, § 1, 10-28-08)



Sec. 106-76.  Contesting violation notice by mail.



   In lieu of requesting a hearing, the registered owner or lease of the
cited vehicle may contest the charges using the same available defenses as
stated below by submitting any and all documentary evidence to the traffic
compliance administrator no later than the hearing date. The traffic
compliance administrator shall forward all timely-submitted materials to the
hearing officer for review and determination.



(MC-811, § 1, 10-28-08)



Sec. 106-77.  Defenses.



   (a)   The following may be considered defenses by the hearing
officer for a violation of section 106-72:



      (1)   That the motor vehicle or registration plates of the
motor vehicle were stolen before the violation occurred, and not under the
control of or in the possession of the owner at the time of the violation;



      (2)   That the driver of the vehicle passed through the
intersection when the light was red either (i) in order to yield the
right-of-way to an emergency vehicle or (ii) as part of a funeral procession;
and



      (3)   Any other evidence or issues provided by municipal or
county ordinance.



   (b)   To demonstrate that the motor vehicle or the registration
plates were stolen before the violation occurred and were not under the
control or possession of the owner at the time of the violation, the owner
must submit proof that a report concerning the stolen motor vehicle or
registration plates was filed with a law enforcement agency in a timely
manner.



(MC-811, § 1, 10-28-08)



Sec. 106-78.  Final determination.



   A final determination of violation liability shall occur following
failure to pay the fine, a failure to request a hearing by the respond-by
date, after a hearing officer's determination of violation liability and the
exhaustion of or failure to exhaust the administrative review procedures
provided by the Municipal Code. Where a person fails to appear at a hearing
to contest the alleged violation in the time and manner specified in a prior
mailed notice, the hearing officer's determination shall become final upon a
failure to pay the amount owed on the date provided in the "Findings,
Decision and Order" letter. Appeal may be made to the Circuit Court of Cook
County on any final determination as provided for by the Administrative
Review Act.



(MC-811, § 1, 10-28-08)



Sec. 106-79.  Notice of determination of liability.



   If the registered owner fails to pay or contest the notice of violation
within 21 days a notice of determination of liability will be sent to the
owner indicating that a fine in the amount of $100 is due to the village. 
The notice will also state that the owner can petition the village to set
aside the determination of liability before it becomes final.  If the owner
does not pay the $100 as specified in the notice or petition the village to
set aside the determination, within 21 days, a notice of final determination
will be sent to the owner indicating that the owner has exhausted all
challenge options and the $100 fine is a debt due and owing to the village
and must be paid within 14 days. The owner will also be notified that the
failure to pay the $100 fine within 14 days will result in a late fee of $100
added to the original fine.



(MC-811, § 1, 10-28-08)



Sec. 106-80.  Notice of final determination.



   A notice of final determination shall be sent following the final
determination of automated traffic law violation liability and the conclusion
of judicial review. The notice of final determination shall include the
following information:



   (a)   A statement that the unpaid fine is a debt due and owing to
the village;



   (b)   A warning that a failure to pay any fine due and owing to the
village within 14 days may result in the village filing a petition in the
Circuit Court of Cook County to have the unpaid fine rendered as a judgment,
or may result in the suspension of the person's drivers license for failure
to pay fines or penalties for five or more violations under this division.



(MC-811, § 1, 10-28-08)



Sec. 106-81.  Petition to set aside determination.



   (a)   A petition to set aside determination of an automated traffic
law violation must be filed with or mailed to the traffic control
administrator within 14 days of the date of mailing of the notice of
determination of liability.  The grounds for the petition are limited to:



      (1)   The person was not the owner or lessee of the cited
vehicle on the date of the violation notice was issued;



      (2)   The person having already paid the fine for the
violation in question; and



      (3)   Excusable failure to appear at or request a new date for
a hearing.



   (b)   Upon receipt of a timely petition to set aside the
determination of liability, the hearing officer shall review the petition to
determine if cause has been shown to set aside the determination. If cause
has been shown, the village shall forward the petitioner a new hearing date
on which the petitioner must appear to present his case. The village shall
notify the petitioner of the hearing officer's decision to grant a hearing or
deny the petition within 14 days of the village's receipt.



(MC-811, § 1, 10-28-08)



Sec. 106-82.  Notice of impending driver's license suspension.



   (a)   A notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be
sent to the person liable for any fine or penalty that remains due and owing
on five or more violations of this division. The notice of impending driver's
license suspension shall state the following information:



      (1)   The failure to pay the fine owing within 45 days of the
notice's date will result in the village notifying the Secretary of State
that the person is eligible for initiation of suspension proceedings under
625 ILCS 5/6-306.5;



      (2)   A statement that the person may obtain a copy of the
original ticket imposing a fine by sending a self-addressed, stamped envelope
to the village along with a request for the copy.



   (b)   The notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be
sent by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the address recorded with the
Secretary of State or, if any notice to that address is returned as
undeliverable, to the last known address recorded in a United States Post
Office approved database.



(MC-811, § 1, 10-28-08)



Sec. 106-83.  Driver's license suspension.



   (a)   The traffic compliance administrator, by certified report, may
request that the Secretary of State suspend the driving privileges of an
owner of a registered vehicle who has failed to pay any fine or penalty due
and owing as a result of five automated traffic violations. The report shall
be certified and contain the following:



      (1)   The name, last known address as recorded with the
Secretary of State, as provided by the lessor of the cited vehicle at the
time of lease, or as recorded in a United States Post Office approved
database if any notice sent under this division is returned as undeliverable,
and driver's license number of the person who failed to pay the fine or
penalty and the registration number of any vehicle known to be registered to
such person in a state;



      (2)   A statement that the report is being made by the village
pursuant to this section; and



      (3)   A statement that a notice of impending driver's license
suspension has been sent to the person named in the report at the address
recorded with the Secretary of State or at the last address known to the
lessor of the cited vehicle at the time of the lease or, if any notice sent
under this division is returned as undeliverable at the last known address
recorded at a United States Post Office approved database; the date on which
such notice was sent; and address to which such notice was sent.



   (b)   The traffic compliance administrator shall notify the
Secretary of State whenever a person named in the certified report has paid
the previously recorded fine or penalty or whenever the municipality
determines that the original report was in error. A certified copy of such
notification shall also be given upon request and at no additional charge to
the person named therein.



   (c)   Any person receiving notice from the Secretary of State that
their driving privileges may be suspended at the end of a specified period
may challenge the accuracy of the certified report prepared by the traffic
compliance administrator. The person shall, within seven days after having
received notice from the Secretary of State, request an opportunity to speak
with the traffic compliance administrator to challenge the accuracy of the
certified report. If the traffic compliance administrator determines that the
original report was in error due to the fact that the person challenging the
report was not the owner or lessee of the vehicle or that the person has
already paid their fine for the five or more automated traffic violations,
the traffic compliance administrator shall immediately notify the Secretary
of State of such error in a subsequent certified report.



(MC-811, § 1, 10-28-08)



Secs. 106-84–106-95.  Reserved.



ARTICLE III. BICYCLES



Sec. 106-96. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Bicycle means a light vehicle with two wheels, neither of which is less
than 16 inches in diameter, having handlebars and seat and propelled by the
feet. It shall also mean all three-wheeled light vehicles having three
wheels, with handlebars and seat and propelled by the feet, providing one of
the three wheels is at least 24 inches in diameter, and all unicycles.



   Chief of police means the chief of police of the village, or any member
of the police department of the village designated by the chief of police to
act in his place and stead.



   Dealer in bicycles means any person engaged in the sale of bicycles at
retail or wholesale.



   Registrant means any person to whom the village clerk shall issue a
registration plate or tag for a bicycle.



   Rental agency means any person engaged in the business of offering for
rental and renting bicycles for use by the public.



   Street, alley or highway means every way dedicated for public travel.



(Code 1965, § 56.01)



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 106-97. Registration.



   (a)   Required. Every resident of the village owning a bicycle shall
register the bicycle with the village clerk.



   (b)   Procedure. An application for the registration of a bicycle
shall be made by the owner to the village clerk, who shall provide a
registration plate or tag to be fastened to the bicycle so registered. Each
bicycle plate or tag, when registered, shall be effective until the
registrant shall sell or transfer title to the bicycle.



   (c)   Tags. The registration plate or tag shall bear consecutive
numbers or combinations of letters with numbers, shall indicate the year
issued, and shall have stamped thereon the name "Homewood." Registration
plates or tags shall also be of such a size or design as shall be read
legibly at a distance of 15 feet. The registration plate or tag shall be
attached by the registrant to a clear and unobstructed location on the rear
of the bicycle and shall so remain during the life of the registration and
shall at all times be kept clean. The village clerk shall keep a record of
the date of the registration of each bicycle and to whom a registration plate
or tag is issued, the number on the tag, and the number of the bicycle frame.
Registration shall be accompanied by a fee of $0.50.



   (d)   Inspection. The chief of police shall inspect each bicycle
previous to the issuance of registration or re-registration plates or tags
therefor, and he may refuse to approve any bicycle which is not properly
equipped or which is in an unsafe condition.



   (e)   Frame and tag serial numbers. It shall be unlawful for any
person willfully or maliciously to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the
number of any bicycle frame of a bicycle registered pursuant to this article;
also to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any registration plate or tag
during the time for which the registration plate or tag is in force. This
article shall not prohibit the village clerk from stamping, in a
distinguishing manner, numbers on the frame of a bicycle upon which no serial
number can be found, or upon which the serial number is illegible or
insufficient for identification purposes.



(Code 1965, § 56.02)



Sec. 106-98. Rental agencies.



   Bicycles offered for rent by a rental agency shall be equipped by the
agency with lights and other safety equipment required by this article, and
shall be kept in good and safe working order. Rental agencies shall comply in
all respects with all of the provisions of this article, and shall be
responsible for the condition of the bicycles they rent. The chief of police
shall make periodic inspections of rental agencies to ascertain that they are
complying with the provisions of this article.



(Code 1965, § 56.03)



Sec. 106-99. Riding bicycles on sidewalks.



   Except in business districts, as identified in section 106-35, bicycles
may be ridden on sidewalks.



(Code 1965, § 52.03)



Sec. 106-100. Emerging from alleys, driveways or garages.



   The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building
shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or sidewalk area extending across any
alleyway, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on the
sidewalk area and upon entering the public street or roadway shall yield the
right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on the street or roadway.



(Code 1965, § 56.04(c))



Sec. 106-101. Parking.



   It shall be unlawful at any time to place any bicycle along buildings
in such manner as to interfere with the ingress or egress thereof or to
interfere  with pedestrians,  or along  roadways  where they  may
interfere  with traffic or with persons  entering or  alighting  from
automobiles.  No person shall move or in any manner interfere with  any
bicycle  which is properly  parked,  nor shall any person interfere with,
or in any manner hinder any person from properly parking a bicycle, except
that members of the police department or fire department may move, or, in
proper cases, prevent the parking of a bicycle when, in the judgment of the
police officer or firefighter, his action is necessary, in order to properly
safeguard persons or property.



(Code 1965, § 56.04(g))



Sec. 106-102. Audible signals on bicycles.



   No person shall operate a bicycle unless it is equipped with a bell or
other device capable of giving an audible signal for a distance of at least
100 feet. However, bicycles shall not be equipped with, nor shall any person
use upon a bicycle, any siren or whistle.



(Code 1965, § 56.04(i))



Sec. 106-103. Reckless riding.



   At no time shall a bicycle be ridden in a reckless, careless, or
negligent manner, or in such a manner as to endanger lives of pedestrians, or
in such a manner to interfere with lawful traffic and the use of the streets.
Riding without hands on the handlebars, deliberate wobbling from side to
side, and other unnecessary and dangerous acts conductive to accidents are
considered reckless riding.



(Code 1965, § 56.04(k))



Sec. 106-104. Turns.



   The operator of a bicycle on a roadway, when making a right turn, shall
follow the righthand lane next to the righthand edge of the roadway, and the
operator of a bicycle on a roadway, when making a left turn, shall approach
the point of turning in the traffic lane nearest the center of the roadway,
and shall not cut the lefthand corner. No operator of a bicycle shall
suddenly start, slow down, stop or attempt to turn or stop, without first
giving the standard hand signals required by state law for motor vehicles
under the same circumstances. (Code 1965, § 56.04(l))



Secs. 106-105--106-130. Reserved.



ARTICLE IV. OPERATION OF VEHICLES*



   *Cross reference(s)--Department of public works, § 2-336 et seq.



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Sec. 106-131. Negligent driving.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle upon a
public way negligently, heedlessly and without due caution in a manner so as
to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property.



(Code 1965, § 52.28)



Sec. 106-132. Boarding or alighting from vehicles.



   No person shall board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is
in motion.



(Code 1965, § 52.33)



Sec. 106-133. Abandoning motor vehicles.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon any motor vehicle on any
public way within the village. Such an abandoned motor vehicle may be removed
by the police department in the manner prescribed in ARTICLE VII of this
Chapter.



(Code 1965, § 52.34)



Sec. 106-134. Riding on fenders, running boards or outside steps.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to ride upon the fenders, running
board or outside step of any vehicle.



(Code 1965, § 52.35(b))



Sec. 106-135. Skateboards, roller skates, bicycles, coasters, sleds and other
toy vehicles.



   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person upon a skateboard, roller
skates, coaster, sled, or other toy vehicle, to go upon any roadway other
than at a crosswalk or to be upon the roof of any building within the Village.



   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person upon a skateboard, roller
skates, or bicycle, to go upon any sidewalk in the following areas:



      (1)   Dixie Highway, both sides, from Harwood Avenue to 183rd
Street;



      (2)   Elm Road, both sides, from Harwood Avenue to Dixie
Highway;



      (3)   Chestnut Road, both sides, from Harwood Avenue to Dixie
Highway;



      (4)   Ridge Road, both sides, from Harwood Avenue to Highland
Avenue;



      (5)   Kroner Lane, both sides, from Harwood Avenue to Dixie
Highway;



      (6)   Hickory Road, both sides, from Harwood Avenue to
Gottschalk Avenue;



      (7)   Harwood Avenue, both sides, from Dixie Highway to
Hickory Road



      (8)   Martin Avenue, both sides, from  Chestnut Road to
Hickory Road; and



      (9)   Vincennes Avenue, both sides from Pine Road South to
Dixie Highway.



   (c)   It shall be unlawful for any person upon a skateboard, roller
skates, coaster, sled, or other toy vehicle to go upon an alley which is
between any of the streets identified in subsection (b) of this section.



   (d)   It shall be unlawful for any person upon a skateboard, roller
skates, bicycle, coaster, sled, or other toy vehicle to go upon a park, a
portion thereof, or parking lot when such park, portion thereof, or parking
lot is conspicuously and clearly posted as prohibiting such uses.



   (e)   Any person upon a skateboard, roller skates, bicycle, coaster,
sled, or other toy vehicle at permitted locations shall yield the
right-of-way to pedestrians using village sidewalks, and shall not otherwise
endanger or interfere with pedestrian traffic on those sidewalks.



(Code 1965, § 52.36)



Sec. 106-136. Processions.



   (a)   Driving through. No driver of a vehicle shall drive between
the vehicles comprising an authorized procession while they are in motion and
when such vehicles are conspicuously designated as required by law.



   (b)   Drivers in a procession. Each driver in a procession shall
drive as near to the righthand side of the roadway as close as practical and
shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as practical and safe.



(Code 1965, § 52.38)



Sec. 106-137. Use of streets by trucks.



   It shall be unlawful to drive any truck, except for the purpose of
making a delivery and then for one block only on any street so designated by
ordinance and properly signposted.



(Code 1965, § 52.41)



Sec. 106-138. Limited load streets.



   It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle on any street in the
village when the gross weight on the surface of the road through any axle of
such vehicle exceeds 16,000 pounds. Where lower limits are imposed by
ordinance and signs, indicating such limitations are posted, it shall be
unlawful to operate a vehicle in excess of such weight on such street, except
for the purpose of making a delivery or picking up a load, in which case such
vehicle may be driven on such street for not more than the minimum distance
necessary for such purpose.



(Code 1965, § 52.42)



Sec. 106-139. False reports.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to make, give or provide
information in an oral or written report required by this chapter with
knowledge or reason to believe that such information is false.



(Code 1965, § 52.46)



Sec. 106-140. Bicycles, motorcycles and motor driven scooters.



   1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate minibikes,
go-carts, snowmobiles, and motor driven scooters and similar vehicles upon
any paved or unpaved street or public way or upon private property without
the consent of the owner within the Village of Homewood.



   2.   The following shall be exempt from the prohibitions contained
in this ordinance:



      a.   Any police vehicle, fire vehicle, municipal vehicle, park
district vehicle, county vehicle or state vehicle operated by an employee in
the course of his or her duties.



      b.   Motorized wheelchairs. For the purpose of this ordinance,
a Motorized Wheelchair means any motorized vehicle designed for and used by a
person with disabilities.



      c.   Electric personal assistive mobility devices, as defined
in section 5/1-117.7 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.).



   3.   Violations. Any person 18 years of age or older who violates
any provision of this ordinance shall be subject to a fine of not less than
$25.00 nor more than $750.00 for each offense. An offense committed by a
minor under the direct control or with the consent of a parent or guardian
may subject the parent or guardian to the penalties provided in this section.



(Code 1965, § 52.50)



Sec. 106-141. Moving of vehicles.



   No person other than a police officer shall start or cause to be
started the motor of any motor vehicle, or shift, change or move the levers,
brake, starting device, gears, or other mechanism of a parked motor vehicle
to a position other than that in which it was left by the owner or driver
thereof, or attempt to do so.



(Code 1965, § 52.59)



Sec. 106-142. Gas and smoke emissions.



   It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which emits dense smoke or
such an amount of smoke or fumes as to be dangerous to the health of persons
or as to endanger the drivers of other vehicles.



(Code 1965, § 52.77)



Sec. 106-143. Unsafe vehicles.



   It is unlawful for any person to drive or move or for the owner to
cause or knowingly permit to be driven or moved on any highway any vehicle or
combination of vehicles which is in such unsafe condition as to endanger any
person or property, or which does not contain those parts or is not at all
times equipped with such lamps and other equipment in proper condition and
adjustment as required by statute, or which is equipped in any manner in
violation of the statute.



(Code 1965, § 52.79)



Sec. 106-144.  Inoperable motor vehicles prohibited.



   (a)   It is hereby declared a nuisance for any person to cause or
permit the existence or storage upon any premises within the village any
inoperable motor vehicle or part thereof.



   (b)   For the purpose of this section, the term Inoperable Motor
Vehicle means any motor vehicle or other vehicle or part thereof from which
for a period of at least seven days, the engine, the wheels, or other parts
have been removed or on which the engine, wheels, or other parts have been
altered, damaged, or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of
being driven under its own motor power.



   (c)   Inoperable Motor Vehicle shall not include:



      (1)   Any motor vehicle rendered temporarily incapable of
being driven under its own motor power in



order to perform ordinary service or repair operations;



      (2)   Any vehicle kept within an enclosed building;



      (3)   Any vehicle on the premises of a place of business
otherwise lawfully engaged in the wrecking, junking, storage, or sale of
motor vehicles or other vehicles;



      (4)   Any motor vehicle not required to be registered in order
to operate it upon a public road or highway;



      (5)   Any motor vehicle more than 25 years old that is
licensed as an antique vehicle pursuant to section 3-804 of the Motor Vehicle
Code (625 ILCS 5/3-804).



   (d)   Upon written notice from the village served in a manner
reasonably calculated to reach the property owner, the owner of private
property on which an inoperable motor vehicle is located must remove the
vehicle out of public view to a closed garage or similar enclosed structure
within the time specified in the notice. If the vehicle is not so moved, the
village shall have the authority to cite the owner of private property on
which an inoperable motor vehicle is located and the vehicle owner, and to
tow and impound the inoperable motor vehicle. Towing of inoperable motor
vehicles by the village pursuant to this section shall be governed by and
subject to the requirements of sections 106-357(c), 106-358 and 106-359 of
this Chapter 106.



(MC-840, § 2, 2-22-11)



Secs. 106-145--106-160. Reserved.



DIVISION 2. RIGHT-OF-WAY



Sec. 106-161. Through streets.



   The streets and parts of streets of the city designated by ordinance as
through streets are hereby declared to be through streets. The driver of a
vehicle shall stop at the entrance to a through street and shall yield the
right-of-way to other vehicles which have entered the intersection or which
are approaching so close on a through street as to constitute an immediate
hazard, unless directed otherwise by the traffic officer or a traffic control
signal.



(Code 1965, § 52.11(a))



Sec. 106-162.  Stop streets.



   The driver of a vehicle shall stop in obedience to a stop sign at an
intersection where a stop sign is erected pursuant to ordinance, at one or
more entrances thereto, and shall proceed cautiously, yielding to the
vehicles not so obliged to stop which are within the intersection or
approaching so close as to constitute an immediate hazard, unless traffic at
such intersection is controlled by a police officer on duty, in which event
the directions of the police officer shall be complied with.



(Code 1965, § 52.11(b))



Sec. 106-163. Yield right-of-way streets.



   (a)   Any street designated by ordinance  as a yield  right-of-way
street and so posted is hereby declared to be a yield right-of-way street.



   (b)   The driver of a vehicle in obedience to a yield right-of-way
sign shall reduce the speed of his vehicle to not more than 20 miles per hour
and shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles which have entered the
intersecting street either from the right or left or which are approaching so
closely on such intersection as to constitute a hazard. However, such driver
having so yielded may proceed at such time as a safe interval occurs.



   (c)   If a driver is involved in a collision at an intersection or
interferes with the movement of other vehicles after driving past a yield
right-of-way sign, such collision shall be deemed prima facie evidence of the
driver's failure to yield the right-of-way.



(Code 1965, § 52.11(c))



Sec. 106-164. Posting signs.



   Appropriate signs shall be posted to show all through, stop and yield
right-of-way streets, as well as all stop intersections.



(Code 1965, § 52.11(d))



Sec. 106-165. No through traffic intersections.



   The driver of a vehicle entering an intersection where signs are posted
prohibiting traffic from proceeding across such intersection and continuing
in the same general direction and requiring the vehicle to make a turning
movement at the intersection shall, upon entering the intersection, make an
authorized turning movement and not proceed through the intersection.
Appropriate signs shall be posted to identify all no through traffic
intersections and to further show which turning movements may be made at such
intersections.



(Code 1965, § 52.11(e))



Sec. 106-166. No through traffic public ways.



   When signs are posted stating "no through traffic permitted," no driver
of a vehicle shall enter such public way at an intersection, proceed directly
through such public way to the next intersection, and leave that public way
at that intersection. No driver shall enter such public way unless that
driver has reason to stop before exiting the way because of a residential,
commercial or industrial use along the public way.



(Code 1965, § 52.11(f))



Sec. 106-167. Right-of-way.



   Except as otherwise provided in this division, the driver of a vehicle
approaching an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to a vehicle which
has entered the intersection from a different highway.



(Code 1965, § 52.18)



Secs. 106-168--106-185. Reserved.



DIVISION 3. TURNING MOVEMENTS



Sec. 106-186. Obedience to no turn signs or no turn on red.



   Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right, left or
U-turn is permitted, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of
any such sign.



(Code 1965, § 52.16)



Secs. 106-187--106-205. Reserved.



DIVISION 4. ONE-WAY STREETS



Sec. 106-206. One-way roadways and rotary traffic islands.



   (a)   Upon a roadway or street designated and signposted for one-way
traffic, a vehicle shall be driven only in the direction designated. The
streets described in Schedule A are hereby designated one-way streets.



   (b)   A vehicle passing around a rotary traffic island shall be
driven on the right of such island.



(Code 1965, § 52.25)



Secs. 106-207--106-225. Reserved.



ARTICLE V. VEHICLE LICENSES*



   *Cross reference(s)--Business licensing generally, § 26-31 et seq.



Sec. 106-226. Required.



   No person residing or having his principal place of business within the
village shall own or use a motor vehicle or motor bicycle, and no person
shall use a motor vehicle or motor bicycle owned by any person residing, or
having his principal place of business within the village, upon the streets
of the village unless such vehicle is licensed as provided in this article,
and the license is properly displayed.



(Code 1965, § 51.01(a))



Sec. 106-227. Application.



   Any person desiring a license for any such vehicle shall file an
application with the village manager, upon such forms as he shall prescribe,
setting forth the name and address of the applicant, a description of the
vehicle for which the license is desired, and the place where such vehicle is
to be kept when not in use, together with such information as may be required
on such forms.



(Code 1965, § 51.01(b))



Sec. 106-228. Fees.



   (a)   The annual motor vehicle license fees shall be as set forth in
the following schedule:



 

 
Cost if purchased on or before May 31
 
Cost if purchased after May 31


All vehicles with 2 wheels
 
$ 20.00
 
$ 45.00


All vehicles with 3 or 4 wheel
 
30.00
 
55.00


All vehicles with 6 or 8 wheels
 
60.00
 
85.00


All vehicles with 10 or more wheels
 
80.00
 
105.00



 



   (b)   The annual motor vehicle license fee for a four-wheeled
vehicle where the owner of that vehicle is 65 years of age or older at the
time of filing an application for such license, and is a resident of the
village, shall be $5.00. This reduced fee for senior citizens shall apply to
only one vehicle per household annually, and shall not apply in any case
where a motor vehicle is used for commercial purposes.



   (c)   Satisfactory proof of age must be furnished by such applicant,
either by birth certificate, valid driver's license or other documentation
acceptable to the village.



   (d)   The term "wheel," as used in the vehicle license fee schedule,
shall mean all disks, rims or circular frames mounted on a vehicle body axle.
Each such wheel shall be counted separately for determination of the
applicable fee.



   (e)   The license period shall commence on May 1 and expire on April
30 following the date of issuance. Village licenses shall be made available
to the public April 1 of each year for the license period and must be
purchased and displayed as provided in this article no later than May 31 of
the period for which they are issued.



(Code 1965, § 51.01(c))  (MC-670)



Sec. 106-229.  Prorating fees.



   On and after October 16 in any year, the vehicle license fee shall be
reduced by 50 percent; provided, however, that this reduced rate shall apply
only to a person whose residence in the village commenced on or after such
date, or who purchased the vehicle on or after such date, or whose vehicle
was out of service for the six-month period prior to such date. Satisfactory
proof of any such fact must be furnished by the applicant.



(Code 1965, § 51.01(d))



Sec. 106-230.  Replacement sticker.



   A fee of $5.00 shall be charged to the vehicle owner by the village for
issuing a vehicle license sticker to replace any previously issued current
vehicle license sticker.



(Code 1965, § 51.01(e)) (MC-670)



Sec. 106-231. Separate revenue fund for fees.



   All revenues derived from such license fees shall be kept as a separate
account in the general fund, and shall be used for street and alley
construction, improvement or repair, or for such other legal purposes as the
board of trustees shall from time to time deem appropriate.



(Code 1965, § 51.01(f))



Sec. 106-232. License plates or stickers.



   The village shall furnish to each applicant a sticker when the license
fee is paid. This sticker shall be placed in a position to be clearly visible
and maintained in a clearly legible condition. Village stickers shall be
placed on the front windshield, in the lower lefthand corner.



(Code 1965, § 51.01(g))



Sec. 106-233. Disabled veterans.



   (a)   The annual motor license fee for a four-wheeled vehicle where
the owner of that vehicle is a disabled American veteran at the time of
filing application for such license, and is a resident of the village, shall
be $2.00.



   (b)   Satisfactory proof that the applicant is a disabled veteran
must be furnished by such applicant, by exhibiting a passenger car
identification card from the state showing the vehicle has disabled American
veteran state license plates.



(Code 1965, § 51.01(h))



Sec. 106-234.  New residents and businesses.



   New residents and businesses required to license vehicles, as
prescribed in this article shall have 30 days from establishing residency or
occupancy in which to obtain the required license. If purchased after this
30-day period, a $25.00 late fee shall be added to the cost of the license.
Satisfactory proof of the date of establishing residency or occupancy must be
furnished by the applicant.



(Code 1965, § 51.01(i)) (MC-670)



Sec. 106-235.  New and replacement vehicles.



   Any person or business required to license vehicles as prescribed in
this article shall have 60 days from the date of purchase of a new or
replacement vehicle in which to obtain the required license for the new or
replacement vehicle. If this license is purchased after this 60-day period, a
$25.00 late fee shall be added to the cost of the license. Satisfactory proof
of the date of purchase of the new or replacement vehicle must be furnished
by the applicant.



(Code 1965, § 51.01(j)) (MC-670)



Sec. 106-236. Display of state registration plates.



   (a)   Registration plates issued for a motor vehicle other than a
motorcycle, trailer, semitrailer, truck-tractor, apportioned bus, or
apportioned truck shall be attached thereto, one in the front and one in the
rear.  The registration plate issued for a motorcycle, trailer or
semitrailer required to be registered hereunder and any apportionment plate
issued to a bus shall be attached to the rear thereof.  The registration
plate issued for a truck-tractor or an apportioned truck required to be
registered hereunder shall be attached to the front thereof.



   (b)   Every registration plate shall at all times be securely
fastened in a horizontal position to the vehicle for which it is issued so as
to prevent the plate from swinging and at a height of not less than 12 inches
from the ground, measuring from the bottom of such plate, in a place and
position to be clearly visible and shall be maintained in a condition to be
clearly legible, free from any materials that would obstruct the visibility
of the plate, including, but not limited to, glass covers and tinted plastic
covers.  Clear plastic covers are permissible as long as they remain clear
and do not obstruct the visibility of the plates.  Registration stickers
issued as evidence of renewed annual registration shall be attached to
registration plates as required by the Secretary of State, and be clearly
visible at all times.



   (c)   No person shall operate a vehicle, nor permit the operation of
a vehicle, upon which is displayed a registration plate, plates or
registration stickers after the termination of the registration period for
which issued.



(MC-837, § 1, 10-12-10)



Sec. 106-237. Antique vehicle rebate program.



   (a)   Upon payment of the full annual municipal motor vehicle
license fee, the owner of an antique vehicle shall be entitled to a rebate of
all but $10.00 of the license fee.



   (b)   Any person seeking the rebate shall file an application on
such forms as the finance director may prescribe, together with a copy of the
current vehicle registration reflecting that the vehicle is licensed as such
by the state.



   (c)   For purposes of this section, the term “antique vehicle”
means a motor vehicle licensed as such by the State of Illinois.



(MC-869, § 1, 4-10-12)



Secs. 106-238-106-255. Reserved



ARTICLE VI. STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Sec. 106-256. No parking places.



   It shall be unlawful to permit any vehicle to stand at any time in any
of the following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other
traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic
control device:



      (1)   In any intersection.



      (2)   In a crosswalk.



      (3)   Upon any bridge or viaduct, or in any subway or tunnel
or the approach thereto.



      (4)   Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30
feet of a point of the curb immediately opposite the end of a safety zone.



      (5)   Within 30 feet of a traffic signal, beacon, or sign on
the approaching side.



      (6)   Within 20 feet of any intersection or crosswalk.



      (7)   At any place where the standing of a vehicle will reduce
the usable width of the roadway for moving traffic to less than 18 feet.



      (8)   Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant.



      (9)   At any place where the vehicle would block the use of a
driveway.



      (10)   Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad grade
crossing.



      (11)   Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire
department station and on the side of the street opposite the entrance to any
such station within 75 feet of such entrance when properly signposted.



      (12)   On any sidewalk or parkway.



      (13)   At any place where official signs prohibit parking.



(Code 1965, § 52.53)



Sec. 106-257. No parking and limited parking zones.



   When signs or markings are in place giving notice thereof, no person
shall park a vehicle at the times indicated upon the streets described in
Schedule B, or for a longer time than indicated upon the streets described in
Schedule C, which schedules are attached as article VII of this chapter.



(Code 1965, § 52.54)



Sec. 106-258. Parking limitation changes.



   The president and board of trustees may, from time to time, prohibit or
limit the hours of parking of vehicles on any street within the village, but
in case such restrictions are provided, appropriate signs stating the parking
limit shall be posted.



(Code 1965, § 52.55)



Sec. 106-259. Street curb markings for no parking zones.



   The application of yellow paint to street curbing, as authorized by the
village manager, shall denote a no vehicular parking zone for the extent of
such marking. Such curb painting may be in lieu of or in combination with the
erection of signs at the discretion of the village manager. No unauthorized
person shall paint or otherwise mark any curb or street.



(Code 1965, § 52.56)



Sec. 106-260. Commercial vehicle parking.



   No person shall park a commercial vehicle on any street or public way
in the village for longer than one hour other than for expeditious unloading
and delivery or pickup and loading; provided, however, that in emergency
situations or where deemed necessary to promote the public health and
welfare, the chief of police may allow additional parking time.



(Code 1965, § 52.57)



Sec. 106-261. Parallel and angle parking.



   Upon those streets which have been marked or signed for angle parking,
vehicles shall be parked at the angle to the curb indicated by such mark or
signs, with the right front wheel within six inches of the curb.



(Code 1965, § 52.58)



Sec. 106-262. Snow removal and street cleaning.



   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any public street during or
after a snowfall once two or more inches of snow has accumulated, until the
snow has been removed from the street by a municipally owned snowplow or by a
subcontractor authorized by the village.



(Code 1965, § 52.60)



Sec. 106-263. Vehicles for sale or peddling.



   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the
purpose of displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon any business
street from which vehicle merchandise is peddled.



(Code 1965, § 52.62)



Sec. 106-264. Loading zones.



   It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stand a passenger
vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the loading or
unloading of passengers, not to exceed 30 minutes in any place designated by
the president and board of trustees as a loading zone and marked as such.



(Code 1965, § 52.63)



Sec. 106-265. Cabstands and busstands.



   No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be parked in any area
designated by ordinance as a cabstand. No vehicle other than a bus shall be
parked in a place so designated as a bus loading zone.



(Code 1965, § 52.64)



Sec. 106-266. Parking in alleys.



   No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or
under such conditions as to leave available less than 15 feet of width of the
roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic. No person shall stop,
stand, or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to block the
driveway entrance to any abutting property. This section shall not apply to
persons operating commercial vehicles parking in an alley for expeditious
unloading and delivery or pickup and loading.



(Code 1965, § 52.65)



Sec. 106-267. Parking on private property.



   It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any private property
without the consent of the owner of the property.



(Code 1965, § 52.66)



Sec. 106-268. Parking of trucks and commercial vehicles on residential
property.



   (a)   For the purpose of this section, "Truck" and "Commercial
Vehicles" shall have the same meaning as defined in the Illinois Motor
Vehicle Code, and the "Class" of a vehicle shall refer to the classes as set
out in Chapter 625 of the Illinois Revised Statutes, as presently in effect
and as amended from time to time.



   (b)   No truck or commercial vehicle may be parked or stored on
property zoned or used for residential purposes, except as authorized by
Section 106-268(c) of this Code.



   (c)   Only one class "B" truck or one class "B" commercial vehicle,
but not one of each, that does not exceed any of the following criteria: 20
feet in length, seven feet in height, or seven feet in width, may be parked
or stored overnight on property, vacant or improved, that is zoned or used
for residential purposes, and only under the following conditions:



      (1)   Such vehicle shall be parked or stored overnight in a
garage structure which complies with the village building code; or



      (2)   If there is no garage on the said property such vehicle
shall be parked or stored overnight in the rear yard of the premises (as
defined in the village zoning ordinance); or



      (3)   If there is no driveway access on the said property to
the rear yard, such vehicle shall be parked or stored overnight in the side
yard of the said premises (as defined in the village zoning ordinance); or



      (4)   If there is no driveway access on the said property to a
side yard, such vehicle may be parked or stored overnight in the front yard
of the premises (as defined in the village zoning ordinance), but not closer
than five feet from the front property line.



(Code 1965, § 52.97; Ord. No. MC-579, §1, 7-8-97)



Sec. 106-269. Overnight parking on public streets.



   (a)   Prohibited generally. When signs are in place giving notice,
no person shall park any vehicle or allow any vehicle to be parked on village
streets between 2.:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on any day, unless the vehicle has
received a temporary or extended parking ban exemption. The prohibition of
this section shall apply to owners and operators of vehicles parked in
violation of this section.



   (b)   Temporary parking ban exemption. Owners or operators of a
vehicle may request a temporary parking ban exemption by contacting the
village police department and furnishing the address where the vehicle will
be parked, vehicle description, license number and reason for the request.
Temporary parking ban exemptions shall be valid for a maximum of five days
and will be granted because of:



      (1)   Driveway or other household repairs that would preclude
use of the driveway;



      (2)   Stalled vehicles;



      (3)   Overnight or late night guests; and



      (4)   Other circumstances approved by the chief of police or
his designee.



   (c)   Extended parking ban exemption. Owners and/or operators of
vehicles may apply for an extended parking ban exemption for that vehicle by
application to the village clerk at the village hall. Applicants must
purchase village vehicle license stickers for all vehicles registered at the
applicant’s address, including the exempted vehicle. Applicants must
furnish the registered owner’s name, the address where the vehicle is
registered, vehicle description, state license plate number, village vehicle
license sticker number, reason for the request and a $5.00 fee for each
exemption sticker. No more than three (3) extended parking ban exemption
stickers shall be issued per household, per year. No extended parking ban
exemption will be issued for recreational vehicles or trailers. Extended
parking ban exemptions will be granted because of:



      (1)   Absence of driveways;



      (2)   Insufficient driveway capacity; or



      (3)   Other circumstances approved by the village manager or
his designee. Extended parking ban exemptions must be applied for annually.
Extended parking ban exemption stickers expire on the same date as the
village vehicle license sticker.



   (d)   Parking ban exemption limited. Vehicles issued temporary or
permanent parking ban exemptions shall only be authorized to park on village
streets between 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. within 300 feet of the vehicle’s
registered address.



   (e)   No exemption from other ordinances. Vehicles granted temporary
or extended exemptions under this section remain subject to the village’s
snow removal parking restrictions and other applicable restrictions and
ordinances.



(MC-960, § 1, 6-14-16)



Sec. 106-270. Unauthorized use of parking places reserved for persons with
disabilities.



   (a)   It shall be prohibited to park any motor vehicle which is not
bearing registration plates or decals issued to a handicapped person, as
defined by section 1-159.1, pursuant to sections 3-116, 11-1301.1 or
11-1301.2, or to a disabled veteran pursuant to section 3-609 of chapter 625
of the Illinois Compiled Statutes, as evidence that the vehicle is operated
by or for a handicapped person or disabled veteran, in any parking place,
including any private or public offstreet parking facility, specifically
reserved, by the posting of an official sign as designated under 625 ILCS
5/11-301, for motor vehicles bearing such registration plates.  Any motor
vehicle bearing a handicapped license plate or a handicapped parking decal or
device containing the international symbol of access issued to handicapped
persons by any local authority, state, district, territory or foreign country
shall be recognized by state and local authorities as a valid license plate
or device and receive the same parking privileges as residents of this state.



   (b)   Any person or local authority owning or operating any public
or private off street parking facility may, after notifying the Homewood
police department, remove or cause to be removed to the nearest garage or
other place of safety any vehicle parked within a stall or space reserved for
use by the handicapped which does not display handicapped registration plates
or a special decal or device as required under this section.



   (c)   Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this
section shall be fined $350.00 in addition to any costs or charges connected
with the removal or storage of any motor vehicle authorized under this
section. Notwithstanding the above, if the defendant is cited pursuant to the
Administrative Adjudication section of this Code (sec. 106-51 through 106-66,
as amended), any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this
section shall be fined according to the “Handicapped Fine Amount”
schedule contained in section 106-64 of this Code in addition to any costs or
charges connected with the removal or storage of any motor vehicle authorized
under this section.



(MC-759, §1, 5-09-06, MC-765, §1, 8-22-06; MC-832, § 1, 6-22-10)



Sec. 106-271.  Truck parking in the Central Business District.



   No person shall park a truck tractor or semitrailer, as defined by the
Illinois Vehicle Code, overnight within the Central Business District.



Sec. 106-272.  Driving, standing or parking on bicycle paths or lanes
prohibited.



   The driver of a vehicle shall not drive, unless entering or exiting a
legal parking space, or stand, or park the vehicle upon any on-street path or
lane designated by official signs or markings for the use of bicycle, or
otherwise drive or place the vehicle in such a manner as to impede bicycle
traffic on such path or lane. The driver of a vehicle shall not stand or park
the vehicle upon any lane designated by pavement markings for the shared use
of motor vehicles and bicycles, or place the vehicle in such a manner as to
impede bicycle traffic on such lane, except for drivers of buses stopping for
the purpose of loading or unloading passengers at a designated bus stop.



(MC-890, § 1, 5-28-13)



Sec. 106-273.  Parking on streets less than 20 feet in width.



   On those streets less than 20 feet in width, when signs are in place
giving notice, vehicles shall only be parked on one side of the street, as
designated by the sign giving said notice.



(MC-959, § 1, 6-14-16)



Secs. 106-274--106-285. Reserved.



DIVISION 2. MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS



Sec. 106-286. Designation.



   The following described properties, presently owned by the village
shall be operated as municipal parking lots:



      (1)   Lot Nos. 1-14 in Block C of Village of Hartford (now
called Homewood) subdivision and Lot Nos. 1-4 in the Severson's subdivision
of Lots 7, 8, 9, 15, and 16 in Block C in the Village of Hartford
subdivision, all being in the Northeast Quarter (NE1/4) of the Southwest
Quarters (SW1/4) of Section 31, Township 36 North, Range 14 East of the Third
Principal Meridian in the Village of Homewood, Cook County, Illinois.
(Harwood Parking Lot.)



      (2)   Lot No. 3, Tax No. 29-31-314-005 and the West Half
(W1/2) of Lot No. 2, Tax No. 29-31-314-006, also known as 2015 Cherry Lane in
the Village of Homewood in Thornton Station, a subdivision of the Southeast
Quarter (SE1/4) of the Southwest Quarter (SW1/4) of Section 31, Township 36

Street and 75 feet west of the west right-of-way line of Dixie Highway, to
the point of beginning; thence, west a distance of 75 feet; thence north a
distance of 150 feet; thence, east along the south right-of-way line of

      (3)   That part of Block F in the Village of Homewood (late
