ARTICLE II. WATER SYSTEM AND STORM SEWERS



Sec. 110-26. Director of public works; duties.



   In addition to other duties prescribed in this chapter, the director of
public works shall have direct charge of the water and sewer divisions of the
department of public works and all property pertaining thereto. He shall
manage the municipal waterworks system and be responsible for the efficiency
of same and perform such other duties prescribed in this chapter and as may
be ordered by the village manager. The director of public works shall also
have supervision of the maintenance and operation of all public sewers and
drains, cleaning of manholes, inspection of all sewers and drains connected
to the public sewers, including inspection of such sewer during construction
and inspection of all connections made with public sewers. The director of
public works shall see to the enforcement of all ordinances, rules and
regulations pertaining to waterworks, sewerage and drainage.



(Code 1965, § 9.01(a))



Sec. 110-27. Inspectional services.



   The building inspector shall, in addition to other duties prescribed in
this chapter, enforce provisions of building ordinances pertaining to water,
sewerage drains, health and sanitation.



(Code 1965, § 9.01(b))



Sec. 110-28. Water and sewer connections; permit.



   (a)   No person shall make any connection with any public sewer line
of the village or any village water line without first having complied with
this article.



   (b)   The term "public sewer" as used in this article shall mean any
storm drainage line, lateral or main, designed or intended to receive
stormwater or surface water.



   (c)   Every person desiring to make a connection with a village
public sewer system or the village water system shall:



      (1)   Make application to the village clerk for a public water
connection permit;



      (2)   Make application for a public water connection
inspection certificate;



      (3)   Pay to the village clerk the permit fees and inspection
charges required;



      (4)   File with the village clerk the bonds required; and



      (5)   Submit to the village clerk, in triplicate,
specifications and diagrams showing the proposed connection to such public
water system.



   (d)   Each permit and inspection certificate shall be valid for a
period of six months after issuance. Upon application to the village clerk
and with the approval of the building inspector, a permit of inspection
certificate may be extended for one additional six-month period.



(Code 1965, § 9.01A)



Sec. 110-29. Connection plans and agreement.



   No person shall construct or connect any private storm drainage sewer
line, lateral or main, or construct or connect any water line (lateral or
main) to the village public sewer systems or water system unless and until:



      (1)   The plans and specifications for such private storm
drainage sewer or water line, lateral, or main, have been approved by the
Director of Public Works and the Board of Trustees; and



      (2)   The owner of the land abutting upon or intended to be
served by such private storm drainage sewer or water line, lateral or main,
have entered into a written agreement approved by the village attorney and
accepted by the board of trustees, which agreement shall be as a covenant
running with the land, and shall provide that no structure intended or
designed for connection with the private sewer systems or water line, lateral
or main shall be erected upon the land except upon compliance with the terms
of this chapter and the procurement of the permits and certificates and the
payment of the fees and charges required.



   A private storm drainage sewer or water line (lateral or main), is
hereby defined as any storm drainage sewer or water line (lateral or main),
other than one constructed with village funds or constructed pursuant to
special assessment or special taxation proceedings. A private storm drainage
sewer or water line, if acceptable, can only become a public facility by
dedication to the village.



(Code 1965, § 9.02A, MC-690))



Sec. 110-30. Connection approval.



   The village clerk shall promptly forward each application for an
inspection certificate, together with the specifications and diagrams in
conjunction therewith, to the building inspector. The building inspector, in
conjunction with the director of public works, shall promptly examine the
same for compliance with village requirements and acceptable plumbing or
sewer construction practice, and they shall note their approval or
disapproval thereon. When they have approved the application, the requisite
permit and inspection certificate shall be issued by the village clerk.



(Code 1965, § 9.03A)



Sec. 110-31. Qualifications for making connections.



   (a)   All water connections to the village water system shall be
made by authorized personnel employed by the village, or by a state licensed
plumber, meeting all requirements of the village. Each such connection
service shall consist of the supply and insertion of a corporation cock only
on the open main at the service location designated by approved engineering
plans.



   (b)   All connections to the public sewer systems of the village
shall be made by or under the direct supervision of a qualified sewer builder
or drainlayer, meeting all requirements of the village. Plumbers and sewer
builders or drainlayers shall be liable on their bonds for all damage to the
village's public facilities, including the cost of complete restoration.



(Code 1965, § 9.04A)



Sec. 110-32. Inspection of connections; release of bond.



   (a)   No person who has made any connection to any village water
line or to any public sewer line of the village shall in any way cover or
backfill such connection unless and until the connection has been inspected
by authorized personnel employed by the village. Approval must be noted, in
writing, by such personnel upon the inspection certificate. Thereafter, the
permittee shall cause the connection to be closed and backfilled in
accordance with village requirements and in good and workmanlike manner.



   (b)   Upon receipt of an inspection certificate bearing all required
written approvals as to the connection and as to the closing and backfilling,
the village clerk shall refund to the order of the permittee any cash
deposited as security upon the permittee's bond or shall release the surety
upon the permittee's bond.



(Code 1965, § 9.05A)



Sec. 110-33. Severing unauthorized connection; reopening files.



   (a)   Any person who has made or caused or procured another to make
any connection to the village water or public sewer systems without having
first procured a permit and/or inspection certificate therefor shall, upon
conviction, be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00.



   (b)   Any person who has made or has caused or procured another to
make a connection to the village water or public sewer systems without having
first procured a permit and/or inspection certificate shall immediately sever
the connection and safely close the village water or public sewer line. Any
person failing so to sever such connection and to safely close the line, upon
conviction, shall additionally be fined no less than $100.00 nor more than
$500.00. Each day thereafter upon which he fails to so sever the connection
and to safely close the village water or public sewer lines shall constitute
a separate offense.



   (c)   Any person who, having a valid permit or inspection
certificate, shall have made or caused or procured another to have made a
connection to village water or public sewer line, and who shall close or
backfill the same, or cause or procure another to close or backfill the same
without first having obtained the written approval of authorized personnel as
set forth in this section for the connection shall, within 48 hours after
such closing and backfilling, remove the backfilling so that the connection
may be readily examined. Any such person failing to remove such backfilling
so as to permit the connection to be readily examined, upon conviction, shall
be fined not less than $100.00 for each day upon which the person permits the
work to remain unopened so that the work may not be readily examined.



(Code 1965, § 9.06A)



Sec. 110-34. Storm sewer connections.



   No person shall connect any drain carrying any toilet, sink, cellar,
basement, septic tank, cesspool, or industrial waste, or any fixture or
device discharging polluted substances, to any stormwater drain or storm
drainage line, lateral or main, in the village.



(Code 1965, § 9.07A)



Sec. 110-35. Specifications of water connections.



   (a)   Pipes for all water connections shall be of copper from the
water main to the Buffalo Box and from the Buffalo Box to the meter. Water
connections made on any water main shall be of standard fittings approved by
the water division of the department of public works.



   (b)   All copper pipes used in any work or existing water
connections or in making of any new connections with the village water system
done under any permit provided for in this article, shall be such as known to
the plumbing trade as "Type K" and must be of standard weight. No permit
shall be issued to any person desiring to make water connections unless the
application is accompanied by specifications approved by the department of
public works.



(Code 1965, § 9.08A)



Sec. 110-36. Water meter and service line responsibility.



   (a)   The village is responsible for furnishing the water meter and
tailpieces, except as provided in subsection (c) of this section. All other
piping and valves are the homeowner's responsibility and must be maintained
in good condition and working order.



   (b)   If the pipes and/or valves leak or are faulty after water
meter replacement or maintenance, it is the homeowner's responsibility unless
caused by village negligence.



   (c)   The water main, service lateral to curbstop, and curbstop are
the village's responsibility. The village will be responsible for all leaks,
replacement of pipes, valves, curbboxes and water line freezing from water



main to curbstop only. The village will not be responsible for leaks, repair
or replacement and freezing of water meter and tailpieces.



   (d)   The homeowner and user is responsible for the maintenance of
the water service line from the Buffalo Box in the village right-of-way (the
parkway or sidewalk) to the water meter.



   (e)   The homeowner and/or user shall repair any service line leaks
from the curbstop to the home, completing the work within three working days,
to minimize water loss and property damage.



(Code 1965, § 9.09A)



Sec. 110-37. Water meters damaged by freezing.



   Any water meter installed inside a building, either residential,
commercial or industrial, which is damaged by freezing, shall be repaired or
replaced by the village at the water customer's expense. The water customer
shall pay all costs including all damage associated with thawing the water
service. If a building heated with natural gas is without gas service at any
time between December 1 and March 31, the village may discontinue water
service to the building, after providing at least 24 hours prior notice to
the property owner, tenant, or property manager. If a building utilizing
electric heat is without electric service at any time between December 1 and
March 31, the village may discontinue water service to the building, after
providing at least 24 hours prior notice to the property owner, tenant, or
property manager. Water service shall not be reinstated until any past due
bills are paid in full, together with payment of the reinstatement fee listed
in section 110-204 of this Code. However, the owner or occupant shall be
given an opportunity to be heard before the village manager prior to shutoff.



(Code 1965, § 9.10A; MC-857, § 1, 10-25-11)



Sec. 110-38. Frozen water services.



   (a)   It is the water customer's responsibility to maintain and
protect the water service from the outside service line valve through the
entire plumbing system of the building.



   (b)   At the water customer's written request, the village will
arrange to thaw a water customer's frozen water service line. The water
customer shall pay all costs including all damage, if any, associated with
thawing the water service line. Such written request shall be in a form
approved by the village.



   (c)   The water customer is not responsible for normal repair or
maintenance of the water meter but is entirely responsible for protecting the
water meter from damage including damage due to freezing.



(Code 1965, § 9.11A)



Sec. 110-39. Water supply required; connection to public water system.



   (a)   Every owner of each building situated within the Village which
is intended for human habitation or occupancy that does not have its own
functioning water well system on premises, and abutting on any street, alley
or right-of-way in which there is located any public water main of the
Village is hereby required at the owners' expense to connect to the public
water system provided  that the public water main is located within 200 feet
of the property line.



   (b)   Where a public water supply system is not available for
connection, the building water supply shall remain connected to a private
water supply system complying with the provisions of this code.
Reconstruction of existing private systems that do not have the availability
of a public water supply shall comply with the provisions of this code.



Secs. 110-40--110-65. Reserved.



ARTICLE III. SANITARY SEWERS*



   *Cross reference(s)--Health and sanitation, ch. 50; solid waste, ch. 90.



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Sec. 110-66. Definitions.



   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:



   Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, as amended, Public
Law 92-500, 33 USC 1251 et seq.



   Audit means an audit as a separate report from other funds in
accordance with General Services Administration Policy Circular, FMC 73-2,
and shall cover the following:



      (1)   Financial operations are properly conducted;



      (2)   Financial reports are presented fairly;



      (3)   Applicable laws and regulations have been complied with;



      (4)   Resources are managed and used in an economical and
efficient manner; and



      (5)   Desired results and objectives are being achieved in a
financially effective  manner.



   Billable flow means a user’s recorded monthly water usage as metered
by the village, plus metered water from wells and other sources, and less any
sewer-exempt metered data.



   Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means the quantity of oxygen, expressed
in mg/l, utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under
standard laboratory procedures in five days at 20 degrees Celsius.



   Building drain, sanitary means the extension from the building drain to
the public sewer or other place of disposal which conveys sanitary or
industrial sewage only (also called house or service connection).



   Collection sewer means a sewer whose primary purpose is to collect
wastewaters from individual point source discharges.



   Commercial building sewer means a building sewer serving a user engaged
in the purchase or sale of goods, transaction of business, or otherwise
rendering a service.



   Depreciation means an annual operating cost reflecting capital
consumption and obsolescence (reduction of future service potential) of real
and personal properties.



   Director of community development means the chief administrator of the
village, department of community development, or his designee.



   Director of public works means the chief administrator of the village,
department of public works, or his designee.



   Dissolved solids means that concentration of matter in the sewage
consisting of colloidal particulate matter one micron in diameter or less,
and both organic and inorganic molecules and ions present in such solution.



   Easement means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land
owned by others.



   Garbage means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial
preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the commercial
handling, storage and sale of produce.



   IEPA means Illinois Environmental Protection Agency.



   Incompatible pollutant means any nontreatable waste product including
nonbiodegradable dissolved solids.



   Industrial building sewer means a building sewer serving a
manufacturing or process facility.



   Infiltration means the water unintentionally entering the public sewer
system, including sanitary building drains and sewers, from the ground,
through such means as, but not limited to, defective pipes, pipe joints,
connections, or manhole walls. Infiltration does not include and is
distinguished from inflow.



   Infiltration/inflow means the total quantity of water from both
infiltration and inflow without distinguishing the source.



   Inflow means the water discharge into a sanitary sewer system,
including building drains and sewers, from such sources as, but not limited
to, roof leaders; cellar, yard, and area drains; foundation drains;
unpolluted cooling water discharges; drains from springs and swampy areas;
manhole covers; cross connections from storm sewers and/or combined sewers;
catchbasins; stormwaters; surface runoff; and street wash waters or drainage.
Inflow does not include, and is distinguished from, infiltration.



   Interceptor sewer means a sewer whose primary purpose is to transport
wastewater from collection sewers to a treatment facility.



   Natural outlet means any outlet, including storm sewers and combined
sewer overflows, into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of
surface water or groundwater.



   Operation and maintenance costs means all costs, direct and indirect,
not including debt service, but inclusive of expenditures attributable to
administration, treatment and collection of wastewaters necessary to ensure
adequate wastewater collection and treatment on a continuing basis, conform
to applicable regulations, and ensure optimal longterm facility management.



   Person means any individual, firm, company, association, society,
corporation or group discharging any wastewater to the wastewater treatment
facility.



   pH means the term used to express the intensity of the acid or base
condition of a solution, calculated by taking the logarithm of the reciprocal
of the hydrogen ion concentration. The concentration is the weight of
hydrogen ions, in grams per liter of solution. Neutral water for example has
a hydrogen ion concentration of 10-7 and a pH value of seven.



   Pretreatment means the treatment of industrial sewage from privately
owned industrial sources prior to introduction of the waste effluent into a
public treatment works, in accordance with 40 CFR 128.



   Private sewer means a sewer which is not owned by the village.



   Properly shredded garbage means garbage that has been shredded to such
a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions
normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half
inch (1.25 centimeters) in any dimension.



   Public sewer means a sewer which is owned and controlled by the village.



   Replacement means expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment,
accessories, or appurtenances which are necessary during the service life of
the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such
works were designed and constructed.



   Residential building sewer means a building sewer serving a premises or
building used primarily as a domicile for one or more persons.



   Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sanitary and industrial
wastes, and to which stormwater, surface water and groundwater are not
intentionally admitted.



   Sewage  means the combination of the liquid- and water-carried wastes
from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions,
including polluted cooling water and unintentionally admitted
infiltration/inflow.



   Sewage, industrial means a combination of liquid and water carried
wastes, discharged from any industrial establishment and resulting from any
trade or process carried on in that establishment (this shall include the
wastes from pretreatment facilities and polluted cooling water).



   Sewage, sanitary means the combination of liquid and water-carried
wastes discharged from toilet and other sanitary plumbing facilities.



   Shall is mandatory; may is permissive.



   Slug means any discharge of water or wastewater which is a
concentration of any given constituent or in any quantity of flow which
exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five
times the average 24-hour concentration or flows during normal operation and
shall adversely affect the collection system and/or performance of the
wastewater treatment works.



   Standard Methods means the laboratory procedures set forth in the
latest edition, at the time of analysis, of "Standard Methods for the
Examination of Water and Waste Water" prepared and published jointly by the
American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association, and
the Water Pollution Control Federation, and 40 CFR 136, 3, 4 and 5, and/or
other recognized procedures by USEPA and the IEPA.



   Storm sewer means a sewer for conveying water, groundwater, or
unpolluted water from any source and to which sanitary and/or industrial
wastes are not intentionally admitted.



   Suspended solids means total suspended matter that either floats on the
surface of, or is in suspension in water, wastewater, or other liquids and is
removable by laboratory filtration as prescribed in Standard Methods.



   USEPA means United States Environmental Protection Agency.



   Useful life means the anticipated term in years of physical and/or
functional productivity of elements of and/or the whole wastewater treatment
process, which can be reevaluated as a result of preventive maintenance,
renewal which offsets physical and/or functional obsolescence, renewal of
capital elements due to consumption, and physical and/or functional
betterments, either direct or indirect.



   User charge system means the system of charges levied on users for the
cost of operation and maintenance, and replacement reserve requirements on
new and old wastewater collection/treatment facilities, pursuant to section
204(b) of PL 92-500; and 40 CFR 35.935-13 (February 11, 1974 Federal
Register).



   Village manager means the chief administrator of the village, or his
designee.



   Wastewater treatment facilities means the structures, equipment, and
processes required to collect, transport, and treat domestic and industrial
wastes and dispose of the effluent and accumulated residual solids.



   Watercourse means a natural or artificial channel for the passage of
water, either continuously or intermittently.



(Code 1965, § 9.01B)  (MC-932, § 1, 8-25-15)



   Cross reference(s)--Definitions generally, § 1-2.



Sec. 110-67. Protection of sewage works from damage.



   No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully or intentionally
break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure,
appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the sewer system.



(Code 1965, § 9.05B(f))



Sec. 110-68. Powers and authority of inspectors.



   (a)   The director of public works and other duly authorized
employees of the village bearing village credentials and identification shall
be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection,
observation, measurement, sampling and testing pertinent to discharge to the
community system in accordance with the provisions of this article.



   (b)   The director of public works or other duly authorized
employees are authorized to request and obtain information from industry
officials concerning industrial processes which have a direct bearing on the
kind and source of discharge to the wastewater collection system. An
industrial user may withhold information considered confidential, but the
user must first establish that the revelation to the village of the
information in questions would result in an advantage to competitors.



   (c)   While performing the necessary work on private properties, the
director of public works or duly authorized employees of the village shall
observe all known safety rules applicable to the premises established by the
company.



   (d)   The director of public works and other duly authorized
employees of the village bearing village credentials and identification shall
be permitted to enter all private properties through which the village holds
a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to,
inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any
portion of the wastewater facilities lying within such easement. All entry
and subsequent work, if any, on the easement, shall be done in full
accordance with the terms of the easement pertaining to the private property
involved.



   (e)   Employees of the IEPA, and the USEPA, bearing proper
credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all publicly
owned property for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement,
sampling and testing in accordance with provisions of this article. While
performing the necessary work, the IEPA and USEPA employees shall observe the
provisions of the village safety policy.



(Code 1965, § 9.05B(g))



Sec. 110-69. Service line responsibility.



   (a)   That portion of the sewer line from the village main to a
residential building is a private sewer. The property owner and user are
responsible for the maintenance of such sewer line.



   (b)   The homeowner and/or user shall repair any service line leaks
from the curbstop to the residence, or replace as necessary, completing the
work within three working days of discovery of the leak or need for
maintenance.



   (c)   The homeowner and user is responsible for the sanitary sewer
service from the village main to the house. (Code 1965, § 9.06B)



Sec. 110-70. Penalty for violation of article.



   The village may revoke any permit for sewage disposal as a result of
any violation of any provision of this article. Upon violation of this
article, the village may initiate prosecution immediately, or it may elect to
serve the violator with written notice stating the nature of the violation
and setting a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof.
Even though the village may elect to give such notice, the village may
determine at any time that the violator is not acting to correct the
situation and may initiate prosecution. Any person who shall violate any
provision of this article shall, on conviction, be fined in an amount not
less than $50.00 and not exceeding $750.00 for each violation.



(Code 1965, § 9.07B)



Secs. 110-71--110-90. Reserved.



DIVISION 2. USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS



Sec. 110-91. Required.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be
deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the
village, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the village, any human or
animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste.



(Code 1965, § 9.02B(a))



Sec. 110-92. Discharge of polluted waters to natural outlets restricted.



   It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the
village or in any area polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has
been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article.



(Code 1965, § 9.02B(b))



Sec. 110-93. Septic tanks.



   Except as provided in this division, it shall be unlawful to construct
any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or
used for the disposal of sewage.



(Code 1965, § 9.02B(c))



Sec. 110-94. Toilet facilities required; connection to public sewer.



   The owners of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human
occupancy, employment recreation or other purposes situated within the
village and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is
now located, or may in the future be located, any public sanitary sewer of
the village are hereby required at the owners' expense to install suitable
toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the
proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article, within
90 days after the date of official notice to do so, provided that the public
sewer is within 200 feet of the property line.



(Code 1965, § 9.02B(d))



Sec. 110-95. Pretreatment.



   If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged
to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the
characteristics enumerated in section 110-155, and/or which are in violation
of the standards for pretreatment provided in 40 CFR 403, June 26, 1978, and
any amendments thereto, and which may, in the judgment of the director of
public works, have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works processes,
equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise created a hazard to life
or constitute a public nuisance, the director of public works may:



      (1)   Reject the wastes;



      (2)   Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for
discharge to the public sewers;



      (3)   Require control over the quantities and rates of
discharge; and/or



      (4)   Require payment to cover the added costs of handling and
treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges, under the
provisions of division 2 of article IV of this chapter.



(Code 1965, § 9.05B(h))



Secs. 110-96--110-115. Reserved.



DIVISION 3. PRIVATE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS



Sec. 110-116. Conditions.



   Where a public sanitary sewer is not available for connection under the
provisions of section 110-94, the building sewer shall remain connected to a
private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this
division. Construction of new private sewage disposal systems is prohibited.
Reconstruction of existing private systems that do not have the availability
of a public sewer shall comply with the provisions of this division or
connect to an existing sanitary sewer.



(Code 1965, § 9.03B(a))



Sec. 110-117. Permit required.



   Before commencement of reconstruction of an existing private sewage
disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the
director of public works. The application for such permit shall be made on a
form furnished by the village, which the applicant shall supplement by any
plans, specifications and other information as are deemed necessary by the
director of public works. A permit and inspection fee of $100.00 shall be
paid to the village at the time the application is filed.



(Code 1965, § 9.03B(b))



Sec. 110-118. Inspection required.



   A permit for reconstruction of an existing private sewage disposal
system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the
satisfaction of the director of public works. He shall be allowed to inspect
the work at any stage of construction, and, in any event, the applicant for
the permit shall notify the director of public works when the work is ready
for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered.



(Code 1965, § 9.03B(c))



Sec. 110-119. Code requirements.



   The type, capacities, location and layout of a private sewage disposal
system shall comply with all recommendations of the State of Illinois Private
Sewage Disposal Licensing Act (225 ILCS 225/1 et seq.) and the code
promulgated pursuant to such Act and with the IEPA. No permit shall be issued
for any reconstruction of a private sewer disposal system employing
subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than
40,000 square feet. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to
discharge to any natural outlet.



(Code 1965, § 9.03B(d))



Sec. 110-120. Disconnection and connection to public sewer upon availability
of public sewers; abandonment and filling.



   At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served
by a private sewage disposal system, as provided in section 110-94, a direct
connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this article,
and any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private sewage disposal
facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material.



(Code 1965, § 9.03B(e))



Sec. 110-121. Operation and maintenance; expense.



   The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal
facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, and at no expense to the
village.



(Code 1965, § 9.03B(f))



Sec. 110-122. Additional requirements.



   No statement contained in this division shall be construed to interfere
with any additional requirements that may be imposed or required by any other
local governmental body, the state or the federal government.



(Code 1965, § 9.03B(g))



Secs. 110-123--110-140. Reserved.



DIVISION 4. BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS



Sec. 110-141. Unauthorized connections.



   No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connection with or
opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance of a
public sewer without first obtaining a written permit from the village.



(Code 1965, § 9.04B(a))



Sec. 110-142. Disposal to sewer regulated.



   All disposal by any person into the sewer system is unlawful except
those discharges in compliance with federal standards promulgated pursuant to
the Act and more stringent state and local standards.



(Code 1965, § 9.04B(b))



Sec. 110-143. Permit application.



   There shall be two classes of building sewer permits:



      (1)   For residential and commercial service; and



      (2)   For service to establishments producing industrial
wastes.



   In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a
special form furnished by the village. The permit application shall be
supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered
pertinent in the judgment of the director of public works. A permit and
inspection fee of $100.00 for a residential or commercial building sewer
permit and $200.00 for an industrial building sewer permit shall be paid to
the village at the time the application is filed.



(Code 1965, § 9.04B(c))



Sec. 110-144. Wastewater treatment plant capacity required for new
connections.



   A building sewer permit will only be issued and a sewer connection
shall only be allowed if it can be demonstrated that the downstream sewerage,
including sewers, pump stations and wastewater facilities, have sufficient
reserve capacity to adequately and efficiently handle the additional
anticipated waste load.



(Code 1965, § 9.04B(d))



Sec. 110-145. Costs for connections.



   All costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of
the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the
village from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned
by the installation of the building sewer.



(Code 1965, § 9.04B(e))



Sec. 110-146. Separate building sewer requirements.



   A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every
building.



(Code 1965, § 9.04B(f))



Sec. 110-147. Old building sewers in new buildings.



   Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only
when they are found on examination and test by the director of public works,
to meet the requirements of this article.



(Code 1965, § 9.04B(g))



Sec. 110-148. Construction requirements.



   The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building
sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe,
jointing, testing, and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the
requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and
regulations of the village. In the absence of code provisions or in
amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate
specifications of the Illinois Plumbing Code and village standards shall
apply.



(Code 1965, § 9.04B(h))



Sec. 110-149. Building sewer elevations; lifting.



   Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building
at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any
building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer,
sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by a means
which is approved by the director of public works and discharged to the
building sewer.



(Code 1965, § 9.04B(i))



Sec. 110-150. Clear water connections.



   No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, foundation drains,
areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a
building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or
indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.



(Code 1965, § 9.04B(j))



Sec. 110-151. Connection requirements.



   The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall
conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes, or other
applicable rules and regulations of the village. In the absence of code
provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set
forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing
Materials, Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9, and
the Illinois Plumbing Code and village standards shall apply. All such
connections shall be made gastight and watertight and verified by proper
testing. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be
approved by the director of public works before installation.



(Code 1965, § 9.04B(k))



Sec. 110-152. Inspection and connection.



   The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the director
of public works when the building sewer is ready for inspection and
connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the
supervision of the director of public works.



(Code 1965, § 9.04B(l))



Sec. 110-153. Safety; barricades and lights; restoration of property; bonds.



   All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately
guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard.
Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the
course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the village.
Bonds shall be furnished to the village as required by this Code.



(Code 1965, § 9.04B(m))



Sec. 110-154. Clear water discharges.



   No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any stormwater,
surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated
cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer.
(Code 1965, § 9.05B(a))



Sec. 110-155. Prohibited discharges.



   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the
following materials to any sewer:



      (1)   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature high enough to
create damaging or adverse effects on the treatment process or to prevent
compliance with IEPA regulations.



      (2)   Any water or waste which may contain more than 100 parts
per million by weight of fat, oil, grease, or hexane extractable material.



      (3)   Gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other
combustible, flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas of whatsoever kind
or nature.



      (4)   Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such
size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other
interference with the proper operation of the wastewater facilities such as,
but not limited to, ashes, bones, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal,
glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood,
paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk
containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders.



      (5)   Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or
higher than 9.0 or having any other corrosive property capable of causing
damage or hazard to sewers, structures, equipment and personnel of the sewer
works.



      (6)   Any waters or wastes containing any toxic or poisonous
solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by
interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any wastewater
treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public
nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the wastewater
treatment plant.



      (7)   Any waters or wastes containing BOD or suspended solids
of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required
to handle such materials at the wastewater treatment plant, except as may be
permitted by specific, written agreement with the sanitary district serving
the property, which agreement may provide for special charges, payments or
provisions of treating and testing equipment.



      (8)   Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. Garbage
grinders may be connected to sanitary sewers from homes, hotels,
institutions, restaurants, hospitals, catering establishments or similar
places where garbage originates from the preparation of food in kitchens for
the purpose of consumption on the premises or when served by caterers.



      (9)   Any wastes containing radioactive material or
radioisotopes (giving off radiant energy in the form of alpha, beta, or gamma
rays) in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment
process constituting a hazard to humans or animals, or creating any hazard in
the receiving waters of the wastewater treatment plant.



      (10)   Any amount of the following constituents exceeding that
listed in this subsection as follows:

      (11)   Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes
constituting slugs as defined in section 110-66.



      (12)   No provision of this section shall be construed to
provide lesser discharge standards than are presently or may hereafter be
imposed and required by the USEPA or the IEPA.



(Code 1965, § 9.05B(b))



Sec. 110-156. Grease, oil and sand interceptors.



   Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the
opinion of the director of public works, they are necessary for the proper
handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any
flammable wastes, sand, or other harmful ingredients; except that such
interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling
units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the
director of public works, and shall be located as to be readily and easily
accessible for cleaning and inspection.



(Code 1965, § 9.05B(c))



Sec. 110-157. Pretreatment and flow-equalizing expenses borne by owner.



   Where pretreatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided, they
shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by
the owner at his expense.



(Code 1965, § 9.05B(d))



Sec. 110-158. Analysis standards.



   All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters
and wastes to which reference is made in this article shall be determined in
accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination
of Water and Waste Water," published by the American Public Health
Association, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon
suitable samples taken at the control manhole, shall be considered to be the
nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the
building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily
accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works
and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb, and property. The
particular analyses involved will determine whether a 24-hour composite of
all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample should be
taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are
obtained from 24-hour composites of all outfalls, whereas pH's are determined
from periodic grab samples.



(Code 1965, § 9.05B(e))



Secs. 110-159--110-175. Reserved.



ARTICLE IV. RATES AND CHARGES



DIVISION 1. GENERALLY



Sec. 110-176. Connection fees and charges.



   (a)   The village clerk shall collect with each application for the
permit or certificate listed in this subsection, the fee or charge set forth
in conjunction therewith; provided, however, that wherever application is
made by a person who has met the requirements of land subdivision and
inspection provisions set forth in chapter 98, such person shall not be
subject to connection inspection charges.



      (1)   Storm sewer connection



         Permit . . . . . . . . . .  $ 500.00



      (2)   A water connection permit excludes the cost of tapping
which is performed by the developer himself unless a previous agreement
between the village and the developer has been reached.



         3/4-inch connection. . . . . . . . . . 200.00



         1-inch connection ¼. . . . . . . . . . 250.00



         1 1/2-inch connection . . . . . . . . . . 350.00



         2-inch connection. . . . . . . . . . 600.00



         6-inch connection. . . . . . . . . . 500.00



      (3)   Storm sewer connection inspection certificate. . . . . .
. . . . 75.00



      (4)   Water connection inspection certificate. . . . . . . . .
. 75.00



   (b)   In those areas of the village where the village extends the
water and/or sewer lines and all of the owners of property adjacent thereto
do not agree to participate in any advanced payment or prepayment of such
extension costs by an executed written agreement with the village, and the
cost of such extension is not provided by special assessment or special
service area procedure, then each such owner shall pay, in addition to the
other charges of this section, a fair and reasonable charge for connection,
for the construction, expansion and extension of the works of the system.
Such additional connection charge shall be assessed against new or additional
users of the extended system and shall be determined by the village in each
such case.



   (c)   The village clerk shall require applicants for public sewer or
water connection permits to post a bond payable to the village in the sum of
$500.00 for each connection, unless the applicant has met the performance
bond requirements set forth in chapter 98, applicable to land subdivision.
Each bond shall be secured by a cash deposit of $500.00 or a commercial
surety company authorized to do surety business in the state. The bond shall
be forfeited if any work is begun under such bond and is not completed within
90 days after such work is begun, or if the permittee shall have failed to
comply with any of the requirements of this article, or if the work is not
completed at the end of the permit period unless it shall have been
previously withdrawn with village approval.



   (d)   All water connection permits and inspection charges shall be
paid into the water fund, and all storm sewer connection inspection charges
shall be paid into the corporate fund of the village.



(Code 1965, § 9.01C)



Secs. 110-177--110-195. Reserved.



DIVISION 2. WATER AND SEWER CHARGES



Sec. 110-196.  Rates established.



   There are hereby established charges for the use of and the service
supplied by the village, based upon the amount of water consumed (as shown by
the water meters) as follows:



      (1)   Combined water and sewer service rates per 1,000
gallons. The combined rate for water and sewer service is hereby determined
to be $11.58 per 1,000 gallons billed in 2012, $12.44 per 1,000 billed in
2013, $13.39 per 1,000 gallons billed in 2014, and $14.41 per 1000 gallons
billed in 2015 and thereafter.



      (2)   Water service only, rate per 1,000 gallons. The rate for
each such water service only user is hereby determined to be $8.24 for each
1,000 billed in 2012, $8.97 for each 1,000 gallons billed in 2013, $9.80 for
each 1000 gallons billed in 2014, and $10.70 for each 1,000 gallons billed in
2015 and thereafter.



      (3)   Sewer service only; charge for service. Any user
connected to the village sewer system, but having no connection to the water
system, shall have a water meter installed to measure the amount of water
entering the village sewer system. Such meter shall be installed by the
village when the meter span is in place, and shall be subject to the same
regulation and control by the village as though it were attached to the
village water system. The meter shall be connected in such a way that all
water entering the village sewer system shall pass through the meter. The
director of public works or their designee shall inspect and approve all
village installations to ensure compliance with this subsection. The rate to
be charged to such sewer service only users shall be $3.34 for each 1,000
gallons billed in 2012, $3.47 for each 1,000 gallons billed in 2013, $3.59
for each 1000 gallons billed in 2014, and $3.71 for each 1,000 gallons billed
in 2015 and thereafter.



      (4)   Minimum charge for each water and sewer bill generated.
The minimum charge for each water and sewer bill generated shall be $13.43
for 2012, $14.29 for 2013, $15.24 for 2014, and $16.26 for 2015 and
thereafter, except that the minimum charge if billed on a monthly basis in
2015 and thereafter shall be $5.42. If the bill generated is for water only
or sewer only, the charge shall be $6.72 in 2012, $7.15 in 2013, $7.62 in
2014, and $8.13 in 2015 and thereafter, except that the minimum charge if
billed on a monthly basis in 2015 and thereafter shall be $2.71.



      (5)   Water and/or sewer service not within village limits.
When a location receiving village water and/or sewer service is located
outside of the corporate limits of the village, all users of such service
shall pay a 50 percent surcharge in addition to the rates established in this
section. 



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(a))  (MC-544, 4-25-95; MC-864, § 1, 1-10-12; MC-932,
§ 1, 8-25-15)



Sec. 110-197. Educational and religious rate.



   All connections, the premises of which are used exclusively as
educational institutions providing grammar school, junior high or high school
educations, or used exclusively as a church, or used exclusively as a school
and church, shall be billed at the rates established in this division, less
25 percent.



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(b))



Sec. 110-198. Security deposit.



   A security deposit shall be charged to those users holding leasehold
interests in the premises to be connected upon application for services. This
deposit shall be returned upon payment of the final bill. The security
deposit thus required shall be as follows:



   For each connection to the sewer system   $50.00



   For each connection to the water system   50.00



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(c), Ord. No. MC-687, 1-14-03)



Sec. 110-199. Charges for water meters.



   No water shall be taken from the village water system except through a
meter leased from the village. At the time of original meter assignment, the
lessee shall pay to the village clerk a charge equal to 100 percent of the
cost of such meter to the village at the date of assignment, plus a 15
percent administrative fee.



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(d))



Sec. 110-200.  Meter or Read-O-Matic/Radio failing to register.



   If the inside meter fails to register the quantity of water, the charge
shall be based on the average quantity registered at that location during the
same period of time the previous year. If no such reading is available, the
charge shall be based upon the average of prior available readings for this
location, making any required reasonable adjustment because of climatic
conditions or other factors. If the outdoor Read-O-Matic/Radio fails to
register for any reason, or if there is a discrepancy between the
Read-O-Matic/Radio reading and the meter reading, the reading of indoor meter
shall be the reading used in computing the water bill. The village shall be
allowed entrance to the premises to read indoor meters upon reasonable
request. No adjustment shall be made to any water bill because of leakage.



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(e))  (MC-932, § 1, 8-25-15)



Sec. 110-201. Liability of owner, occupant and user; late payment.



   The property owner, and the occupant of such premises, the property
manager (if any), and the user of water or sewer service, are jointly and
severally liable to pay for the service on such premises, and the service is
furnished to the premises by the village only upon the condition that the
property owner, property manager, occupant and user of the service, are
jointly liable therefor to the village. Bills shall be rendered monthly for
residential,  commercial and industrial accounts, and shall be payable
within 20 days after the date thereof. If the bill is not paid on or before
the date due, a 10 percent penalty shall be added to the then current
charges. Upon request from the party responsible for payment of the water
bill and full payment of the remaining invoice, the finance director or his
designee is authorized to waive the ten percent penalty, provided invoices
for the previous 24 months have been paid on time and further provided that
the village has not yet posted a notice of impending water shutoff at the
service location. The 10 percent penalty may only be waived twice for each
account.



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(f))  (MC-555; MC-858, § 1, 10-25-11; MC-932, § 1,
8-25-15)



Sec. 110-202. Water shutoffs.



   Permission to use water is given under the express condition that if
for any cause the supply of water should be shut off, no damages shall be
claimed by any customer.



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(g))



Sec. 110-203. Lien for charges.



   If the charges for water services are not paid when due, such charges
shall be deemed delinquent, and thereafter, such delinquencies shall
constitute liens upon the real estate for which such services are supplied.
The village clerk shall file sworn statements showing such delinquencies in
the office of the recorder of deeds or registrar of titles, as appropriate,
of the county wherein such premises are situated, and the filing of such
statements shall be deemed notice of such charges for such service. Every
lien recorded pursuant to this section shall include an additional $50.00
charge to recover the costs expended by the village in preparing said lien,
plus the actual recording cost as determined by the Cook County Recorder of
Deeds.



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(h)) (MC-818, § 1, 6-23-09)



Sec. 110-204. Service discontinuation; fees and requirements.



   (a)   Service discontinuation for non-payment. If charges for water
and sewer service are not paid in full on or before the first day of the
month after the due date, as provided in the water and sewer regulations
promulgated by the finance director as from time to time amended, then such
service may be discontinued and shall not be reinstated until all past due
bills and related charges are paid in full, together with payment of the fees
provided below. However, the owner, occupant, or property manager shall be
given an opportunity to be heard before the village manager prior to shutoff.
Partial payment of a water and sewer bill shall not limit the village’s
right to discontinue service until full payment is made.



   (b)   Fee for notice of impending shutoff. If payment for water and
sewer service is overdue and the village posts a notice at the service
location of the date service may be shutoff for non-payment (the “shutoff
date”), a $25.00 tag fee shall be assessed unless the bill is paid before
8:00 a.m. on the date the notice is posted.



   (c)   Fee for non-payment prior to shutoff date or reinstatement of
discontinued service. A fee of $75.00 shall be due if water and sewer charges
are not paid in full prior to the shutoff date, or to reinstate service that
has been discontinued.



Water service will be restored no later than the next business day after
payment is received. All requests to reinstate water service on the same 
business day payment is received shall incur an additional $75.00 charge.



   (d)   Reinstatement - access to premises. Water service shall not be
restored unless a person at least 18 years of age is present and is able to
grant access to the premises. The village reserves the right to inspect and
verify proper operation of the water meter and interior plumbing before
restoring water service to any premises.



   (e)   Temporary reinstatement. At the request of a licensed real
estate agent, property manager, lender's agent, or the property owner, and
after payment of a non-refundable $ 100.00 fee, water service may temporarily
be restored to premises where service has been discontinued for non-payment
solely for the purpose of verifying that the plumbing is functional. Water
service shall not be temporarily reinstated unless a person at least 18 years
of age is present and is able to grant access to the premises. There shall be
no charge for temporarily restoring water service to premises to allow
verification that the plumbing is functional if all water and sewer charges
have been paid in full.



(MC-859, § 1, 10-25-11; MC-872, § 1, 7-10-12; MC-932, § 1, 8-25-15)



Sec. 110-205. Rendering bills.



   The finance director shall render bills for water and sewer service, or
either of them, and all other charges in connection therewith, and collect
all monies due thereon. 



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(j)) (MC-863, § 1, 10-25-11)



Sec. 110-206. Water revenue.



   All revenue and monies derived from the operation of the waterworks
system shall be held by the village separate and apart from all other funds
of the village. All of such sums without any deductions shall be delivered to
the village treasurer not more than two days after receipt of same, or at
such more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the
president and board of trustees.



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(k))



Sec. 110-207. Waterworks revenue fund.



   The village treasurer, or some person designated by him, shall receive
all such revenues from the waterworks system and all other funds and monies
incident to the operation of such system. He deposits the revenues in a
separate fund designated as the "Waterworks Revenue Fund of the Village of
Homewood, Illinois," and the treasurer shall administer such fund in every
respect in the manner provided by division 139 of article 11 of the Municipal
Code (65 ILCS 5/11-139-1 et seq.).



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(l))



Sec. 110-208. Records and accounts.



   The finance director shall establish a proper system of accounts, and
proper entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the waterworks
and sewer system. At regular annual intervals the president and board of
trustees shall cause to be made an audit by an independent auditing concern
of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the combined system.



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(m); MC-863, § 1, 10-25-11)



Sec. 110-209. Water meter reading and maintenance.



   All water meters, touch pads, and radio reads referred to in this
division are the property of the village and are subject to village control.
The director of public works or his designee shall have the right upon
reasonable request to enter on the premises of the customer to read, repair
or replace the meter, touch pad, and radio read. These items shall be made
accessible to be serviced by the homeowner, property owner, tenant, or
property manager.  If after two attempts made at least 24 hours apart, the
village is unable to enter the premises to read, repair or replace a meter,
touch pad, or radio read, the village may discontinue water service to the
building, after providing at least 24 hours prior notice to the property
owner, tenant, or property manager. Water service shall not be reinstated
until the meter, touch pad, or radio read is read, repaired, or replaced as
appropriate, and the reinstatement fee listed in section 110-204 of this Code
is paid. However, the owner or occupant shall be given an opportunity to be
heard before the village manger prior to shutoff.



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(n); MC-860, § 1, 10-25-11)



Sec. 110-210. Certification and filing with county.



   A copy of article II of this chapter, properly certified by the village
clerk, shall be filed in the office of the county recorder of deeds, and
shall be deemed notice to all owners of real estate of their liability for
water and sewer services supplied any occupant or user of such services on
their properties.



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(o))



Sec. 110-211. Meter testing charge.



   (a)   The village will cause meters to be tested when requested by a
water and/or sewer customer. The charge for meter tests will be $50.00 for
five-eighths by one-half-inch, five-eighths by three-quarters-inch;
three-quarters by one-inch meters, if performed by village personnel, or the
actual charge if performed by an independent testing company.



   The charge for meter tests for 1 1/2-inch and two-inch meters will be
$100.00. The charge for meter tests of three inches, four inches and six
inches will be the actual charge of the independent testing company, plus
administrative costs.



      (1)   If the meter test indicates that the meter is
registering greater than the AWWA standard for that meter, the cost of the
meter test will be the village's responsibility.



      (2)   If the meter test indicates that the meter is
registering at or less than the AWWA standard for that meter, the customer
will be responsible for the cost of the test.



   (b)   All customers requesting a meter test will be advised of this
section prior to performing the meter test. The customer will be billed by
the village upon completion of the test. Bills will be payable upon receipt
by the customer.



(Code 1965, § 9.02C(p))



Sec. 110-212.  Cash only customers.



   (a)   Any water/sewer customer who provides more than one check in
an 18 month period to the Village of Homewood that is returned to the village
due to insufficient funds in the customer's account at the customer's
financial institution will be put on a "cash only" basis for future
water/sewer bills. Water/sewer customer's checks returned to the village
stamped "Account Closed" or "Refer to Maker" or words of similar import will
be put on a cash only basis for future water/sewer bills. Any water/sewer
customers who receive a shut off notice will be required to pay their
outstanding water/sewer bill on a "cash only" basis.



   (b)   A "cash only" basis shall mean that water and sewer bills must
be paid only with cash, certified check, debit card, credit card, or a
cashier's check.



   (c)   Any person or business placed on a "cash only" basis for
water/sewer bills shall be given written notice of that designation and shall
have the right to appeal that decision to the village manager by giving the
village a written request for an informal hearing. That request must be
received by the village within 10 days after receipt of the "cash only"
notice. The village manager will schedule a hearing 21 days after receipt of
that request. The "cash only" basis shall apply pending such hearing. At the
conclusion of the hearing, the village manager may uphold the "cash only"
designation or set it aside.



   (d)   Any resident or business that has paid their water/sewer bill
on a "cash only" basis for 18 months and is current with such payments may
have the "cash only" basis rescinded.



(MC-861, § 1, 10-25-11)



Sec. 110-213.  Fee for telephone payment.



   A convenience fee of $5.00 shall be added to any water/sewer payment
made by telephone with a credit card or a debit card.



(MC-861, § 1, 10-25-11)



Sec. 110-214.  Application for service required; fee.



   (a)   Upon a change in occupancy, ownership, or control of any
premises receiving water or sewer service, the property owner, tenant, or
property manager shall complete an application for service so that there is
always on file with the village a current application from at least one party
responsible for payment of water and sewer service.



   (b)   Water and sewer service applications shall be made upon forms
provided by the finance director or his designee.



   (c)   In addition to the application, all applicants shall furnish
valid photo ID, a copy of the lease, settlement statement or other evidence
of property ownership or control, a non-refundable $60.00 application fee,
and any other fees or deposits required under this chapter.



   (d)   If no service application is completed within ten days after a
change in occupancy, ownership, or control of any premises receiving water or
sewer service, the village may discontinue water service to the premises
after providing at least 24 hours prior notice to the property owner, tenant,
or property manager. Water and sewer service shall not be reinstated until
all requirements of this section are satisfied and a reinstatement fee as
provided in Section 110-204 is paid.



(MC-862, § 1, 10-25-11)



Sec. 110-215.  Adequate assurance of payment required after bankruptcy
filing - Residential Accounts.



   (a)   Except as otherwise provided under federal bankruptcy law, a
residential Customer is required to provide an adequate assurance of payment
for future service within twenty (20) days of filing a petition for
bankruptcy. If the village is notified of such petition or is listed as a
creditor, an adequate assurance deposit must be provided within twenty (20)
days of such notice or a written request for such deposit by the village.



   (b)   Adequate assurance of payment will be in the form of a One
Hundred Fifty Dollar ($150.00) cash deposit. The deposit shall not earn
interest.



   (c)   Failure to timely provide the aforementioned adequate
assurance of payment will result in termination of further water and sewer
service as provided in Section 110-204 of this Code.



   (d)   If service is disconnected due to non-payment of the required
adequate assurance, the service may not be recoimected until full payment of
such adequate assurance, reconnect charges and all outstanding post-petition
service charges and fees are paid.



   (e)   If, after payment of the adequate assurance deposit, an
account becomes past due, service may be terminated as provided in Section
110-204 of this Code and the deposit used to pay all existing charges, Upon
reestablishing the required deposit balance, the payment of reconnect
charges, and the payment of any post-petition charges and fees not covered by
the cash deposit, service will be restored.



   (f)   Except as otherwise ordered by the Bankruptcy Court, the
adequate assurance deposit may be applied to the account after three (3)
years, provided the account has had no delinquent payments during the
previous twelve (12) months.



   (g)   Cash deposits will be applied to the account’s final bill
and remaining funds, if any, will be refunded. If the final bill exceeds the
cash deposit, the balance due after application of the deposit shall be due
on or before the date specified on the final bill.



(MC-961, § 1, 6-28-16)



Sec. 110-216 Adequate assurance of payment required after banlcruptcy filing
- Non-Residential Accounts.



   (a)   Except as otherwise provided under federal bankruptcy law, a
non-residential Customer is required to provide an adequate assurance of
payment for future service within thirty (30) days of filing a pelition for
bankruptcy. If the village is notified of such petition or is listed as a
creditor, an adequate assurance deposit must be provided within thirty (30)
days of such notice or a written request for such deposit by the village.



   (b)   For purposes of this section, the term “assurance of
payment” means a:



      (1)   Cash deposit;



      (2)   Letter of credit;



      (3)   Certificate of deposit;



      (4)   Surety bond; or



      (5)   Prepayment of utility consumption in an amount
equivalent to the two (2) highest months of charges for the service premises
over the previous twelve (12) months.



   (c)   Failure to timely provide the aforementioned adequate
assurance of payment will result in termination of further water and sewer
service as provided in Section 110-204 of this Code.



   (d)   If service is discormected due to non-payment of the required
adequate assurance, the service may not be reconnected until full payment of
such adequate assurance, reconnect charges and all outstanding post-petition
service charges and fees are paid.



   (e)   If, after payment of the adequate assurance deposit, an
account becomes past due, service may be terminated as provided in Section
110-204 of this Code and the deposit used to pay all existing charges. Upon
reestablishing the required deposit balance, the payment of reconnect
charges, and the payment of any post-petition charges and fees not covered by
the cash deposit, service will be restored.



   (f)   Except as otherwise ordered by the Bankruptcy Court, the
adequate assurance deposit may be applied to the account after three (3)
years, provided the account has had no delinquent payments during the
previous twelve (12) months.



   (g)   Cash deposits will be applied to the account’s final bill
and remaining funds, if any, will be refunded. If the final bill exceeds the
cash deposit, the balance due after application of the deposit shall be due
on or before the date specified on the final bill.



(MC-961, § 1, 6-28-16)



Secs. 110-217--110-230. Reserved.



DIVISION 3. SEWER USER CHARGE SYSTEM



Sec. 110-231. Establishment of revenue system.



   All unit charges levied by ordinance for the operation, maintenance,
replacement and debt service of the village sewer system are hereby repealed
and in lieu thereof a user charge shall be assessed to all users, in
accordance with the provisions of this division.



(Code 1965, § 9.03C(a))



Sec. 110-232. Composition of charge; adjustments.



   (a)   The user charge for the use of and for the service supplied by
the sewer system of the village shall consist of a sewer charge for the
following:



      (1)   Operation and maintenance.



      (2)   Replacement charge including depreciation, improvement
and extensions to the sewer system.



      (3)   Bonds and interest.



      (4)   Debt service reserve.



   (b)   The basic sewer charge, as determined in section 110-234(1)
and (2) shall be applied to sewer usage as recorded by village water meters.
Adjustments to such billings may be made only under the following
circumstances and conditions:



      (1)   The user experiences a plumbing leak beyond the user's
control.



      (2)   The user demonstrates to the satisfaction of the finance
director that none of the water consumption caused by the leak was returned
to the sewer system.



      (3)   The user furnishes proof that the plumbing leak was
repaired within three working days.



      (4)   The adjustment shall be based on an analysis of the
user's consumption history as determined by the finance director.



      (5)   The adjustment applies to sewer charges only.



(Code 1965, § 9.03C(b); Ord. No. MC-542, § 1, 4-11-95; MC-863, § 1,
10-25-11)



Sec. 110-233. Annual sewer budget.



   The village manager shall, no less than once per annum, prepare an
estimate of anticipated costs for each category of user charge, as outlined
hereafter, for the forthcoming fiscal year. These estimates shall be made in
the form of a user charge rate amendment and shall be submitted to the
village board for enactment of May 1 of each fiscal year. These anticipated
costs shall consist of the following:



      (1)   Operation and maintenance costs. Annual operation and
maintenance costs shall be determined for the sewer system.



      (2)   Replacement costs. Annual replacement costs shall be
determined sufficient to cover depreciation, improvements, extensions and
replacement of equipment, accessories and appurtenances in the sewer system
owned by the village, as required, in order to ensure continued peak
performance and maintain design capacity over the sewer system's useful life.



      (3)   Bond and interest costs. Annual debt service costs for
outstanding sewer bonds shall be determined for the sewer system.



      (4)   Debt service reserve costs. Sufficient reserve costs for
debt service purposes shall be determined for the sewer system.



(Code 1965, § 9.03C(c))



Sec. 110-234. Determination of bill.



   The basic sewer bill for all users shall be determined dividing annual
billing and handling charges by the annual number of total bills generated.
Annual billing and handling charges are determined by the sum of the
following:



      (1)   Minimum bill. The minimum bill shall be determined by
dividing annual billing and handling charges by the annual number of total
bills generated. Annual billing and handling charges are determined by the
sum of the following:



         a.   Water meter maintenance inspection and repair.



         b.   Water meter reading.



         c.   Mailing and processing of sewer bills.



         d.   Sewer bill collection.



      (2)   Unit rates. The unit rate for the sewer charge shall be
the sum of the amounts determined by:



         a.   Dividing estimated annual operation and maintenance
costs by estimated annual water usage per 1,000 gallons.



         b.   Dividing estimated annual replacement costs by
estimated water usage per 1,000 gallons.



         c.   Dividing total bond and interest costs by estimated
water usage per 1,000 gallons.



         d.   Dividing total debt service reserve costs by
estimated water usage per 1,000 gallons.



(Code 1965, § 9.03C(d))



Sec. 110-235. Billing for sewer service.



   Billing for sewer service shall be done monthly for all accounts. The
minimum charge for providing sewer service shall be as established in section
110-196(4). In addition to this minimum charge, the following unit charge
shall be applied to user’s sewer use: For operation, maintenance,
replacement, bond and interest and debt service reserve, the charge shall be
as established in section 110-196. The charges established in this section
shall remain in effect until amended as provided in this division.



(Code 1965, § 9.03C(e))  (MC-932, § 1, 8-25-15)



Sec. 110-236. Water from private sources.



   A user receiving all or part of his water from a private well or other
source not metered, or other public or private supplier of potable water
shall install at the user's expense an appropriate metering device for the
purpose of determining billable flow.



(Code 1965, § 9.03C(f))



Sec. 110-237. Accounting.



   (a)   Enumeration of accounts. All the revenue of the sewer system,
from every source, shall be designated and accounted for in a separate
accounting fund known as the "Waterworks and Sewerage Revenue Fund of the
Village of Homewood, Illinois." Money in this revenue fund is required to be
set aside, on a periodic basis, not less than four times per annum, into each
of the following accounts. All credits to the following accounts shall be
derived from monies in the waterworks and sewerage revenue fund.



      (1)   Operation and maintenance account. To this account there
shall be deposited, on a periodic basis, an amount sufficient to pay the
reasonable expenses of maintenance and operation of the sewer system
including, but not limited to, salaries, wages, materials, supplies, power
and services rendered.



      (2)   Depreciation, improvement and extension account. To this
account there shall be deposited, on a periodic basis, an amount sufficient
to pay for depreciation, improvements, extensions, and any other expenditures
for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories, or appurtenances which
are necessary during the service life of the sewer system in order to
maintain the capacity and performance for which such system was designed and
constructed.



      (3)   Bond and interest account. To this account there shall
be deposited, on a periodic basis, sufficient funds to pay the amount of the
total maturing interest and principal on those outstanding bonds which mature
during that fiscal year.



      (4)   Debt service reserve account. To this account there
shall be deposited, on a periodic basis, an amount sufficient to create a
debt service reserve for the purposes of paying maturing interest on
principal on outstanding bonds whenever such funds are not available from
other sources.



      (5)   Surplus account. To this account there shall be
deposited all funds in the sewerage revenue fund not otherwise transferred to
the operation and maintenance account, the replacement account, the bond and
